layer_sequence_x.name: layer_sequence_x

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

parameters.name: pos_x
parameters.description: The X position to move the sequence element to

layer_sequence_x.description: With this function you can set the position along the X (horizontal) axis of the room for the given sequence element. You supply the sequence element ID as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions along with the X position to set and the sequence will be moved to the new position.

window_set_showborder.name: window_set_showborder

parameters.name: show
parameters.description: Whether to show the window border (true) or not (false).

window_set_showborder.description: Sets whether the border around the window is shown in windowed mode.

device_mouse_raw_y.name: device_mouse_raw_y

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.

device_mouse_raw_y.description: This function returns raw y position of the touch on a device. What this means is that it returns the actual device definition of the y position that is being touched, not the GameMaker one, and as such will ignore things like view position and scaling. Note that the maximum number of device touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs

place_empty.name: place_empty

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to check.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to check.

parameters.name: object_id
parameters.description: Optional! The object to check against.

place_empty.description: You can use this function to check and see if the calling instance would collide with any other instance of an object or all instances in your game. For this to collision to resolve correctly, the instance running the code must have a valid collision mask (either for the sprite itself, or through the mask_index) and it will only register collisions with those instances that also have a valid mask.

gesture_get_drag_time.name: gesture_get_drag_time
gesture_get_drag_time.description: This function is used to get the time it takes for a Drag Start Gesture event to be triggered by a touch or click. This time will also affect how the Tap Event is triggered as a touch/click and release before this time is up will be considered a Tap. The time is measured in seconds and has a default value of 0.16.

is_debug_overlay_open.name: is_debug_overlay_open
is_debug_overlay_open.description: Returns true if the debug overlay is open and false otherwise

physics_fixture_set_collision_group.name: physics_fixture_set_collision_group

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the fixture that is to be bound

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: the group that this fixture is assigned to (either a positive value, 0, or a negative value)

physics_fixture_set_collision_group.description: Once you have created your fixture you can define it as being part of a collision group. This means that you can tell instances with that fixture to always collide or never collide with other instance that have fixtures bound to them with the same collision group. The values that can be assigned are based on positive or negative numbers, with 0 being the default value (meaning that the instance with this fixture setting is ignored unless a collision event is created for it). Here is an image to help explain:

display_set_gui_size.name: display_set_gui_size

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the GUI

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the GUI

display_set_gui_size.description: This function will only affect things drawn in the Draw GUI Event and can be used to set a specific width and height for all GUI components in that event, and no matter what size of display or window is used to display the GUI, it will be scaled to fit correctly. Where the GUI is positioned (ie: the (0,0) position) will depend on whether you have used the function display_set_gui_maximise() or not. If you do not use this function (the default setting) then the GUI layer will be positioned with its (0,0) point at the same position as that for the application surface (the area where your game is being drawn) and the width and height will be stretched to fit the this surface, such that setting a GUI width of 256px with this function when the application surface is 512px would stretch those 256 pixels to fit, effectively making the pixels twice as large. This is ideal for those games that have aspect ratio correction set in the global Game Settings.

draw_set_halign.name: draw_set_halign

parameters.name: halign
parameters.description: Horizontal alignment.

draw_set_halign.description: This function is used to align text along the horizontal axis and changing the horizontal alignment will change the position and direction in which all further text is drawn with the default value being fa_left. The following constants are accepted:

part_type_orientation.name: part_type_orientation

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: ang_min
parameters.description: The minimum starting angle of the particles.

parameters.name: ang_max
parameters.description: The maximum starting angle of the particles.

parameters.name: ang_incr
parameters.description: The increase (or decrease if set negative) of the angle in degrees per step.

parameters.name: ang_wiggle
parameters.description: The amount the angle wiggles clockwise/counterclockwise per step.

parameters.name: ang_relative
parameters.description: Whether to set its angle relative to the direction of the particle's motion (true) or not (false).

part_type_orientation.description: This function is used to determine the orientation of the particle sprite when it is created and can also be used to make the particle orientation increase or decrease over its lifetime. The minimum and maximum orientation values default at 0 but these values can be changed to randomise the orientation following the standard GameMaker directions of 0 degrees being right, 90 degrees being up, 180 degrees being left and 270 degrees being down. If you set them to the same value the particles will all be created with the same orientation.

tile_get_index.name: tile_get_index

parameters.name: tiledata
parameters.description: the tile-data to check

tile_get_index.description: This function can be used to get the tile index (the position of the tile within the tile set image) from a set of tile-data. You give the tile-data, which can be retrieved using the function tilemap_get(), and the function will return an integer value for the index or -1 if there is an error.

device_mouse_check_button_released.name: device_mouse_check_button_released

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.

parameters.name: button
parameters.description: The button of the device that is being checked.

device_mouse_check_button_released.description: This function returns true or false depending on whether the device touch that you specify has been released or not. The device argument refers to the device touch number, which can be from 0 to n and note that the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs (most devices will support at least 4 simultaneous touches). This function is only triggered once by the actual releasing action, and the constants listed on this page can be used to check for the mouse buttons. Note that mb_right will only have been detected if a double tap touch is detected and held on the second tap before release (this behavior can be disabled using the function device_mouse_dbclick_enable()).

instance_position.name: instance_position

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to check for instances.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to check for instances.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for instances of.

instance_position.description: With this function you can check a position for a collision with another instance or all instances of an object. When you use this you are checking a single point in the room for an instance or an object. This check will be done against the bounding box of the instance or against the mask of the instance if that instance has precise collisions checked and will return the unique instance id. If you do not need the id of the colliding instance you should consider using position_meeting() instead. This function also accepts the special keywords all and other and will return the keyword noone if no collision occurs or the unique ID value of the instance found if a collision does occur.

timeline_delete.name: timeline_delete

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the time line to delete.

timeline_delete.description: With this function you can delete any time line from your game. if this time line was created in the GameMaker Asset Browser, please note that it is removed completely from the game and trying to call the indexed time line again after using this function will cause an error. If the time line was created dynamically using the timeline_add() function, then this function should be used the moment that the time line is no longer needed to prevent any memory leaks that could slow down (and eventually crash) your game.

call_cancel.name: call_cancel

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: The handle of the call to cancel

call_cancel.description: Cancels a delayed call set up by call_later.

layer_sequence_get_headpos.name: layer_sequence_get_headpos

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

layer_sequence_get_headpos.description: With this function you supply the sequence element ID - as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions - and it will return the current playhead position (the current frame the playhead is on).

draw_set_font.name: draw_set_font

parameters.name: font
parameters.description: The name of the font to use.

draw_set_font.description: This function will set the font to be used for all further text drawing. This font must have been added into the font assets of the game or have been created using either the font_add() or font_add_sprite().

audio_emitter_get_vz.name: audio_emitter_get_vz

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to use.

audio_emitter_get_vz.description: This function returns the current velocity along the z axis for the given audio emitter.

layer_clear_fx.name: layer_clear_fx

parameters.name: layer_name_or_id
parameters.description: The name or ID of the layer to modify

layer_clear_fx.description: This function is used to clear the FX struct that is applied to the specified layer.

shader_current.name: shader_current
shader_current.description: This function will return the index ID value of the shader currently being used for rendering, or it will return -1 if no shader is being used.

gif_add_surface.name: gif_add_surface

parameters.name: gif_index
parameters.description: The ID of gif to add the surface data to

parameters.name: surface
parameters.description: The ID of the surface to use as the added frame

parameters.name: delay_time
parameters.description: The delay time for the frame (in 100ths of a second)

parameters.name: xoffset
parameters.description: [Optional] The offset along the X axis of the surface to add from

parameters.name: yoffset
parameters.description: [Optional] The offset along the Y axis of the surface to add from

parameters.name: quantization
parameters.description: [Optional] The quantization amount from 0 to 3 (0 lowest quality, 3 highest quality, default is 2)

gif_add_surface.description: With this function you can save a frame to a GIF file from a surface. You supply the GIF file ID (as returned by the function gif_open()) and a surface ID (as returned by the function surface_create()), as well as a delay time between frames. The delay time is calculated in 1/100ths of a second, but note that once the GIF has been created, if you use it for promotional purposes for example, different browsers may interpret the frame delay slightly differently - see here for more details. You may (optionally) supply X and Y offset values for the surface being used to add to the GIF, in which case the part drawn to the GIF will begin from the offset and not the default (0,0) position, permitting you to select only a section of the surface to add. You can also supply a quantization value, which is an integer between 0 and 3, where 0 is full quantization and 3 is zero quantization (lower values will have a subsequent degradation in quality, but create a smaller GIF). Note that there isn't much difference between the default quality of 2, and the highest of 3, and using 3 will significantly slow down the creation of the GIF so care should be taken when using the maximum value.

vertex_format_add_colour.name: vertex_format_add_colour
vertex_format_add_colour.description: Tell GameMaker to accept colour data as part of the new vertex format being created.

point_in_circle.name: point_in_circle

parameters.name: px
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the point to check.

parameters.name: py
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the point to check.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the circle centre.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the circle centre.

parameters.name: rad
parameters.description: The radius of the circle.

point_in_circle.description: When using this function, you define a circular area and GameMaker will work out whether the given point falls within its bounds or not. If the point falls within the defined circle the function will return true otherwise the function will return false.

skeleton_slot_colour_set.name: skeleton_slot_colour_set

parameters.name: slot
parameters.description: The slot name to set, a string

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour to set, either an integer, a constant, or a hex value.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha to set from 0 to 1.

skeleton_slot_colour_set.description: With this function you can set an attachment slot colour and alpha so all sprites attached to it will be drawn with these blend values. Keep in mind that the instance sprite can have a blend colour and alpha setting (image_blend and image_alpha), as can the attachment (see the function skeleton_attachment_create_colour()), and so the final colour and alpha that the assigned attachment sprite for the slot will have will be a composite of all these values.

tilemap_get_y.name: tilemap_get_y

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to get the y position of

tilemap_get_y.description: Using this function you can retrieve the y position (within the room) of the tile map element. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and the function will return the y-axis position.

layer_sequence_get_sequence.name: layer_sequence_get_sequence

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

layer_sequence_get_sequence.description: With this function you supply the sequence element ID - as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions - and it will return the sequence object struct. This function bypasses the need to first get the sequence instance struct and permits you to access the sequence data directly. You can find out more about the format of the sequence object struct on this page.

dtan.name: dtan

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The angle (in degrees) to return the tangent of.

dtan.description: In a right angled triangle dtan(val) = Opposite / Adjacent where "val" is one of the three angles.

ini_key_exists.name: ini_key_exists

parameters.name: section
parameters.description: The section in the open .ini file to check a key in.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to check for.

ini_key_exists.description: This function checks to see if a key exists in the currently open ini and will return true if it does or false otherwise. This is not a necessary check to prevent errors as, when a key does not exist, reading from a non-existent key will just return a default value. It can be useful to see if an ini file has saved specific data and a few other things, however.

draw_triangle_color.name: draw_triangle_color

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the triangle's first corner.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the triangle's first corner.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the triangle's second corner.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the triangle's second corner.

parameters.name: x3
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the triangle's third corner.

parameters.name: y3
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the triangle's third corner.

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The colour of the first corner.

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The colour of the second corner.

parameters.name: col3
parameters.description: The colour of the third corner.

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the triangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

draw_triangle_color.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a triangle or a filled triangle. If it is filled you can define the individual colours for each corner point and if these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()).

physics_fixture_bind.name: physics_fixture_bind

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the fixture that is to be bound

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: the target instance that is to receive the fixture (can be an instance id, an object id, other, or all)

physics_fixture_bind.description: Once we have defined our fixture it has to be bound to an instance. This means that its properties are transferred to the selected instance, not the actual fixture itself, so that one fixture can be bound to multiple instances if all are to have the same properties. You can specify an object index for the target and all instances present in the room at the time will receive that fixtures properties (but not any new instances of the object created later), or you can use the special keywords other and all. You can even specify a parent object and all children instances with that parent will also receive the fixture. Once the fixture has been bound to all the instances that you need, it can be deleted if no longer necessary and the instances with that fixtures properties will not be affected and maintain those properties.

part_system_destroy.name: part_system_destroy

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system to destroy.

part_system_destroy.description: With this function you can destroy a given particles system and remove it from memory. This should always be called when the system is no longer needed, like at the end of a room, or in the destroy event of an instance, otherwise you could end up with particles appearing in later rooms and no way to remove them as well as a memory leak which will eventually crash your game.

window_mouse_get_locked.name: window_mouse_get_locked
window_mouse_get_locked.description: Returns whether the mouse cursor was locked using function window_mouse_set_locked.

layer_background_get_alpha.name: layer_background_get_alpha

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to get the information from

layer_background_get_alpha.description: This function can be used to get the alpha value of the background element. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and the function will return a value between 0 (fully transparent) and 1 (fully opaque).

shader_set_uniform_f_buffer.name: shader_set_uniform_f_buffer

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: The handle of the shader constant to set.

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to use.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset position (in bytes) within the buffer to read the data from.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: The number of entires to read from the buffer.

shader_set_uniform_f_buffer.description: With this function you can set values of a shader constant from a buffer. You must previously have gotten the "handle" of the constant using the function shader_get_uniform(), and you will have to have previously initialised the buffer and filled it with buffer_f32 data.

display_get_sleep_margin.name: display_get_sleep_margin
display_get_sleep_margin.description: This function can be used to get the current sleep margin value used for the render timing of your game, and will return a millisecond value. For more information on display timing, please see display_set_timing_method().

gpu_get_tex_max_mip.name: gpu_get_tex_max_mip
gpu_get_tex_max_mip.description: With this function you can get the currently set maximum mipmap level which is to be used, where a value of 0 is the highest resolution, 1 is to use the first mipmap, 2 is the second etc... Note that this can be quite useful for avoiding bleeding artifacts when rendering textures, for example, setting the texture page border to 8px and then setting the max mipmap level to 3 will ensure you don't get any bleeding problems at greater render distances.

draw_text_ext_transformed_colour.name: draw_text_ext_transformed_colour

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to draw.

parameters.name: sep
parameters.description: The distance in pixels between lines of text.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The maximum width in pixels of the string before a line break.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scale.

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scale.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle of the text.

parameters.name: c1
parameters.description: The colour for the top left of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c2
parameters.description: The colour for the top right of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c3
parameters.description: The colour for the bottom right of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c4
parameters.description: The colour for the bottom left of the drawn text.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha for the text.

draw_text_ext_transformed_colour.description: This function is a combination of the base draw_text() function with the draw_text_ext(), draw_text_transformed() and draw_text_colour() functions. As such, this is the most general of all functions for drawing text and gives a large amount of flexibility when drawing. Note that the "width" argument is based on a scale of 1, so if the scale is different, this value should be changed proportionally. For example, if the base width for a line break is 300 and you set the scale to 2, then the text will appear wrong, over-running the given width. Instead you should have set the width to 150 to compensate the scaling.

file_text_write_real.name: file_text_write_real

parameters.name: fileid
parameters.description: The id of the file to edit.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The real value to write to the file.

file_text_write_real.description: With this function you can write a number to the previously opened text file. Note that as the value to be written can be a real number, all decimals will be written with a "." point as separator. If the file already contains information, this information will be erased and the string will be written at the beginning of the file, unless you have opened the file with the file_text_open_append(). You can also avoid this by using the file_text_readln() function along with the file_text_eof() function to loop through the contents of the file until you get to the end and then start writing.

game_load.name: game_load

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The name of the file to load.

game_load.description: With this function you can load a game that has been previously saved using game_save(). Note that it will restore the version of the game that was used to create the save, so any updates made after it will not be visible. For more info, read the page on game_save().

median.name: median

parameters.description: The values to compare.

median.description: This function returns the median of the input values, that is, the middle value. When the number of arguments is even, the smaller of the two middle values is returned and the function can have as many arguments as required (note that more arguments will mean that the function will be slower to parse) which must all be real values. This means that, for example, median(43, 12, 25, 19, 6) would return 19 as it is the middle value between all the rest.

date_get_month.name: date_get_month

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to check.

date_get_month.description: This function returns the month of the given datetime value.

instance_nearest.name: instance_nearest

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to check from.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to check from.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for instances of.

instance_nearest.description: This function will check all the instances of the given object to see which is nearest to the given x/y point. All checks will be from the given x/y position to the origin (the x/y position) of instances of the object specified. If no instances of the object exist, the function will return the keyword noone, but if there are instances then it will return the id of the instance found. Please note that if the instance running the code has the same object index as the object being checked, then it will be included in the check (this includes checks for parent objects if the calling instance is also a child of the parent).

camera_set_view_angle.name: camera_set_view_angle

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The new angle to set the camera view to

camera_set_view_angle.description: You can use this function to update the angle of the view camera within the room. You give the unique camera ID value (as returned by the different camera_create() functions) and then give the angle that you wish to set the camera view to. The default value is 0° with positive values rotating the camera counter-clockwise, ie: setting the value to 90 will rotate the camera 90° to the left.

gpu_set_zfunc.name: gpu_set_zfunc

parameters.name: cmp_func
parameters.description: The comparison mode to use (see list above)

gpu_set_zfunc.description: This function can be used to set the z-buffer testing comparison mode (see gpu_set_ztestenable() for more information). The values available for use are any of the following constants (the default value is cmpfunc_lessequal):

asset_get_index.name: asset_get_index

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the game asset to get the index of (a string).

asset_get_index.description:
This function gets the unique identifying index for a game asset from its name.
			
			If the asset is not found, the function will return a value of -1, otherwise it will return the unique index id for the asset being checked. This id can then be used in other functions as you would any other index value, like the sprite_index or the path_index, for example. Please note that although this function can be used to reference assets from strings, you should always make sure that the asset exists before using it otherwise you may get errors that will crash your game.

rectangle_in_circle.name: rectangle_in_circle

parameters.name: sx1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the source rectangle.

parameters.name: sy1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top side of the source rectangle.

parameters.name: sx2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right side of the source rectangle.

parameters.name: sy2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom side of the source rectangle.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the centre of the circle

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the centre of the circle.

parameters.name: rad
parameters.description: The radius around the center point in which to check for a collision.

rectangle_in_circle.description: This function will check a rectangular area that you define to see if it is either not in collision, completely within the destination bounds, or if it is simply touching, a defined circular area. If they are not touching at all the function will return 0, if the source is completely within the destination it will return 1, and if they are simply overlapping then it will return 2. The image below illustrates this:

instance_change.name: instance_change

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The new object the calling object will change into.

parameters.name: perf
parameters.description: Whether to perform that new object's create and destroy events (true) or not (false).

instance_change.description: You can use this function to change one instance of an object into another instance of a different object, and while doing so decide whether to perform the initial instances Destroy and Clean Up Events and the new instances Create Event. In this way, you can have (for example) a bomb change into an explosion - in which case the "perf" argument would probably be true as you would want the bomb to perform its Destroy Event and Clean Up Event, as well as the explosion to perform its Create Event - or you could have your player character change into a different one - in which case the "perf" argument would probably be false as you do not want the instances to perform their Create and Destroy/Clean Up events.

draw_enable_drawevent.name: draw_enable_drawevent

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Set to true or false.

draw_enable_drawevent.description: With this function you can choose to enable (true) or disable (false) the draw event for all instances in the game, thus giving you control over how and when things are draw, useful if you wish to implement a "frame skip" technique. Note that this doesn't just prevent instances drawing to the screen, it suppresses the draw event completely meaning that care should be taken since any game logic that is present in that event will not be run either. One important thing to understand about this function is that if you call it right at the start of the game, before the initial frame is rendered (ie: the Create Event of the first object in the first room of the game), then the game window will not be rendered. This could be useful for online projects that require a server which doesn't need to render anything.

gpu_get_alphatestref.name: gpu_get_alphatestref
gpu_get_alphatestref.description: You can use this function to find the current value for the alpha test reference (default is 0, but you can use gpu_set_alphatestref() to set this value to something other than this).

scheduler_resolution_set.name: scheduler_resolution_set

parameters.name: milliseconds
parameters.description: The new resolution value (in milliseconds) or -1 for default

scheduler_resolution_set.description: This function is used to change the resolution of the Windows thread scheduler. The resolution value supplied in the argument needs to be in milliseconds.

variable_instance_names_count.name: variable_instance_names_count

parameters.name: instance_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the instance to check.

variable_instance_names_count.description: With this function you can find the total number number of variables defined for an instance. You supply the instance ID to check, and the function will return an integer value for the number of variables encountered, or (if no instance of the given ID exists) -1.

game_change.name: game_change

parameters.name: working_directory
parameters.description: The directory in which the new game will launch.

parameters.name: launch_parameters
parameters.description: Command line parameters to be passed to the new game.

game_change.description: This function allows you to close the currently running title and launch another title, it will only work in VM and on certain platforms it will only work in a package build and not in run\debug.

gpu_set_tex_max_aniso.name: gpu_set_tex_max_aniso

parameters.name: maxaniso
parameters.description: The maximum level for anisotropic filtering (default: 16)

gpu_set_tex_max_aniso.description: With this function you can set the current maximum level of anisotropy when using the tf_anisotropic filter mode (see gpu_get_tex_mip_filter() for more information). The input value must range between 1 and 16.

window_get_width.name: window_get_width
window_get_width.description: With this function you can get the current width (in pixels) of the game window.

audio_pause_sound.name: audio_pause_sound

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to pause.

audio_pause_sound.description: With this function you can pause any sound that is currently playing. The sound can either be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions) or a sound asset, in which case all instances of the given sound will be paused.

random_get_seed.name: random_get_seed
random_get_seed.description: To generate a random number GameMaker starts with a random seed number. With this function you can retrieve that seed, which can then be stored to reproduce a specific series of random events. For example, say you have a procedurally generated game, but want the player to be able to go back to previously discovered areas. Well, at the start of each area, you can store the random seed with this function and so every time you need to go back there, you can use random_set_seed() to set the seed to what it was previously and so force GameMaker to reproduce the same set of "random" functions that it used previously.

ds_list_create.name: ds_list_create
ds_list_create.description: This function will create a new list data-structure and return the index value. This value should be stored in a variable and used in all further function calls relating to the list. Note that if you try and access a value in the list before it has been populated - i.e. the list is "empty" - then the return value may be 0 since internally the first few entries in the list are set when created to minimize performance issues when initially adding items to the list (although the ds_list_size() function will still return 0 on a newly created list). If you wish to ensure that the list is "truly" empty on create, then you should call ds_list_clear() after creating the list, which will then mean that any values returned for unpopulated list slots will be undefined.

ds_list_write.name: ds_list_write

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to write.

ds_list_write.description: This function returns a string which can then be stored or transferred to another data structure using the ds_list_read() function.

file_bin_position.name: file_bin_position

parameters.name: binfile
parameters.description: The ID of the file to get the position in.

file_bin_position.description: This function will returns the current position in bytes, where 0 is the first position, of the file with the given file id. You supply the file ID value, as returned by the function file_bin_open().

show_debug_overlay.name: show_debug_overlay

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: switch on (true) or off (false) the debug overlay.

parameters.name: minimised
parameters.description: if true then FPS is opened minimised (default) or false for full size

parameters.name: scale
parameters.description: scale of the debug display. NOTE: clamped to between 0.5 and 4

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: alpha level of the debug windows. NOTE: clamped to between 0 and 1

show_debug_overlay.description: This function can be used to switch on and off the standard debug overlay when testing your game and is disabled by default. The debug overlay shows a graphic CPU/GPU usage bar in the actual game window itself along with the current real fps value, number of texture swaps and the number of vertex batches (note that texture swaps and vertex batches will never be zero and will normally show values of 2 or 3, since even with an empty room an no objects GameMaker still has to draw and batch things).

asset_clear_tags.name: asset_clear_tags

parameters.name: name_or_index
parameters.description: The name of the asset (a string) or its index value (an integer).

parameters.name: asset_type
parameters.description: OPTIONAL! The type of asset to clear the tags from, only used when supplying an index for the first argument.

asset_clear_tags.description:
This function clears all tags present on the given asset from the Asset Browser and returns whether any tags were removed.
			
			You supply either the asset name (as a string) or its asset index, and if you supply an asset index value, then you will need to supply the optional asset type argument (a constant), as assets of different types can have the same index, even though they cannot have the same name.

physics_particle_delete_region_box.name: physics_particle_delete_region_box

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of the center of the area to delete.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of the center of the area to delete.

parameters.name: halfwidth
parameters.description: The half width of the rectangle.

parameters.name: halfheight
parameters.description: The half height of the rectangle.

physics_particle_delete_region_box.description: With this function you can delete (remove) all the particles that fall within the bounds of the defined rectangular area from the physics simulation in the current room. The function takes the x and y position for the center of the area to delete as well as the half width and height of the rectangle (in pixels) which defines the area.

os_lock_orientation.name: os_lock_orientation

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: Set to true or false to enable or disable orientation locking.

os_lock_orientation.description: With this function you can "lock" your device to the current orientation until such time as you "free" it to allow all Game Options enabled orientations again for that target platform. Note that you likely want to confirm the orientation is as desired before locking.

ds_grid_get_disk_sum.name: ds_grid_get_disk_sum

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: xm
parameters.description: The x position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: ym
parameters.description: The y position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: r
parameters.description: The radius of the disk on the grid.

ds_grid_get_disk_sum.description: This function can be used to add all the values all the cells found within the defined disk area of a grid together, as shown in the image below:

random_range.name: random_range

parameters.name: n1
parameters.description: The low end of the range from which the random number will be selected.

parameters.name: n2
parameters.description: The high end of the range from which the random number will be selected.

random_range.description: This function returns a random number between the specified range, and this return value does not need to be an integer. For example, random_range(20,50) will return a random number from 20 to 50, but the value may be a real number like 38.65265. Real numbers can also be used as input arguments.

camera_get_end_script.name: camera_get_end_script

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_end_script.description: This function can be used to retrieve the ID of the script function assigned as the end function for the given camera. If no script function is assigned then the function will return -1.

string_lower.name: string_lower

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to convert to lowercase.

string_lower.description: With this function you can force a string to contain only lower case characters.

physics_world_draw_debug.name: physics_world_draw_debug

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: The flag value for showing different debug features

physics_world_draw_debug.description: This function will draw a representation of the physics world system of the room to help with debugging when you are having trouble getting the physics scene to work right. Sometimes the problem can be in the rendering part of your game, for example a sprite may be drawn at the wrong position or rotation, giving the appearance of incorrect physics, or it may be that your calculations are not correct. Either way, this function will help you to find and resolve the problem by drawing what is going on in your physics system. To do this, you need tell it which part of the system to draw, and this is done by passing a value created from the bits stored in various "flag" constants:

audio_emitter_set_listener_mask.name: audio_emitter_set_listener_mask

parameters.name: emitterid
parameters.description: The unique ID of the emitter to set the mask of

parameters.name: mask
parameters.description: The bitmask data to set for the sound

audio_emitter_set_listener_mask.description: This function can be used to set the the bit-mask for an emitter so that all sounds played through the emitter will play only from those listeners specified. You can create a bit-mask by using the audio_get_listener_info() and then using the bitwise or ("|") to create a custom mask with those listeners that you require the sound to play from, and then apply this custom mask to the emitter. This mask will over-ride the default mask or that which you may have set using the function audio_set_listener_mask().

instance_destroy.name: instance_destroy

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The instance ID or object_index to destroy (optional, default is the calling instance)

parameters.name: execute_event_flag
parameters.description: Set to true or false to perform the destroy event or not (optional, default is true)

instance_destroy.description: You call this function whenever you wish to destroy an instance, normally triggering a Destroy Event and also a Clean Up Event. This will remove it from the room until the room is restarted (unless the room is persistent). Calling the function with no arguments will simply destroy the instance that is currently in scope and running the code, but you can provide an optional "id" argument and target a specific instance by using the instance id value, or you can target all instances of a particular object by using an object_index. For example:

surface_save_part.name: surface_save_part

parameters.name: surface_id
parameters.description: The ID of the surface to set as the drawing target.

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The name of the saved image file.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The starting x position within the surface.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The starting y position within the surface.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the part to save.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the part to save.

surface_save_part.description: This function will save a part of a surface to disc using the given filename. The surface must be saved as a *.png format file, and the (x,y) position must be given as local coordinates to the surface, bearing in mind that the top left corner of the surface is always (0,0).

time_source_reconfigure.name: time_source_reconfigure

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

parameters.name: period
parameters.description: The period of the time source

parameters.name: units
parameters.description: The units that the period is measured in

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The callback to be invoked when the time source expires

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: The arguments to be passed to the callback

parameters.name: reps
parameters.description: The number of repetitions the time source should perform

parameters.name: expiry_type
parameters.description: The expiry type of the time source

time_source_reconfigure.description: Resets and reconfigures the time source. Additionally resets all of the time source's children.

sprite_get_bbox_top.name: sprite_get_bbox_top

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to check.

sprite_get_bbox_top.description: This function returns the relative position of the top of the sprite bounding box. This value is given as a relative value based on the upper left corner of the base sprite asset being (0,0). it is the same value as can be found in the sprite editor for the collision mask properties. The image below shows how it is calculated:

camera_get_update_script.name: camera_get_update_script

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_update_script.description: This function can be used to retrieve the ID of the script function assigned as the update script for the given camera. If no script is assigned then the function will return -1.

draw_rectangle_color.name: draw_rectangle_color

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the rectangle.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top of the rectangle.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right of the rectangle.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the rectangle.

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The colour of the top left corner.

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The colour of the top right corner.

parameters.name: col3
parameters.description: The colour of the bottom right corner.

parameters.name: col4
parameters.description: The colour of the bottom left corner.

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the rectangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

draw_rectangle_color.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rectangle or a filled rectangle by defining an area where the (x1,y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2,y2) position is the bottom right corner. If it is filled you can define the individual colours for each corner point and if these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

array_insert.name: array_insert

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index (position) in the array to insert the value(s)
The value to insert

array_insert.description: With this function you can insert a value (or values) into an array at any given position. The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array, the index (position) in the array to insert at, as well as at least one value to insert, although you can optionally provide further arguments and they will all be inserted into the array in consecutive order from the given index.

layer_sequence_get_headdir.name: layer_sequence_get_headdir

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

layer_sequence_get_headdir.description: With this function you supply the sequence element ID - as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions - and it will return the current playhead direction, which will be one of the constants listed below.

font_get_uvs.name: font_get_uvs

parameters.name: font
parameters.description: The index of the font to use.

font_get_uvs.description: This function returns an array with the UV coordinates for the font texture on the texture page, filling in the array with the following values:

network_connect_raw.name: network_connect_raw

parameters.name: socket
parameters.description: The id of the socket to use.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The URL or IP to connect to (a string).

parameters.name: port
parameters.description: The port to connect to.

network_connect_raw.description: With this function you can send a request to connect to a server. The function takes the socket id to connect through (see network_create_socket()) and requires you to give the IP address to connect to (a string) as well as the port to connect through, and if the connection fails a value of less than 0 will be returned. The difference between this function and network_connect() is that this function can connect to any server and does nothing to the raw data, meaning that you have to implement the protocols yourself at the server end. Note that by default the function is synchronous, meaning that your game may appear to "hang" as the connection is made. You can set a timeout value for connection, or alternatively make the creation asynchronous, using the function network_set_config(), or alternatively use the function network_connect_async_raw() instead.

camera_get_begin_script.name: camera_get_begin_script

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_begin_script.description: This function can be used to retrieve the ID of the script function assigned as the begin script for the given camera. If no script function is assigned then the function will return -1.

mp_linear_path.name: mp_linear_path

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The index of the path to be used.

parameters.name: xgoal
parameters.description: The target x position.

parameters.name: ygoal
parameters.description: The target y position.

parameters.name: stepsize
parameters.description: The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.

parameters.name: checkall
parameters.description: Whether to check for collisions with all instances (true) or just solid ones (false).

mp_linear_path.description: This function computes a straight line path from the current instance position to the point specified by the "xgoal" and "ygoal" values. It uses the indicated step size, the same as in the function mp_linear_step(). The indicated path must already exist and will be overwritten by the new path and the function will return if a complete path was found (true) or not (false). If false is returned then a path is still generated, but it will only run up to the position where the path was blocked.

buffer_get_alignment.name: buffer_get_alignment

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to check.

buffer_get_alignment.description: With this function you can get the a byte alignment for the given buffer ID.

path_get_closed.name: path_get_closed

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to check.

path_get_closed.description: This function can be used to return whether the path is flagged as closed (true) or open (false), ie whether the path loops or if it has a definitive beginning and end.

buffer_load_ext.name: buffer_load_ext

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to load into.

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The name of the file to load from.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset within the buffer to load to (in bytes).

buffer_load_ext.description: This function will load the buffer data that was previously saved using the buffer_save() functions into an already created buffer. You give the id of the previously created buffer to load into, then the saved buffer file to load, and finally the offset from the start of the buffer (in bytes) that you wish to load the data to.

draw_tile.name: draw_tile

parameters.name: tile set
parameters.description: The ID of the tile set to use

parameters.name: tiledata
parameters.description: The tile data to use

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: The frame number for the animated tile to use (default 0 for non-animated tiles)

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position within the room to draw at

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position within the room to draw at

draw_tile.description: With this function you can draw any given tile from a tile set - compete with rotations, flips and mirrors - setting the frame (if animated) and the position within the room. The tile set ID value is the tile set index as set in the IDE and the tile data is the data "blob" that contains all the information about the tile index and the transformations that have been applied. You can use the function tilemap_get() to get the tile data which can then be manipulated using the Tile Functions, or you can construct it yourself using the following tile constants along with the index value of the tile to create:

sprite_duplicate.name: sprite_duplicate

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to duplicate.

sprite_duplicate.description: This function will return the index of a newly created sprite that is a duplicate (copy) of the one input as the "index" argument. If the function fails, -1 is returned. This function must be used to copy any sprites from the original assets before any transformations can be done on them. For example, if you wish to change the bounding box for a sprite, or set its alpha from another sprite, you must first duplicate it, then perform the operation on the duplicated sprite and use that. A duplicated sprite will be places on its own unique texture page when created, meaning that duplicating multiple sprites will create multiple texture pages and have an impact on performance, so use this function only when necessary.

draw_sprite_ext.name: draw_sprite_ext

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to draw.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling of the sprite as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: rot
parameters.description: The rotation of the sprite. 0=right way up, 90=rotated 90 degrees counter-clockwise etc...

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour with which to blend the sprite. c_white is to display it normally.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha of the sprite (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

draw_sprite_ext.description: This function will draw the given sprite as in the function draw_sprite() but with additional options to change the scale, blending, rotation and alpha of the sprite being drawn. Changing these values does not modify the resource in any way (only how it is drawn), and you can use any of the available sprite variables instead of direct values for all the arguments in the function. The image below illustrates how different values affect the drawing of the sprite:

time_source_stop.name: time_source_stop

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

time_source_stop.description: Stops the time source and all of its children.

ds_map_keys_to_array.name: ds_map_keys_to_array

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map to use.

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: OPTIONAL! The array to append the DS map keys to.

ds_map_keys_to_array.description: With this function you can retrieve all of the keys that a DS map contains. You supply the DS map ID to get the keys from (as returned by ds_map_create()) and the function will return an array where each entry in the array is a key from the DS map. The function has an optional second argument where you can supply an array that you have created, in which case the map key data will be appended onto any existing data in the array. Note that the function will modify the array supplied directly, but will also return a reference to it (or a reference to a new array if none is supplied).

device_mouse_check_button.name: device_mouse_check_button

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked

parameters.name: button
parameters.description: The button of the device that is being checked.

device_mouse_check_button.description: This function returns true or false depending on whether the given mouse button is being held down on the given device. For the mouse button you can supply one of the constants listed on this page.

mp_linear_step.name: mp_linear_step

parameters.name: xgoal
parameters.description: The target x position.

parameters.name: ygoal
parameters.description: The target y position.

parameters.name: stepsize
parameters.description: The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.

parameters.name: checkall
parameters.description: Whether to check all instances (true) or just solid ones (false).

mp_linear_step.description: With this function you tell an instance to take a "step" towards a specific point, specified by the xgoal and ygoal values. The size of the step (which is how many pixels the instance should move each step) is indicated by the stepsize, and if the instance is already at the position it will stop and not move any further, contrary to other, simpler functions like move_towards_point(). The stepsize is also the distance "ahead" that the object will check each step for a collision, and you can choose whether the instance stops at a collision with any instance or only those that are flagged as solid. The function will return whether it has reached the goal position (true) or if it has failed (false).

sequence_track_new.name: sequence_track_new

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of track to create, a constant, listed above.

sequence_track_new.description: With this function you can create a new sequence track struct, supplying the type of track that you wish to make which will be one of the following constants:

layer_sprite_angle.name: layer_sprite_angle

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to change

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle of the sprite (default is 0)

layer_sprite_angle.description: Using this function you can change the angle for the given sprite element on a layer. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and then set the angle value, from 0 to 359 anti-clockwise, where 0 is to the right, 90 is to the top, 180 is to the left and 270 is to the bottom. If you set a value greater than 360 this will be looped to bring it within the 0 - 359 range.

sprite_save.name: sprite_save

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to save.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The sub-image of the sprite to save.

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The filename for the saved sprite.

sprite_save.description: This function can be used to save any sub-image of a sprite to disc, giving it the specified filename. The sprite must have been added at runtime (you cannot save sprites added through the IDE) and the file must be saved with a *.png extension.

collision_circle_list.name: collision_circle_list

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle to check.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the center of the circle to check.

parameters.name: rad
parameters.description: The radius (distance in pixels from its center to its edge).

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for instance collisions.

parameters.name: prec
parameters.description: Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).

parameters.name: notme
parameters.description: Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).

parameters.name: list
parameters.description: The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.

parameters.name: ordered
parameters.description: Whether the list should be ordered by distance (true) or not (false).

collision_circle_list.description: This function is the same as the collision_circle() function, only instead of just detecting one instance in collision at a time, it will detect multiple instances. You supply the x/y position of the center of the circular area to check along with the radius and the object to check for, and you can set the check to be precise (in which case all instances being checked will need to have precise collision masks) and whether the check should include the calling instance or not.

date_inc_second.name: date_inc_second

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to add to.

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: The number of seconds (must be an integer) to add.

date_inc_second.description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of seconds, and it will return the new datetime value.

effect_create_depth.name: effect_create_depth

parameters.name: depth
parameters.description: The depth to assign the created effect to.

parameters.name: kind
parameters.description: The kind of effect (use one of the constants listed above).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x positioning of the effect if relevant.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y positioning of the effect if relevant.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the effect.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour of the effect.

effect_create_depth.description: With this function you can create a simple effect at a specified depth. If the effect is anything other ef_rain or ef_snow then you can define an x/y position to create the effect, and the size can be a value of 0, 1, or 2, where 0 is small, 1 is medium and 2 is large.

layer_tilemap_exists.name: layer_tilemap_exists

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target (or the layer name as a string)

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to check

layer_tilemap_exists.description: You can use this function to check and see if a tile map element exists on any given layer. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()) and the function will return either true if the element exists, or false if it does not.

mp_potential_settings.name: mp_potential_settings

parameters.name: maxrot
parameters.description: The number of degrees either side of the current direction that the instance can rotate in a step

parameters.name: rotstep
parameters.description: The number of degrees either side of the current direction that the instance can check for a collision

parameters.name: ahead
parameters.description: The number of steps ahead that the instance can check for a collision. Larger values are slower than lower ones.

parameters.name: onspot
parameters.description: Use this to allow the instance to rotate on the spot when no path is found (true) or not (false)

mp_potential_settings.description: The mp_potential_ functions do their work using a number of parameters that can be changed using this function. Globally the method works as follows: it first tries to move straight towards the goal, looking a number of steps ahead which can be set with the parameter "ahead" (default value is 3). Reducing this value means that the instance will start changing direction later as it doesn't "see" as far ahead, and increasing it means it will start changing direction earlier. If this check leads to a collision then it starts looking at directions more to the left and to the right of the ideal, straight-line direction. It does this in steps of size "rotstep" (default value is 10), and reducing this gives the instance more movement possibilities but will be slower as it needs more processing power.

font_get_last.name: font_get_last

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: Index of the font to check.

font_get_last.description: When defining a font in GameMaker, you can define a range of characters to include. This is because the font itself is not actually included with your game (for legal reasons) but an image of the font is included on a texture page and that is what your game will use (just like any other graphics asset). This means that you will want to keep the number of characters that you use to a minimum and specify only the range of characters that your game will need so as to keep texture memory as optimised as possible. This function can be used to find the last character (as an UTF8 value) that was used when your font asset was added to your game.

move_bounce_solid.name: move_bounce_solid

parameters.name: adv
parameters.description: Whether to enable advanced bouncing (true) or not (false).

move_bounce_solid.description: With this function you can command an instance to bounce off only those instances marked as solid within the room. You can also tell it to use precise collision checking when enabled, but be aware that this requires all instances to have precise masks enabled and will greatly slow down your game when many instances are involved due to the amount of processing that has to be done. This should normally go in the step event of an instance, but can be used selectively in a collision event too.

ds_grid_value_disk_y.name: ds_grid_value_disk_y

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: xm
parameters.description: The x position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: ym
parameters.description: The y position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: r
parameters.description: The radius of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to find.

ds_grid_value_disk_y.description: With this function you can get the y coordinate (within the given grid disc-shaped region) of the value being searched for. You give the DS grid index (as returned by ds_grid_create()) along with the x/y positions for the center cell of the disk. Then you give the radius (as an integer value) around the center cell to search, before supplying the value to search for. If the value being searched for does not exist, then the function will return -1.

texture_get_height.name: texture_get_height

parameters.name: tex
parameters.description: The texture page asset pointer to use

texture_get_height.description: Returns the height of the texture with the given id, which is always a value within the range 0 - 1. This can then be used when mapping textures to models or primitives.

room_restart.name: room_restart
room_restart.description: This function will restart the current room, as if it had just been entered. Note that the room will not restart until the end of the event where the function was called, so any code after this has been called will still run if in the same event. This function will also trigger the Room End event.

parameters.name: uniform_id
parameters.description: The handle of the shader constant to set.

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: A previously initialised array of integer values.

path_set_precision.name: path_set_precision

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to change.

parameters.name: prec
parameters.description: The precision of the path. Must be an integer between 1 and 8.

path_set_precision.description: With this function you can change the "smoothness" of a path. This value must be between 1 and 8, with a low value creating straighter edges with sharper curves between points, while a higher value will round the points and make the path a lot more "curvy". Note that this function will have no visible effect if the path has not been set to smooth in the path editor or using the function path_set_kind(). This function changes the actual path asset, and so will permanently affect how the path is used by all instances in the game from the moment the function is used until the end of the game. If this is not what you require, then you should use a function like path_duplicate() to create a copy of the path first, then call this function on the duplicated asset (don't forget to call path_delete() on the asset when it is no longer required).

instance_number.name: instance_number

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to total the number of instances of.

instance_number.description: With this function you can find out how many active instances of the specified object exists in the room. When checking using this function, if the object is a parent, then all child objects will also be included in the return value, and also note that those instances which have been deactivated with the instance deactivate functions will not be included in this check.

push_local_notification.name: push_local_notification

parameters.name: fire_time
parameters.description: The date/time to fire the off the notification

parameters.name: title
parameters.description: The notification title (a string)

parameters.name: message
parameters.description: The notification message text (a string)

parameters.name: data
parameters.description: The data package to send to your game (a string)

push_local_notification.description: This function can be used to set a local notification to be shown on a given date at a given time. The "fire_time" is the date/time that the notification should be pushed to the user device (you can use the GameMaker Date and Time Functions to get this), and you can give the notification a title and a message text as well as a payload string which will be passed to your game when the users taps the notification.

skeleton_attachment_destroy.name: skeleton_attachment_destroy

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name (as a string) of the attachment to destroy.

skeleton_attachment_destroy.description: This function destroys a custom attachment previously created using the skeleton_attachment_create() or skeleton_attachment_replace() functions. Any slots using the attachment will be cleared.

physics_joint_set_value.name: physics_joint_set_value

parameters.name: joint
parameters.description: The index of the joint that you wish to change

parameters.name: field
parameters.description: The constant for the joint property that you wish to change

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The new value for the joint property

physics_joint_set_value.description: Certain joint properties can be changed and set even after the creation of the joint. There are a number of constants that can be used in this function and they can be found here: Physics Joint Constants.

time_source_get_state.name: time_source_get_state

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

time_source_get_state.description: Returns the current active state of the time source.

physics_fixture_set_chain_shape.name: physics_fixture_set_chain_shape

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: The index of the fixture

parameters.name: loop
parameters.description: Whether to close the chain (true) or not (false).

physics_fixture_set_chain_shape.description: This function defines a "chain" fixture shape. A chain fixture is comprised of a number of points, which are then connected together using edge shapes to join them. The function itself takes the index (ID) of the fixture and can tell the fixture to loop or not. Setting this to true will connect the last point to the first point with an edge, while setting it to false will not. Note that this function on prepares the fixture to accept the points required to make the chain, and these should be added after calling this function using physics_fixture_add_point(), much as you would when building a polygon fixture.

gamepad_get_option.name: gamepad_get_option

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

parameters.name: option_name
parameters.description: The name of the option to get the value from (a string, see the table above)

gamepad_get_option.description: This function can be used to retrieve the given option value. You supply the gamepad "slot" to check, as well as the option string and the function will return the associated value. The available option string will depend on the platform that the project is being run on, as listed below:

part_emitter_destroy.name: part_emitter_destroy

parameters.name: ps
parameters.description: The particle system to destroy the emitter from.

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to destroy.

part_emitter_destroy.description: This function will remove the specified emitter from the given system and clear it from memory (this will also stop any particles from being produced by the given emitter, but it does NOT remove them from the room). This function should always be called when the given emitter is no longer needed for the system to prevent memory leaks and errors.

skeleton_animation_get_position.name: skeleton_animation_get_position

parameters.name: track
parameters.description: The animation track to get the frame of.

skeleton_animation_get_position.description: This function will return the current position of the specified animation track in the range (0.0 to 1.0). The function will return -1 if no animation is assigned to the specific track given.

date_get_minute_of_year.name: date_get_minute_of_year

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The date to check.

date_get_minute_of_year.description: This function returns the minute of the given datetime value within the year (from the total number of minutes for the year, taking into account leap years).

skeleton_animation_get.name: skeleton_animation_get
skeleton_animation_get.description: With this function you can get the current animation set being used by your skeletal animation sprite. The return value is a string, which will be the name of the set as you defined it in your skeletal animation program.

array_concat.name: array_concat

parameters.name: array0
parameters.description: The variable that holds the first array.

parameters.name: array1
parameters.description: The variable that holds the second array.
The variable that holds the nth array.

array_concat.description: With this function you can concatenate two or more arrays into a single one.

surface_reset_target.name: surface_reset_target
surface_reset_target.description: With this function you reset all further drawing from the target surface back to the screen. Please note that to start drawing to a surface you must first have called the function surface_set_target() and then this one after you have finished, for each surface target that you have set or else nothing will be drawn on the screen as all further drawing (even in other instances) will be done on the surface. You should also realise that nothing will be seen if the surface itself is not drawn on the screen in the draw event of an instance.

vertex_normal.name: vertex_normal

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to write the information to.

parameters.name: nx
parameters.description: The x component of the surface normal.

parameters.name: ny
parameters.description: The y component of the surface normal.

parameters.name: nz
parameters.description: The z component of the surface normal.

vertex_normal.description: This function will add surface normal data to the vertex currently being defined for the custom primitive. You supply the buffer to write the data into as well as the x, y and z component parts of the normal.

buffer_exists.name: buffer_exists

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to check.

buffer_exists.description: This function can be used to check a variable to see if it holds a valid buffer ID value or not. If it does the function will return true otherwise it will return false.

audio_resume_sync_group.name: audio_resume_sync_group

parameters.name: group_index
parameters.description: The group index to resume.

audio_resume_sync_group.description: This function will resume the given sync group if it is playing and has previously been paused (using the function audio_pause_sync_group). The group index is the value returned when you created the group using the function audio_create_sync_group().

file_text_close.name: file_text_close

parameters.name: fileid
parameters.description: The id of the file to close.

file_text_close.description: Once you have finished working with a given file (whether reading from it or writing to it), you must close the file again, or else you risk losing the information contained within. This also prevents memory leaks and makes sure that you never go over the file limit by having more than 32 files open.

lin_to_db.name: lin_to_db

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The value to convert.

lin_to_db.description: Converts a linear gain to a gain in decibels (dB).

surface_format_is_supported.name: surface_format_is_supported

parameters.name: format
parameters.description: The surface format to be tested.
