Normally you would assign these attachments in your animation program (Spine), but with this function you can create your own at run-time using a sprite asset from your game. the function requires that you give the attachment a UNIQUE name (as a string) and then set the sprite_index and image_index to use, as well as the x and y origin (which can be different to that defined by the sprite in the sprite properties), and you can also set any transforms that you wish to be applied to the image when attached, as well as the colour to be blended with the image and it's alpha (transparency) value. If the attachment was successfully created the function will return 1 and if it was not (you supplied an invalid sprite index, or the base sprite is not a Spine sprite) then it will return -1.

part_system_colour.name: part_system_colour

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system to change the colour and alpha of.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The new colour with which to blend the particle system. c_white is to display it normally.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The new alpha of the particle system (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

part_system_colour.description: This function can be used to change colour and alpha with which the particle system is blended.

keyboard_key_press.name: keyboard_key_press

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to simulate a press of.

keyboard_key_press.description: With this function you can simulate the press of any key on the keyboard. When used, the key will be flagged as being pressed until the corresponding release function is called (see keyboard_key_release()). The function will take a keycode value as returned by the function ord() (only capital letters from A-Z or numbers from 0-9), or any of the vk_* constants listed on the main Keyboard Input page.

move_and_collide.name: move_and_collide

parameters.name: dx
parameters.description: The x component of direction to move in.

parameters.name: dy
parameters.description: The y component of direction to move in.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for collisions with.

parameters.name: num_iterations
parameters.description: The number of steps the motion will be broken down into to resolve collisions, defaults to 4

parameters.name: xoff
parameters.description: The x component of direction to move to attempt to avoid obstacles. If not specified the perpendicular to the direction of movement is used.

parameters.name: yoff
parameters.description: The y component of direction to move to attempt to avoid obstacles. If not specified the perpendicular to the direction of movement is used.

parameters.name: max_x_distance
parameters.description: The maximum distance in the x direction the instance will move. If less than or equal to 0 no clamping is performed.

parameters.name: max_y_distance
parameters.description: The maximum distance in the y direction the instance will move. If less than or equal to 0 no clamping is performed.

move_and_collide.description: With this function you can tell an instance to move in a direction, resolving collisions on the way and specify a direction in which the instance will attempt to move to get past obstacles, thus allowing traversal of slopes or small steps. Returns an array of instances that it has collided with.

time_source_get_time_remaining.name: time_source_get_time_remaining

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

time_source_get_time_remaining.description: Returns the time left before the next expiry of the time source, measured in its own units.

path_clear_points.name: path_clear_points

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to clear.

path_clear_points.description: With this function you can remove all point definitions from a path, effectively making an "empty" path. This does not delete the path, for that you should use path_delete(), however it should be noted that this function changes the actual path asset, and so will permanently affect how the path is used by all instances in the game from the moment the function is used until the end of the game. If this is not what you require, then you should use a function like path_duplicate() to create a copy of the path first, then call this function on the duplicated asset (don't forget to call path_delete() on the asset when it is no longer required).

draw_flush.name: draw_flush
draw_flush.description: With this function you can flush the entire draw pipeline. This is a debug only function and in general it should not be used unless indicated by a member of the YoYo Games Support staff, as indiscriminate use will cause serious performance issues with your game.

distance_to_point.name: distance_to_point

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to check.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to check.

distance_to_point.description: This function calculates the distance from the edge of the bounding box of the calling instance to the specified x/y position in the room, with the return value being in pixels. Note that if the calling object have no sprite or no mask defined, the results will be incorrect.

tilemap_get_tileset.name: tilemap_get_tileset

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to get the tile set from

tilemap_get_tileset.description: Using this function you can retrieve the index value of the tile set resource assigned to a given tile map element on a layer. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and the function will return the tile set index value.

mp_grid_create.name: mp_grid_create

parameters.name: left
parameters.description: Starting x coordinate of the mp_grid in the room

parameters.name: top
parameters.description: Starting y coordinate of the mp_grid in the room

parameters.name: hcells
parameters.description: Number of horizontal cells that the mp_grid will contain

parameters.name: vcells
parameters.description: Number of vertical cells that the mp_grid will contain

parameters.name: cellwidth
parameters.description: The width (in pixels) of each individual cell of the mp_grid

parameters.name: cellheight
parameters.description: The height (in pixels) of each individual cell of the mp_grid

mp_grid_create.description: With this function you can create an mp_grid for the motion planning functions. It returns an index that should be stored in a variable for use in all the other MP grid function calls. The x and y coordinates indicate the position of the top-left corner of the grid, hcells and vcells indicate the number of horizontal and vertical cells to be created within the grid, and cell width and cell height indicate the size of the cells in pixels. You can create and maintain multiple grid structures at the same moment if you need them for different things, but be aware that each grid will require memeory, and the more cells they have the more memory they will require. Also note that the MP functions are quite processor heavy to use so the more often you call them and the higher the cell resolution then the more likely you are to have a drop in performance.

audio_pause_all.name: audio_pause_all
audio_pause_all.description: With this function you can pause all sounds that are currently playing.

matrix_stack_top.name: matrix_stack_top
matrix_stack_top.description: This function returns the current top matrix of the stack, but does not remove it (for that use matrix_stack_pop()).

draw_primitive_begin_texture.name: draw_primitive_begin_texture

parameters.name: kind
parameters.description: The kind of primitive you are going to draw.

parameters.name: tex
parameters.description: The texture to use with the primitive.

draw_primitive_begin_texture.description: This function must be called before you define the vertices of a textured primitive. You must give the kind of primitive to use (see draw_primitive_begin() for more information) and the id of a texture to use, which can be a sprite or background image asset. This asset id can be gotten from the functions sprite_get_texture(), for example (use -1 for no texture).

room_instance_add.name: room_instance_add

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the room to add an object instance to.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of the new instance.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of the new instance.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to add an instance of.

room_instance_add.description: With this function you can add an instance into any room other than the current one and at any position within that room. The function returns the unique id of the instance which can then be used in further function calls to set properties etc... of that instance, but only once the game has entered the specified room. If you wish to create an instance in the current room you should be using the function instance_create_layer(). Note that calling this function on a room asset created in the Asset Browser will permanently add the instance to the room, and even calling game_restart() will not return the room to it's original state (only ending the game and opening it again will start with the room in its original state again).

draw_skeleton_instance.name: draw_skeleton_instance

parameters.name: instance
parameters.description: The index of the instance to draw the sprite from.

parameters.name: animname
parameters.description: The name of the animation to get the frame from (a string).

parameters.name: skinname
parameters.description: The name of the skin to use (a string).

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: The animation frame to draw (from 0 to image_number - 1).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: rot
parameters.description: The rotation of the sprite. 0=normal, 90=turned 90 degrees counter-clockwise etc.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour with which to blend the sprite.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha of the sprite (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

draw_skeleton_instance.description: This function is only for use with instances which have sprites assigned to them created using the skeletal animation program Spine. While you can draw these sprites using the normal draw functions (like draw_self()), there are times when you may want to draw a single frame or show a change of skin texture without actually changing the sprite properties for an instance. In these cases you can draw the sprite that has been assigned to the instance with this function, where you give the unique Instance ID and then the name of the animation to get the frame from (a string, as set within the program used to make the sprite). Next you give the name of the skin to use (again, as set when the sprite was made), and a frame value. The frame value is for telling GameMaker what part of the animation to show and is a value between 0 and the image_number. The rest of the arguments are the same as those used for normal sprite drawing and will change the scale, angle, blend colour and alpha of the final animation frame being drawn.

layer_background_get_id.name: layer_background_get_id

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target

layer_background_get_id.description: This function can be used to retrieve the unique ID value of the background element on a layer. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you use the layer name along with layer_get_id()) and the function will return the ID value associated with the background element on the layer. Note that this function is specifically designed for use with backgrounds that have been added in the IDE, as if you add a background to a layer through code using the function layer_background_create(), then it will return the unique ID for the background element added.

ini_open_from_string.name: ini_open_from_string

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string containing all the ini information.

ini_open_from_string.description: This function will create an ini file from a string and open it for reading/writing. The string should be correctly formatted as an ini file (ie: with sections, line breaks keys and values) otherwise the ini file will not be created correctly. Note that this ini file is temporary and will be removed from memory the moment it is closed, losing any information that was stored in it, however the ini_close() function returns a string of the full ini file which can then be saved to a server or to disk.

fx_get_parameter.name: fx_get_parameter

parameters.name: filter_or_effect
parameters.description: The FX struct to get the parameter from

parameters.name: parameter_name
parameters.description: The FX struct to get the parameter from

fx_get_parameter.description: This function is used to retrieve the value of a parameter from an FX Struct.

camera_create.name: camera_create
camera_create.description: This function will create an "empty" camera, ie: a camera with no view or projection settings defined. Once you have created the camera you can then use the different matrix functions to set the view and projection matrices. You can also use this function to create the camera and then use the different camera_set_* functions to set up the view, however note that you must provide at least a position and view size, otherwise the resulting camera will not be valid and give odd results if applied to a view port (if you do not set the object following, borders or move speed these will be set to the default values for a view camera in the Room Editor).

part_type_color2.name: part_type_color2

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: colour1
parameters.description: The colour the particle will start at.

parameters.name: colour2
parameters.description: The colour the particle will end at.

part_type_color2.description: This function can be used to set a two colour gradient for each particle created of the given type. The first colour is that which all particles will start with, and the second colour is the one on which the particle will end with, and a smooth gradient change will occur to the colour over the particles lifetime from one colour to the other.

get_save_filename_ext.name: get_save_filename_ext

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description: The file type filter and/or name.

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The suggested filename to use.

parameters.name: directory
parameters.description: The directory to start the search from.

parameters.name: caption
parameters.description: The caption for the window.

get_save_filename_ext.description: This function opens a dialogue and asks the player for a filename to save to with the given filter. The filter has the form "name1|mask1|name2|mask2|...", where the mask may contain the different options with a semicolon between them and you can also use a "*" to mean any string. For example: "bitmaps|*.bmp;*.wmf", would ask the user to select the name of a bitmap file from the system, but only those that have the two specified extensions (bmp and png). this function does not save the file itself! It only returns a string with the full name and path of the file. If the user presses "Cancel" an empty string "" is returned. You may also add in a directory to start the search from, and a caption to be shown at the top of the window instead of the default one.

show_debug_message.name: show_debug_message

parameters.name: string_or_format
parameters.description: The custom debug message to show or a string format.
Values to be replaced on the format string (non-strings will be converted to strings).

show_debug_message.description: This function will create a custom debug message that is shown in the compiler window at runtime. Note that the message can be either a string or a real number, but if you need both then the number will have to be converted to string first using the string() function (see the example below) and that if the number has more than two decimal places then you should use string_format() to show them as by default decimals are rounded to the nearest two decimal places (so "1.2468" would show as "1.25" in the output window). This function also supports template format strings when using "{x}" (i.e. {0},{1},...) as placeholders and passing the correspondent values as separate arguments.

layer_get_y.name: layer_get_y

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to get the y position of

layer_get_y.description: You can use this function to retrieve the y position of the layer within the currently scoped room. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the function returns a real number for the x position of the layer, relative to the (0,0) position of the room. Default is 0.

tileset_get_name.name: tileset_get_name

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the tile set to get the name of.

tileset_get_name.description: This function will return the name as a string of the specified tile set. This name is the one that has been specified for the tile set in the Asset Browser of the main GameMaker window. Please note that this is only a string and cannot be used to reference the tile set directly - for that you would need the tile set index. You can, however, use this string to get the tile set index using the returned string along with the function asset_get_index().

ini_section_exists.name: ini_section_exists

parameters.name: section
parameters.description: The section in the open .ini file to check for.

ini_section_exists.description: This function checks to see if a section exists in the currently open ini and will return true if it does or false otherwise. This is not a necessary check to prevent errors as, when a section does not exist, reading from a non-existent section will just return a default value, however it can be useful to see if an ini file has saved specific data.

ln.name: ln

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The input value.

ln.description: The natural logarithm ln(n) is the amount of time needed to reach a certain level of continuous growth, where n is the level reached. So if we want to find out how many time units we need to get 20 growth we would use ln(20) which returns 2.99 units of time to get that amount of growth.

gpu_get_texrepeat_ext.name: gpu_get_texrepeat_ext

parameters.name: sampler_id
parameters.description: The sampler id from the shader.

gpu_get_texrepeat_ext.description: With this function you can check to see whether texture repeating is enabled (returns true) or not (returns false) for a given shader sampler texture.

date_time_of.name: date_time_of

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to extract the time from.

date_time_of.description: Returns the time value of the given datetime. The time returned ignores Daylight Saving Time (and so is Universal Time) and would normally be used in conjunction with another date/time handling function.

get_timer.name: get_timer
get_timer.description: This function returns the time that your game has been running on the chosen platform in microseconds (there are 1 million microseconds per second).

part_type_sprite.name: part_type_sprite

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to set the particle type to.

parameters.name: animate
parameters.description: Whether to follow the sprite's animation normally (true) or not (false).

parameters.name: stretch
parameters.description: Whether to stretch the sprite's animation to match the particle lifespan (true) or not (false).

parameters.name: random
parameters.description: Whether to choose a random sub-image (true) or not (false).

part_type_sprite.description: This function can be used to set a particle type to use a custom sprite from the game assets. You can select the sprite and then tell GameMaker to use the sprite and animate it or not, and if you choose animated, then you can also choose to have the sub-images changed at an interval such that the animation will begin and end at the beginning and end of the lifetime of each particle created (so that if you have a lifetime set to a 15 step minimum and a 30 step maximum, no matter what value the lifetime has the animation will be made to fit, with it running faster for the shorter lifetimes and slower for the longer). You can also select to choose a random sub-image so that if the sprite is not animated, a different image will be chosen at random to create the sprite, or if the particle is animated it will start the animation at a random point.

draw_text_ext_color.name: draw_text_ext_color

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to draw.

parameters.name: sep
parameters.description: The distance in pixels between lines of text.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The maximum width in pixels of the string before a line break.

parameters.name: c1
parameters.description: The colour for the top left of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c2
parameters.description: The colour for the top right of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c3
parameters.description: The colour for the bottom right of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c4
parameters.description: The colour for the bottom left of the drawn text.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha for the text.

draw_text_ext_color.description: This function is a combination of the base draw_text() function with the draw_text_ext() and draw_text_colour() functions, permitting you to define gradient colours for text as well as the line spacing and maximum width per line all together.

array_copy.name: array_copy

parameters.name: dest
parameters.description: The ID of the array to copy to.

parameters.name: dest_index
parameters.description: The index within the array to copy to.

parameters.name: src
parameters.description: The ID of the array to copy from.

parameters.name: src_index
parameters.description: The index with the array to start copying from.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: The length (number of array indices) to copy.

array_copy.description: With this function you can copy all or part of an array into another array at any position. You need to supply both the source and the destination arrays (both need to have been created previously), as well as a position within the source array to copy from and a position within the destination array to copy to. Finally you need to specify the length of the array (or the length of the part that you want) to copy. If the data being copied exceeds the length of the destination array, the array will be extended to accept the data.

date_minute_span.name: date_minute_span

parameters.name: date1
parameters.description: The first datetime.

parameters.name: date2
parameters.description: The datetime to compare it to.

date_minute_span.description: With this function you can get the number of minutes between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete minutes will be returned as a fraction.

part_type_color_hsv.name: part_type_color_hsv

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: hmin
parameters.description: The minimum the final colour's hue component can be.

parameters.name: hmax
parameters.description: The maximum the final colour's hue component can be.

parameters.name: smin
parameters.description: The minimum the final colour's saturation component can be.

parameters.name: smax
parameters.description: The maximum the final colour's saturation component can be.

parameters.name: vmin
parameters.description: The minimum the final colour's value component can be.

parameters.name: vmax
parameters.description: The maximum the final colour's value component can be.

part_type_color_hsv.description: With this function you can set a hue, saturation and value range for all particles of the given type. You supply a minimum value and a maximum value for each of the three components and the particles created will have a random colour based on the given range of parameters. In this way you can create particles of the same hue but different saturations, or of different hues but the same value (luminosity) etc... All values must be between 0 and 255.

ds_list_destroy.name: ds_list_destroy

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to remove.

ds_list_destroy.description: This function will remove the given list data-structure from memory, freeing up the resources it was using and removing all values that it contained. This function should always be used when you are finished using the ds_list to prevent memory leaks that can slow down and crash your game. Note that destroying a list will de-reference any data structures stored in it giving a memory leak, so you would need to go through the list and destroy all data structure items manually before destroying it to prevent this. The only time this is not required is when you have flagged any items in the list as another DS list or as a DS map, in which case these items will be destroyed and their memory cleaned up automatically as well.

physics_joint_enable_motor.name: physics_joint_enable_motor

parameters.name: joint
parameters.description: The joint that you wish to enable or disable the motor on

parameters.name: motor
parameters.description: Whether you wish to turn the motor on (true) or off (false)

physics_joint_enable_motor.description: When you have a joint with a motor (prismatic or revolute), you may want to be able to switch the motor on or off depending on variables and conditions within the game. For this, you need to have stored the index of the joint previously in a variable and then you can switch the motor on or off by using this function and setting the "motor" argument to true or false.

draw_line_width_colour.name: draw_line_width_colour

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width in pixels of the line.

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The colour of the start of the line.

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The colour of the end of the line.

draw_line_width_colour.description: With this function you can draw a line of a specific width with the colour blended between colour 1 at the first point and colour 2 at the second point. The colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour(). Please note that the line being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

variable_struct_remove.name: variable_struct_remove

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The struct reference to remove the variable from

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the variable to remove (as a string)

variable_struct_remove.description: With this function you can remove a variable from a struct. You supply the struct ID to remove the variable from and the string name of the variable to be removed.

fx_get_name.name: fx_get_name

parameters.name: filter_or_effect
parameters.description: The FX struct to get the name of

fx_get_name.description: This function is used to retrieve the name of a filter/effect from its struct.

texturegroup_get_sprites.name: texturegroup_get_sprites

parameters.name: tex
parameters.description: The name of the texture group to check (a string)

texturegroup_get_sprites.description: With this function you can retrieve the sprite index of each of the sprites assigned to texture pages within the given texture group. You supply the texture group ID string (as defined in the texture Group Editor) and the function will return a 1D array where each entry contains the sprite index for a sprite resource. If the function fails - ie: an invalid group is given, or the group has no texture assigned to it - then the array will be empty (0 length).

ds_grid_value_disk_exists.name: ds_grid_value_disk_exists

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: xm
parameters.description: The x position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: ym
parameters.description: The y position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: r
parameters.description: The radius of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to find.

ds_grid_value_disk_exists.description: With this function you can check to see if a specific value (real or string) is present within a circular area of a given DS grid. If it is present the function will return true otherwise it will return false.

place_meeting.name: place_meeting

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to check.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to check.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The instance or object to check for.

place_meeting.description: With this function you can check a position for a collision with another instance or all instances of an object using the collision mask of the instance that runs the code for the check. When you use this you are effectively asking GameMaker to move the instance to the new position, check for a collision, move back and tell you if a collision was found or not. This will work for precise collisions, but only if both the instance and the object being checked for have precise collision masks selected otherwise only bounding box collisions are applied. This function also accepts the special keywords all and other. Please note that should you need to get the unique instance id of the object being collided with, you should use instance_place().

skeleton_bone_data_get.name: skeleton_bone_data_get

parameters.name: bone
parameters.description: The name (as a string) of the bone.

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: The (previously created) DS map that stores the bone data.

skeleton_bone_data_get.description: Your skeletal animation is made up of a number of "bones", which you will have defined and given names to in your animation program. This function can be used to get information on the named bone at any time and store the data in an empty DS map, which you must have created previously. Note that this data refers to the default pose for the skeleton, and not the current pose that is being drawn. If you need the data from the current pose, use skeleton_bone_state_get().

skeleton_attachment_exists.name: skeleton_attachment_exists

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name (as a string) of the attachment to check.

skeleton_attachment_exists.description: This function checks if a custom attachment has been created using the skeleton_attachment_create() or skeleton_attachment_replace() functions.

gpu_get_texfilter.name: gpu_get_texfilter
gpu_get_texfilter.description: With this function you can check to see whether texture filtering (linear interpolation) is enabled (returns true) or not (returns false). For more information on texture filtering, see the function gpu_set_texfilter().

point_in_triangle.name: point_in_triangle

parameters.name: px
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the point to check.

parameters.name: py
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the point to check.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first corner of the triangle to check.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the first corner of the triangle to check.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the second corner of the triangle to check.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the second corner of the triangle to check.

parameters.name: x3
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the third corner of the triangle to check.

parameters.name: y3
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the third corner of the triangle to check.

point_in_triangle.description: When using this function, you define a triangular area and GameMaker will work out whether the given point falls within its bounds or not. If the point falls within the defined triangle the function will return true otherwise the function will return false.

ptr.name: ptr

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The value to convert.

ptr.description: This function will attempt to convert a given value into a pointer data type, where the value must be either a real, a string, an int64, an int32, or a ptr. Anything else will cause the game to crash with an error message.

layer_has_instance.name: layer_has_instance

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target (or the layer name as a string)

parameters.name: instance_id
parameters.description: The unique instance ID or the object index of the instance to check for

layer_has_instance.description: This function can be used to check if a given instance is currently assigned to the given layer. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the instance ID of the instance to check for. You can also give an object_index (ie: the name of the object in the Asset Browser) and the function will check if any instances of that object are on the given layer. The function will return true if the instance is on the layer and false if it is not.

skeleton_get_num_bounds.name: skeleton_get_num_bounds
skeleton_get_num_bounds.description: This function will return the number of bounding boxes associated with the skeleton animation sprite assigned to the instance running the code. This can then be used along with the function skeleton_get_bounds() to retrieve data about each of the bounding boxes.

audio_sound_is_playable.name: audio_sound_is_playable

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to check.

audio_sound_is_playable.description: This function can be used to checks if the given sound index can be played currently. This is needed due to the different ways streamed and unstreamed sound playback is handled on the HTML5 target platform, and will return true if the sound can be played and false if it can't. Note that on all other platforms other than HTML5, the function will always return true..

window_mouse_get_y.name: window_mouse_get_y
window_mouse_get_y.description: With this function you can get the y position of the mouse cursor (in pixels) within the browser if it is an HTML5 game or within the display if it is a Windows, Ubuntu (Linux) or macOS game.

view_get_hport.name: view_get_hport

parameters.name: view_port
parameters.description: The view port to target (0 - 7)

view_get_hport.description: This function can be used to retrieve the height of the given view port.

ds_grid_create.name: ds_grid_create

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the grid to be created.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height of the grid to be created.

ds_grid_create.description: With this function you can create a new DS grid data structure of the specified cell width and height. This function returns an id which must be used in all further functions that deal with this DS grid.

room_assign.name: room_assign

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the room to be copied to.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The index of the room to be copied from.

room_assign.description: This function will copy one room to another, removing all instances, tiles etc... from the room that is being copied to and replacing them completely with the new room contents. You supply the index to for the room to be copied to (either as defined in the asset browser or as returned by the function room_add()) as well as the index of the source room. Note that calling this function on a room asset created in the Asset Browser will permanently change the contents of the room, and even calling game_restart() will not return the room to it's original state (only ending the game and opening it again will start with the room in its original state again).

extension_get_option_count.name: extension_get_option_count

parameters.name: extension_name
parameters.description: The name of your extension asset as a string

extension_get_option_count.description:
This function returns the total number of options that exist in the extension with the given name.
			
			The function will return undefined if the provided extension name is invalid.

parameters.name: default
parameters.description: Subscriptions

ds_priority_find_priority.name: ds_priority_find_priority

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the priority queue to use.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to find the priority of.

ds_priority_find_priority.description: With this function you can retrieve the priority of any given value. If the value does not exist in the priority queue then undefined will be returned.

date_get_second.name: date_get_second

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to check.

date_get_second.description: This function returns the second of the given datetime value.

gpu_get_tex_mip_bias_ext.name: gpu_get_tex_mip_bias_ext

parameters.name: sampler_index
parameters.description: The index of the shader sampler to get

gpu_get_tex_mip_bias_ext.description: With this function you can retrieve the mipmap bias value for a given shader sampler. You supply the index value for the shader sampler (as returned by the function shader_get_sampler_index(), and the function will return a value of 0.0 for no bias, or a greater value where 1 equals the first mipmap, 2 equals the second mipmap etc... This controls the rate at which the mip map is swapped and will generally make the shader textures blurrier the higher the value and the greater the "distance" being viewed. Note that this can return negative values too, in which case shader textures will be sharper over a greater distance the lower the value.

array_map_ext.name: array_map_ext

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: function
parameters.description: The function to be executed for mapping the values. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return the mapped value.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_map_ext.description: With this function you can mutate an existing array by mapping the element values using the given predicate. This function returns the number of mapped elements. The mapped elements will keep their original position on the array. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.

buffer_peek.name: buffer_peek

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to use.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset position (in bytes) within the buffer to read the given data from.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of data that is to be read from the buffer (see the list of constants here).

buffer_peek.description: With the buffer_read() function, you can read data from the given buffer at the current "seek" position, with each piece of data being read advancing this position by the bytes being read or written. However, it may be necessary for you to read a given piece of data without wanting to change the current seek position, and that's when you would use this function. You simply supply the function with a buffer id, and then an offset position (from the buffer start) within that buffer to read from, as well as the data type that you are wanting to read.

sprite_prefetch_multi.name: sprite_prefetch_multi

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: Array with the sprite indices to fetch

sprite_prefetch_multi.description: This function can be used to prefetch (place into texture memory) a number of texture pages that contain the sprites given. You supply an array populated with the sprite indices (as defined when you created the sprite asset) and the texture pages that they are on will be loaded into memory. Note that the function will return -1 if prefetch is not supported for the chosen resource or the target platform is HTML5, or it will return 0 if all worked correctly.

draw_set_circle_precision.name: draw_set_circle_precision

parameters.name: precision
parameters.description: The precision of all circles drawn after this function is called.

draw_set_circle_precision.description: To optimise performance when drawing circles, GameMaker basically draws a polygon shape with enough sides to make it appear circular. However, depending on how big or small you need your circles to be, you may find that changing this value can help increase the performance of your game, or make the circles look better. The precision value that you can input into this function is the number of sides the circle polygon has, and this number can be anything between 4 and 64, but must be a number divisible by 4, with a default value of 24.

layer_sprite_get_index.name: layer_sprite_get_index

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to get the information from

layer_sprite_get_index.description: This function can be used to get the current image index value of the sprite element. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and the function will return real value that represents the image index being shown for the sprite. The function will return -1 if either the sprite element doesn't exist or the element doesn't have a valid sprite assigned to it.

camera_set_view_mat.name: camera_set_view_mat

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera.

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: The unique matrix ID returned when you created the matrix.

camera_set_view_mat.description: This function will set the view matrix for a given camera. You give the unique camera ID value (as returned by the different camera_create() functions) and a view matrix to be applied. You can find out more about creating view matrices from the section Matrix Functions, specifically matrix_build_lookat().

vertex_submit.name: vertex_submit

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to use.

parameters.name: primitive
parameters.description: The primitive base type.

parameters.name: texture
parameters.description: The texture to use (or -1 for no texture).

vertex_submit.description: You can use this function to submit the contents of a vertex buffer to the graphics pipeline for use with a shader. You supply the buffer index to use, the base primitive type to use (see the constants below) and the texture that is to be used. The base primitive type is only used for assigning the order in which the vertexes that you stored in the buffer are drawn and connected, but the actual data used for each of the vertexes will be that which you defined when creating the vertex buffer.

shader_set_uniform_matrix_array.name: shader_set_uniform_matrix_array

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: The handle of the shader constant to set.

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: A previously initialised array of floating point values.

shader_set_uniform_matrix_array.description: This function resets the draw target and should be called when you no longer wish to use the current shader (set using shader_set()).

file_bin_write_byte.name: file_bin_write_byte

parameters.name: binfile
parameters.description: The ID of the file to write to.

parameters.name: byte
parameters.description: The data to write.

file_bin_write_byte.description: This function will write a byte of data to the file identified by the file ID at the current write position. You supply the file ID value, as returned by the function file_bin_open() and the byte of data to write.

part_type_color_mix.name: part_type_color_mix

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: colour1
parameters.description: The first colour the blend will take from.

parameters.name: colour2
parameters.description: The second colour the blend will take from.

part_type_color_mix.description: With this function you can set the given particle type to be a random blend of two colours.

buffer_save_ext.name: buffer_save_ext

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to save.

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The name of the file to save as.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset within the buffer to save from (in bytes).

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the buffer area to save (in bytes).

buffer_save_ext.description: With this function you can save part of the contents of a buffer to a file, ready to be read back into memory using the buffer_load() function. The "offset" defines the start position within the buffer for saving (in bytes), and the "size" is the size of the buffer area to be saved from that offset onwards (also in bytes).

display_get_timing_method.name: display_get_timing_method
display_get_timing_method.description: This function can be used to retrieve the timing method to be used for rendering your game. The method can be one of the constants listed below.

mouse_check_button_released.name: mouse_check_button_released

parameters.name: numb
parameters.description: Which mouse button constant to check for.

mouse_check_button_released.description: This function will return true if the mouse button being checked has been released or false if it has not. This function will only be triggered once for any mouse button when it is released and to trigger it again the button will need to have been pressed and released again. You supply the mouse button to check from one of the following constants:

sha1_file.name: sha1_file

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The file to generate the sha1 hash for.

sha1_file.description: In cryptography, SHA-1 is a cryptographic hash function designed by the United States National Security Agency and is employed in several widely used applications popular Git where it is used to check for file changes, and the protocols TLS and SSL, PGP, SSH, S/MIME, and IPsec. This function will take an input file and return a 160 bit message digest in ASCII format unique to that file to be used for integrity verification at any later date.

sign.name: sign

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The number to get the sign of.

sign.description: This function returns whether a number is positive, negative or neither and returns 1, -1, 0 respectively. For example - sign(458) will return 1, sign(-5) will return -1 and sign(0) will return 0.

date_inc_hour.name: date_inc_hour

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to add to.

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: The number of hours (must be an integer) to add.

date_inc_hour.description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of hours, and it will return the new datetime value.

layer_depth.name: layer_depth

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to set the depth of (or the layer name as a string)

parameters.name: depth
parameters.description: The new depth for the layer

layer_depth.description: This function can be used to change the depth of the given layer, changing the order in which its contents will be rendered to the screen. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and then give the new depth to set it to (an integer value form -16000 to 16000). The layer depth is defined as being higher when "further away" from the camera and lower when "closer" to the camera, so if you have three layers with depths -100, 0, 100, the layers will draw in the order 100, 0, -100, so that the "top" layer (i.e., the closest to the camera view and so drawn over everything else) will be the layer with the -100 depth.

window_set_caption.name: window_set_caption

parameters.name: caption
parameters.description: The new caption.

window_set_caption.description: With this function you can change or set the windows caption for the room that you are currently in. This caption appears at the top of the window, beside the game icon, when the game is not in full screen mode.

date_compare_date.name: date_compare_date

parameters.name: date1
parameters.description: The first date.

parameters.name: date2
parameters.description: The date to compare it to.

date_compare_date.description: With this function you can check two dates to see which one is the earlier or later than the other. The function returns -1 if date1 is earlier, 0 if both dates are the same, and 1 if date1 is later.

physics_joint_rope_create.name: physics_joint_rope_create

parameters.name: inst1
parameters.description: The first instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: inst2
parameters.description: The second instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: w_anchor1_x
parameters.description: The first x coordinate for the joint, within the game world

parameters.name: w_anchor1_y
parameters.description: The first y coordinate for the joint, within the game world

parameters.name: w_anchor2_x
parameters.description: The second x coordinate for the joint, within the game world

parameters.name: w_anchor2_y
parameters.description: the second y coordinate for the joint, within the game world

parameters.name: maxlength
parameters.description: The maximum length that the joint can "stretch"

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

physics_joint_rope_create.description: A rope joint is one which is used to join two instances that you want to keep a constant distance apart, no matter what other forces are acting on it. With a distance joint, you can get "joint stretching" where the two fixtures will separate and behave strangely should too much stress be put on the joint, however the rope joint does not do this and will not stretch any further than the maximum defined length. When you create a rope joint the two instances should already be created and have a fixture assigned, then you define the two anchor points in room coordinates. The first anchor point is connected to instance 1, the second anchor point is connected to instance 2 and the distance and the maxlength argument sets the maximum length constraint on the joint. The image below shows how this works:

layer_element_move.name: layer_element_move

parameters.name: element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the element to move

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to move the element to (or the layer name as a string)

layer_element_move.description: You can use this function to move an element from one layer to another. You give the element ID, as returned by the function used to create the element or the room editor or the function layer_get_all_elements(), and then you give the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact).

variable_struct_get_names.name: variable_struct_get_names

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The struct reference to check.

variable_struct_get_names.description: With this function you can retrieve an array populated with the variable names from a struct. You pass in the struct reference to check, and each entry in the array will be a string of the variable names that the struct contains.

ds_priority_change_priority.name: ds_priority_change_priority

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the priority queue to change.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to change the priority of.

parameters.name: priority
parameters.description: The new priority of the value.

ds_priority_change_priority.description: This function will take a given value and change its priority within the referenced priority queue.

time_source_get_period.name: time_source_get_period

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

time_source_get_period.description: Returns the period of the time source, measured in its own units.

ds_stack_read.name: ds_stack_read

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to read into.

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to read from.

parameters.name: legacy (optional)
parameters.description: Can be either true or false or omitted completely.

ds_stack_read.description: With this function you can recreate a saved DS stack (one that has previously been written as a string using ds_stack_write()). You must first create a new DS stack to read the string into, and if the DS stack already exists and has information stored in it, then this will be cleared before reading. This function is of vital importance when creating save/load mechanisms for your game.

string_length.name: string_length

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to measure the number of characters of.

string_length.description: This function returns the number of characters comprising a given string. It can be useful for things like working out when to limit a custom text entry's character length (eg: capping a player's name to 10 characters). Remember that this is different to string_width() in that it measures the number of characters in the string, not its width as drawn on the screen in pixels.

draw_surface.name: draw_surface

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the surface to draw.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of where to draw the surface.

draw_surface.description: With this function you can draw a surface at a given position within the room, with the top left corner of the image being drawn at the specified x/y position.

gpu_get_tex_mip_enable.name: gpu_get_tex_mip_enable
gpu_get_tex_mip_enable.description: With this function you can get whether mipmapping is switched off, switched on for everything or switched on only for texture groups selected in the Texture Group Manager. The function will return one of the constants listed below, with the default setting being mip_markedonly.

colour_get_red.name: colour_get_red

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to check

colour_get_red.description: This function returns the amount of red used to make the given colour, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no red and 255 is all red. The following image illustrates this:

buffer_copy.name: buffer_copy

parameters.name: src_buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to copy from.

parameters.name: src_offset
parameters.description: The data offset to start copying from (in bytes).

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the data to copy (in bytes).

parameters.name: dest_buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to copy to.

parameters.name: dest_offset
parameters.description: The offset position to copy the data to (in bytes).

buffer_copy.description: This function can be used to copy a segment (or all) of the data stored in one buffer to another. When using two buffers and copying from one to the other, both buffers must have previously been created using the buffer_create() function (for example), and you can specify a data offset (in bytes) for the start point of the data to be copied from the source buffer relative to the start of the buffer, as well as another data offset to define the position to copy the data to in the destination buffer.

string_format.name: string_format

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The real number to be turned into a string.

parameters.name: tot
parameters.description: The total number of places of the main number to be shown. Zeroes or spaces will be inserted to match this.

parameters.name: dec
parameters.description: The number of decimal places to be included.

string_format.description: Turns a real number into a string using your own formatting, where you can choose how many "places" are saved to the string and how many decimal places are saved also. Both can be very handy, some games prefer to display a score as a set number of digits, while control over decimal places can be good for a high accuracy the two decimal places of string() cannot provide. If the number of places specified is greater than the value to be shown and/or the number plus the decimal places that have been specified is less than the total places, then spaces will be added before the value to make up the difference (see the example below). Zeros will be added to the right of the decimal point if the value given is less than the total and the number of decimal places to include. The default format is no extra spaces on the left, and only two decimal places on the right, eg "265.73".

audio_listener_get_data.name: audio_listener_get_data

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The listener to get the data for (default 0).

audio_listener_get_data.description: This function will create a DS map and populate it with the position, velocity and orientation values for the given listener. The default listener index is 0, but you can use the function audio_get_listener_info() to get the different indices available for the target platform. If you provide an incorrect listener index then the function will return -1.

min.name: min

parameters.description: The values to compare.

min.description: This function returns the minimum of the input values, of which it can have as many as you require (note that more arguments will mean that the function will be slower to parse). For example min(12, 96, 32, 75) will return 12 as that is the lowest of all the input values.

math_set_epsilon.name: math_set_epsilon

parameters.name: epsilon
parameters.description: The new epsilon value (from 0 to 0.999999999).

math_set_epsilon.description: Epsilon is a value used to determine whether two numbers subject to rounding error are close enough to be considered "equal". It is useful when dealing with floating point maths as it can reduce the "rounding errors" that make certain operations return values that appear incorrect or contrary to what we expect. For example, we may have added a value to the image index of a sprite and expect the result to be a single integer, but due to the nature of floating point maths, the actual final value ends up being something like 5.0000002, so when we have the following check:

path_add_point.name: path_add_point

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to add the point to.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the new point.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the new point.

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed factor of the point (default value is 100).

path_add_point.description: With this function you can add a point to the specified path and set its speed factor. This point is added onto the end of the path, irrespective of the position of the point, and the factor is equal to the percentage of path_speed that the following instance actually goes at when it reaches this point in the path. If you wish to place a path point at some other position that is not the end, you should use path_insert_point().

dbg_section_delete.name: dbg_section_delete

parameters.name: section
parameters.description: handle to the section

dbg_section_delete.description: Declare a new debug section this will be added to the current debug view that is active. NOTE: if no debug view is active then a "Default" view is created for you.

variable_global_set.name: variable_global_set

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the global variable to set (as a string)

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to set the global variable to

variable_global_set.description: With this function you can set the value of a given global variable. You supply the name of the global variable to set the value of as a string (see example code below), and then the value to set (can be any valid data type). If the global variable does not exist already in the game it will be created and then assigned the value.

string_ext.name: string_ext

parameters.name: format
parameters.description: The input string format.

parameters.name: val_array
parameters.description: An array of values to replace the placeholders.

string_ext.description: This function returns a new string using a format string with placeholder information and an array of values. The placeholders should follow the format "{x}" where x is the index of the value in the array that it should be replaced with.

audio_create_play_queue.name: audio_create_play_queue

parameters.name: queueformat
parameters.description: The format of the buffer data to use (buffer_u8 or buffer_s16).

parameters.name: queuerate
parameters.description: The sample rate of the data in the buffer queue.

parameters.name: queuechannels
parameters.description: The channels to use from one of the constants listed below.

audio_create_play_queue.description: This function prepares a buffer queue for audio. You pass data format (only buffer_u8 or buffer_s16 are currently supported), the sample rate (which can be between 1000hz and 48000hz), and the channels that the audio requires from one of the constants listed below:

layer_sequence_angle.name: layer_sequence_angle

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The new angle to rotate the sequence element to

layer_sequence_angle.description: With this function you can set the angle of rotation for the given sequence element. You supply the sequence element ID as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions along with the new angle to set and the sequence will be rotated about its origin to the new position. Angles in GameMaker are calculated with 0º to the right, and go anti-clockwise - so 90º is up, 180º is left and 270º is down - and the default angle for a sequence would be 0º.

sprite_collision_mask.name: sprite_collision_mask

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to set the bounding box of.

parameters.name: sepmasks
parameters.description: Whether to create collision masks for each sub-image of the sprite (true), or one mask for all (false).

parameters.name: bboxmode
parameters.description: What kind of bounding box to use. 0 = automatic, 1 = full image, 2 = user defined.

parameters.name: bbleft
parameters.description: The maximum left position of the bounding box.

parameters.name: bbtop
parameters.description: The maximum top position of the bounding box.

parameters.name: bbright
parameters.description: The maximum right position of the bounding box.

parameters.name: bbbottom
parameters.description: The maximum bottom position of the bounding box.

parameters.name: kind
parameters.description: The kind of mask, a constant (see the table in the description).

parameters.name: tolerance
parameters.description: Indicates the tolerance in the transparency value (0=no tolerance, 255=full tolerance).

sprite_collision_mask.description: With this function you can set the properties of the collision mask that a sprite should have. If you select either automatic (0) or full image (1) as the bounding box mode then the individual bounding box values can be set to 0. However for a user defined mask (2) you will have to set these values. The different bounding box values are always relative to the top left corner of the sprite (irrespective of the x and y origin) which is considered position (0, 0).

ds_list_delete.name: ds_list_delete

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the list to change.

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: Where in the list to delete the value.

ds_list_delete.description: With this function you can remove the value stored at a specific position within the list.

vertex_format_add_color.name: vertex_format_add_color
vertex_format_add_color.description: Tell GameMaker to accept colour data as part of the new vertex format being created.

vertex_color.name: vertex_color

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to write the information to.

parameters.name: color
parameters.description: The colour for this vertex (can be a constant or a hex value).

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha value for the vertex (from 0 to 1).

vertex_color.description: If your defined vertex format takes a colour value you can use this function to add that data to the vertex being defined for the current primitive. The function needs a buffer to store the data in and will take either a colour constant, or a hex value (using the standard GameMaker format of BGR, eg: $FF0000 for blue) as well as an alpha value from 0 (transparent) to 1 (fully opaque).

camera_set_view_speed.name: camera_set_view_speed

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera.

parameters.name: xspeed
parameters.description: The speed (number of pixels per game frame) that the view should move on the horizontal (x) axis

parameters.name: yspeed
parameters.description: The speed (number of pixels per game frame) that the view should move on the vertical (y) axis

camera_set_view_speed.description: You can use this function to update the speed of the view camera within the room. You give the unique camera ID value (as returned by the different camera_create() functions) and then give the x and y (horizontal and vertical) speed that it should move when set to follow a given instance. The speed is calculated as pixels per step and can be set to "-1" to make the camera move instantly, but if the camera is not set to follow any instance then the values set here will have no visible effect.

physics_get_density.name: physics_get_density

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the id of the bound fixture

physics_get_density.description: When you bind a fixture to an instance using physics_fixture_bind() this returns an "id" for the bound fixture. You can use this id to get the density value of the bound fixture (not the "base" fixture) at any time using this function.

layer_vspeed.name: layer_vspeed

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to set the vertical speed of

parameters.name: vspd
parameters.description: The vertical speed (in pixels per game frame) to set

layer_vspeed.description: You can use this function to set the vertical speed (in pixels per game frame) of the layer within the currently scoped room. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the speed value to set, where a positive value is downwards and a negative value upwards.

shader_set_uniform_matrix.name: shader_set_uniform_matrix

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: The handle of the shader constant to set.

shader_set_uniform_matrix.description: With this function you can set the value (or values) of a shader constant to the current transform matrix (as set using the Matrix Functions). You must previously have gotten the "handle" of the constant using the function shader_get_uniform().

buffer_async_group_option.name: buffer_async_group_option

parameters.name: option
parameters.description: The option to set.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value to set (can be string or real, depending on the option).

buffer_async_group_option.description: With this function you can set some platform specific options for the buffer group being saved. The options available are as follows:

dbg_text.name: dbg_text

parameters.name: dbgref
parameters.description: reference to the variable to change or a string to show

dbg_text.description: Creates a text entry (from a variable) within the current debug section, this text can be multiline and is not split into 2 columns but shown in a single column. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.

motion_add.name: motion_add

parameters.name: dir
parameters.description: The added direction.

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The added speed.

motion_add.description: This function will modify the current direction and speed of the instance running the code, combining the values given with the current values. If you wish to simply change these values, you should be using the function motion_set().

gamepad_button_value.name: gamepad_button_value

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

parameters.name: button
parameters.description: Which gamepad button constant to check for.

gamepad_button_value.description: With this function you can get the current value of an analogue button, from 0 to 1, where 0 is no pressure and 1 is full pressure. You supply the gamepad slot index to check, along with either a button constant (as listed here), or an integer value between 0 and gamepad_button_count() -1.

gc_get_target_frame_time.name: gc_get_target_frame_time
gc_get_target_frame_time.description: With this function you can retrieve the current target frame value for the garbage collector. The value returned is in microseconds (where 1,000,000 microseconds equals one second) and the default target frame time is 100 microseconds. If you wish to change this value then you should use the function gc_target_frame_time().

room_goto.name: room_goto

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the room to go to.

room_goto.description: This function permits you to go to any room in your game project, whether created using code or in the Asset Browser. You supply the room index (stored in the variable for the room name, or as a variable returned from the function room_add()). Note that the room will not change until the end of the event where the function was called, so any code after this has been called will still run if in the same event. This function will also trigger the Room End event.

layer_x.name: layer_x

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to set the x position of

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position in the room to set the layer to

layer_x.description: You can use this function to set the x position of the layer within the currently scoped room. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the function will move the layer the given number of pixels along the horizontal axis of the room.

date_current_datetime.name: date_current_datetime
date_current_datetime.description: Returns the date-time value of the current moment. The time returned is based on the default time zone for the system (ie: local time). You can change the base time zone to use with the function date_set_timezone()

array_create_ext.name: array_create_ext

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the array to create.

parameters.name: function
parameters.description: The function to be used for element initialisation. Accepts the following arguments (index) and should return the init value of the element.

array_create_ext.description: With this function you can create an array of a given size, initialising each element with the provided function.

layer_get_vspeed.name: layer_get_vspeed

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to get the vertical speed from

layer_get_vspeed.description: You can use this function to retrieve the vertical speed (in pixels per game frame) of the layer within the currently scoped room. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the function returns a real number for the vertical speed, where a positive value is down and a negative value up. Default is 0 (unless set in the room editor).

shader_get_uniform.name: shader_get_uniform

parameters.name: shader
parameters.description: The index of the shader to use.

parameters.name: uniform
parameters.description: The shader constant to get the handle of (a string).

shader_get_uniform.description: Since you cannot change the value of a shader constant within the shader itself, you have to set it before calling the shader using one of the available uniform set functions. However, to be able to do that you must first call this function to get the "handle" of the shader constant that you will want to change.

sin.name: sin

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The angle (in radians) to return the sine of.

sin.description: In a right angled triangle sin(val) = Opposite / Hypotenuse where val is one of the three angles.

skeleton_skin_set.name: skeleton_skin_set

parameters.name: skinname
parameters.description: The name (a string) of the skin to use (or a reference returned by the skeleton_skin_create() function).

skeleton_skin_set.description: A skeletal animation sprite can be drawn with a variety of textures (called "skins"), permitting you to use one single animation for multiple different purposes. For example, you may have a generic walk animation and this can be used by your NPC characters, enemies, etc... in a game simply by changing the skin it is drawn with. These skins need to have been previously created and named in your animation program, and this name is passed into the function (as a string) to set the sprite to use that skin when being drawn.

part_type_blend.name: part_type_blend

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: additive
parameters.description: Whether the particles should be blended additively (true) or normally (false).

part_type_blend.description: With this function you can make your particles be drawn with an additive blend mode (true) or not (false). Additive blending is a special blend mode that adds the luminosity values of each particle as they overlap, so that light colours will gradually get brighter (until they appear white) as they overlap, and dark colours become more and more transparent with black being almost invisible. This function can give some beautiful particle effects but may not always be necessary. For example, a smoke trail would have additive blending off to keep the effect gray, but a flame effect would probably have it on to make the particles more translucent and brighter.

skeleton_slot_color_set.name: skeleton_slot_color_set

parameters.name: slot
parameters.description: The slot name to set, a string

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour to set, either an integer, a constant, or a hex value.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha to set from 0 to 1.

skeleton_slot_color_set.description: With this function you can set an attachment slot colour and alpha so all sprites attached to it will be drawn with these blend values. Keep in mind that the instance sprite can have a blend colour and alpha setting (image_blend and image_alpha), as can the attachment (see the function skeleton_attachment_create_colour()), and so the final colour and alpha that the assigned attachment sprite for the slot will have will be a composite of all these values.

audio_group_load_progress.name: audio_group_load_progress

parameters.name: groupid
parameters.description: The index of the audio group to check (as defined in the Audio Groups Window)

audio_group_load_progress.description: This function will check the loading progress for an audio group and return an (approximate) value between 0 and 100.

layer_force_draw_depth.name: layer_force_draw_depth

parameters.name: force
parameters.description: Whether to enable (set to true or disable (set to false) Z depth forcing

parameters.name: depth
parameters.description: The new Z depth

layer_force_draw_depth.description: This function forces all layers to be drawn at the specified z depth. This does not change the order the layers are rendered in and they'll still be drawn in depth order, it simply changes what z value is used. In general you do not need to worry about this, but if you have layers that have a depth outside of the legal range (-16000 to 16000) then they won't be rendered, so you can force the Z depth to a reasonable value - 0 for example - and they will all be rendered fine. Note that this is generally only for use with legacy projects from previous version of GameMaker where you could have draw depths higher or lower than the permitted layer range.

fx_get_single_layer.name: fx_get_single_layer

parameters.name: filter_or_effect
parameters.description: The FX struct to get the parameter from

fx_get_single_layer.description: Returns if the filter or effect is forced on a single layer.

physics_fixture_bind_ext.name: physics_fixture_bind_ext

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the fixture that is to be bound

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: the target instance that is to receive the fixture (can be an instance id, an object id, other, or all)

parameters.name: xoffset
parameters.description: the offset along the x-axis

parameters.name: yoffset
parameters.description: the offset along the y-axis
