physics_fixture_bind_ext.description: Once we have defined our fixture it has to be bound to an instance. This means that its properties are transferred to the selected instance, not the actual fixture itself, so that one fixture can be bound to multiple instances if all are to have the same properties. You can specify an object index for the target and all instances present in the room at the time will receive that fixtures properties (but not any new instances of the object created later), or you can use the special keywords other and all. You can even specify a parent object and all children instances with that parent will also receive the fixture. Once the fixture has been bound to all the instances that you need, it can be deleted if no longer necessary and the instances with that fixtures properties will not be affected and maintain those properties.

gpu_set_tex_mip_enable.name: gpu_set_tex_mip_enable

parameters.name: setting
parameters.description: The mipmap setting (a constant, default: mip_markedonly)

gpu_set_tex_mip_enable.description: With this function you can change whether mipmapping is switched off, switched on for everything, or switched on only for texture groups selected in the Texture Group Manager. The function requires one of the constants listed below.

particle_exists.name: particle_exists

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system asset to check for.

particle_exists.description: With this function you can check to see if a particle system asset with the given index exists or not.

extension_exists.name: extension_exists

parameters.name: extension_name
parameters.description: The name of your extension asset as a string

extension_exists.description: This function tells whether an extension with the given name exists (true) or not (false).

layer_sequence_headdir.name: layer_sequence_headdir

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

parameters.name: direction
parameters.description: The playhead direction, a constant, listed above

layer_sequence_headdir.description: With this function you can set the direction for the given sequence playhead. You supply the sequence element ID as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions, and then give the playhead direction which should be one of the following constants:

physics_particle_set_flags.name: physics_particle_set_flags

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the particle.

parameters.name: flags
parameters.description: The flags to set on the particle.

physics_particle_set_flags.description: With this function you can change the particle flags for an individual particle. The index value is the particle ID as returned by the function physics_particle_create(), while the flags are the return value of a combination of the following constants:

keyboard_key_release.name: keyboard_key_release

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to simulate a release of.

keyboard_key_release.description: With this function you can simulate the release of any key on the keyboard. The function will take a keycode value as returned by the function ord() (only capital letters from A-Z or numbers from 0-9), or any of the vk_* constants listed on the main Keyboard Input page.

window_set_colour.name: window_set_colour

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour to set the region.

window_set_colour.description: This function can set the background colour of the game window. This colour represents that which will be used for those areas of the game window that are not occupied by any views. The following image illustrates this:

date_create_datetime.name: date_create_datetime

parameters.name: year
parameters.description: The year to set.

parameters.name: month
parameters.description: The month to set.

parameters.name: day
parameters.description: The day to set.

parameters.name: hour
parameters.description: The hour to set.

parameters.name: minute
parameters.description: The minute to set.

parameters.name: second
parameters.description: The second to set.

date_create_datetime.description: This function will create a datetime value from the component given as the arguments.

font_get_sdf_enabled.name: font_get_sdf_enabled

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the font.

font_get_sdf_enabled.description: With this function you can determine whether SDF rendering is enabled or disabled for the specified font

buffer_create.name: buffer_create

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size (in bytes) of the buffer.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of buffer to create (see the constants list above).

parameters.name: alignment
parameters.description: The byte alignment for the buffer

buffer_create.description: You use this function to allocate a portion of memory as a buffer in your game, with the function returning the unique buffer id that should be stored in a variable and used for all further function calls to the buffer. The buffer can then be used to store different types of data (specified when you write to the buffer using the buffer_write() function, with the following constants being used to define the buffer type:

audio_emitter_get_listener_mask.name: audio_emitter_get_listener_mask

parameters.name: emitterid
parameters.description: The unique ID of the emitter to get the mask of

audio_emitter_get_listener_mask.description: This function will return the bit-mask data that defines which audio listeners an emitter should play sounds from. For more information see the section on Audio Listeners.

camera_get_view_speed_x.name: camera_get_view_speed_x

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_view_speed_x.description: This function can be used to retrieve the movement speed of the given camera along the x axis (horizontal movement). The return value will be in pixels per game frame.

camera_get_view_y.name: camera_get_view_y

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_view_y.description: This function can be used to retrieve the y position of the view for a given camera. Note that this function is only valid for cameras created using camera_create_view() or for those added in the room editor.

window_handle.name: window_handle
window_handle.description: With this function you can get the internal Windows id value (the HWND, a pointer). This function is really only useful for extension writers who need the window handle to call Windows API's in DLL code (the returned pointer should be cast into a string and then in the C++ just cast it to an HWND). The table below shows the platforms supported along with what they return:

gpu_get_blendmode_dest.name: gpu_get_blendmode_dest
gpu_get_blendmode_dest.description: This function can be used to retrieve the current destination extended blend mode factor being used for drawing. The value returned will be one of the following constants ("s" denotes a value taken from the source while a "d" denotes a value from the destination):

arcsin.name: arcsin

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The value to return the inverse sine of.

arcsin.description: Returns the inverse sine of x, in that if sin(x)=n, arcsin(n)=x, and the resulting number will be between -pi/2 and pi/2.

achievement_logout.name: achievement_logout
achievement_logout.description: This function logs the user out of the chosen leaderboard and achievement service. This will stop all further achievements and scores from being recorded.

shader_reset.name: shader_reset
shader_reset.description: This function resets the shader used for drawing and should be called when you no longer wish to use the current shader (set using shader_set()).

physics_particle_get_data_particle.name: physics_particle_get_data_particle

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index (ID) of the particle to get the data from.

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The (previously created) buffer to use to store the data.

parameters.name: flags
parameters.description: The flags to use to extract data about specific particle types.

physics_particle_get_data_particle.description: This function returns various pieces of information about a single particle in the physics simulation using the given flags checked. The particle index (its ID) is that which was returned by the function physics_particle_create(), and the buffer used must have been created previously using the function buffer_create(). It should be of the "grow" type, with the size being approximately that of the expected return data. The flags themselves are set using the constants given below, and you would use the bitwise or "|" to create a single flag value to get the desired information.

network_connect_async.name: network_connect_async

parameters.name: socket
parameters.description: The id of the socket to use.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The URL or IP to connect to (a string).

parameters.name: port
parameters.description: The port to connect to.

network_connect_async.description: With this function you can send a request to connect to a server. The function takes the socket id to connect through (see network_create_socket()) and requires you to give the IP address to connect to (a string) as well as the port to connect through, and if the connection fails a value of less than 0 will be returned. The connection uses a special protocol that ensures only GameMaker games connect to each other, however if you need to connect to a server that is not a GameMaker game, you can use network_connect_async_raw(). Note that this function is asynchronous, generating an Asynchronous Networking event of the type network_type_non_blocking_connect.

texturegroup_unload.name: texturegroup_unload

parameters.name: groupname
parameters.description: The name of the texture group to unload (a string)

texturegroup_unload.description: With this function you can unload all pages in the specified texture group. You supply the texture group ID string (as defined in the texture Group Editor) for the group to unload.

ds_grid_get_mean.name: ds_grid_get_mean

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The left cell column of the region.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The top cell row of the region.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The right cell column of the region.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The bottom cell row of the region.

ds_grid_get_mean.description: This function can be used to find the mean value for all the cells found within the defined region of a grid (all cell values are added together and then divided by the total number of cells that make the region), as shown in the image below:

string_height.name: string_height

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to measure the height of.

string_height.description: This function will return the height (in pixels) of the input string, taking into account the line separation and any line-breaks the text may have. It is very handy for calculating distances between text elements based on the tallest of the letters that make up the string as it would be drawn with draw_text() using the currently defined font.

collision_circle.name: collision_circle

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle to check.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the center of the circle to check.

parameters.name: rad
parameters.description: The radius (distance in pixels from its center to its edge).

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for instance collisions.

parameters.name: prec
parameters.description: Whether the check is based on pixel-perfect collisions (true = slow) or its bounding box in general (false = fast).

parameters.name: notme
parameters.description: Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).

collision_circle.description: Collision_circle creates a circular zone of the radius given by the user around the points x1,y1 and then checks that zone for a collision with any instance of the object specified by the argument "obj". This check can be either precise or not, but for precise collisions to be enabled, the object or instance that you are checking for must also have precise collisions enabled for their sprite. If not, the default check is based on bounding boxes. The following image illustrates how this works:

file_find_first.name: file_find_first

parameters.name: mask
parameters.description: The mask to use for searching.

parameters.name: attr
parameters.description: The specific file attribute to look for.

file_find_first.description: This function will return the name of the first file that satisfies the mask and the attributes. If no such file exists, then an empty string is returned. The mask can contain a path and can contain wildchars, for example 'C:\temp\*.doc'. The attributes give the additional files you want to see, so the normal files are always returned when they satisfy the mask. You can add up the following constants to see the type of files you want (if you do not wish to add any attributes, use 0):

effect_create_layer.name: effect_create_layer

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The layer ID (or name) to assign the created effect to.

parameters.name: kind
parameters.description: The kind of effect (use one of the constants listed above).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x positioning of the effect if relevant.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y positioning of the effect if relevant.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the effect.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour of the effect.

effect_create_layer.description: With this function you can create a simple effect on a specified layer. If the effect is anything other ef_rain or ef_snow then you can define an x/y position to create the effect, and the size can be a value of 0, 1, or 2, where 0 is small, 1 is medium and 2 is large.

buffer_copy_from_vertex_buffer.name: buffer_copy_from_vertex_buffer

parameters.name: vertex_buffer
parameters.description: The index of the vertex buffer to copy from.

parameters.name: start_vertex
parameters.description: The starting vertex.

parameters.name: num_vertices
parameters.description: The total number of vertices to use.

parameters.name: dest_buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to copy to.

parameters.name: dest_offset
parameters.description: The offset position to copy the data to (in bytes).

buffer_copy_from_vertex_buffer.description: This function can be used to copy some (or all) of the vertex data stored in one vertex buffer into a previously created regular buffer. When copying from a vertex buffer into a regular buffer with this function, both buffers must have previously been created (using the vertex_create_buffer() and buffer_create() functions, for example). You can specify the range of vertex data that you wish to copy into the buffer, where the start vertex can be anywhere between 0 and the number of vertices -1, and you can give the number of vertices from that point on to copy. You can use the function vertex_get_number() on the vertex buffer to get the total number of vertices stored. Finally you give the buffer index to copy the vertex data into, as well as a data offset to define the position to copy the vertex data to in the destination buffer.

variable_instance_set.name: variable_instance_set

parameters.name: instance_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the instance to use

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the variable to set (as a string)

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to set the variable to

variable_instance_set.description: With this function you can set the value of a given variable in an instance. You supply the unique instance ID value (which can be found from the Instance Properties in the room editor, or is returned when you call the function instance_create_layer()) as well as the name of the variable to set the value of as a string (see example code below), and then finally the value to set (can be any valid data type). If the variable does not exist already in the instance it will be created and then assigned the value.

file_find_next.name: file_find_next
file_find_next.description: This function returns the name of the next file that satisfies the previously given mask and the attributes (defined by file_find_first()). If no such file exists, the empty string is returned.

ds_grid_write.name: ds_grid_write

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid to write.

ds_grid_write.description: This function can be used to convert the given ds_grid into a string, which can then be stored in an external file (for example). You can read the returned string from this function back into a ds_grid using the function ds_grid_read().

audio_emitter_pitch.name: audio_emitter_pitch

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to change.

parameters.name: pitch
parameters.description: The pitch multiplier (default 1).

audio_emitter_pitch.description: This function can be used to change the pitch of all sounds emitted from the given emitter. It is a pitch multiplier, in that the input value multiplies the current pitch by that amount, so the default value of 1 is no pitch change, while a value of less than 1 will lower the pitch and greater than 1 will raise the pitch. It is best to use small increments for this function as any value under 0 or over 5 may not be audible anyway.

file_delete.name: file_delete

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The name of the file to delete.

file_delete.description: This function will delete the specified file from the system. It should be noted that this function will only delete those files that GameMaker is able to create and parse: ini files, text files and binary files, or those files made to store game created resources like sprites or surfaces. However, it will not delete any other file. The function will also return true if the file has successfully been removed, or false in any other circumstances.

ds_priority_copy.name: ds_priority_copy

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the priority queue to copy to.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The id of the priority queue to copy from.

ds_priority_copy.description: This function can be used to copy the contents of one priority queue into another. Note that this does NOT remove the contents from the original priority queue, nor does it destroy the original priority queue. When using this function the priority queue being copied to must have been previously created and if it contained any items before the copy, then these will be cleared first (meaning this information will be lost).

gamepad_get_axis_deadzone.name: gamepad_get_axis_deadzone

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

gamepad_get_axis_deadzone.description: This function can be used to get the "dead zone" value of the joystick axis. You specify the device slot to get, and the function will return a value between 0 to 1, where value reflects the threshold under which the joystick axis is considered to be at 0.

tilemap_get_cell_x_at_pixel.name: tilemap_get_cell_x_at_pixel

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to get the cell x position of

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position within the room to use for getting the cell

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position within the room to use for getting the cell

tilemap_get_cell_x_at_pixel.description: Using this function you can retrieve the x-axis position of an individual tile map cell by giving the relative x-axis position within the room. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), as well as the x and y position within the room and the function will return the x position of the cell within the tile map for that point. Note that if the value is outside of the tile map area, and no cell is available, it will return -1.

animcurve_create.name: animcurve_create
animcurve_create.description: This function creates an empty animation curve struct, ready for you to populate with channel data.

sprite_set_offset.name: sprite_set_offset

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to change the offset of.

parameters.name: xoff
parameters.description: The x position of the origin.

parameters.name: yoff
parameters.description: The y position of the origin.

sprite_set_offset.description: This function can be used to set the x and y origin of a sprite, and takes relative values based on the (0,0) position being the upper left corner of the sprite. The following image illustrates this:

draw_text_colour.name: draw_text_colour

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to draw.

parameters.name: c1
parameters.description: The colour for the top left of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c2
parameters.description: The colour for the top right of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c3
parameters.description: The colour for the bottom right of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c4
parameters.description: The colour for the bottom left of the drawn text.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha for the text.

draw_text_colour.description: This function will draw text in a similar way to draw_text() only now you can choose the colours to use for colouring the text as well as the alpha value, and these new values will be used instead of the base drawing colour and alpha.

filename_path.name: filename_path

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The file name and path to use.

filename_path.description: Using this function returns the path part of the indicated file path, including the final backslash.

sequence_get.name: sequence_get

parameters.name: sequence_index
parameters.description: The sequence index as defined in the asset browser.

sequence_get.description: With this function you can retrieve the sequence object struct from a sequence asset index. You supply the asset index for the sequence as defined in the asset browser, and the function will return the sequence object struct that can then be accessed, or -1 if the sequence doesn't exist or the asset index given is not a sequence.

is_int32.name: is_int32

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The argument to check.

is_int32.description: This function returns whether a given variable is a 32bit integer or not. In some cases you want to check and see what data type a variable holds in GameMaker and that's when you would use this function. It returns true or false depending on whether the value is an int 32 or not.

variable_struct_names_count.name: variable_struct_names_count

parameters.name: struct_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the struct to check.

variable_struct_names_count.description: With this function you can find the total number number of variables defined for a struct. You supply the struct ID to check, and the function will return an integer value for the number of variables encountered, or (if no struct of the given ID exists) -1.

room_exists.name: room_exists

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the room to check.

room_exists.description: With this function you can check and see whether the room you specify exists or not. This function takes the room index (a real number) and not the room name (a string). This function is most useful when you are creating rooms dynamically using the function room_add(), but you can also use the read only variables room_first and room_last or the functions room_next() and room_previous() to get a specific room index, or provide a variable that has stored the index of any other room in your game.

network_set_config.name: network_set_config

parameters.name: config_value
parameters.description: The config constant to set (refer to the table at the top of this page).

parameters.name: setting
parameters.description: The setting of the config value.

network_set_config.description: With this function you can set different network configurations.

ds_grid_value_x.name: ds_grid_value_x

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x position of the left of the region in the grid, from 0 to (grid width - 1).

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y position of the top of the region in the grid, from 0 to (grid height - 1).

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x position of the right of the region in the grid, from 0 to (grid width - 1).

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y position of the bottom of the region in the grid, from 0 to (grid height - 1).

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to find.

ds_grid_value_x.description: With this function you can get the x coordinate (within the given rectangular grid region) of the value being searched for. You give the DS grid index (as returned by ds_grid_create()) along with the x/y positions for the top left and bottom right corners of the grid region to search, before supplying the value to search for. If the value being searched for does not exist, then the function will return -1.

audio_emitter_get_vy.name: audio_emitter_get_vy

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to use.

audio_emitter_get_vy.description: This function returns the current velocity along the y axis for the given audio emitter.

buffer_md5.name: buffer_md5

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to use.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The data offset value.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the buffer.

buffer_md5.description: In cryptography, MD5 (Message-Digest algorithm 5) is a widely used cryptographic hashing function with a 128-bit hash value and has been employed in a wide variety of security applications. It is also commonly used to check the integrity of data. This function will take the input data from a given buffer (or part of the buffer) and return the 32-character hexadecimal MD5 hash that is unique to that data. In this way you can generate a secure key which can be stored and used to check the integrity of the information being sent to (or received from) an external server (for example). When applying this to buffers using this function you must specify the buffer id of the buffer to use, then an offset value (in bytes) for where to begin, and then a size (again in bytes) for the region to be hashed.

ds_grid_value_exists.name: ds_grid_value_exists

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x position of the left of the region in the grid.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y position of the top of the region in the grid.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x position of the right of the region in the grid.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y position of the bottom of the region in the grid.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to find.

ds_grid_value_exists.description: With this function you can check to see if a specific value (real or string) is present within a rectangular area of a given DS grid. If it is present the function will return true otherwise it will return false.

audio_resume_all.name: audio_resume_all
audio_resume_all.description: With this function you can resume all sounds that have been paused previously.

achievement_login_status.name: achievement_login_status
achievement_login_status.description: This function is currently only useful for Google Play on the Android platform. It will check to see if the user is already logged into Google services, in which case it will return true, or not, returning false. If it returns true there is no need to call the achievement_login() function.

tile_get_empty.name: tile_get_empty

parameters.name: tiledata
parameters.description: the tile-data to check

tile_get_empty.description: This function can be used to check whether a given set of tile-data is for an empty tile or not. You give the tile-data, which can be retrieved using the function tilemap_get(), and the function will return true if the tile is empty, or false if there is a tile index.

skeleton_bone_state_get.name: skeleton_bone_state_get

parameters.name: bone
parameters.description: The name (as a string) of the bone.

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: The (previously created) DS map that stores the bone data.

skeleton_bone_state_get.description: Your skeletal animation is made up of a number of "bones", which you will have defined and given names to in your animation program, and this function can be used to get certain data for the named bone at any time. Note that this data refers to the current pose for the skeleton, depending on the animation set used, and the function requires a previously created DS map, which will then have the following keys and their equivalent values after calling the function:

part_type_subimage.name: part_type_subimage

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The sub-image (frame) of the sprite to use.

part_type_subimage.description: This function can be used to set a particle type to use a custom sub-image (frame) of a sprite. If the particle's sprite is animated, then this sub-image will be used as the starting frame of the animation.

layer_get_all.name: layer_get_all
layer_get_all.description: This function will return an array populated with the unique ID values of each layer in the room.

layer_y.name: layer_y

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to set the y position of

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position in the room to set the layer to

layer_y.description: You can use this function to set the y position of the layer within the currently scoped room. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the function will move the layer the given number of pixels along the vertical axis of the room.

part_type_alpha2.name: part_type_alpha2

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: alpha1
parameters.description: The start alpha of the particle.

parameters.name: alpha2
parameters.description: The end alpha of the particle.

part_type_alpha2.description: This function can be used to set an alpha value (transparency) gradient for each particle created of the given type. The first alpha is that which all particles will start with, and the second alpha is the one on with which the particle will end with, and a smooth gradient change will occur to the alpha over the particles lifetime from one to the other. This can be from 0 (transparent) to 1 (opaque).

timeline_moment_add_script.name: timeline_moment_add_script

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the time line to add a moment to.

parameters.name: step
parameters.description: The moment (step) to add to.

parameters.name: script
parameters.description: The index of the script function to add into the moment.

timeline_moment_add_script.description: With this function you can dynamically add a script function to Timelines at any given "moment" within that time line, where a "moment" is the equivalent of one game tick (or step). In this way you can create a new time line using the timeline_add() function and add different behaviours at any point, or simply modify a previously created time line resource with new behaviours. Note that the function cannot require any additional arguments when using this function, and if you use it to modify a Timeline asset present in the Asset Browser, then all instances that use this timeline will be affected, and the change will last until the end of the game (calling game_restart() will not reset the change either).

fx_set_single_layer.name: fx_set_single_layer

parameters.name: filter_or_effect
parameters.description: The FX struct to modify

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Flag for if the filter or effect should be forced on a single layer.

fx_set_single_layer.description: This function is used to force a filter or effect onto a single layer.

colour_get_value.name: colour_get_value

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to check

colour_get_value.description: This function will return the value (luminosity) of the given colour. This is the amount of the "light" that is mixed into the final colour and is part of the hue, saturation and value method for defining a colour. The following image illustrates how this value corresponds to the HSV scale of colour:

rectangle_in_rectangle.name: rectangle_in_rectangle

parameters.name: sx1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the source rectangle.

parameters.name: sy1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top side of the source rectangle.

parameters.name: sx2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right side of the source rectangle.

parameters.name: sy2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom side of the source rectangle.

parameters.name: dx1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the destination rectangle to check against.

parameters.name: dy1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top side of the destination rectangle to check against.

parameters.name: dx2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right side of the destination rectangle to check against.

parameters.name: dy2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom side of the destination rectangle to check against.

rectangle_in_rectangle.description: This function will check two rectangular areas that you define to see if the source rectangle is either not in collision, completely within the destination rectangles bounds, or if they are simply touching. If they are not touching at all the function will return 0, if the source is completely within the destination it will return 1, and if they are simply overlapping then it will return 2. The image below illustrates this:

audio_pause_sync_group.name: audio_pause_sync_group

parameters.name: group_index
parameters.description: The group index to pause.

audio_pause_sync_group.description: his function will pause the given sync group if it is playing, with the group index being the value returned when you created the group using the function audio_create_sync_group(). This does not stop the sound, and calling audio_resume_sync_group(), will start it playing from the same position it was paused at again.

texturegroup_get_fonts.name: texturegroup_get_fonts

parameters.name: tex
parameters.description: The name of the texture group to check (a string)

texturegroup_get_fonts.description: With this function you can retrieve the font index of each of the fonts assigned to texture pages within the given texture group. You supply the texture group ID string (as defined in the texture Group Editor) and the function will return a 1D array where each entry contains the font index for a font resource. If the function fails - ie: an invalid group is given, or the group has no texture assigned to it - then the array will be empty (0 length).

gpu_get_blendenable.name: gpu_get_blendenable
gpu_get_blendenable.description: This function can be used to retrieve the alpha-blending state. If it returns true then alpha-blending is enabled, and if it returns false it is disabled. By default this is on and so the function will return true

animcurve_get_channel.name: animcurve_get_channel

parameters.name: curve_struct_or_id
parameters.description: The ID or struct pointer of the animation curve to target

parameters.name: channel_name_or_index
parameters.description: The channel name (a string) or the channel index (an integer).

animcurve_get_channel.description: This function returns the struct containing the channel data for the channel specified in an animation curve asset or struct (as returned by animcurve_get()).

string_ends_with.name: string_ends_with

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The input string.

parameters.name: substr
parameters.description: The string to check against.

string_ends_with.description: This function determines whether a string ends with the characters of a specified string, returning true or false as appropriate.

file_bin_open.name: file_bin_open

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The name of the file to read from.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: the indicator of what can be done with the file.

file_bin_open.description: This function will open the binary file with the indicated name. The mode indicates what can be done with the file:

skeleton_slot_color_get.name: skeleton_slot_color_get

parameters.name: slot
parameters.description: The slot name to check, a string

skeleton_slot_color_get.description: With this function you can get an attachment slot colour. You supply the slot name (a string) and the function will return an integer value for the colour.

array_get.name: array_get

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the array to get the value from.

array_get.description: With this function you can retrieve the value from an index in an array. The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array and the index to get the value from within that array. Note that if the array index given is out of bounds then the game will crash with an error. This function can also be used for multi-dimension arrays, as long as you specify which dimension you want to get when you supply the array index, following this pattern:

ds_priority_size.name: ds_priority_size

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to check.

ds_priority_size.description: This function will return the "size" of the priority queue, ie: the number of items that have been prioritized in it.

string_concat_ext.name: string_concat_ext

parameters.name: values_array
parameters.description: An array of values be concatenated.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset of the range (allows negative values, from end of string).

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: The number of elements to concatenate (allows negative values, reverse traversing).

string_concat_ext.description: This function concatenates a range of elements in an array, non-string values will be converted to string.

camera_set_default.name: camera_set_default

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_set_default.description: This function can be used to set the default camera to use a custom camera that you have previously created using one of the camera_create() functions. When you create a room with no active view ports or view cameras, GameMaker still uses a camera to show the action in the game. This camera is called the default camera and can be set and manipulated (and even destroyed) just like any other camera.

tilemap_set_width.name: tilemap_set_width

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to set the width of

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width value (in "cells")

tilemap_set_width.description: This function can be used to resize a tile map element. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and the new width of the tile map in tile cells.

sequence_get_objects.name: sequence_get_objects

parameters.name: sequence_struct_or_id
parameters.description: The sequence object struct or ID to get the objects from.

sequence_get_objects.description: With this function you can retrieve an array of all the object indices that have instances being created within the given sequence. You supply either the sequence object struct (as returned by the function sequence_create() or sequence_get()) or the sequence ID (as returned by the function layer_sequence_get_sequence() or from the sequence instance struct property sequence) and the function will return an array, where each item in the array is an object_index for the different objects being used by the sequence to create instances.

ds_list_is_list.name: ds_list_is_list

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the list to check.

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: The position within the list to check.

ds_list_is_list.description: With this function you can check to see if another DS list is stored at the given position within a DS list. If the given position contains a DS list ID, then the function will return true otherwise it will return false.

gesture_get_rotate_time.name: gesture_get_rotate_time
gesture_get_rotate_time.description: This function is used to get the angle which a pair of touches must exceed in order to trigger a Rotate Start Gesture. The angle is measured in degrees and has a default value of 5°.

physics_particle_group_get_centre_y.name: physics_particle_group_get_centre_y

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The particle group to get.

physics_particle_group_get_centre_y.description: With this function you can retrieve the y component of the center of mass of an entire group of particles. The group value is that which was returned when you created the group of particles using the function physics_particle_group_end(), and the function will return a value which is the combined value of the currently set flags.

layer_background_blend.name: layer_background_blend

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to change

parameters.name: blend
parameters.description: The colour to blend with the background sprite (default is c_white)

layer_background_blend.description: This function controls the blending (or "tinting") of the background sprite and the default value is -1 (which represents the constant c_white, which can also be used). Any other value (including internal colour constants like c_red, or c_aqua) will blend the specified colour with the original sprite. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and then set the blending colour to use. Below you can see an example of a sprite that has been blended with different colours:

show_error.name: show_error

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to show in the pop-up message.

parameters.name: abort
parameters.description: Whether to abort (true) or not (false).

show_error.description: This function will show a custom string as an error message. You can also specify whether the game should be aborted after the error, however please note that this only exists for compatibility reasons and showing errors will require the game to be aborted regardless of the value specified in this argument.

ds_queue_destroy.name: ds_queue_destroy

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to remove.

ds_queue_destroy.description: This function will remove the given queue data-structure from memory, freeing up the resources it was using and removing all values that it contained. This function should always be used when you are finished using the DS queue to prevent memory leaks that can slow down and crash your game.

virtual_key_delete.name: virtual_key_delete

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the virtual key to delete.

virtual_key_delete.description: If your game has different rooms or instances to control menus and game-play and other things, then it is probable that you will need to change the position and key maps of your virtual keys at some point. For that you can use this function to delete the old ones before creating the new ones (if necessary). The function requires that you supply the ID of the virtual key to delete - as returned by virtual_key_add().

environment_get_variable.name: environment_get_variable

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name (a string) of the environment variable to check.

environment_get_variable.description: This function returns the value (a string) of the environment variable with the given name (also a string). You can get the available environment variables on macOS and Ubuntu (Linux) by typing "env" into the terminal app, and for information on Windows environment variables, if you are using the command prompt then type "echo %PATH%", and using PowerShell it's "ls env". Note that on both macOS and Ubuntu (Linux) the "HOME" environment variable will return the "~/" path which maps to "/Users/<username>" on macOS and "/home/<username>" on Ubuntu (Linux).

physics_particle_get_density.name: physics_particle_get_density
physics_particle_get_density.description: With this function you can find out what the current density is for particles in the physics simulation (you can set this value using physics_particle_set_density()).

draw_text_transformed_color.name: draw_text_transformed_color

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to draw.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scale.

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scale.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle of the text.

parameters.name: c1
parameters.description: The colour for the top left of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c2
parameters.description: The colour for the top right of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c3
parameters.description: The colour for the bottom right of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c4
parameters.description: The colour for the bottom left of the drawn text.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha for the text.

draw_text_transformed_color.description: This function is a combination of the base draw_text() function with the draw_text_transformed() and draw_text_colour() functions, permitting you to scale and rotate text as well as colour it with a gradient fill and change its alpha value, ignoring the base alpha and colour settings for drawing.

vertex_update_buffer_from_vertex.name: vertex_update_buffer_from_vertex

parameters.name: dest_vbuff
parameters.description: The destination vertex buffer to copy to.

parameters.name: dest_vert
parameters.description: The index of the first vertex within the destination vertex buffer to copy to.

parameters.name: src_vbuff
parameters.description: The source vertex buffer to copy vertices from.

parameters.name: src_vert
parameters.description: The index of the first vertex to copy from the source vertex buffer.

parameters.name: src_vert_num
parameters.description: The number of vertices to copy.

vertex_update_buffer_from_vertex.description: This function updates contents of a vertex buffer using contents of another vertex buffer. The vertex buffers must not be frozen!

gc_enable.name: gc_enable

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: enable (true) or disable (false) the garbage collector.

gc_enable.description: With this function you can enable or disable the garbage collector. Calling the function with true as the argument enables it and using false disables it (not recommended). It is enabled by default.

array_shuffle_ext.name: array_shuffle_ext

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when shuffling the array. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: How many entries should be shuffled. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_shuffle_ext.description: With this function you can shuffle an array (or subsection) in place, nothing is returned

event_perform.name: event_perform

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of event to perform (see the table above).

parameters.name: numb
parameters.description: The specific event constant or value, if one is necessary (otherwise, just use 0).

event_perform.description: This function will perform the specified event, with the designated argument, for the instance running the code. There are many options here which allow complete simulation of all possible events, but note that this literally just performs all the code in the event and the game will not modify anything to make it trigger itself manually, for example if you choose to perform a keyboard press event, the event will be triggered but relevant key will not be recognised as having been pressed. Or if you perform an alarm event, the alarm counter will not be set to -1 but rather continue to count down.

weak_ref_any_alive.name: weak_ref_any_alive

parameters.name: weak_ref
parameters.description: The weak reference to the struct you want to check.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: OPTIONAL! The index into the array to start checking from

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: OPTIONAL! The number of positions from the given index to check

weak_ref_any_alive.description: With this function you can check the weak reference to various structs to see if it they are still "alive" or not. You supply an array of weak references to check (each weak reference should have been created using the function weak_ref_create()), and the function will return true if any of the structs are still being referenced somewhere or false if they are not and have been garbage collected. Note that if you supply an array where any of the values are not a weak references, the function will return undefined.

font_exists.name: font_exists

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: Index of the font to check.

font_exists.description: This function returns whether a font with the specified index exists or not. You can check font indices as defined from the Asset Browser, or fonts that have been added using functions like font_add().

video_enable_loop.name: video_enable_loop

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Set loop enable or disable.

video_enable_loop.description: This function will enable or disable the loop

draw_texture_flush.name: draw_texture_flush
draw_texture_flush.description: With this function you can remove all textures from video memory, and they will then be reloaded on first use. This is the only effective way to manage video memory when you have multiple texture pages for a game, and you should flush the texture memory between levels on your game and organise the graphics using the texture group feature to ensure that the minimum number of textures are used.

layer_get_id_at_depth.name: layer_get_id_at_depth

parameters.name: depth
parameters.description: The depth to check and retrieve the layer IDs from.

layer_get_id_at_depth.description: You can use this function to get the IDs of all layers assigned a specific depth. You give the depth to check and the function will return an array with 1 or more entries depending on whether there are any layers at the given depth or not. If there are no layers at the given depth then the array will have a single entry at the [0] position with a value of -1, but, if there are layers at the depth, then an entry will be made in the array for each layer found - the entry value will be the unique ID value for a layer.

file_text_eof.name: file_text_eof

parameters.name: fileid
parameters.description: The id of the file to check.

file_text_eof.description: This function returns true when the end of a given opened text file has been reached or false if not.

date_inc_day.name: date_inc_day

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to add to.

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: The number of days (must be an integer) to add.

date_inc_day.description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of days, and it will return the new datetime value.

physics_remove_fixture.name: physics_remove_fixture

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The ID of the instance to remove the fixture from

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: The ID of the fixture that is to be removed from the instance

physics_remove_fixture.description: This function removes (or "un-binds") a fixture from an instance or instances. It requires the unique "id" of the bound fixture (as returned by the function physics_fixture_bind() and it will remove all the currently defined physics properties for the instance, permitting you to redefine a new fixture and bind that to the instance. In this way you can change the instances physical properties without having to destroy and re-create it.

device_mouse_x_to_gui.name: device_mouse_x_to_gui

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.

device_mouse_x_to_gui.description: This function returns the x position of the touch on the device in relation to the GUI layer. Since the GUI layer can be set to be a different size independently of the screen resolution and the room size, it can sometimes be complicated to get the exact point on the GUI layer that a user has touched the screen. With this function you can get that position based on the actual GUI size, making GUI buttons and HUD elements easier to create and interact with. If you are running this on a the HTML5 or PC and Mac modules then this value is updated constantly, as long as the device (usually a mouse) is plugged in, however for mobile devices, this will only be updated while the screen is being touched, and note that the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs. Also note that on HTML5 only "device 0" will function correctly and other devices may give wrong values.

time_source_get_parent.name: time_source_get_parent

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

time_source_get_parent.description: Returns the index of the parent of this time source.

tilemap_get_tile_height.name: tilemap_get_tile_height

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to get the tile cell height of

tilemap_get_tile_height.description: Using this function you can retrieve the height (in pixels) of each tile cell of the tile map element. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and the function will return the tile set cell height.

achievement_get_pic.name: achievement_get_pic

parameters.name: char
parameters.description: The id of the person to get the image of (either from a friends list or a leaderboard)

achievement_get_pic.description: This function will send a request to the server for the image of a player or a friend and will trigger a callback Social Asynchronous Event which contains the async_load map populated with the relevant key/value pairs. The id key of this DS Map is used to identify the correct callback (there can be more than one trigger function for any given asynchronous event), and will be paired with the constant achievement_pic_loaded as well as a number of other key/value pairs. The exact contents of the map are shown below:

object_get_mask.name: object_get_mask

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The index of the object to check

object_get_mask.description: This function will tell you whether the object you are checking has a mask index or not, and if it does then it will return the index of that mask, or -1 if it does not. Please note that this is not an instance function! You can have an object with no mask while an instance of that same object can have one and vice-versa, or they can even have different masks. You can set an individual instances mask index using the mask_index instance variable.

window_mouse_get_delta_x.name: window_mouse_get_delta_x
window_mouse_get_delta_x.description: Returns how many pixels has the mouse cursor moved on the x axis since the last frame.

tilemap_set.name: tilemap_set

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to change

parameters.name: tiledata
parameters.description: The tile data to set

parameters.name: xcell
parameters.description: The cell (grid) position to set along the x-axis

parameters.name: ycell
parameters.description: The cell (grid) position to set along the y-axis

tilemap_set.description: This function can be used to set any cell (grid square) within the tile map element on the layer to a new tile. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and then the tile data to set as well as the position within the tile map. You can retrieve tile data using the function tilemap_get() and then use the tile_ functions to change it before setting the cell using this function. The function will return true if the tile was successfully set and false if there was an issue and it wasn't set.

draw_set_swf_aa_level.name: draw_set_swf_aa_level

parameters.name: aa
parameters.description: The anti-aliasing value to use from 0 to 1.

draw_set_swf_aa_level.description: This function can be used to set the anti-aliasing (AA) level for SWF format vector sprites. This can be a real value from 0 to 1 and will "smooth" the edges of these sprites. Note that to see this effect, you must first have enabled AA using the function draw_enable_swf_aa().

audio_set_listener_mask.name: audio_set_listener_mask

parameters.name: mask
parameters.description: The bit-mask data to set for the listeners

audio_set_listener_mask.description: When using multiple listeners on a system, you can set the bit-mask for a sound and have it heard from the flagged listener only. However, you can also set the global mask using this function and all sounds played normally will be heard from the listeners flagged by this mask, without the need to set the mask for each sound individually.

string_hash_to_newline.name: string_hash_to_newline

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to convert over multiple lines

string_hash_to_newline.description: This function returns a string where the "#" symbol has been converted into a new line. So a string formatted as:

path_append.name: path_append

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The new index of the path.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The index of the path that will be appended to 'index'.

path_append.description: With this code you can append one path onto another one, effectively joining them together, and for this to work, both paths must previously exist. In general you would want to use this function on paths created using path_add(), since if you use it on a path asset, it will permanently affect the path for instances in the game from the moment the function is used until the end of the game.

tilemap_get_mask.name: tilemap_get_mask

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to get the mask of

tilemap_get_mask.description: This function can be used to retrieve the bit mask value for the given tile map. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and the function will return the current mask value or -1 if there is an error or 0 if no mask is specified. For further information on tile map bit masks, see the function tilemap_set_mask().

path_get_speed.name: path_get_speed

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to check.

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: How far through the path to check. Between 0 (start) and 1 (end), can be decimal.

path_get_speed.description: This function returns the speed factor of any given position on a path. The position should be a value between 0 and 1 (you can use path_position, for example, if you need the current position of the instance) with 0 being the start position and 1 being the end. The value returned will be the factor by which the actual path_speed is being set. For example, on a path with only two points, 0 and 1, where the point 0 speed factor is 100 and point 1 speed factor is 0, the function path_get_speed(path, 0.5) will return 50.

audio_queue_sound.name: audio_queue_sound

parameters.name: queueindex
parameters.description: The index of the queue to add to.

parameters.name: bufferid
parameters.description: The buffer to add to the queue.

parameters.name: bufferoffset
parameters.description: The offset within the source buffer to start from.

parameters.name: bufferlength
parameters.description: The length of the buffer (the number of the bytes in the buffer).

audio_queue_sound.description: This function will add the data from a buffer into the audio queue that you previously created using the function audio_create_play_queue(). You specify the queue index to add to, and the buffer ID to get the data from as well as the position (offset) within the buffer and the number of bytes to add. Once you have added audio from a buffer to a queue, the buffer cannot be deleted until you have first freed the queue using the function audio_free_play_queue(), and the buffer properties should match those of the the queue that you are adding the sound to.

collision_line.name: collision_line

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for instance collisions.

parameters.name: prec
parameters.description: Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).

parameters.name: notme
parameters.description: Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).

collision_line.description: Collision_line checks along a line from point x1,y1 to point x2,y2 for a collision with any instance of the object specified by the argument "obj". this check can be either precise or not, but for precise collisions to be enabled, the object or instance that you are checking for must also have precise collisions enabled for their sprite. If not, the default check is based on bounding boxes. The following image illustrates how this works:

layer_sprite_yscale.name: layer_sprite_yscale

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to change

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The yscale value (default is 1)

layer_sprite_yscale.description: Using this function you can change whether the given sprite element on a layer should be scaled along the y axis or not. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and then set the scale value. A scale of 1 indicates no scaling (1:1), smaller values will scale down (0.5, for example, will half the height of the sprite used), larger values will scale up, and negative values will mirror the sprite and scale it unless the value used is exactly -1 (in which case the sprite used is just mirrored top-to-bottom about its (0, 0) position with no scaling).

buffer_async_group_begin.name: buffer_async_group_begin

parameters.name: groupname
parameters.description: The name of the group (as a string).

buffer_async_group_begin.description: This function is called when you want to begin the saving out of multiple buffers to multiple files. The "groupname" is a string and will be used as the directory name for where the files will be saved, and should be used as part of the file path when loading the files back into the IDE later (using any of the buffer_load() functions). This function is only for use with the buffer_save_async() function and you must also finish the save definition by calling buffer_async_group_end() function otherwise the files will not be saved out.

part_type_speed.name: part_type_speed

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: speed_min
parameters.description: The minimum speed the particle can start at.

parameters.name: speed_max
parameters.description: The maximum speed the particle can start at.

parameters.name: speed_incr
parameters.description: How much the particle speed should increase or decrease per step.

parameters.name: speed_wiggle
parameters.description: How much should randomly be added or subtracted from the particle's speed per step.

part_type_speed.description: This function is used to set the movement speed of the particle when it is created and can also be used to make the particle increase or decrease its speed over its lifetime. The minimum and maximum speed values default at 1, which means that the particle will move 1 pixel each step, and if they are set to the same value, the initial speed for all particles will be the same, but if set to different values, each particle will start with a random speed from within the given range. For example if you have a minimum of 3 and a maximum of 6, all particles will be created with a speed between three and six pixels per step.

surface_exists.name: surface_exists

parameters.name: surface_id
parameters.description: The ID of the surface to check.

surface_exists.description: This function is essential when working with surfaces due to their volatile nature. Surfaces are always held in texture memory which means that they can be destroyed from one moment to the next (for example, when a screensaver starts on windows, or when minimised on an Android device), so you should always check that a surface exists before doing anything with it (this includes drawing it to the screen). The example code below shows a typical use of this command in the draw event of an instance to check for a surface and re-create it if it has been removed (note that the surface will have been originally created in the create event of the object).

audio_group_unload.name: audio_group_unload

parameters.name: groupid
parameters.description: The index of the audio group to unload (as defined in the Audio Groups Window)

audio_group_unload.description: This function will unload all the sounds that are flagged as belonging to the given Audio Group into memory. The function will return true if unloading is initiated and false if the group ID is invalid, or it has already been flagged for unloading. Note that any audio currently being played when this function is called will be stopped.

tan.name: tan

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The angle (in radians) to return the tangent of.

tan.description: In a right angled triangle tan(val) = Opposite / Adjacent where val is one of the three angles.

ds_stack_write.name: ds_stack_write

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to write.

ds_stack_write.description: This function returns a string which can then be stored or transferred to another data structure using the ds_stack_read() function.

array_filter.name: array_filter

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: function
parameters.description: The function to be executed as filter. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return a boolean.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_filter.description: With this function you can create a new array with only the elements that return true to the given predicate. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.

extension_get_option_names.name: extension_get_option_names

parameters.name: extension_name
parameters.description: The name of your extension asset as a string

extension_get_option_names.description:
This function returns an array containing the names of all the options that exist in the extension with the given name.
			
			The function will return undefined if the provided extension name is invalid.

gamepad_is_connected.name: gamepad_is_connected

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad "slot" to check.

gamepad_is_connected.description: This function will return whether a gamepad is connected to the given "slot" (returns true) or not (returns false). You would normally use this function in conjunction with the gamepad_get_device_count() function to get the correct number of available game pads and/or gamepad "slots". Note that there may be a slight delay between the user connecting the gamepad and GameMaker detecting it as being connected (this is especially the case when dealing with bluetooth connected controllers).

randomize.name: randomize
randomize.description: This function sets the seed to a random value. Should you need to keep a consistent value over a number of runs of a game, you should be using random_set_seed(). Please note, that when using the random number functions in GameMaker the initial seed is always the same, as this makes tracing errors and debugging far easier. Should you wish to test with true random, you should call this function at the start of your game. The function will return the new randomised seed value (an unsigned 32bit integer).

vertex_float1.name: vertex_float1

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to write the information to.

parameters.name: float
parameters.description: The input value.

vertex_float1.description: This function will add a floating point value to the vertex data. The vertex must have been formatted correctly to accept this using the vertex_format_add_custom() function.

dbg_view_delete.name: dbg_view_delete

parameters.name: view
parameters.description: handle to the view

dbg_view_delete.description: Declare a new debug view that can be accessed from the debug overlay.

math_get_epsilon.name: math_get_epsilon
math_get_epsilon.description: This function will return the current epsilon value for the target platform. For more information on epsilon, please see the function math_set_epsilon().

rollback_get_player_prefs.name: rollback_get_player_prefs

parameters.name: player id
parameters.description: Player id

rollback_get_player_prefs.description: This function is used to get the preferences for a given player. Undefined will be returned if no preferences have been set. If the player id argument is not given, the preferences for the local player will be returned.

parameters.name: default
parameters.description: Config

gc_get_stats.name: gc_get_stats
gc_get_stats.description: With this function you can retrieve information about the current state of the garbage collector. The function will return a struct which will have the following member variables (note that "objects" here refers to anything that can be garbage collected and not general object instances as defined in the Asset Browser):

lengthdir_y.name: lengthdir_y

parameters.name: len
parameters.description: The length away of the point to return.

parameters.name: dir
parameters.description: The direction of the point to return.

lengthdir_y.description: This function is used to get the y component of a position "len" pixels from the starting point and in direction "dir". If you imagine a circle around your instance, and then imagine a point anywhere on that circle, to move to that point we need to move the object so many pixels in that direction... so this function (when used with lengthdir_x()) gets the position of that point on the circle to be used in code by the instance. See the image below for details:

string_repeat.name: string_repeat

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to repeat.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: The number of times to repeat the string.

string_repeat.description: This function simply returns the same string repeated a given number of times over itself.

color_get_value.name: color_get_value

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to check

color_get_value.description: This function will return the value (luminosity) of the given color. This is the amount of the "light" that is mixed into the final color and is part of the hue, saturation and value method for defining a color. The following image illustrates how this value corresponds to the HSV scale of color:

part_type_size_x.name: part_type_size_x

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: size_min
parameters.description: The minimum size the particle can start at on the x axis.

parameters.name: size_max
parameters.description: The maximum size the particle can start at on the x axis.

parameters.name: size_incr
parameters.description: How much the particle should increase or decrease on the x axis per step.

parameters.name: size_wiggle
parameters.description: How much should randomly be added or subtracted from the particles size on the x axis per step.

part_type_size_x.description: This function is used to configure particle size similarly to part_type_size(), except only for the x axis. You can use function part_type_size_y() to configure the size on the y axis separately as well.

sprite_get_info.name: sprite_get_info

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to get the information for.

sprite_get_info.description: This function is used to retrieve information for the given sprite. You supply a sprite index (which can be an asset added through the Asset Browser or a sprite added at runtime) and the function returns a struct with the following variables:

tileset_get_texture.name: tileset_get_texture

parameters.name: tileset
parameters.description: The index of the tile set to use.

tileset_get_texture.description: This function returns a special pointer for the tile set texture page. This value can then be used in other draw functions, particularly in the 2D primitive functions, as well as the Shader functions. You can get more information about the returned texture page using the different texture_ functions found here.

ds_priority_find_min.name: ds_priority_find_min

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the priority queue to use.

ds_priority_find_min.description: With this function you can find the value stored in the priority queue with the lowest priority, and if more than one value has the same priority then any one of them could be returned in any order. However, unlike ds_priority_delete_min(), this function will not remove the value from the queue.

device_mouse_raw_x.name: device_mouse_raw_x

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.

device_mouse_raw_x.description: This function returns the raw x position of a touch on the device. What this means is that it returns the actual device definition of the x position that is being touched, not the GameMaker one, and as such will ignore things like view position and scaling. Note that the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs

date_compare_time.name: date_compare_time

parameters.name: datetime1
parameters.description: The first datetime.

parameters.name: datetime2
parameters.description: The datetime to compare the first one to.

date_compare_time.description: With this function you can check two dates and times to see which one has the time component earlier or later than the other. The function returns -1 if datetime1 is earlier, 1 if datetime1 is later and 0 if they are the same, and it ignores the date, so literally just which of the times is further through its given day.

video_get_position.name: video_get_position
video_get_position.description: This function will return the position of video in milliseconds

tile_get_rotate.name: tile_get_rotate

parameters.name: tiledata
parameters.description: the tile-data to check

tile_get_rotate.description: This function can be used to check whether in a given set of tile-data the tile has been rotated 90 degrees or not. You give the tile-data, which can be retrieved using the function tilemap_get(), and the function will return true if the tile is rotated, or false if not.

mp_grid_get_cell.name: mp_grid_get_cell

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Index of the mp_grid that is to be used

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the grid to check.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the grid to check.

mp_grid_get_cell.description: With this function you can check any given cell of the mp_grid to see if it has been flagged as occupied or not, giving the index of the (previously created) mp_grid and the x an y coordinates of the cell to check. If it has been occupied or the position being checked is out of the grids bounds then the function will return -1 otherwise it will return 0.

camera_set_view_size.name: camera_set_view_size

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the camera view in pixels

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the camera view in pixels

camera_set_view_size.description: You can use this function to update the size of the view camera within the room. You give the unique camera ID value (as returned by the different camera_create() functions) and then give the width and height (in pixels) to set the camera to.

sprite_set_bbox.name: sprite_set_bbox

parameters.name: ind
