parameters.description: The index of the sprite to set the bounding box on.

parameters.name: left
parameters.description: The left side of the bounding box

parameters.name: top
parameters.description: The top of the bounding box.

parameters.name: right
parameters.description: The right side of the bounding box

parameters.name: bottom
parameters.description: The bottom of the bounding box.

sprite_set_bbox.description: This function can be used to set the bounding box values for a sprite. You supply the sprite index to use and then the left, top, right and bottom values for the bounding box positions. The positions are absolute values, where the (0, 0) position corresponds to the top left corner of the sprite, regardless of the offset for the sprite, any "empty" pixels the sprite may have, or where it is being drawn in the room.

ds_map_exists.name: ds_map_exists

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: the id of the data structure to check

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: the key to check for

ds_map_exists.description: This function will return true if the specified key exists in the (previously created) DS map , and false if it does not.

point_in_rectangle.name: point_in_rectangle

parameters.name: px
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the point to check.

parameters.name: py
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the point to check.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the rectangle to check.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top side of the rectangle to check.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right side of the rectangle to check.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom side of the rectangle to check.

point_in_rectangle.description: When using this function, you define a rectangular area and GameMaker will work out whether the given point falls within its bounds or not. If the point falls within the defined rectangle the function will return true otherwise the function will return false.

bool.name: bool

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The value to convert.

bool.description: This function will attempt to convert a given value into a boolean data type, where the value will be returned as true if it is greater than 0.5 and false otherwise.

move_towards_point.name: move_towards_point

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of the point to move towards.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of the point to move towards.

parameters.name: sp
parameters.description: The speed to move at in pixels per step.

move_towards_point.description: This function simply tells the instance running the code to move towards a set point at a set speed. Bear in mind that it is up to you to tell it what to do once it gets there, as it won't just stop by itself. This means that you can get a "vibrating" instance as it moves (for example) 3 pixels forward, overshoots the x/y target position by 2, then moves 3 pixels back again, overshooting the target point by one and so on... There are a number of ways that this can be avoided, for example using distance_to_point() to see how far from the specified location the instance is before moving.

audio_group_set_gain.name: audio_group_set_gain

parameters.name: groupid
parameters.description: The index of the audio group to stop (as defined in the Audio Groups Window)

parameters.name: volume
parameters.description: The final value for the group volume.

parameters.name: time
parameters.description: The length of the change in gain in milliseconds.

audio_group_set_gain.description: With this function you can fade a group of sounds in or out over a given length of time, or it can be used to set the group gain instantly. The time is measured in milliseconds, and the function requires that you input a final level of gain for the group to have reached by the end of that time. This gain can be between 0 (silent) and 1 (full volume) and the scale is linear, such that a value of 0.5 would be half volume. To instantly change the gain, simply set the time argument to 0. Note that on some platforms you can have a gain of greater than 1, although a value of 1 is considered "full volume" and anything greater may introduce audio clipping.

asset_remove_tags.name: asset_remove_tags

parameters.name: name_or_index
parameters.description: The name of the asset (a string) or its index value (an integer).

parameters.name: tags
parameters.description: A single asset tag string or an array with various asset tags.

parameters.name: asset_type
parameters.description: OPTIONAL! The type of asset to remove the tags from, only used when supplying an index for the first argument.

asset_remove_tags.description:
This function removes one or more tag strings to any asset from the Asset Browser.
			
			You supply either the asset name (as a string) or its asset index, as well as either a single tag string or an array where each item is a single tag string. If you supply an asset index value, then you will need to supply the optional asset type argument (a constant), as assets of different types can have the same index, even though they cannot have the same name.

skeleton_animation_get_duration.name: skeleton_animation_get_duration

parameters.name: animname
parameters.description: The name (a string) of the animation set to use.

skeleton_animation_get_duration.description: This function will return the time required for the given animation set to run before looping back to the beginning. The return value is in seconds.

sequence_keyframe_new.name: sequence_keyframe_new

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of keyframe to create, a constant, listed above.

sequence_keyframe_new.description: With this function you can create a new track keyframe struct, supplying the type of track that the keyframe will be applied to, which will be one of the following constants:

layer_sprite_get_sprite.name: layer_sprite_get_sprite

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to get the information from

layer_sprite_get_sprite.description: This function can be used to get the current sprite index of the sprite element. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and the function will return a real value that represents the sprite index being shown. If the element has no sprite assigned, the function will return -1.

parameters.name: flags
parameters.description: The flags to set on the particle.

parameters.name: groupflags
parameters.description: The group flags to set on the particle (see Description below).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to create the particle group at.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to create the particle group at.

parameters.name: ang
parameters.description: The angle (in degrees) to rotate the group to on create.

parameters.name: xv
parameters.description: The initial horizontal velocity.

parameters.name: yv
parameters.description: The initial vertical velocity.

parameters.name: ang_velocity
parameters.description: The initial angular velocity.

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The base colour to use for the particle group.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The base alpha to use for the particle group.

parameters.name: strength
parameters.description: Set the cohesion strength between particles in the group.

parameters.name: category
parameters.description: The user defined category to which the group belongs.

rollback_leave_game.name: rollback_leave_game
rollback_leave_game.description: This function leaves the current game.

event_perform_object.name: event_perform_object

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object that should have its event triggered.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of event to perform.

parameters.name: numb
parameters.description: The specific event, if one is necessary (otherwise, just use 0).

event_perform_object.description: This functions works the same as event_perform() except that this time you can specify events from another object. There are many options here which allow complete simulation of all possible events, but note that this literally just performs all the code in the event and the game will not modify anything to make it trigger itself manually, for example if you choose to perform a keyboard press event, the event will be triggered but the relevant key will not be recognised as having been pressed. Or if you perform an alarm event, the alarm counter will not be set to -1 but rather continue to count down. You can find a complete list of the available constants this function requires from the the page for the function event_perform().

physics_set_restitution.name: physics_set_restitution

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the id of the bound fixture

parameters.name: restitution
parameters.description: the new restitution value to apply

physics_set_restitution.description: When you bind a fixture to an instance using physics_fixture_bind() this returns an "id" for the bound fixture. You can use this id to set the restitution value of the bound fixture, not the "base" fixture, at any time using this function. Restitution is usually set as a value between 0 and 1, but you can use higher values if required, although the results may be unpredictable.

date_get_week.name: date_get_week

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to check.

date_get_week.description: This function returns the week of the given datetime value within the year.

physics_draw_debug.name: physics_draw_debug
physics_draw_debug.description: When creating a physics system in GameMaker, it is often important to have a visual representation of what is actually happening with an instance. This can be achieved by using physics_draw_debug(), which draws a schematic outline of the physical properties associated with the instance running the code. Here is an image of how it looks:

achievement_reset.name: achievement_reset
achievement_reset.description: This function will reset all achievements back to their initial values for the game. This function is provided as a debug function and it is not recommended that you permit the end-user to do this in your games.

ds_map_set.name: ds_map_set

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map to use.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to set.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value to set the key to.

ds_map_set.description: With this function you can set the value of a key within a given DS map. You supply the DS map ID value (as returned by the function ds_map_create()), then give the key you want to set and the value to set it to. Keys can be integers or strings, and if the given key does not exist then it will be created for you and set to the value. This function is the same as using the DS map accessor to set/create a map key/value pair. The function does not return anything, so if you need to check if the key value has been replaced or a new key has been created, then you should use the function ds_map_replace().

keyboard_check_direct.name: keyboard_check_direct

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to check the down state of.

keyboard_check_direct.description: This function will return true if the key with the particular keycode is pressed, or false if it is not, by checking the hardware directly. It allows for a few more checks, in particular you can use keycodes vk_lshift, vk_lcontrol, vk_lalt, vk_rshift, vk_rcontrol and vk_ralt to check whether the left or right shift, control or alt key is pressed. The function will take a keycode value as returned by the function ord() (only capital letters from A-Z or numbers from 0-9), or any of the vk_* constants listed on the main Keyboard Input page.

layer_sequence_xscale.name: layer_sequence_xscale

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The new X axis scale value to apply to the sequence element

layer_sequence_xscale.description: With this function you can set the X scale for the given sequence element. You supply the sequence element ID as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions along with the new scale to set on the X axis and the sequence will be scaled by this amount. A scale of 1 indicates no scaling (1:1), smaller values will scale down (0.5, for example, will half the width of the sequence), larger values will scale up and negative values will mirror the sequence about its origin and scale it unless the value used is exactly -1 (in which case the sequence is just mirrored about its origin with no scaling).

draw_light_define_direction.name: draw_light_define_direction

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index number of the light (arbitrary)

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x component of the light vector

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y component of the light vector

parameters.name: z
parameters.description: The z component of the light vector

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to use for the light (either a constant, a real or a hex value).

draw_light_define_direction.description: This function is for defining a directional light, where the direction and intensity are set by the values input for the x, y and z unit vector (meaning that they must be between -1 and 1, where 1 or -1 is full intensity, and 0 is no intensity). The lights can also be given a colour, which will also affect the perceived intensity of the light as certain colours appear "darker" than others. You must also give the light an index number which what will be used in other functions to reference it.

skeleton_animation_mix.name: skeleton_animation_mix

parameters.name: animfrom
parameters.description: The name (a string) of the first animation set to interpolate from.

parameters.name: animto
parameters.description: The name (a string) of the second animation set to interpolate to.

parameters.name: duration
parameters.description: The duration of the interpolation (from 0 to 1)

skeleton_animation_mix.description: You can switch animation sets easily using the skeleton_animation_set() function, but this may cause a skip or stutter as one animation is swapped for another. To prevent this, you can set the mix value between two animation sets and the sprite will interpolate between them. normally you would want to do this in the Create Event of the instance with the skeletal animation as it only needs set once, and GameMaker will interpolate all further changes to the sprite using the animation sets in that instance. Note that the duration value is from 0 to 1, where a value of 0.5 would have a "half and half" interpolation from one set to the other.

analytics_event_ext.name: analytics_event_ext

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: A string to send to the provider.

parameters.name: string_param[0 -9]
parameters.description: The parameter to send (a string).

parameters.name: value[0 - 9]
parameters.description: The value of the parameter (a real number).

analytics_event_ext.description: This function will send the specified text to the analytics provider that you have set up through the HTML5 Game Options. This function can be used to create a custom analytic to track something outside of the scope of the provider being used, and will also accept custom parameter/value pairs, where the parameter is a string and the value a real number. For Google Analytics, you can only add in one extra pair while Flurry will accept up to 7.

audio_listener_set_position.name: audio_listener_set_position

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The listener to get the data for (default 0).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of the listener (default 0).

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of the listener (default 0).

parameters.name: z
parameters.description: The z position of the listener (default 0).

audio_listener_set_position.description: With this function you can change the position of a given listener within the 3D audio space. The default listener index is 0, but you can use the function audio_get_listener_info() to get the different indices available for the target platform. The example image below shows the default position for the listener in the audio space:

path_duplicate.name: path_duplicate

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the existing path to duplicate.

path_duplicate.description: This function takes a path and copies it into a new path. The new path is created in the process, and the index is returned to be used in all further calls to use this new path.

ds_grid_value_disk_x.name: ds_grid_value_disk_x

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: xm
parameters.description: The x position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: ym
parameters.description: The y position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: r
parameters.description: The radius of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to find.

ds_grid_value_disk_x.description: With this function you can get the x coordinate (within the given grid disc-shaped region) of the value being searched for. You give the DS grid index (as returned by ds_grid_create()) along with the x/y positions for the center cell of the disk. Then you give the radius (as an integer value) around the center cell to search, before supplying the value to search for. If the value being searched for does not exist, then the function will return -1.

string_width.name: string_width

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to measure the width of.

string_width.description: This function will return the width (in pixels) of the input string, taking into account any line-breaks the text may have. It is very handy for calculating distances between text elements based on the total width of the letters that make up the string as it would be drawn with draw_text() using the currently defined font.

achievement_load_friends.name: achievement_load_friends
achievement_load_friends.description: This function will send a request to the server for information on all the logged in users friends and will trigger a callback Social Asynchronous Event which contains the async_load map populated with the relevant key/value pairs. The id key of this DS Map is used to identify the correct callback (there can be more than one trigger function for any given asynchronous event), and will be paired with the constant achievement_friends_info as well as a number of other key/value pairs for each friend. The exact contents of the map are shown below:

object_set_solid.name: object_set_solid

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the object to change.

parameters.name: solid
parameters.description: The new solidity of the object (true=solid, false=not solid).

object_set_solid.description: With this function you can flag a specific object as being solid or not (for more information on the "solid" flag see the section on the Object Editor). This means that all instances of this object that are created after solid has been changed will be created with this new state, while instances that are already in the room may not be affected.

skeleton_animation_set_position.name: skeleton_animation_set_position

parameters.name: track
parameters.description: The animation track to set the frame of.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The new position for the animation track.

skeleton_animation_set_position.description: This function will set the animation assigned to the given track to the proportional position you supply. The position should be an real value between 0.0 and 1.0. If you supply a value outside of this range, the animation will be looped to make up the difference, for example if the given position is 1.5 the actual position will be 0.5.

animcurve_get_channel_index.name: animcurve_get_channel_index

parameters.name: curve_struct_or_id
parameters.description: The ID or struct pointer of the animation curve to target

parameters.name: channel_name
parameters.description: The channel name (a string).

animcurve_get_channel_index.description:
This function returns the index value for any given animation curve channel.
			
			You supply the animation curve ID or struct, where the curve ID is the name of the animation curve as it was defined in the Asset Browser, or the struct pointer as returned by the function animcurve_create(). You then supply the name of the channel, as a string, and the function will return the index value associated with that channel. Note that if the curve or channel does not exist then you will get an error.

buffer_load.name: buffer_load

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The name of the file to load from.

buffer_load.description: This function is used to load a buffer that was previously saved using the buffer_save() functions, as well as any Included Files or files loaded externally. It will return a new buffer's ID which is created by the function as a "grow" buffer (see here) with a byte alignment of 1. This ID should be stored in a variable and used in all further function calls to this buffer. If the load fails for whatever reason, the function will return -1 and a message will be shown in the compiler output window saying that the load has failed.

surface_copy.name: surface_copy

parameters.name: destination
parameters.description: The ID of the surface to copy the other surface to.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to copy to.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to copy to.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The ID of surface to be copied.

surface_copy.description: This function simply takes the image from one surface and copies it onto another one at the specified local position within that surface (where the (0,0) position is the top left corner of the destination surface). If the destination surface already has information this will be overwritten by the copy, and the function does not change the source surface in any way.

texture_flush.name: texture_flush

parameters.name: tex_id
parameters.description: The texture page ID (an integer) or a texture group ID (a string)

texture_flush.description: This function can be used to "flush" a texture page or a group of texture pages, ie: remove them from VRAM when no longer required. You supply the unique texture page ID (as returned by the texturegroup_* functions) to flush a single page, or you can supply a texture group name (as defined in the Texture Group Editor) to flush all the texture pages in the group.

network_send_raw.name: network_send_raw

parameters.name: socket
parameters.description: The id of the socket to use.

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The id of the buffer to get the data from.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size (in bytes) of the data.

parameters.name: options
parameters.description: Optional flags to affect how the data is sent.

network_send_raw.description: With this function you can send a "raw" data packet through the network. The function takes the socket id to connect through and then you must supply the buffer id which contains the data to be sent (for more information on buffers see Reference - Buffers) and finally the size (in bytes) of the data packet. The data sent is not formatted by GameMaker in any way and the receiving devices will get the data as a stream which means you will have to handle it yourself. The function will return the number of bytes of data sent, or a number less than 0 if the send has failed.

physics_apply_torque.name: physics_apply_torque

parameters.name: torque
parameters.description: The torque (in Newton metres) to be applied

physics_apply_torque.description: When we talk about torque, we are generally talking about the tendency of a force or impulse to rotate an instance about its centre of mass, but in GameMaker you can also apply torque independently to an instance, causing it to rotate in a given direction. How much torque you apply to get the desired rotation all depends on the size and density of the fixture you assign to your instance, as both these properties go towards defining its mass, which defines its inertia, which affects torque! The general rule of thumb is that if an instance has a lot of inertia, you will need a lot of torque to get it to start rotating. It should also be noted that other factors like gravity and collisions can also affect the torque of an instance. Here is an image to help explain:

sprite_delete.name: sprite_delete

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to be deleted.

sprite_delete.description: This function will delete a sprite from the game, freeing any memory that was reserved for it. This is a very important function for those moments when you need to create and change sprites from external sources (like loading a sprite from a file with sprite_add(), or duplicating a sprite using sprite_duplicate()) and should always be used to remove those assets that are no longer needed by a game, or to clear an indexed asset from a variable before re-assigning another asset to that variable. This cannot be used to delete sprites that are included in the game as part of the assets in the Asset Browser.

instance_deactivate_object.name: instance_deactivate_object

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object or instance to deactivate (the keyword all can also be used).

instance_deactivate_object.description: With this function you can deactivate a single instance or all instances of a specific object from all those that have been activated previously. Note that if you have deactivated an instance or object that has been flagged as Persistent, then you will need to reactivate it again with the function instance_activate_object() before changing room, otherwise it will not be carried over and will be discarded instead. Note too that deactivation is not instantaneous, and an instance that has been deactivated in this way will not be considered to be inactive until the end of the event in which the function was called.

window_set_max_width.name: window_set_max_width

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The maximum width in pixels for the game window.

window_set_max_width.description: This function can be used to set a maximum window width for your game. If you enable the window resize option in the Game Options for the target platform, then the player can resize the game window to any size they wish, however by using this function you can limit the maximum width to the size you specify. If you wish to go back to the default behaviour (ie: no minimum), then use a value of -1.

sprite_set_nineslice.name: sprite_set_nineslice

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to modify

parameters.name: nineslice
parameters.description: The Nine Slice struct to apply

sprite_set_nineslice.description: This function is used to apply a Nine Slice struct to a sprite. You supply the sprite index and the Nine Slice struct to apply, which can be retrieved using sprite_nineslice_create() or sprite_get_nineslice().

gpu_get_zwriteenable.name: gpu_get_zwriteenable
gpu_get_zwriteenable.description: This function can be used to retrieve whether z-writing is enabled (the function returns true) or not (the function returns false). The default value is that z-writing is enabled, so the function will return true.

part_type_gravity.name: part_type_gravity

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: grav_amount
parameters.description: Strength of the gravity.

parameters.name: grav_direction
parameters.description: The direction of the gravity.

part_type_gravity.description: This function will set the gravity that is to affect each particle of the given type that is created. The gravity strength value is added to the particle speed every step and is usually a small value like 0.5, while the direction is the direction of the gravity "pull" and follows the standard GameMaker directions of 0° being right, 90° being up, 180° being left and 270° being down.

ds_grid_copy.name: ds_grid_copy

parameters.name: destination
parameters.description: This index of the grid to copy to.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: This index of the grid to copy from.

ds_grid_copy.description: With this function you can copy the contents of one grid into another one. Both grids must have been created previously using the ds_grid_create() function.

os_set_orientation_lock.name: os_set_orientation_lock

parameters.name: landscape_enable
parameters.description: true if landscape orientation is allowed, false otherwise

parameters.name: portrait_enable
parameters.description: true if portait orientation is allowed, false otherwise

os_set_orientation_lock.description: With this function you can "lock" your device to the current orientation until such time as you "free" it to allow all Game Options enabled orientations again for that target platform. Note that you likely want to confirm the orientation is as desired before locking.

ds_map_find_last.name: ds_map_find_last

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map to use.

ds_map_find_last.description: This function returns the last key stored in the DS map. This is not the last key in the order that you have added them! DS maps are not stored in a linear form, for that use DS lists, so all this does is find the last key as stored by the computer. This can be useful if your have to iterate through the DS map looking for something, but should be avoided if possible as it can be slow.

array_union.name: array_union

parameters.name: array0
parameters.description: The variable that holds the first array.

parameters.name: array1
parameters.description: The variable that holds the second array.
The variable that holds the nth array.

array_union.description: With this function you can join two or more arrays into a single one, removing the duplicates

ds_priority_find_max.name: ds_priority_find_max

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the priority queue to use.

ds_priority_find_max.description: With this function you can find the value stored in the priority queue with the highest priority, and if more than one value has the same priority then any one of them could be returned in any order. However, unlike ds_priority_delete_max(), this function will not remove the value from the queue.

ds_map_create.name: ds_map_create
ds_map_create.description: This function is used to create a new, empty, DS map and will return its id which is then used to access the data structure in all other DS map functions.

part_system_drawit.name: part_system_drawit

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system to draw.

part_system_drawit.description: This function draws the given particle system.

surface_set_target_ext.name: surface_set_target_ext

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The render target index to use (from 0 to 3).

parameters.name: surface_id
parameters.description: The ID of the surface to use.

surface_set_target_ext.description: This function is for use with the Shader Functions and sets the MRT (0 - 3) for native level shaders (DX9, DX11, OpenGL).

sprite_merge.name: sprite_merge

parameters.name: ind1
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to merge.

parameters.name: ind2
parameters.description: The index of the sprite that ind1 is to be merged with.

sprite_merge.description: This function will merge the sprite indexed in argument 1 ("ind2") with that which is indexed in argument 0 ("ind1"). The images themselves are NOT merged together, but rather the image indices are merged, with the sub images from sprite "ind2" appended onto those of sprite "ind1", ie: they are added on at the end. Note that if the sprites are different sizes, then the appended sprites are stretched to fit the image size for "ind1".

gamepad_get_description.name: gamepad_get_description

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad "slot" to get the name of.

gamepad_get_description.description: This function will return a string with the description of the given gamepad, for example, a PS3 controller may return a string similar to "PLAYSTATION(R)3 Controller", or an XBox360 controller could return "Xbox 360 Controller (XInput STANDARD GAMEPAD)". This string is hardware dependant and the returned value will depend on the gamepad plugged into the device "slot" that is being checked.

path_get_name.name: path_get_name

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to check.

path_get_name.description: This function will return the name of the path that is referenced as a string. The name is whatever has been used to define the path in the editor or (if the path has been created through a code function) it will return a string with the format " _newpathXX" where "XX" is the number of the path generated, starting at 0 and incrementing by one every time a new path is created. Please note that this is only a string and cannot be used to reference the path directly - for that you would need the path index ID. You can, however, use this string to get the path index ID using the returned string along with the function asset_get_index().

tilemap_get_global_mask.name: tilemap_get_global_mask
tilemap_get_global_mask.description: This function can be used to retrieve the bit mask value for all tile maps, returning the current mask value or -1 if there is an error or 0 if no mask is specified. For further information on global tile map bit masks, see the function tilemap_set_global_mask().

array_last.name: array_last

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

array_last.description: With this function you can return the last element of the array or undefined if the array is empty.

layer_get_element_layer.name: layer_get_element_layer

parameters.name: element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the element to get the layer of

layer_get_element_layer.description: You can use this function to get the Layer ID that the given element is on. You supply the unique element ID value (for example, as returned by the function that created the element or from the room editor) and the function will return the unique ID of the layer that the element is found on. If the element ID given is not a valid one, then the function will return -1.

clickable_exists.name: clickable_exists

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the clickable to check.

clickable_exists.description: This function returns whether a clickable DOM icon has been created with the specified index exists or not. Please note, that the value used for checking must have been initialised previously or else you will get an error causing GameMaker to close.

http_get.name: http_get

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The web address of the server that you wish to get information from

http_get.description: With this function, you connect to the specified URL in order to retrieve information. As this is an asynchronous function, GameMaker will not block while waiting for a reply, but will keep on running unless it gets callback information. This information will be in the form of a string and will trigger an Async Event in any instance that has one defined in their object properties. You should also note that HTTP request parameters (the bits sometimes "tacked on" to the end of a URL when you submit a form on a web page) are perfectly acceptable when using this function, for example:

window_get_cursor.name: window_get_cursor
window_get_cursor.description: With this function you can get the current cursor being used in the game window, with the return value being any one of the constants listed below (to set the current cursor being used you can use the function window_set_cursor() which also takes these constants):

sprite_prefetch.name: sprite_prefetch

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The sprite index to fetch

sprite_prefetch.description: This function can be used to prefetch (place into texture memory) a texture page with the given sprite. You supply the sprite index as defined when you created the sprite asset, and the texture page it is on will be loaded into memory. Note that the function will return -1 if prefetch is not supported for the chosen resource or the target platform is HTML5, or it will return 0 if all worked correctly.

path_set_kind.name: path_set_kind

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to change.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The kind of the path, 0 for straight or 1 for smooth.

path_set_kind.description: This function can be used to set the kind of path that you wish the specified resource to be. This can be either a straight line path (set to 0) or a smoothed path (set to 1) in which case the path precision has to be taken into account too (the precision can be set too using path_set_precision()). This function changes the actual path resource, and so will permanently affect how the path is used by all instances in the game from the moment the function is used until the end of the game.If this is not what you require, then you should use a function like path_duplicate() to create a copy of the path first, then call this function on the duplicated asset (don't forget to call path_delete() on the asset when it is no longer required).

gpu_set_zwriteenable.name: gpu_set_zwriteenable

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: The comparison mode to use (see list above)

gpu_set_zwriteenable.description: This function can be used to toggle on (true) and off (false) depth ordering using the z-buffer. When an instance is rendered in GameMaker , the depth of a generated pixel (its z coordinate) is stored in the z-buffer, then, if another instance of the scene must be rendered at the same pixel, the two depths are compared (z-testing - see gpu_set_ztestenable()) and the one "closer" to the observer is then saved to the z-buffer, replacing the old one. However, this is not always what you wish to happen and there are moments when you may want something to be drawn over everything else, no matter what its z value is. In those cases you can use this function to switch off writing to the z-buffer and so force whatever is being drawn to be drawn over everything else. Note that the description given here is for the default z-testing comparison mode, but that can be changed

buffer_base64_encode.name: buffer_base64_encode

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to use.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The data offset value.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the buffer.

buffer_base64_encode.description: This function will convert the data from the given buffer into a base64 format encoded string. This is a commonly used encoding scheme that is often used for any media that needs to be stored or transferred over the internet as text, and renders the output unreadable to the human eye. To use this you need to specify an already created buffer, the offset value (which is the point within the buffer at which you wish to start encoding) as well as the size, in bytes, of the buffer memory to encode.

show_question.name: show_question

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to show in the pop-up question.

show_question.description: This function creates a pop-up message box with two buttons for "Yes" and "No". It returns true or false depending on which one of the two buttons the user presses.

physics_particle_set_category_flags.name: physics_particle_set_category_flags

parameters.name: category
parameters.description: The particle category to set.

parameters.name: flags
parameters.description: The flags to set on the particle.

physics_particle_set_category_flags.description: With this function you can change the particle flags for a category of particles. The category value is that which you defined in the function physics_particle_create() or (if you created a group) physics_particle_group_begin(), while the flags are the return value of a combination of the following constants:

string_starts_with.name: string_starts_with

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The input string.

parameters.name: substr
parameters.description: The string to check against.

string_starts_with.description: This function determines whether a string begins with the characters of a specified string, returning true or false as appropriate.

dsin.name: dsin

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The angle (in degrees) to return the sine of.

dsin.description: In a right angled triangle dsin(val) = Opposite / Hypotenuse where "val" is one of the three angles.

skeleton_slot_list.name: skeleton_slot_list

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The sprite index of the Spine skeletal animation to get the list from.

parameters.name: list
parameters.description: The ID of the DS list to populate with the bone names.

skeleton_slot_list.description: With this function you can populate a (pre-created) DS list with all the names of the slots created as part of the skeletal animation sprite. The names will be strings and can then be used in the other skeleton animation slot functions for these types of sprite.

gpu_get_blendmode_src.name: gpu_get_blendmode_src
gpu_get_blendmode_src.description: This function can be used to retrieve the current source extended blend mode factor being used for drawing. The value returned will be one of the following constants ("s" denotes a value taken from the source while a "d" denotes a value from the destination):

ini_write_real.name: ini_write_real

parameters.name: section
parameters.description: The section of the .ini to write to.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key within the relevant section of the .ini to write to.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The real value to write to the relevant destination.

ini_write_real.description: You can use this function to write a value (numeric) to an ini data file. Ini Files are split into sections and then each section is subsequently split into key - value pairs. So a typical ini file would look something like this:

instance_create_layer.name: instance_create_layer

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position the object will be created at

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position the object will be created at

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The layer ID (or name) to assign the created instance to

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object index of the object to create an instance of

parameters.name: var_struct
parameters.description: A structure that contains variables that are copied into the new instance before the Create Event is called

instance_create_layer.description: With this function you can create a new instance of the specified object at any given point within the room and on the layer specified. The layer can be identified using the layer ID value (as returned by the function layer_create()) or by the name of the layer (as a string, for example "instance_layer") as defined in the room editor.

object_get_physics.name: object_get_physics

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The index of the object to check.

object_get_physics.description: This function will tell you whether the object you are checking has been flagged as "physics enabled"  - in which case it'll return true, - or not - in which case it will return false.

colour_get_hue.name: colour_get_hue

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to check

colour_get_hue.description: This function will return the hue of the given colour. This is the "pure" colour tone which is part of the hue, saturation and value (luminosity) method for defining a colour. The following image illustrates how this value corresponds to the HSV scale of colour:

string_ord_at.name: string_ord_at

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to check.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The position to get the character code from.

string_ord_at.description: You can use this function to return a specific character code at a specific position within a string, with the index starting at 1 for the first character. If no character is found or the string is shorter than the value given to index, -1 is returned.

date_get_weekday.name: date_get_weekday

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The date to check.

date_get_weekday.description: This function returns the week day value of the given datetime. This will be a value from 0 to 6.

virtual_key_show.name: virtual_key_show

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the virtual key to show.

virtual_key_show.description: Once you have created your virtual key for your devices, you may need to debug and test that it is correctly positioned and working properly. For that you would call this function, using the index of the virtual key that you want to see (previously created and stored using virtual_key_add()) which will draw a coloured rectangle to represent the key on the screen. Once you are happy with things it is recommended that you create and place your own graphic in its area.

path_rescale.name: path_rescale

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to scale.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: What to multiply the current horizontal scale by. Default scale is 1.

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: What to multiply the current vertical scale by. Default scale is 1.

path_rescale.description: This function can be used to re-scale the given path along both (or either) the vertical and horizontal axis, basically moving each of the path points to a new position corresponding to this scale around the centre of the path. This function changes the actual path asset, and so will permanently affect how the path is used by all instances in the game from the moment the function is used until the end of the game. If this is not what you require, then you should use a function like path_duplicate() to create a copy of the path first, then call this function on the duplicated asset (don't forget to call path_delete() on the asset when it is no longer required).

layer_get_visible.name: layer_get_visible

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target (or the layer name as a string)

layer_get_visible.description: With this function you can check whether a layer is visible or not. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the function will return true if it is visible, and false otherwise.

ds_queue_copy.name: ds_queue_copy

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the NEW queue.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The ORIGINAL queue to copy to id.

ds_queue_copy.description: This function can be used to copy the contents of one queue into another. Note that this does NOT remove the contents from the original queue, nor does it destroy the original queue. When using this function the queue being copied to must have been previously created and if it contained any items before the copy, then these will be cleared first (meaning this information will be lost).

object_exists.name: object_exists

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The index of the object to check.

object_exists.description: This function returns whether an object with the specified index exists or not. Note that this checks to see if an object is present in the Asset Browser, and not actually in the game room. For that you should use the function instance_exists().

audio_emitter_get_y.name: audio_emitter_get_y

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to use.

audio_emitter_get_y.description: This function returns the current y position of the given audio emitter.

matrix_multiply.name: matrix_multiply

parameters.name: matrix1
parameters.description: The first matrix index to use.

parameters.name: matrix2
parameters.description: The second matrix index to use.

matrix_multiply.description: With this function you can multiply two matrix arrays together to create a new transform matrix. The function will return the new matrix index which should be stored in a variable for future use.

timeline_exists.name: timeline_exists

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the time line to check for.

timeline_exists.description: With this function you can check and see whether a time line exists (returns true) or not (returns false). This is particularly useful when creating Timelines dynamically using the timeline_add() function, but you should note that if you search for an uninitialised variable (that would otherwise be assigned to a time line's index) an error will be thrown.

ds_grid_resize.name: ds_grid_resize

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: This index of the grid to resize.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The new width of the grid.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The new height of the grid.

ds_grid_resize.description: With this function you can resize the given DS grid to have a different width and/or height. If the grid size is larger than the current grid, the new cells will have a base value of 0, and if the size is smaller then the values held in the cells that are no longer within the new size will be lost. All other cells will be left untouched.

ds_grid_get_disk_min.name: ds_grid_get_disk_min

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: xm
parameters.description: The x position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: ym
parameters.description: The y position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: r
parameters.description: The radius of the disk on the grid.

ds_grid_get_disk_min.description: This function can be used to find the minimum value for all the cells found within the defined disk area of a grid, as shown in the image below:

gpu_set_tex_max_aniso_ext.name: gpu_set_tex_max_aniso_ext

parameters.name: sampler_index
parameters.description: The index of the shader sampler to get

parameters.name: maxaniso
parameters.description: The maximum anisotropic level to use (default: 16).

gpu_set_tex_max_aniso_ext.description: With this function you can set the maximum level of anisotropy when using the tf_anisotropic filter mode (see gpu_get_tex_mip_filter() for more information) on a shader sampler. You supply the index value for the shader sampler (as returned by the function shader_get_sampler_index(), and then a value within the range of 1 and 16 to set the level.

room_goto_next.name: room_goto_next
room_goto_next.description: With this function you can make your game go to the next one as listed in the Room Manager at the time the game was compiled. If this room does not exist, an error will be thrown and the game will be forced to close. Note that the room will not change until the end of the event where the function was called, so any code after this has been called will still run if in the same event.

room_instance_clear.name: room_instance_clear

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the room to clear all instances in.

room_instance_clear.description: This function will clear a room of all instances (no destroy events shall be called for the instances that are being removed). Note that calling this function on a room asset created in the Asset Browser will permanently clear the room of instances, and even calling game_restart() will not return the room to it's original state (only ending the game and opening it again will start with the room in its original state again).

mp_grid_clear_cell.name: mp_grid_clear_cell

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Index of the mp_grid that is to be used

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: Horizontal position of the cell to clear

parameters.name: v
parameters.description: vertical position of the cell to clear

mp_grid_clear_cell.description: This function can be used to clear a specific "cell" of an MP grid. Cells are not calculated as room coordinates, but rather as grid coordinates, where (0,0) is the top let corner of the grid. this means that to clear a cell at a specific position in the room, we must change the x and y coordinates into cell coordinate dividing them by the resolution of the MP grid. The code example below shows how this works.

video_get_status.name: video_get_status
video_get_status.description: This function will return the status of the video

room_set_viewport.name: room_set_viewport

parameters.name: rm
parameters.description: The index of the room to set

parameters.name: vind
parameters.description: The index of the view port to set

parameters.name: vis
parameters.description: The visibility of the view port (true is visible, false is invisible)

parameters.name: xport
parameters.description: The x position for the view port in the room

parameters.name: yport
parameters.description: The y position of the view port in the room

parameters.name: wport
parameters.description: The width (in pixels) of the view port

parameters.name: hport
parameters.description: The height (in pixels) of the view port

room_set_viewport.description: With this function you can set the view port properties for any room in your game except the current one. You supply the room index to set the view port in, the view port index (from 0 to 7) and then whether the view port should be visible at the start of the room or not (set to true to make the port visible, and false otherwise). After that you set the x and y coordinate (corresponding to the top left position of the view port) and then the width and height in pixels.

layer_is_draw_depth_forced.name: layer_is_draw_depth_forced
layer_is_draw_depth_forced.description: This function can be used to retrieve the Z depth set for rendering layers within the room. See layer_force_draw_depth() for more information.

ds_queue_clear.name: ds_queue_clear

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to clear.

ds_queue_clear.description: With this function you can clear all data from the given queue data-structure. This does NOT destroy the data-structure (for that you should use ds_queue_destroy()) it only wipes all data from it and returns an empty queue.

dbg_button.name: dbg_button

parameters.name: label
parameters.description: label to use.

parameters.name: dbgref
parameters.description: reference to the function to call

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: width of button in pixels.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: height of button in pixels.

dbg_button.description: Creates a button within the current debug section, the given method will be called when the button is pressed; it is not split into 2 columns but shown in a single column. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.

clickable_change_ext.name: clickable_change_ext

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the clickable icon to change.

parameters.name: tpe
parameters.description: The texture page entry for the sprite to be used

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The new x position within the window.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The new y position within the window.

parameters.name: scale
parameters.description: The scale of the icon (default 1).

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The image alpha of the icon (default 1).

clickable_change_ext.description: With this function you can change the sprite and position of a clickable icon previously created with clickable_add(). Bear in mind that the position is based on the window, not the canvas, (0,0) position and that the sprite must be referenced directly from the texture page (see: sprite_get_tpe()). This function also permits you to change the scale of the sprite used (as a multiplier so that 1 is the default, 0.5 would be half and 2 would be double) and the alpha value from 0 (fully transparent) to 1 (fully opaque) for the final icon on the screen.

gpu_set_alphatestenable.name: gpu_set_alphatestenable

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable or disable alpha testing (true / false)

gpu_set_alphatestenable.description: This function will enable or disable alpha testing for your game (by default this is disabled). By switching alpha testing on you can then use the companion function gpu_set_alphatestref() to set the "cut-off" value at which all alpha values will be set to 0. The image below shows the difference that can be seen when alpha testing is switched on or off:

part_system_color.name: part_system_color

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system to change the color and alpha of.

parameters.name: color
parameters.description: The new color with which to blend the particle system. c_white is to display it normally.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The new alpha of the particle system (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

part_system_color.description: This function can be used to change color and alpha with which the particle system is blended.

ds_grid_multiply_disk.name: ds_grid_multiply_disk

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: xm
parameters.description: The x position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: ym
parameters.description: The y position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: r
parameters.description: The radius of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to multiply the cells within the disk with.

ds_grid_multiply_disk.description: This function will take all the values in a given disc-shaped region of the DS grid, and multiply each one by the given amount.

achievement_show_challenge_notifications.name: achievement_show_challenge_notifications

parameters.name: receive
parameters.description: Show challenges received pop-up (true) or not (false).

parameters.name: local
parameters.description: Show completed local challenges pop-up (true) or not (false).

parameters.name: remote
parameters.description: Show completed remote challenges pop-up (true) or not (false).

achievement_show_challenge_notifications.description: With this function you can show, or suppress, the various different "toast" pop-up notifications relating to challenges. When the arguments are set to true these messages will appear, informing the player of any local or remote challenges received as well as those challenges that have been completed, while setting them to false will suppress these notifications.

layer_instance_get_instance.name: layer_instance_get_instance

parameters.name: element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the instance element to get the ID of

layer_instance_get_instance.description: This function can be used to get the unique instance ID of the given instance element. You give the instance element ID (see the code example below for how to get this), and the function will return a real value that represents the unique instance id for the element. If the element is not an instance, the function will return -1.

tilemap_get_width.name: tilemap_get_width

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to get the width of

tilemap_get_width.description: Using this function you can retrieve the width (in cells) of the tile map element. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and the function will return the width (number of cells wide).

ds_priority_read.name: ds_priority_read

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to write.

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to write from.

parameters.name: legacy (optional)
parameters.description: Can be either true or false or omitted completely.

ds_priority_read.description: With this function you can recreate a saved DS priority (one that has previously been written as a string using ds_priority_write()). You must first create a new DS priority to read the string into, and if the DS priority already exists and has information stored in it, then this will be cleared before reading. This function is of vital importance when creating save/load mechanisms for your game.

vertex_create_buffer_from_buffer_ext.name: vertex_create_buffer_from_buffer_ext

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to create the vertex buffer from.

parameters.name: format
parameters.description: The primitive vertex format to use.

parameters.name: src_offset
parameters.description: The offset within the the source buffer to copy from.

parameters.name: vert_num
parameters.description: The number of vertices the buffer should have.

vertex_create_buffer_from_buffer_ext.description: As with the function vertex_create_buffer(), this function will create a new vertex buffer, only now the vertex data it stores is copied from the regular buffer that is specified as the source. The buffer is pre-formatted with the vertex format for building primitives for use with (for example) shaders, and you can also supply an offset within the source buffer to copy from and the number of vertices that the final buffer should have. Note that if the number of vertices does not match those being copied you may get corrupted vertex data.

mouse_wheel_down.name: mouse_wheel_down
mouse_wheel_down.description: This function returns true if the mouse wheel is being rotated downwards and false otherwise.

part_system_create.name: part_system_create

parameters.name: partsys
parameters.description: A particle system resource to create an instance of.

part_system_create.description: This function is used to create a new particle system and will return a unique index number that should be stored and used in all further functions relating to that system. The system will be assigned a managed layer and will be set to have a depth of 0. Managed layers are not accessible to the user and used only for internal management when depth is used instead of layers. Normally you would use the function part_system_create_layer() instead of this one.

ds_stack_size.name: ds_stack_size

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to check.

ds_stack_size.description: This function will return the "size" of the stack, ie: the number of items that have been pushed onto it.

network_send_udp.name: network_send_udp

parameters.name: socket
parameters.description: The id of the socket to use.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The url or IP to connect to (a string).

parameters.name: port
parameters.description: The port to connect to.

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The id of the buffer to get the data from.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size (in bytes) of the data.

network_send_udp.description: With this function you can send data over the network using UDP to a server. The function takes the socket id to connect through, the URL to connect to and the port to use. You must then supply the buffer id which contains the data to be sent (for more information on buffers see Reference - Buffers) and finally the size (in bytes) of the data. UDP is "connectionless" in that you don't actually do a connect, you just send a packet directly to an IP, and the server gets incoming data from an IP address and has to deal with it "as is". The function will return the number of bytes of data sent, or a number less than 0 if the send has failed. It is worth noting that the final size of the data being sent that is returned by this function will also include the GameMaker header information, which is an additional 12 bytes.

part_particles_create_colour.name: part_particles_create_colour

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to create the particles.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to create the particles.

parameters.name: parttype
parameters.description: The index (type) of the particles to be created.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour blending for the particles.

parameters.name: number
parameters.description: The number of particles to create.

part_particles_create_colour.description: This function is ideal for those effects that do not require any of the functionality offered by particle emitters (for example, to create smoke from a missile, or a simple explosion effect) as it permits you to quickly and easily create particles at any position in the game room. You can also colour the particles "on the fly" as they are created with this function, and this colour will over-ride the predefined colour of the particle, but it does not blend this colour over the particles lifetime. Note that you must have created the particle system and the particle type previously for this function to be used.

draw_text_ext_transformed_color.name: draw_text_ext_transformed_color

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to draw.

parameters.name: sep
parameters.description: The distance in pixels between lines of text.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The maximum width in pixels of the string before a line break.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scale.

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scale.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle of the text.

parameters.name: c1
parameters.description: The colour for the top left of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c2
parameters.description: The colour for the top right of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c3
parameters.description: The colour for the bottom right of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c4
parameters.description: The colour for the bottom left of the drawn text.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha for the text.

draw_text_ext_transformed_color.description: This function is a combination of the base draw_text() function with the draw_text_ext(), draw_text_transformed() and draw_text_colour() functions. As such, this is the most general of all functions for drawing text and gives a large amount of flexibility when drawing. Note that the "width" argument is based on a scale of 1, so if the scale is different, this value should be changed proportionally. For example, if the base width for a line break is 300 and you set the scale to 2, then the text will appear wrong, over-running the given width. Instead you should have set the width to 150 to compensate the scaling.

draw_get_lighting.name: draw_get_lighting
draw_get_lighting.description: This function will return whether lighting is enabled (true) or not (false) for the whole scene.

layer_destroy.name: layer_destroy

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to destroy (or the layer name as a string)

layer_destroy.description: This function will destroy the given layer. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and this will remove it from the current room. If the layer is one that has been designed in the room editor, then the next time you leave the room and then return, the layer will be recreated again with the original contents, however if the room is persistent, the layer will be removed unless room persistence is switched off again. When you destroy a layer in this way, all it's contents will be removed too, so any reference IDs for backgrounds or tile maps, etc... will no longer be valid and any instances assigned to the layer will be destroyed (performing their Destroy Event at the same time, if they have one, as well as the Clean Up Event).

part_system_automatic_draw.name: part_system_automatic_draw

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system to change.

parameters.name: automatic
parameters.description: Whether automatic drawing is on (true) or not (false).

part_system_automatic_draw.description: This function can be used to switch off the drawing of a particle system so that any updates done to the system (automatic or otherwise) will not be seen. This is a purely visual option and when set to false you will not be able to see the particles as they are not drawn, but they still exists and are changing position, colour etc... as they would normally. When automatic drawing is off, you can explicitly order GameMaker to draw the current state of the particle system using the function part_system_drawit(), and if you set this function to true again you can switch automatic drawing back on.

file_text_open_append.name: file_text_open_append

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The name of the file to append to.

file_text_open_append.description: This function opens the text file with the indicated filename for writing (if the file does not exist, it is created), returning the unique id of the file that which should be stored in a variable as it will be used for all further actions to do with that file. The position within the file for writing to is set to the last line of text that the file contains. Note that if the file can't be created (because of an illegal filename, for example) the function will return -1.

gamepad_button_count.name: gamepad_button_count

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

gamepad_button_count.description: This function will return the total number of buttons available for the gamepad connected to the given device "slot".

arctan2.name: arctan2

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate to calculate.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate to calculate.

arctan2.description: This function returns the inverse tangent of an angle y/x, where y = Opposite side of triangle and x = Adjacent side of triangle. Unlike arctan() the function arctan2(y, x) is valid for all angles and so may be used to convert a vector to an angle without risking division by zero, and it also returns a result in the correct quadrant.

draw_path.name: draw_path

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The path to draw

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where the path is drawn

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where the path is drawn

parameters.name: absolute
parameters.description: Whether the path is drawn at the absolute position (true) or the relative position (false)

draw_path.description: With this function you can get GameMaker to draw a path to the screen. The path will be drawn as a simple line, and can be either relative to the calling instance or at the absolute position it was created at in the path editor or through code. This function is extremely useful when debugging dynamic paths (for example, those created for instances with the mp_grid_path() function).

array_find_index.name: array_find_index

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: function
parameters.description: The function used to perform the search. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return a boolean.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_find_index.description: With this function you can find the index of the first element that returns true to the given predicate. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.

window_mouse_get_x.name: window_mouse_get_x
window_mouse_get_x.description: With this function you can get the x position of the mouse cursor (in pixels) within the browser if it is an HTML5 game or within the display if it is a Windows, Ubuntu (Linux) or macOS game.

date_set_timezone.name: date_set_timezone

parameters.name: timezone
parameters.description: The time zone to use for the base time.

date_set_timezone.description: Sets the base time zone to use for all the rest of the date and time functions. This time zone can either be local (as set by the system) or UTC, and you would use one of the following constants to define which is being used (by default this is local time):

is_handle.name: is_handle

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The argument to check.

is_handle.description: This function returns whether a given variable is a handle that references an internal type.

rollback_start_game.name: rollback_start_game
rollback_start_game.description: This function starts the current game.

animcurve_channel_new.name: animcurve_channel_new
animcurve_channel_new.description: This function creates a new animation curve channel struct.

vertex_format_add_custom.name: vertex_format_add_custom

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The data type that this custom vertex data will hold (see the type constants listed below).

parameters.name: usage
parameters.description: The use that the data will get(see the usage constants listed below).

vertex_format_add_custom.description: This function permits you to use a custom data type for specific vertex format attributes as part of the new vertex format being created. The available values to use are defined by the data type constant that you choose, listed below:

audio_stop_all.name: audio_stop_all
audio_stop_all.description: This function will stop all sounds that are currently playing.

physics_fixture_set_angular_damping.name: physics_fixture_set_angular_damping

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the index of the fixture

parameters.name: damping
parameters.description: the angular damping of the fixture, usually between 0 and 1

physics_fixture_set_angular_damping.description: If you think about any rotating object in the "real world", unless it has a motor or is in space, it slows down over time due to the influence of external forces (like friction with the air around it). We can use the function physics_fixture_set_angular_damping() in GameMaker to simulate this effect and reduce the velocity of rotation of instances in the physics world, as, without it, any rotating instance would continue to rotate infinitely. Damping parameters should be between 0 and infinity, with 0 meaning no damping, and infinity meaning full damping. Normally you will use a damping value between 0 and 1, but you can use any non-negative value if required.

ds_map_copy.name: ds_map_copy

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map you are copying to

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The id of the map you are copying from

ds_map_copy.description: You can use this function to copy the contents of one map into another one that you have previously created using ds_map_create(). If the DS map that is being copied to is not empty, then this function will clear it first before copying. The original DS map remains unchanged by this process.

shader_get_sampler_index.name: shader_get_sampler_index

parameters.name: shader
parameters.description: The index of the shader to use.

parameters.name: uniform
parameters.description: The shader sampler to get the handle of (a string).

shader_get_sampler_index.description: Since you cannot change the value of a shader sampler within the shader itself, you have to set it before calling the shader using one of the available uniform set functions. However, to be able to do that you must first call this function to get the "handle" of the shader sampler that you will want to set.

string_set_byte_at.name: string_set_byte_at

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to change the byte of.

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: The position within the string (starting at 1) to change the byte of.

parameters.name: byte
parameters.description: The new byte value.

string_set_byte_at.description: This function sets a byte directly in a string (based on the UTF8 format) and returns a copy of the string with the changes.

draw_vertex_color.name: draw_vertex_color

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the vertex.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the vertex.

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to draw this vertex with.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha to draw this vertex with (0-1).

draw_vertex_color.description: This function defines the position of a vertex for a primitive, with its own colour and alpha setting. The final look of the primitive will depend on the primitive type chosen to draw and the order with which you add the vertexes to it (see draw_primitive_begin() for more information) and the vertexes with different colours and alphas will blend smoothly from one to the other. To end and draw the primitive you must call draw_primitive_end().

network_resolve.name: network_resolve

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The URL to get the IP of (a string).

network_resolve.description: This function will return the IP address of the given URL.

physics_particle_count.name: physics_particle_count
physics_particle_count.description: This function will return the number of particles that are active in a physics enabled room.

video_pause.name: video_pause
video_pause.description: This function will pause the video

json_encode.name: json_encode

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: a DS map with the information to encode (or an array)

parameters.name: prettify
parameters.description: Whether of not the result JSON string should be prettified. Defaults to false.

json_encode.description: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a lightweight data-interchange format which is easy for to read and write, for both people and machines. It is built on two basic structures:

font_get_name.name: font_get_name

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: Index of the font to check.

font_get_name.description: This function can be used to get the name (as a string) that was given to the font when it was added as an asset to the GameMaker Asset Browser. Please note that this is only a string and cannot be used to reference the font directly - for that you would need the font index.
