You can, however, use this string to get the font index using the returned string along with the function asset_get_index().

layer_script_begin.name: layer_script_begin

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target (or the layer name as a string)

parameters.name: script
parameters.description: The script function index to assign to the layer (or -1)

layer_script_begin.description: With this function you can assign a script function to a layer and it will be called before the layer is rendered. When adding a function to a layer, in this way it will be run at the start of each of the different draw events so you may want to check in the function assigned which event is currently rendering and adapt the code to suit. This can be done by checking the event_type and/or the event_number (see the extended example below). Note that the function is not meant to be called in any draw events or step events, but rather only needs to be called at the start of the room in the Room Creation Code or in the Create Event / Room Start Event of an instance.

sprite_flush.name: sprite_flush

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index (resource name) of the sprite asset to flush

sprite_flush.description: With this function you can remove the given texture page for the given sprite from texture memory. You supply the sprite index (as defined when creating the sprite resource) and the texture page it is assigned to will be removed from texture memory. Note that if the texture page is used elsewhere in the room (by another instance sprite or a background, etc...) you may get a minor performance hit as the page is immediately reloaded, so care should be taken when using this function. Note that the function will return -1 if flush is not supported for the chosen resource, or it will return 0 if all worked correctly.

color_get_saturation.name: color_get_saturation

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The color to check

color_get_saturation.description: This function will return the saturation of the given color. This is the amount of the color tone that is mixed into the final color and is part of the hue, saturation and value (luminosity) method for defining a color. The following image illustrates how this value corresponds to the HSV scale of color:

shader_set_uniform_f.name: shader_set_uniform_f

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: The handle of the shader constant to set.

parameters.name: value1
parameters.description: The floating point value (or values) to set the shader constant to.

parameters.name: value2
parameters.description: The floating point value (or values) to set the shader constant to.

parameters.name: value3
parameters.description: The floating point value (or values) to set the shader constant to.

parameters.name: value4
parameters.description: The floating point value (or values) to set the shader constant to.

shader_set_uniform_f.description: With this function you can set the value (or values) of a shader constant. You must previously have gotten the "handle" of the constant using the function shader_get_uniform(), and you will have to know what type of constant it is to pass the correct number of floating point values through to it, ie: if you have a vec2 you will need to pass two values to the function.

buffer_delete.name: buffer_delete

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to delete.

buffer_delete.description: With this function you can delete a buffer previously have created using the function buffer_create() from memory, releasing the resources used to create it and removing any data that it may currently contain.

http_set_request_crossorigin.name: http_set_request_crossorigin

parameters.name: origin_type
parameters.description: The cross origin type to use (a string)

http_set_request_crossorigin.description: With this function you can set the cross origin type to use when loading images from a file. The function is exclusively for the HTML5 platform and is only useful when loading sprites from a file using the sprite_add() function. Note that when set to "use-credentials" you no longer need to give an absolute path to the sprite being loaded, but instead would give a relative path (as shown in the example below). By default the cross origin type is set to "anonymous".

physics_fixture_set_box_shape.name: physics_fixture_set_box_shape

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the index of the fixture

parameters.name: halfwidth
parameters.description: the half width of the box

parameters.name: halfheight
parameters.description: the half height of the box

physics_fixture_set_box_shape.description: This function defines a box shape for your fixture. It takes the half width and height as the physics world uses this value far more than whole width/height values to determine things like collisions.

network_create_server.name: network_create_server

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of server to create (see the constants listed below).

parameters.name: port
parameters.description: The port that the server will use.

parameters.name: max_client
parameters.description: The maximum number of clients that can connect at once.

network_create_server.description: This function is used to create a new network server for your game, using one of the permitted connection protocols (see the constants listed below). You supply the server type, then give it a port to use, and finally the number of maximum connections that should be permitted at any one time to the server (note that this number is up to you, but too many connected clients will saturate the network or the device CPU won't be able to handle the processing of that number of players, so use with care). The function returns a unique id which should be used stored in a variable and used to identify the server in all further network functions, or a value of less than 0 if the connection fails.

make_colour_hsv.name: make_colour_hsv

parameters.name: hue
parameters.description: The hue of the colour

parameters.name: sat
parameters.description: How saturated the colour is

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: How dark the colour is

make_colour_hsv.description: GameMaker provides this function (as well as others) to permit the user to make their own colours. This particular function takes three component parts, the hue, the saturation and the value (also know as "luminosity") to create the colour desired. These values are taken as being between 0 and 255 so you can make 16,777,216 (256*256*256) colours with this! Below you can see an image of how these components look when separated:

layer_background_stretch.name: layer_background_stretch

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to change

parameters.name: stretch
parameters.description: The stretch toggle, which can be true or false

layer_background_stretch.description: Using this function you can toggle a background element sprite to stretch to fit the room or remain at 1:1 with the resolution. You supply the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and then set the stretch argument to true or false. When set to true the element sprite will be stretched to fit the room (either scaled up or scaled down depending on the sizes of the sprite and the room), and when set to false, the element sprite will be displayed at its native resolution.

physics_particle_get_group_flags.name: physics_particle_get_group_flags

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The particle group to get.

physics_particle_get_group_flags.description: With this function you can retrieve the group flags for a group of particles. The group value is that which was returned when you created the group of particles using the function physics_particle_group_end(), and the function will return a value which is the combined value of the currently set flags.

part_system_angle.name: part_system_angle

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system to change the rotation of.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The new rotation of the particle system in degrees.

part_system_angle.description: This function can be used to change the rotation of the particle system.

surface_create.name: surface_create

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the surface to be created.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height of the surface to be created.

parameters.name: format
parameters.description: The format of the surface to be created.

surface_create.description: This function is used to create a surface and will return the index of the surface which should be stored in a variable for future function calls. When the surface is first created, it may contain "noise" as basically it is just an area of memory that is put aside for the purpose (and that memory may still contain information), so you may want to clear the surface before use with a function like draw_clear_alpha().

gpu_set_tex_mip_enable_ext.name: gpu_set_tex_mip_enable_ext

parameters.name: sampler_index
parameters.description: The index of the shader sampler to get

parameters.name: setting
parameters.description: The mipmap setting (a constant, default: mip_markedonly)

gpu_set_tex_mip_enable_ext.description: With this function you can set whether mipmapping is switched off, switched on for everything or switched on only for texture groups selected in the Texture Group Manager on a shader sampler. You supply the index value for the shader sampler (as returned by the function shader_get_sampler_index(), and then one of the constants listed below.

gamepad_get_mapping.name: gamepad_get_mapping

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: Which gamepad index "slot" to get the mapping from.

gamepad_get_mapping.description: This function can be used to retrieve the mapping string for the gamepad. This string will be either:

ds_grid_add_disk.name: ds_grid_add_disk

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: xm
parameters.description: The x position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: ym
parameters.description: The y position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: r
parameters.description: The radius of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to add to the cells within the disk.

ds_grid_add_disk.description: This function can be used to add a given value (real or string) to all the values of the cells found within the defined disk area of a grid. The value to be added must be of the same type as that held within the grid cells, ie: you cannot add a string to a real or vice-versa, and for strings this corresponds to concatenation.

date_hour_span.name: date_hour_span

parameters.name: date1
parameters.description: The first datetime.

parameters.name: date2
parameters.description: The datetime to compare the first one to.

date_hour_span.description: With this function you can get the number of hours between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete hours will be returned as a fraction.

shader_set_uniform_f_array.name: shader_set_uniform_f_array

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: The handle of the shader constant to set.

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: A previously initialised array of floating point values.

shader_set_uniform_f_array.description: With this function you can set a shader constant to hold an array of values. You must previously have gotten the "handle" of the constant using the function shader_get_uniform(), and you will have to have previously initialised the array.

tilemap_get_frame.name: tilemap_get_frame

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to get the frame index of

tilemap_get_frame.description: Since tiles can be animated, it can sometimes be useful to know which frame is currently being drawn and react accordingly, so with this function you can retrieve the current frame index for a given tile map. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and the function will return the frame index.

ds_grid_set_grid_region.name: ds_grid_set_grid_region

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the destination grid.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The index of the source grid.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The left position of the region of cells to copy from the source grid.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The top position of the region of cells to copy from the source grid.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The right position of the region of cells to copy from the source grid.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The bottom position of the region of cells to copy from the source grid.

parameters.name: xpos
parameters.description: The x position on the destination grid to copy the source region to.

parameters.name: ypos
parameters.description: The y position on the destination grid to copy the source region to.

ds_grid_set_grid_region.description: This function can be used to copy the contents of a rectangular area of grid cells from one (previously defined) DS grid to another, or it can be used to copy a region from within the same grid. The following images illustrate both ways that this function can be used:

window_get_height.name: window_get_height
window_get_height.description: With this function you can get the current height (in pixels) of the game window.

gpu_set_alphatestref.name: gpu_set_alphatestref

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: Sets the reference value for alpha testing from 0 to 255 (default value is 0)

gpu_set_alphatestref.description: This function will set the reference value for the alpha testing (when it has been enabled using the gpu_set_alphatestenable()). This is the "cut-off" threshold at which pixels with alpha will not be drawn.

collision_ellipse_list.name: collision_ellipse_list

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the ellipse to check.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top side of the ellipse to check.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right side of the ellipse to check.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom side of the ellipse to check.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for instance collisions.

parameters.name: prec
parameters.description: Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).

parameters.name: notme
parameters.description: Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).

parameters.name: list
parameters.description: The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.

parameters.name: ordered
parameters.description: Whether the list should be ordered by distance (true) or not (false).

collision_ellipse_list.description: This function is the same as the collision_ellipse() function, only instead of just detecting one instance in collision at a time, it will detect multiple instances. You supply the x/y positions of the top left and bottom right of the elliptical area to check along with the object to check for, and you can set the check to be precise (in which case all instances being checked will need to have precise collision masks) and whether the check should include the calling instance or not.

move_snap.name: move_snap

parameters.name: hsnap
parameters.description: The horizontal snapping (the size in pixels between 'cells').

parameters.name: vsnap
parameters.description: The vertical snapping (the size in pixels between 'cells').

move_snap.description: This function is used to "snap" the instance to a grid of a given size. It will be snapped to the nearest corresponding position on the "invisible" grid that the hsnap and vsnap values define.

draw_line_width_color.name: draw_line_width_color

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width in pixels of the line.

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The colour of the start of the line.

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The colour of the end of the line.

draw_line_width_color.description: With this function you can draw a line of a specific width with the colour blended between colour 1 at the first point and colour 2 at the second point. The colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour(). Please note that the line being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

draw_roundrect_color_ext.name: draw_roundrect_color_ext

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the rounded rectangle.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top of the rounded rectangle.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right of the rounded rectangle.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the rounded rectangle.

parameters.name: xrad
parameters.description: The radius of the curve along the x axis from the rectangle corners.

parameters.name: yrad
parameters.description: The radius of the curve along the y axis from the rectangle corners.

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The center colour.

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The outside edge colour.

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the rectangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

draw_roundrect_color_ext.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rounded rectangle or a filled rounded rectangle where the (x1,y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2,y2) position is the bottom right corner. If the rectangle is filled, then the colour arguments will be used to generate a colour gradient from the centre to the edges, where colour 1 is the centre colour and colour 2 the edge colour. You must also supply radius values for the x and y axis (in pixels) and the corners will be rounded by these amounts. You can define how precise the drawing of the corners is with the function draw_set_circle_precision(). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

path_set_closed.name: path_set_closed

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to change.

parameters.name: closed
parameters.description: Whether the path is closed (true) or not (false).

path_set_closed.description: This function can be used to flag a given path as being open (false) or closed (true). A closed path has its start point connected to its end point, forming a loop, and an open path has a definitive, unconnected start and finish. This function changes the actual path asset, and so will permanently affect how the path is used by all instances in the game from the moment the function is used until the end of the game.If this is not what you require, then you should use a function like path_duplicate() to create a copy of the path first, then call this function on the duplicated asset (don't forget to call path_delete() on the asset when it is no longer required).

skeleton_skin_list.name: skeleton_skin_list

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The sprite index of the Spine skeletal animation to get the list from.

parameters.name: list
parameters.description: The ID of the DS list to populate with the animation names.

skeleton_skin_list.description: With this function you can populate a (pre-created) DS list with all the names of the skins included as part of the skeletal animation sprite. The names will be strings and can then be used in the other skeleton animation skin functions for these types of sprite.

gpu_get_tex_mip_enable_ext.name: gpu_get_tex_mip_enable_ext

parameters.name: sampler_index
parameters.description: The index of the shader sampler to get

gpu_get_tex_mip_enable_ext.description: With this function you can get whether mipmapping is switched off, switched on for everything or switched on only for texture groups selected in the Texture Group Manager on a shader sampler. You supply the index value for the shader sampler (as returned by the function shader_get_sampler_index(), and the function will return one of the constants listed below.

part_system_create_layer.name: part_system_create_layer

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer ID value or string to assign the particle system to (can be any layer type)

parameters.name: persistent
parameters.description: Flag the particle system as persistent (set to true) or not (set to false)

parameters.name: partsys
parameters.description: A particle system resource to create an instance of.

part_system_create_layer.description: This function will create a new particle system on a given layer. You give the unique layer ID as returned by the function layer_create() or the name of the layer to use as a string - for example "instance_layer" - and then flag the system as being persistent or not. If the system is not flagged as persistent then it will be automatically destroyed at the end of the room it was created in (this is the same as if you had called the function part_system_destroy() and will also destroy any emitters associated with the system). However, when flagged as persistent, the system will be carried to the next room when the room is changed, and if the following room does not have a layer with the same name or depth as the one assigned, then a new layer will be created for the system that is persisting across the rooms, and it will be named the same as original layer. When changing rooms, if there is another layer in the following rooms with the same name, then the persisted instance will be assigned to the layer with the that name regardless of the depth of the layer. Finally, if a persisted system moves to a room with a layer at the same depth as the layer the system was created on, it will not be assigned to this layer, but instead a new layer will be created at the same depth (with the same name as the original layer).

keyboard_virtual_hide.name: keyboard_virtual_hide
keyboard_virtual_hide.description: This function can be used to hide the virtual keyboard on the device running the game. Calling this function will generate a System Asynchronous Event, in which the async_load DS map will be populated with the following key/value pairs:

ds_map_values_to_array.name: ds_map_values_to_array

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map to use.

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: OPTIONAL! The array to append the DS map values to.

ds_map_values_to_array.description: With this function you can retrieve all of the values that a DS map contains for each key in the map. You supply the DS map ID to get the keys from (as returned by ds_map_create()) and the function will return an array where each entry in the array is a value from the DS map (for example, if the map has 10 keys, then an array of 10 entries will be returned with each entry corresponding to a value for a key). The function has an optional second argument where you can supply an array that you have created, in which case the map key value data will be appended onto any existing data in the array. Note that the function will modify the array supplied directly, but will also return a reference to it (or a reference to a new array if none is supplied).

matrix_stack_is_empty.name: matrix_stack_is_empty
matrix_stack_is_empty.description: This function can be used to check whether the matrix stack is empty (returns true) or not (returns false).

choose.name: choose

parameters.description: An input value that can be string, integer, variable or constant.

choose.description: Sometimes you want to specify something other than numbers for a random selection, or the numbers you want are not in any real order or within any set range. In these cases you would use choose() to generate a random result. For example, say you want to create an object with a random sprite at the start, then you could use this function to set the sprite index to one of a set of given sprites. Note that you can have as many as you require (note that more arguments will mean that the function will be slower to parse).

timeline_get_name.name: timeline_get_name

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the time line to check the name of.

timeline_get_name.description: This function can be used to get the name of a time line as a string. if the time line has been created dynamically using the timeline_add() function, the name returned will have the format "__newtimelineN" where "N" is the number of the time line (starting from 0). Please note that this is only a string and cannot be used to reference the timeline directly - for that you would need the timeline index. You can, however, use this string to get the timeline index using the returned string along with the function asset_get_index().

ds_list_clear.name: ds_list_clear

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to clear.

ds_list_clear.description: With this function you can clear all data from the given list data-structure. This does NOT destroy the data-structure (for that you should use ds_list_destroy()) it only wipes all data from it and makes the list empty (zero in size). Note that clearing a list will de-reference any data structures stored in it giving a memory leak, so you would need to go through the list and destroy all data structure items manually before clearing it to prevent this. The only time this is not required is when you have flagged any items in the list as another DS list or as a DS map, in which case these items will be destroyed (not cleared!) and their memory cleaned up automatically when the parent is cleared.

audio_get_listener_info.name: audio_get_listener_info

parameters.name: num
parameters.description: The listener number to get the data for.

audio_get_listener_info.description: This function will create a DS map and populate it with information for the given listener.

buffer_get_surface.name: buffer_get_surface

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to use.

parameters.name: surface
parameters.description: The index of the surface to use.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The data offset value (in bytes).

buffer_get_surface.description: With this function you can write information from a surface to a given buffer. The buffer must have been created previously and should be a 1-byte aligned buffer large enough to store data for the surface you are going to write (if unsure, use a grow buffer or see the example at the bottom of this page).

max.name: max

parameters.description: The values to compare.

max.description: This function returns the maximum of the input values, of which it can have up to 16. For example max(12, 96, 32, 75) will return 96 as that is the highest of all the input values.

physics_particle_group_get_y.name: physics_particle_group_get_y

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The particle group to get.

physics_particle_group_get_y.description: With this function you can retrieve the y position in the room of a group of particles. The group value is that which was returned when you created the group of particles using the function physics_particle_group_end(), and the function will return a value which is the combined value of the currently set flags.

string_digits.name: string_digits

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to get the digits from.

string_digits.description: You can use this function to parse a given string and get any numbers from it. For example, say you have this text - "I am 81 years old". With this function you would get a return string of "81".

fx_create.name: fx_create

parameters.name: filter_or_effect_name
parameters.description: The name of the filter/effect to create (as a string).

fx_create.description: This function is used to create a new FX Struct for a given effect type, which contains information on the effect and the values for its parameters.

skeleton_attachment_replace.name: skeleton_attachment_replace

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name (as a string) of the attachment to create.

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The sprite_index to get the attachment image from.

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The image_index to get the attachment image from.

parameters.name: xorigin
parameters.description: The x origin for the image being used.

parameters.name: yorigin
parameters.description: The y origin for the image being used.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling of the image, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling of the image, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: rot
parameters.description: The rotation of the image. 0=normal, 90=turned 90 degrees counter-clockwise etc.

skeleton_attachment_replace.description: When you create you skeletal animation sprite, you can assign attachment slots and attachments to go in them. These are simply images that are apart from the animation but when attached will move along with the bone they are attached to. Normally you would assign these attachments in your animation program (Spine), but with this function you can create/replace your own at run-time using a sprite asset from your game. the function requires that you give the attachment a name (as a string) and then set the sprite_index and image_index to use, as well as the x and y origin (which can be different to that defined by the sprite in the sprite properties), and you can also set any transforms that you wish to be applied to the image when attached. If the attachment was successfully created the function will return 1 and if it was not (you supplied an invalid sprite index, or the base sprite is not a Spine sprite) then it will return -1.

achievement_get_challenges.name: achievement_get_challenges
achievement_get_challenges.description: This function will send a request to the server for information on all current challenges and will trigger a callback Social Asynchronous Event which contains the async_load map populated with the relevant key/value pairs. The id key of this DS Map is used to identify the correct callback (there can be more than one trigger function for any given asynchronous event), and will be paired with the constant achievement_challenge_list_received as well as a number of other key/value pairs for each challenge. The exact contents of the map are shown below:

rollback_get_input.name: rollback_get_input

parameters.name: player_id
parameters.description: The player id to get the input for

rollback_get_input.description: This function returns a struct containing fields w,a,s,d,z,x,c,space,up,left,down,right and the corresponding last_? fields for last frames input.

instance_create_depth.name: instance_create_depth

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position the object will be created at

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position the object will be created at

parameters.name: depth
parameters.description: The depth to assign the created instance to

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object index of the object to create an instance of

parameters.name: var_struct
parameters.description: A structure that contains variables that are copied into the new instance before the Create Event is called

instance_create_depth.description: With this function you can create a new instance of the specified object at any given point within the room and at the depth specified. The depth can be any value, where the lower the depth the "nearer" to the camera things will be drawn and the higher the depth the further away, so an instance at depth -200 will be drawn over an instance at depth +300 (for example).

display_get_orientation.name: display_get_orientation
display_get_orientation.description: This function will return one of two constants GameMaker has to tell you whether the device running the game is being held in landscape or portrait mode (see the table below). Note that this function may not correctly detect the orientation of the device when used in the HTML5 target module. However this is easily mimicked by the use of the following script:

debug_event.name: debug_event

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The custom debug event string to use.

parameters.name: param
parameters.description: Extra configuration parameter.

debug_event.description: This function generates a custom debug event that will be shown in the Graph View of the debugger when a game is being run in Debug Mode. If you require messages to be displayed when not in debug mode, then you should be using show_debug_message(). It is worth noting that the function will also take two reserved strings to help perform debugging using external applications like Visual Studio. These strings are:

part_type_step.name: part_type_step

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: step_number
parameters.description: The quantity of the new particle to create per step.

parameters.name: step_type
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to create.

part_type_step.description: This function can be used to make your particle type stream another type each step until the end of its lifetime. You can set a negative value for the step number and a particle will be emitted at a random interval based on that, so that, for example, a value of -3 will have a 1:3 chance of emitting a particle each step.

array_sort.name: array_sort

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: sorttype_or_function
parameters.description: The sort type (true for ascending or false for descending) or a function reference to use for sorting.

array_sort.description: With this function you can sort an array in ascending order or descending order or using a custom function to define the sort order. The function requires you to provide the array to sort, and then either of the following:

camera_get_proj_mat.name: camera_get_proj_mat

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_proj_mat.description: This function can be used to retrieve the projection matrix. The function returns the matrix ID value which can then be used in other matrix functions or to set the projection matrix of another camera (using camera_set_proj_mat()).

array_intersection.name: array_intersection

parameters.name: array0
parameters.description: The variable that holds the first array.

parameters.name: array1
parameters.description: The variable that holds the second array.
The variable that holds the nth array.

array_intersection.description: With this function you can create an array of elements common to all the input arrays, removing duplicates.

part_type_death.name: part_type_death

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: death_number
parameters.description: The quantity of the new particle to create at the particle death. If a negative value, it will instead create a fraction chance one is created (eg -3 would mean that one is created every 3 or so steps).

parameters.name: death_type
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to create.

part_type_death.description: This function can be used to make your particle burst another type of particle at the end of its lifetime.

layer_exists.name: layer_exists

parameters.name: layer_name
parameters.description: The name of the layer (a string or ID value)

layer_exists.description: This function can be used to check if the given layer exists. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the function will return a boolean value of true if it exists or false if it does not.

audio_emitter_position.name: audio_emitter_position

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to change.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position.

parameters.name: z
parameters.description: The z position.

audio_emitter_position.description: With this function you can change the position of an audio emitter within the 3D audio space. The position will affect the sound in different ways depending on where the listener is positioned within the audio space too (default position is (0, 0, 0). See audio_listener_position() for more information), so for example if the emitter position is set to (100, 0, 0) and the current listener is at (200, 0, 0) the audio streamed from the emitter will appear to be on the left of the audio field. The image below shows a visual representation of emitters and their relative positions to the listener:

gpu_set_state.name: gpu_set_state

parameters.name: ds_map
parameters.description: The GPU state to set as a DS Map.

gpu_set_state.description: This function will set the current GPU state using the passed-in DS Map. The supplied map can be created using the function gpu_get_state().

struct_set.name: struct_set

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The struct reference to set

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the variable to set (as a string)

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to set the variable to

struct_set.description: With this function you can set the value of a given variable in a struct. You supply the struct reference as well as the name of the variable to set the value of as a string (see example code below), and then finally the value to set (can be any valid data type). If the variable does not exist already in the struct it will be created and then assigned the value.

network_send_packet.name: network_send_packet

parameters.name: socket
parameters.description: The id of the socket to use.

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The id of the buffer to get the data from.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size (in bytes) of the data.

network_send_packet.description: With this function you can send a data "packet" through the network. The function takes the socket id to connect through and then you must supply the buffer id which contains the data to be sent (for more information on buffers see Reference - Buffers) and finally the size (in bytes) of the data packet. Packets sent with this function are formatted such that the GameMaker game receiving the data can "split" the packets correctly, and the function will return the number of bytes of data sent, or a number less than 0 if the send has failed. It is worth noting that the final size of the data being sent that is returned by this function will also include the GameMaker header information, which is an additional 12 bytes.

is_string.name: is_string

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The argument to check.

is_string.description: This function returns whether a given variable is a string number or not. In some cases you want to check and see if a variable in GameMaker holds a string and not a real and that's when you would use this function. It does not return the string but rather true or false, so a value of, for example, "fish" for n will return true, but a value of 200 for n will return false.

font_enable_effects.name: font_enable_effects

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the font.

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Whether to enable (true) or disable (false) effects rendering for the specified font.

parameters.name: params
parameters.description: A struct containing any initial values for the font's effect parameters.

font_enable_effects.description: With this function you can enable or disable built-in effects rendering for the specified font. Built-in effects will only have an effect with SDF-enabled fonts.

audio_sound_length.name: audio_sound_length

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to check.

audio_sound_length.description: This function will return the length of the given sound in seconds. The sound can either be a referenced from index for an individual sound being played which has been stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions, or an actual sound asset from the Asset Browser.

place_free.name: place_free

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to check.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to check.

place_free.description: You can use this function to check and see if the calling instance would collide with any instance flagged as solid in your game. Now, it should be noted that for this to work, the instance running the code must have a valid collision mask (either for the sprite itself, or through the mask_index) and it will only register collisions with those solid flagged instances that also have a valid mask.

string_foreach.name: string_foreach

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to iterate over.

parameters.name: func
parameters.description: A function to be called for each character in range (allows arguments 'char' and 'pos').

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: The position to start the iteration from (allows negative values, from end of string).

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: The number of iterations to execute (allows negative values, reverse traversing).

string_foreach.description: This function iterates over each character of a string calling a provided function. It allows to specify a start position (1-based) and a length.

window_set_min_width.name: window_set_min_width

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The minimum width in pixels for the game window.

window_set_min_width.description: This function can be used to set a minimum window width for your game. If you enable the window resize option in the Game Options for the target platform, then the player can resize the game window to any size they wish, however by using this function you can limit the minimum width to the size you specify. If you wish to go back to the default behaviour (ie: no minimum), then use a value of -1.

layer_tilemap_create.name: layer_tilemap_create

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target (or the layer name as a string)

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of the tile map in the room

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of the tile map in the room

parameters.name: tile set
parameters.description: The tile set index to be used

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width tile map (in cells)

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the tile map (in cells)

layer_tilemap_create.description: With this function you can assign a tile-set resource to a layer to be used as a tile map in your project. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and then an initial (x, y) position to add the tile map to the room, the tile set resource to use, and then the width and height of the tile map in cells (ie: a width of 20 and a height of 10 will create a tile map with 200 cells that is 20 cells wide and 10 cells tall), with the size of the cells themselves being defined by the tile set chosen. It is worth noting that you cannot place tiles at negative positions within the tile map, so all tiles must be placed within the cell spaces 0 to width - 1, 0 to height - 1.

buffer_crc32.name: buffer_crc32

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to use.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The data offset value.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the buffer.

buffer_crc32.description: This function will take input data from a buffer and returns a crc32 checksum hash. You specify the buffer ID of the buffer to use, then an offset value (in bytes) for where to begin, and then a size (again in bytes) for the region to be hashed, and the function will return a 32 bit integer value for that region.

external_free.name: external_free

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The name of the dll or dylib that you want to free

external_free.description: This function frees the memory associated with the dll or dylib with the given name. This should be done whenever the file in question is no longer needed in the game, normally (for example) in a Game End event.

ds_list_mark_as_list.name: ds_list_mark_as_list

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the list to mark.

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: The position within the list to mark.

ds_list_mark_as_list.description: This function will "mark" (or "flag") a given position within a previously created DS list as holding another DS list. This functionality is required when encoding JSON strings (which you can create using json_encode()), but can also be useful when nesting data-structures, as items marked in this way will automatically be garbage collected (destroyed) when the parent DS list is destroyed. This means that you do not have to manually go through the list contents and destroy the marked data structures individually before destroying the "parent" list. However, if you delete the list position individually, the DS list it contained will not be garbage collected and you should call the appropriate DS list destroy function before deleting the item from the parent list position. Also note that if you call the function ds_list_clear() on a list, any items flagged as lists will be destroyed as well when the list is cleared.

path_end.name: path_end
path_end.description: Calling this function will end the current path that the instance is following, as set when the function path_start() was called..

string_insert.name: string_insert

parameters.name: substr
parameters.description: The substring to be inserted.

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to be copied.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The position in characters of the string to insert the substring.

string_insert.description: With this function you can create a new string made up of two strings, where one has been inserted into the other at a given position. It can be useful, for example, to add a user name into a predefined text and so make the player of your game feel more involved in the action. Keep in mind when calculating the position to insert into that strings are indexed from 1, so the first character in a string is 1 and not 0 as you may expect.

ds_queue_write.name: ds_queue_write

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to write.

ds_queue_write.description: This function returns a string which can then be stored or transferred to another data structure using the ds_queue_read() function.

screen_save.name: screen_save

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The filename for the screenshot to save

screen_save.description: With this function you can save a screenshot of the game as it currently appears in the game window. The file will be saved to the working directory of the game, which in windows is located at <drive>:/Users/YOURUSERNAME/AppData/Local/[Game Name]/ and on Mac it would be ~/Library/Application Support/[Game Name]/. The image captured will be the final render of the application surface of the game, or (if the app surface has been disabled) it will be an image of the whole display or window. It is important to note that the function is designed to be called in the Draw GUI End Event, which should give consistent results across all platforms. Using it in any other event may not work as expected, and may give different results across different targets and even devices. Should you need more control over what is being saved, you should use the function screen_save_part().

tilemap_get_at_pixel.name: tilemap_get_at_pixel

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to get the tile-data of

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The position along the x-axis to get the tile data from (in room pixels)

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The position along the y-axis to get the tile data from (in room pixels)

tilemap_get_at_pixel.description: Using this function you can retrieve the tile data from a position (within the room) of the tile map element. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()) as well as the x and y position in the room to get the tile data from and the function will return the tile data "blob". This data is essentially a bit mask that contains the tile index, the flip/rotate/mirror booleans and any mask data that has been applied (see tilemap_set_mask() for details), and the resulting data value can then be used in the tile_* functions to change a tiles properties. If you need to get the tile data from a specific tile cell you should be using the function tilemap_get() instead.

layer_get_element_type.name: layer_get_element_type

parameters.name: element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the element to get the type of

layer_get_element_type.description: You can use this function to get the element type for the given element. You supply the unique element ID value (for example, as returned the function that created the element or from the room editor) and the function will return one of the following constants (or -1 if the element does not exist or the ID value is erroneous):

buffer_poke.name: buffer_poke

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to use.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset position (in bytes) within the buffer to write the given data to.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of data that is to be written to the buffer (see the list of constants here).

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The data to add to the buffer, in accordance with the type specified.

buffer_poke.description: With the buffer_write() function, you can write data to the given buffer at the current "seek" position, with each piece of data advancing this position by the bytes being written or read. However, it may be necessary for you to change a given piece of data without wanting to change the current seek position, and that's when you would use this function. You simply supply the function with a buffer index, and then the offset position from the buffer start (in bytes) within that buffer to write to, as well as the data type and the value to be written.

gpu_get_blendmode.name: gpu_get_blendmode
gpu_get_blendmode.description: This function can be used to retrieve the current blend mode being used for drawing. The returned value will be one of the following constants (the default value is bm_normal):

gesture_get_flick_speed.name: gesture_get_flick_speed
gesture_get_flick_speed.description: This function is used to get the speed required for a Flick Gesture event to be triggered when a touch or click is released. The speed is measured in inches per second and has a default value of 2.0.

physics_set_density.name: physics_set_density

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the id of the bound fixture

parameters.name: density
parameters.description: the new density value to apply

physics_set_density.description: When you bind a fixture to an instance using physics_fixture_bind() this returns an "id" for the bound fixture. You can use this id to set the density value of the bound fixture, not the "base" fixture, at any time using this function.

draw_rectangle.name: draw_rectangle

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the top left corner of the rectangle.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top left corner of the rectangle.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the bottom right corner of the rectangle.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom right corner of the rectangle.

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the rectangle is drawn filled (false) or as a one pixel wide outline (true).

draw_rectangle.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rectangle or a filled rectangle where the (x1,y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2,y2) position is the bottom right corner. Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

tilemap_y.name: tilemap_y

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to change

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position for the tile map

tilemap_y.description: This function controls the position along the y-axis of the room of the asset tile map element on the layer. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and then set the y value to use (based on the room coordinates).

layer_background_htiled.name: layer_background_htiled

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to change

parameters.name: htile
parameters.description: The horizontal tiling toggle, which can be true or false

layer_background_htiled.description: Using this function you can change whether the given background element on a layer should be tiled horizontally or not. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and then set the tiling value. If set to true then the element will be displayed tiled horizontally across the room, and when set to false, the element will not be tiled. This function is for 2D projects only, and will not work correctly when a 3D camera projection is used.

tilemap_get_x.name: tilemap_get_x

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to get the x position of

tilemap_get_x.description: Using this function you can retrieve the x position (within the room) of the tile map element. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and the function will return the x-axis position.

skeleton_animation_list.name: skeleton_animation_list

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The sprite index of the Spine skeletal animation to get the list from.

parameters.name: list
parameters.description: The ID of the DS list to populate with the animation names.

skeleton_animation_list.description: With this function you can populate a (pre-created) DS list with all the names of the animations included as part of the skeletal animation sprite. The names will be strings and can then be used in the other animation functions for these types of sprite.

skeleton_bone_state_set.name: skeleton_bone_state_set

parameters.name: bone
parameters.description: The name (as a string) of the bone.

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: The (previously created) DS map that stores the bone data.

skeleton_bone_state_set.description: Your skeletal animation is made up of a number of "bones", which you will have defined and given names to in your animation program, and this function can be used to set certain data for the named bone at any time. Note that this data will set the current pose for the skeleton, depending on the animation set used, and the function requires a previously created DS map, which should have the following keys and their required values:

skeleton_get_minmax.name: skeleton_get_minmax
skeleton_get_minmax.description: This function will return an array with the total bounding box value for all the individual bounding boxes assigned to a skeleton animation sprite. The returned array will have 4 elements:

path_flip.name: path_flip

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to flip.

path_flip.description: This function takes all the path points and flips them along the horizontal axis. This function changes the actual path asset, and so will permanently affect how the path is used by all instances in the game from the moment the function is used until the end of the game.If this is not what you require, then you should use a function like path_duplicate() to create a copy of the path first, then call this function on the duplicated asset (don't forget to call path_delete() on the asset when it is no longer required).

color_get_green.name: color_get_green

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The color to check

color_get_green.description: This function returns the amount of green used to make the given color, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no green and 255 is all green. The following image illustrates this:

skeleton_animation_get_ext.name: skeleton_animation_get_ext

parameters.name: track
parameters.description: The track number to get the animation set name of.

skeleton_animation_get_ext.description: A single skeletal animation sprite can have various animation sets, and these sets can be assigned different tracks so that you can "mix and match" animation sets. This function will return the name of the animation set currently used by the given track number (as set by the function skeleton_animation_set_ext).

ds_grid_sort.name: ds_grid_sort

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid to sort.

parameters.name: column
parameters.description: The column to use for sorting the rows

parameters.name: ascending
parameters.description: Whether to sort lowest to highest (true), or highest to lowest (false).

ds_grid_sort.description: This function can be used to sort a DS grid based on the values from a given column (much as you would sort files by date, size etc... in the OS file explorer). The following image shows an example:

audio_start_sync_group.name: audio_start_sync_group

parameters.name: group_index
parameters.description: The group index to play.

audio_start_sync_group.description: With this function you can start playing a previously created sync group. You need to supply the group index which is the value returned when you created the group using the function audio_create_sync_group().

physics_particle_draw.name: physics_particle_draw

parameters.name: typemask
parameters.description: The mask to compare the particles flags with.

parameters.name: category
parameters.description: The user defined category to draw (use 0 to draw all categories).

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The sprite to use for each particle.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The image_index of the sprite to draw.

physics_particle_draw.description: This function will draw a sprite at the position of all the particles that share the same user defined category value, and that have flags which coincide with those set for the mask. The mask value is defined in the same way as you would define the flags when creating the particle (see the function physics_particle_create() for an example), ie: using the bitwise or "|" to mask off the appropriate bits for each flag.

part_particles_clear.name: part_particles_clear

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system.

part_particles_clear.description: With this function you can clear all the particles currently created by the system from the room. It does not reset or remove the particle types themselves, just their visual representation, and if you have any object streaming particles from an emitter, these particles disappear but will begin to appear again the next step after calling this code.

file_text_eoln.name: file_text_eoln

parameters.name: fileid
parameters.description: The id of the file to check.

file_text_eoln.description: With this function you can get GameMaker to check the currently opened file to see if the line being read has finished. The function returns true if the end of the line has been reached and false otherwise.

gamepad_axis_count.name: gamepad_axis_count

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

gamepad_axis_count.description: This function will return the number of "axis" controls on the device being checked. These controls are the analogue direction "thumbsticks" on most controllers.

draw_light_get.name: draw_light_get

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index number of the light (from 0 to 7)

draw_light_get.description: This function will get the specified light parameters as an array with the following 6 elements -

buffer_resize.name: buffer_resize

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to change the size of.

parameters.name: newsize
parameters.description: The new size of the buffer (in bytes).

buffer_resize.description: With this function you can resize a given buffer to be the size (in bytes) that you specify.

zip_add_file.name: zip_add_file

parameters.name: zip_object
parameters.description: The zip object which the file should be added to.

parameters.name: dest
parameters.description: The destination path within the zip file.

parameters.name: src
parameters.description: The path to the source file to be added.

zip_add_file.description: This function will add a reference to the specified source file with the desired destination path in the specified zip file. The file will be loaded and added to the zip on the call to zip_save().

surface_set_target.name: surface_set_target

parameters.name: surface_id
parameters.description: The ID of the surface to set as the drawing target.

surface_set_target.description: With this function you set all further drawing to the target surface rather than the screen and in this way you can tell GameMaker to only draw specific things to the specified surface. Please note that if you do not call surface_reset_target() after you have finished, nothing will be drawn on the screen as all further drawing (even in other instances) will be done on the surface. You should also realise that nothing will be seen if the surface itself is not drawn on the screen in the draw event of an instance. You can check the return value of this function too as a debug tool to check whether the surface target was set or not, with a return value of 0 being a failure to set the target and any other positive value being a success.

string_trim.name: string_trim

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The input string.

parameters.name: substrs
parameters.description: An array of strings to be used during trimming.

string_trim.description: This function removes whitespace from both ends of a string and returns a new string, without modifying the original string. You can optionally provide an array of strings to be used for trimming if you want to remove something other than whitespaces.

window_get_showborder.name: window_get_showborder
window_get_showborder.description: Returns whether the border around the window is shown in windowed mode.

layer_sequence_get_angle.name: layer_sequence_get_angle

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

layer_sequence_get_angle.description: With this function you supply the sequence element ID - as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions - and it will return the current angle of the sequence element in the game room. Note that angles are returned in degrees, and 0º is to the right, 90º is up, 180º is to the left and 270º is down.

ds_map_delete.name: ds_map_delete

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map to change.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key (along with its associated value) to delete.

ds_map_delete.description: With this function you can remove any given key (and its corresponding value) from the given, previously created, DS map .

gpu_get_tex_mip_bias.name: gpu_get_tex_mip_bias
gpu_get_tex_mip_bias.description: With this function you can retrieve the mipmap bias value, where a value of 0 equals no bias, 1 equals the first mipmap, 2 equals the second mipmap etc... This controls the rate at which the mip map is swapped and will generally make rendered textures blurrier the higher the value and the greater the "distance" being viewed. Note that this can return negative values too, in which case rendered textures will be sharper over a greater distance the lower the value.

static_set.name: static_set

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The struct reference to set.

parameters.name: static_struct
parameters.description: The struct to set as the static

static_set.description: sets the static struct on the given struct.

is_real.name: is_real

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The argument to check.

is_real.description: This function returns whether a given variable is a real number (single, double or integer) or not. In some cases you want to check and see if a variable holds a real number, and that's when you would use this function. It does not return the real number but rather true or false, so a value of, for example, "fish" would return false, however a value of 200 would return true.

gpu_get_tex_mip_filter_ext.name: gpu_get_tex_mip_filter_ext

parameters.name: sampler_index
parameters.description: The index of the shader sampler to get

gpu_get_tex_mip_filter_ext.description: With this function you can get the current mip filter mode for a given shader sampler. You supply the index value for the shader sampler (as returned by the function shader_get_sampler_index(), and the function will return one of the mode value constants listed below.

ds_map_secure_save.name: ds_map_secure_save

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to use

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The name of the file to save the map to

ds_map_secure_save.description: This function will save the contents of the given DS map to a file that is linked to the device it was created on (meaning it can't be read if transferred to any other device). The file itself can have almost any extension (for example, *.dat, *.json, *.bin, etc...) and will be obfuscated and stored to local storage on the target platform. You can then re-load the ds_map using the function ds_map_secure_load(). Note that if the DS map being saved contains an array, this array will be converted into a DS list instead when saved.

gif_open.name: gif_open

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the gif to create

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the gif to create

parameters.name: clear_colour
parameters.description: [Optional] The colour (RGB) to clear the gif to

gif_open.description: With this function you can create an empty GIF format image, ready to have data added to it. When you call the function, you need to specify the width and height of the GIF (in pixels, and there is no upper limit on size except for available memory), and the function will return the unique ID value used to identify the gift in subsequent functions, or it will return -1 if the gif could not be initialized (for example, if the width/height are too big for the memory available). You may also specify an optional argument to set the "clear colour" for the GIF. This is an RGB value (no alpha component), and will clear the gif to this colour before anything is added to it. If you do not supply a clear colour argument, the default colour of black will be used.

ansi_char.name: ansi_char

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The raw byte value.

ansi_char.description: This function returns a string containing the character with raw BYTE value set. This will not, and should not, be displayed, but it will save correctly to disk for use in encoding.

physics_particle_group_get_angle.name: physics_particle_group_get_angle

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The particle group to get.

physics_particle_group_get_angle.description: With this function you can retrieve the rotation (angle) in the room of a group of particles. The group value is that which was returned when you created the group of particles using the function physics_particle_group_end(), and the function will return a value which is the combined value of the currently set flags.

video_get_volume.name: video_get_volume
video_get_volume.description: This function will return the volume 0-1

gpu_set_blendmode_ext_sepalpha.name: gpu_set_blendmode_ext_sepalpha

parameters.name: src
parameters.description: Source blend mode factor for RGB (see constants above).

parameters.name: dest
parameters.description: Destination blend mode factor for RGB(see constants above)

parameters.name: alphasrc
parameters.description: Source blend mode factor Alpha (see constants above).

parameters.name: alphadest
parameters.description: Destination blend mode factor Alpha (see constants above)

gpu_set_blendmode_ext_sepalpha.description: When GameMaker goes to draw a pixel there is a source colour (the colour of the pixel we're going to draw) and a destination colour(the colour that's already in the pixel we're drawing to), so when determining the new colour of the pixel, the source and destination colours are calculated according to the chosen blend mode. Each component of the colours is stored as a floating point value between 0 and 1, and the new colour is calculated by multiply each component of the source colour by some factor and by multiplying each component of destination colour by some other factor and then adding the results together component by component.

date_inc_month.name: date_inc_month

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to add to.

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: The number of months (must be an integer) to add.

date_inc_month.description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of months, and it will return the new datetime value.

draw_ellipse_color.name: draw_ellipse_color

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the ellipse.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top of the ellipse.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right of the ellipse.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the ellipse.

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The colour of the center.

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The colour of the edge.

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the ellipse is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

draw_ellipse_color.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of an ellipse or a filled ellipse by defining a rectangular area that will then have the ellipse created to fit. If it is filled you can define the interior and exterior fill colours. If these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()). You can define how precise the drawing is with the function draw_set_circle_precision().

variable_struct_exists.name: variable_struct_exists

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The struct reference to check

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the struct variable to check for (as a string)

variable_struct_exists.description: With this function you can check whether a variable exists within the given struct or not. You supply the struct reference to use as well as the variable name to check for as a string (see example code below). The function will return true if a variable with the given name exists for the struct and false otherwise.

gesture_get_pinch_angle_towards.name: gesture_get_pinch_angle_towards
gesture_get_pinch_angle_towards.description: This function is used to get the angle within which a touch must be moving towards another touch before a Pinch In Gesture may potentially be started. The angle is measured in degrees and has a default value of 45°.

array_foreach.name: array_foreach

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: function
parameters.description: The function to be executed for each array entry. Accepts the following arguments (value, index).

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_foreach.description: With this function you can execute a method on all or a range of elements in the array. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.

window_set_size.name: window_set_size

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The new width of the window.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The new height of the window.

window_set_size.description: With this function you can change the size of the game window. If you use this function to change the size of the game window, the contents of the window will be scaled to fit with a 1:1 ratio to the background canvas which will keep the image crisp and clear (although scaled if the window is other than the room or view size). For example, if you have a 200 x 150 pixel window, and the player stretches the window by dragging the borders, the final window size may be 400 x 300 pixels, but the drawing canvas is STILL 200 x 150, which gives a blurred image as the pixel ratio is now 1:2. However, if you use this function to set the window size, the 1:1 ratio is maintained, even though the image is scaled to fit the new window size.

layer_sprite_create.name: layer_sprite_create

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to use

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to use

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The sprite index to be used

layer_sprite_create.description: With this function you can assign a sprite resource to a layer to be used in your project. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create() or when you use the layer name along with layer_get_id()), a position within the room, and a sprite index (which would be the name of the sprite as shown in the Asset Browser), and it will be added to the layer. The function returns the unique ID value for the element, which can then be used in further layer functions for sprites.

layer_sprite_xscale.name: layer_sprite_xscale

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to change

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The xscale value (default is 1)

layer_sprite_xscale.description: Using this function you can change whether the given sprite element on a layer should be scaled along the x axis or not. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and then set the scale value. A scale of 1 indicates no scaling (1:1), smaller values will scale down (0.5, for example, will half the width of the sprite used), larger values will scale up, and negative values will flip the sprite and scale it unless the value used is exactly -1 (in which case the sprite used is just flipped right-to-left about its origin position with no scaling).

ds_stack_empty.name: ds_stack_empty

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to check.

ds_stack_empty.description: With this function you can check the given DS stack to see if it is empty (returns true) or not (returns false).

skeleton_animation_is_finished.name: skeleton_animation_is_finished

parameters.name: track
parameters.description: The animation track.

skeleton_animation_is_finished.description: This function will return true if the animation on the given track has finished.

tag_get_asset_ids.name: tag_get_asset_ids

parameters.name: tags
parameters.description: A single asset tag string or an array with various asset tags.

parameters.name: asset_type
parameters.description: An asset type constant (listed above)

tag_get_asset_ids.description:
This function gets all the assets of a given type that have the given tags assigned to them.
			
			You supply either a single tag (as a string) or an array, where each item in the array is a tag (as a string), as well as the type of asset to check.

variable_clone.name: variable_clone

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value to be cloned

parameters.name: depth
parameters.description: The depth to be used during the cloning process (defaults to the maxiumum of 128)

variable_clone.description: This function can accept any kind of data as its first parameter, which represents the variable or data structure to be cloned (won't work for instances). The second parameter, "depth" is applicable only for arrays and structs and sets the level of depth to which the cloning process should be performed (with a maximum value of 128)

draw_surface_stretched_ext.name: draw_surface_stretched_ext

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the surface to draw.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width at which to draw the surface.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height at which to draw the surface.

parameters.name: colour
