parameters.description: The colour with which to colour the surface.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha with which to blend the surface.

draw_surface_stretched_ext.description: This function does exactly the same as the draw_surface_stretched() function with the added ability to set the colour blending and alpha value for the surface when it is drawn (similar to the function draw_surface_ext()).

matrix_build_lookat.name: matrix_build_lookat

parameters.name: xfrom
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the position to look from.

parameters.name: yfrom
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the position to look from.

parameters.name: zfrom
parameters.description: The z coordinate of the position to look from.

parameters.name: xto
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the position to look to.

parameters.name: yto
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the position to look to.

parameters.name: zto
parameters.description: The z coordinate of the position to look to.

parameters.name: xup
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the "up" vector.

parameters.name: yup
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the "up" vector.

parameters.name: zup
parameters.description: The z coordinate of the "up" vector.

matrix_build_lookat.description: This function builds a "look-at" (view) matrix based on the specified parameters listed below. Since this function modifies the view matrix and not the projection matrix, you should first initialize the projection matrix using the other matrix function matrix_build_projection_perspective(), then use this function to move the view camera around within the projection.

path_get_precision.name: path_get_precision

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to check.

path_get_precision.description: This function returns with what precision the given path has been "smoothed", and will be an integer value from 1 to 8. Although you can get (and set) this value for a straight-line path it will have no influence over how an instance uses the path as it is only relevant when the path kind is set to "smooth".

layer_background_get_blend.name: layer_background_get_blend

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to get the information from

layer_background_get_blend.description: This function can be used to get the blend colour of the background element. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and the function will return real value that represents the colour assigned.

nameof.name: nameof

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name to convert to string.

nameof.description: returns the argument as a string, resolved at compile time.

rollback_use_manual_start.name: rollback_use_manual_start
rollback_use_manual_start.description: This function enables manual start, meaning that the game will not automatically start once everyone is connected and instead wait for rollback_start_game to be called.

audio_emitter_bus.name: audio_emitter_bus

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The emitter to link to the audio bus.

parameters.name: bus
parameters.description: The audio bus to link the emitter to.

audio_emitter_bus.description: This function links an emitter to an audio bus. Any sounds played on this emitter will be processed by the audio bus.

ds_grid_height.name: ds_grid_height

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: This index of the grid to find the height of.

ds_grid_height.description: This function will return the height of the given grid. This value is the number of cells the grid has along the y-axis and is always an integer, as shown in the image below:

layer_sprite_exists.name: layer_sprite_exists

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target (or the layer name as a string)

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to check

layer_sprite_exists.description: You can use this function to check and see if a sprite element exists on any given layer. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()) and the function will return either true if the element exists, or false if it does not.

date_compare_datetime.name: date_compare_datetime

parameters.name: date1
parameters.description: The first datetime.

parameters.name: date2
parameters.description: The datetime to compare it to.

date_compare_datetime.description: With this function you can check two dates and times to see which one is the earlier or later than the other. The function returns -1 if date1 is earlier, 1 if date1 is later and 0 if they are the same, although since this takes time into account as well, a 0 for matching is very rare (it literally has to be the same second of the same day of the same month of the same year to return a 0).

clickable_change.name: clickable_change

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the clickable icon to change.

parameters.name: tpe
parameters.description: The texture page entry for the sprite to be used.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The new x position within the window.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The new y position within the window.

clickable_change.description: With this function you can change the sprite and position of a clickable icon previously created with clickable_add(). Please note that the position is based on the window, not the canvas, (0,0) position and that the sprite must be referenced directly from the texture page (see: sprite_get_tpe()).

part_type_colour3.name: part_type_colour3

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: colour1
parameters.description: The colour the particle will start at.

parameters.name: colour2
parameters.description: The colour the particle will be halfway through its lifespan.

parameters.name: colour3
parameters.description: The colour the particle will end at.

part_type_colour3.description: This function can be used to set a three colour gradient for each particle created of the given type. The first colour is that which all particles will start with, and the second colour is the one that will be blended to half way through its lifetime and the third colour is the one with which the particle will end with. A smooth gradient change will occur through the colours over the particles lifetime from one colour to the other.

surface_resize.name: surface_resize

parameters.name: surface_id
parameters.description: The ID of the surface to change.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the new surface.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height of the new surface.

surface_resize.description: This function will resize a surface to the given dimensions (in pixels). The "surface_id" is that of a surface you have created previously, or the application_suface, and the function will resize that surface. Note that this will neither crop nor stretch the contents of the surface, but rather it destroys the current surface and recreates it with the same handle (surface_id) with the new dimensions, meaning that it will need to be cleared and drawn to again (unless it is the application_surface in which case GameMaker will do this automatically).

script_execute_ext.name: script_execute_ext

parameters.name: scr
parameters.description: The name of the function/script that you want to call

parameters.name: array_args
parameters.description: The array containing the arguments for the function/script

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: OPTIONAL! The offset into the argument array

parameters.name: num_args
parameters.description: OPTIONAL! The number of arguments to (from the offset onwards)

script_execute_ext.description: This function works similarly to the function script_execute() only you can supply an array that contains the arguments required for the function/script being called. You may also supply two optional arguments to the function to specify an offset into the array to get the arguments from, as well as the number of arguments to use from the array (this must be a maximum of array_length - offset).

achievement_send_challenge.name: achievement_send_challenge

parameters.name: playerid
parameters.description: The unique ID of the player to challenge.

parameters.name: challengeid
parameters.description: The unique challenge ID (as found on the provider dashboard).

parameters.name: score
parameters.description: The score to beat.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: the type of challenge to be issued - one of two constants given below.

parameters.name: message
parameters.description: The message to attach to the challenge.

achievement_send_challenge.description: This function will send a challenge across the network to the chosen player. You can get the playerid using the achievement_load_friends() or the achievement_load_leaderboard() functions and you must also supply the challengeid which is the unique value given the challenge when you created it on your iTunes Connect or Google Play dashboard. You must also supply a score, and a short text message as well as set the challenge type. This can be one of the following constants:

analytics_event.name: analytics_event

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: A string to send to the provider

analytics_event.description: This function will send the specified text to the analytics provider that you have set up through the HTML5 Game Options. This function can be used to create a custom analytic to track something outside of the scope of the provider being used.

path_get_x.name: path_get_x

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to check.

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: How far through the path to check. Between 0 (start) and 1 (end).

path_get_x.description: With this function you can get the x coordinate of a position on any given path. 0 is the start of the path, 1 is the end of the path, and anything in between equates to that far through the path. This needn't be a defining point of the path, it can be anywhere on it.

ds_grid_set_disk.name: ds_grid_set_disk

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: xm
parameters.description: The x position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: ym
parameters.description: The y position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: r
parameters.description: The radius of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to set with the cells within the disk.

ds_grid_set_disk.description: With this function you can set a circular region of a grid to a certain value. You need to supply a starting grid cell (as an x and y axis coordinate) as well as the radius of the disk to set and the value that you wish to set the disk too, as shown by the illustration below:

part_system_automatic_update.name: part_system_automatic_update

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system to change.

parameters.name: automatic
parameters.description: Whether automatic updating is on (true) or not (false).

part_system_automatic_update.description: This function controls whether GameMaker should update the particle system automatically or not, and normally you would not need to use this function as the default value of true (automatic update is on) is what you wish to happen. However, for special effects or for pausing the game, you can set this to false and it will prevent any updates being carried out on the given particle system unless explicitly commanded by the use of the function part_system_update() or you use this function again to turn automatic updates on. No updating means that particles created in this system will no longer change position, colour or any other parameter and that emitters will cease to work too, "freezing" the system at the exact point in which the automatic update was set to false.

object_set_visible.name: object_set_visible

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the object to change.

parameters.name: vis
parameters.description: The new visibility of the object (true=visible, false=invisible).

object_set_visible.description: With this function you can flag a specific object as being visible or not (for more information on the "visible" flag see the section on the Object Editor). This means that all instances of this object that are created after visible has been changed will be created with this new state, while instances that are already in the room may not be affected.

sqrt.name: sqrt

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The number to get the square root of.

sqrt.description: If you multiply a number with itself, you get the square of that number, but sometimes you want to do the reverse and get the square root of a number. So to find what number has been multiplied with itself to get any given positive value we use this function. For example: sqrt(9) will return 3 since 3*3=9.

layer_sprite_get_id.name: layer_sprite_get_id

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target

parameters.name: sprite_element_name
parameters.description: The unique name of the sprite element on the layer as defined in the Room Editor

layer_sprite_get_id.description: This function can be used to retrieve the unique ID value of a sprite element on a layer. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create() or when you use the layer name along with layer_get_id()) and the name of the sprite element as defined in the Room Editor. The function will return the ID value associated with that sprite element on the layer.

matrix_build_projection_perspective.name: matrix_build_projection_perspective

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the projection at the near Z position.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height of the projection at the near Z position.

parameters.name: znear
parameters.description: The near clipping plane.

parameters.name: zfar
parameters.description: The far clipping plane.

matrix_build_projection_perspective.description: This function builds a perspective projection matrix based on the dimensions of the near clipping plane, using the specified parameters listed below.

draw_set_color.name: draw_set_color

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to set for drawing.

draw_set_color.description: With this function you can set the base draw colour for the game. This value will affect all further drawing where appropriate, including fonts, forms, primitives and 3D. If any of those assets are drawn with their own colour value changed, this value will be ignored.

cloud_string_save.name: cloud_string_save

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The data string to be uploaded.

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: A brief description of the data being stored.

cloud_string_save.description: This function will commit a string to the chosen cloud service for storage. The function will return a unique id value that should then be used in the appropriate asynchronous event to identify the DS map that is returned as a "call back" from the cloud service. The string should contain all the information that you need to save for your game as you can only store one single "data blob" to the cloud, and running this function again will overwrite any previously stored values (as will using the cloud_file_save() function). The description should be a short string of information that describes the save, eg: "Level2, Stage2".

color_get_blue.name: color_get_blue

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The color to check

color_get_blue.description: This function returns the amount of blue used to make the given color, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no blue and 255 is all blue. The following image illustrates this:

camera_get_view_speed_y.name: camera_get_view_speed_y

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_view_speed_y.description: This function can be used to retrieve the movement speed of the given camera along the y axis (vertical movement). The return value will be in pixels per game frame.

buffer_base64_decode_ext.name: buffer_base64_decode_ext

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to decode the string into.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The base64 encoded string to decode.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The data offset value.

buffer_base64_decode_ext.description: With this function you can decode a base64 encoded string (created using the buffer_base64_encode() function) into a buffer. Unlike the function buffer_base64_decode(), this will not create a buffer for you, but rather you should already have created the buffer (see buffer_create()), the id of which you would then use with this function. The "offset" is the position within the buffer to decode the given string (in bytes).

room_set_view_enabled.name: room_set_view_enabled

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the room to set.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: Whether to enable (true) or disable (false) views in the given room.

room_set_view_enabled.description: With this function you can enable (true) or disable (false) the view of any room within your game except the current one.

physics_fixture_set_density.name: physics_fixture_set_density

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the index of the fixture

parameters.name: density
parameters.description: the density of the fixture calculated as kg/m²

physics_fixture_set_density.description: The density of something is defined as its mass per unit volume, which basically means how much mass is crammed into the space it takes up in the world. So, a balloon would have a low density as it has little mass that occupies a large space, while a lead bar would have a high density as it has a great mass, yet occupies little space.

string_join.name: string_join

parameters.name: delimiter
parameters.description: The delimiter to use when joining the values.
The values be joined using the delimiter.

string_join.description: This function joins a set of arguments using the provided delimiter, non-string values will be converted to string.

audio_is_paused.name: audio_is_paused

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to check.

audio_is_paused.description: This function will check the given sound to see if it is currently paused. The sound can either be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions) or a sound asset, in which case all instances of the given sound will be checked and if any of them are paused the function will return true otherwise it will return false.

font_add_get_enable_aa.name: font_add_get_enable_aa
font_add_get_enable_aa.description: This function can be used to check whether anti-aliasing (AA) is enabled for fonts added using font_add(). The function will return true if AA is enabled, and false if it is not. Note that AA is enabled by default, but you can change the AA state for added fonts using the function font_add_enable_aa(), as long as it is called before adding the font.

texture_get_uvs.name: texture_get_uvs

parameters.name: texid
parameters.description: The image asset to get the texture from

texture_get_uvs.description: This function returns a 1D array with 4 elements representing the UV coordinates for the image on the texture page, filling in the array with the following values:

ds_map_replace_map.name: ds_map_replace_map

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the ds_map to use.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to replace.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The id of the ds_map to use to replace the one previously stored in the given key.

ds_map_replace_map.description: With this function you can replace a DS Map that has been stored in the given "key" with another map that has been created previously. This function is designed for creating JSON compatible maps which you would then encode using json_encode() and should only be used in conjunction with that functionality.

frac.name: frac

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The number to change.

frac.description: This function returns the fractional part of n, that is, the part behind the decimal dot. It will return only the decimals behind the dot of a value, so frac(3.125) will return 0.125, frac(6.921) will return 0.921, etc...

draw_set_valign.name: draw_set_valign

parameters.name: valign
parameters.description: Vertical alignment.

draw_set_valign.description: This function is used to align text along the vertical axis and changing the vertical alignment will change the position and direction in which all further text is drawn, with the default value being fa_top. The following constants are accepted:

gpu_set_colourwriteenable.name: gpu_set_colourwriteenable

parameters.name: red
parameters.description: Enable/disable the red channel

parameters.name: green
parameters.description: Enable/disable the green channel

parameters.name: blue
parameters.description: Enable/disable the blue channel

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: Enable/disable the alpha channel

gpu_set_colourwriteenable.description: With this function you can switch on or off the colour channels and the alpha channel for all further drawing. For example, you can use this function to create alpha-channel only surfaces (switch off the RGB writing before using the surface), or to create special effects while drawing to the screen. The default value for each of the components is true, and can be supplied as either four unique arguments or as a 4 element 1D array with the following elements in it which will be either true (enabled) or false (disabled):

array_unique.name: array_unique

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_unique.description: With this function you can create a new array with only unique values. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.

os_powersave_enable.name: os_powersave_enable

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: Set to true or false to enable or disable powersave functions.

os_powersave_enable.description: With this function you can turn on or off the power saving features of the device. This is important as certain games (for example those that use the tilt functions) may not generate events that the OS can interpret as being user input and so shut down the screen or exit the game. By setting this function to false you can disable the power saving features and ensure that the screen (and game) are always functioning.

path_shift.name: path_shift

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to change.

parameters.name: xshift
parameters.description: The number of horizontal pixels to shift the path. Negative=left, positive=right.

parameters.name: yshift
parameters.description: The number of vertical pixels to shift the path. Negative=up, positive=down.

path_shift.description: With this function you can shift a path along the horizontal and vertical axis. Please note that this will have no visible effect in-game if the instance following the path being shifted follows it relatively (rather than absolutely) as the path's position is disregarded then. This function changes the actual path asset, and so will permanently affect how the path is used by all instances in the game from the moment the function is used until the end of the game. If this is not what you require, then you should use a function like path_duplicate() to create a copy of the path first, then call this function on the duplicated asset (don't forget to call path_delete() on the asset when it is no longer required).

vertex_float4.name: vertex_float4

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to write the information to.

parameters.name: float
parameters.description: The first input value.

parameters.name: float
parameters.description: The second input value.

parameters.name: float
parameters.description: The third input value.

parameters.name: float
parameters.description: The fourth input value.

vertex_float4.description: This function will add four floating point values to the vertex data. The vertex must have been formatted correctly to accept this using the vertex_format_add_custom() function.

ds_map_empty.name: ds_map_empty

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to check.

ds_map_empty.description: This function will simply return false if the specified (previously created) DS map contains any key/value pairs, or true if it does not.

camera_apply.name: camera_apply

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera.

camera_apply.description: This function will apply the given camera settings to the current camera view being rendered immediately. While you can set any view camera using the specific camera_set_* functions, the new settings will not be used for rendering until the next game frame, but with this function you can make those changes immediately. If you are using multiple views then the function should be used in the Draw Event and you can use the variable view_current to selectively apply the given camera only to the camera view currently being rendered. Note that this does NOT change the camera ID value, only the settings for that camera, and that if you use this function on the default camera (ie: the internal camera GameMaker uses when no view cameras are active) the changes will be overwritten the very next game frame by the internal settings for drawing the room.

clamp.name: clamp

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to clamp.

parameters.name: min
parameters.description: The minimum value to clamp between.

parameters.name: max
parameters.description: The maximum value to clamp between.

clamp.description: With this function you can maintain an input value between a specified range.

path_get_number.name: path_get_number

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to check.

path_get_number.description: This function can be used to return the number of points on a path.

physics_particle_group_polygon.name: physics_particle_group_polygon
physics_particle_group_polygon.description: This function will set the shape of the particle group that is being created. You must first have begun the group definition using the function physics_particle_group_begin(), and then you would use this function to tell GameMaker that you are going to add in the approximate points that will be used to define the polygon shape - approximate because the exact shape will depend on the size of the base particles, as defined by the physics_particle_set_radius() function, as the physics simulation tries to "fit" as many of the particles as possible into the defined shape.

event_inherited.name: event_inherited
event_inherited.description: This function will call the current event of the parent object of the instance. Normally, when an instance has a parent object, it automatically inherits all the same events as the parent, but if (for example) your parent object has a create event and you add one to your child object, all instances of the child object will run the new create event that you have added and not that which is in the parent object. Should you need to use both the parent object event and the child object event of the same type, you should use this function as it will run the parent object event before continuing with the rest of the code or actions that the child event contains.

skeleton_bone_data_set.name: skeleton_bone_data_set

parameters.name: bone
parameters.description: The name (as a string) of the bone.

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: The (previously created) DS map that stores the bone data.

skeleton_bone_data_set.description: Your skeletal animation is made up of a number of "bones", which you will have defined and given names to in your animation program, and this function can be used to set certain data for the named bone at any time. Note that this data refers to the default pose for the skeleton, and not the current pose that is being drawn (for that use the function skeleton_bone_state_set()), and must be set from a previously created DS map, which should have the following keys and their equivalent values:

buffer_save.name: buffer_save

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to save.

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The name of the file to save as.

buffer_save.description: With this function you can save the contents of a buffer to a file, ready to be read back into memory using the buffer_load() function.

darctan2.name: darctan2

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate to calculate.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate to calculate.

darctan2.description: This function returns the inverse tangent of an angle y/x, where y = Opposite side of triangle and x = Adjacent side of triangle. Unlike darctan() the function darctan2() is valid for all angles and so may be used to convert a vector to an angle without risking division by zero, and it also returns a result in the correct quadrant.

directory_create.name: directory_create

parameters.name: dname
parameters.description: The name of the directory to create.

directory_create.description: This function will creates a directory with the given name in the save area.

font_delete.name: font_delete

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the font to delete.

font_delete.description: With this function you can delete a font asset from the game. This is a permanent removal, and changing rooms, or restarting the game will not bring the removed font back. For that the player would need to exit the game and restart that way, so take care when using this function. In general it is only needed for freeing up memory that has been used by a font added to the game through the functions font_add() or font_add_sprite().

dbg_sprite.name: dbg_sprite

parameters.name: dbgrefSprite
parameters.description: reference to the variable for the sprite index

parameters.name: dbgrefSpriteIndex
parameters.description: reference to the variable for the image index

parameters.name: label
parameters.description: label to use.

dbg_sprite.description: Creates a sprite view of the specified sprite with the specified index within the current debug section. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.

gesture_rotate_angle.name: gesture_rotate_angle
gesture_rotate_angle.description: This function is used to set the angle which a pair of touches must exceed in order to trigger a Rotate Start Gesture. The angle is measured in degrees and has a default value of 5°.

date_month_span.name: date_month_span

parameters.name: date1
parameters.description: The first datetime.

parameters.name: date2
parameters.description: The datetime to compare it to.

date_month_span.description: With this function you can get the number of months between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete months will be returned as a fraction.

sprite_get_texture.name: sprite_get_texture

parameters.name: spr
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to use.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The sub-image of the sprite to use.

sprite_get_texture.description: This function returns a special pointer for the sprite texture page. This value can then be used in other draw functions, particularly in the 2D primitive functions, as well as the Shader functions. You can get more information about the returned texture page using the different texture_ functions found here.

variable_instance_exists.name: variable_instance_exists

parameters.name: instance_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the instance to check

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the variable to check for (as a string)

variable_instance_exists.description: With this function you can check whether an instance scope variable exists or not. You supply the unique instance ID value (which can be found from the Instance Properties in the room editor, or is returned when you call the function instance_create_layer()) as well as the variable name to check for as a string (see example code below). The function will return true if a variable with the given name exists for the instance and false otherwise.

instance_find.name: instance_find

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to find the nth instance of

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The number of the instance to find.

instance_find.description: All instances have a unique identifier (id) which can be used to modify and manipulate them while a game is running, but you may not always know what the id for a specific instance is and so this function can help as you can use it to iterate through all of them to find what you need. You specify the object that you want to find the instance of and a number, and if there is an instance at that position in the instance list then the function returns the id of that instance, and if not it returns the special keyword noone. You can also use the keyword all to iterate through all the instances in a room, as well as a parent object to iterate through all the instances that are part of that parent / child hierarchy, and you can even specify an instance (if you have its id) as a check to see if it actually exists in the current room. Please note that as instances are sorted in an arbitrary manner, there is no specific order to how the instances are checked by this function, and any instance can be in any position.

display_get_frequency.name: display_get_frequency
display_get_frequency.description: This function returns the frequency (or refresh rate) of the display that the game is being played on. It will return a real value as frames-per-second, so for example if your monitor is 60hz you will get 60, if it's running at 144hz then you will get 144, and so on.

part_emitter_exists.name: part_emitter_exists

parameters.name: ps
parameters.description: The particle system to check for an emitter.

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to search for.

part_emitter_exists.description: With this function you can check to see if the given particle emitter indexed exists in the given system or not. Note that if the variable being checked is an uninitialised variable (that a particle emitterwould otherwise have its index assigned to) this will throw an error.

shader_enable_corner_id.name: shader_enable_corner_id

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable (true) or disable (false) this function.

shader_enable_corner_id.description: With this function you can set a global state for all shaders being used where, when enabled, the shader "steals" 2 bits from the input colour values. The first is from the lower bit of the red colour value, and the second is from the lower bit of the blue colour value. These values can get then be recovered in the shader to work out which vertex you are dealing with (ie: which corner).

asset_has_tags.name: asset_has_tags

parameters.name: name_or_index
parameters.description: The name of the asset (a string) or its index value (an integer).

parameters.name: tags
parameters.description: A single asset tag string or an array with various asset tags.

parameters.name: asset_type
parameters.description: OPTIONAL! The type of asset to check the tags for, only used when supplying an index for the first argument.

asset_has_tags.description:
This function checks if one or more tag strings is assigned to the given asset from the Asset Browser.
			
			You supply either the asset name (as a string) or its asset index, as well as either a single tag string or an array where each item is a single tag string. If you supply an asset index value, then you will need to supply the optional asset type argument (a constant), as assets of different types can have the same index, even though they cannot have the same name.

network_create_socket_ext.name: network_create_socket_ext

parameters.name: protocol
parameters.description: The network protocol to use

parameters.name: port
parameters.description: The port to use

network_create_socket_ext.description: This function is used to create a new client socket for your game to communicate over the network. You must define the socket protocol (see the list of constants below) and give a port to use, and the function will return a unique id which should be used in all further function calls for that socket, or a value of less than 0 if the connection fails.

ds_priority_delete_max.name: ds_priority_delete_max

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the priority queue to use.

ds_priority_delete_max.description: This function will return the value that has the highest priority in the queue and then remove the value (and priority) from the data structure. If more than one value has the same priority, then any one of them could be returned in any order, but all other values with the same priority will still be in the queue.

variable_instance_get_names.name: variable_instance_get_names

parameters.name: instance_id/global
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the instance to check or the keyword global

variable_instance_get_names.description: With this function you can retrieve an array populated with the instance variable names for an instance, or the global variables for a game. When you pass in an instance ID value, each entry in the array will be a string of the variable name that corresponds to an instance scope variable that has been created in the instance. However if you pass in the keyword global, each entry in the array will be a string of the variable name that corresponds to an global scope variable.

ds_stack_pop.name: ds_stack_pop

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to pop from.

ds_stack_pop.description: This function will pop the top value off of the DS stack , removing it from the stack and returning the value to be stored in a variable. If the stack is empty then the function will return the constant undefined, otherwise it will return the real or string value contained in the stack.

lengthdir_x.name: lengthdir_x

parameters.name: len
parameters.description: The length away of the point to return.

parameters.name: dir
parameters.description: The direction of the point to return.

lengthdir_x.description: This function is used to get the x component of a position "len" pixels from the starting point and in direction "dir". If you imagine a circle around your instance, and then imagine a point anywhere on that circle, to move to that point we need to move the object so many pixels in that direction... so this function (when used with lengthdir_y()) gets the position of that point on the circle to be used in code by the instance. See the image below for details:

fx_get_parameter_names.name: fx_get_parameter_names

parameters.name: filter_or_effect
parameters.description: The FX struct to get the parameter names of

fx_get_parameter_names.description: This function is used to retrieve the name of a filter/effect from its struct.

date_is_today.name: date_is_today

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to use.

date_is_today.description: This function will return true if the given datetime value is the day it is being checked on (ie: today), or false otherwise. This can be a handy function for things like Easter Eggs in your games, or for unlocking seasonal content. Note that this function will be affected by the time zone set (default is local time) which you can change using the date_set_timezone() function.

skeleton_get_bounds.name: skeleton_get_bounds

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The bounding box index to get the values of.

skeleton_get_bounds.description: This function will return an array of values associated with any given bounding box for the currently assigned skeleton animation sprite. You supply the index number for the bounding box to get the details of (you can retrieve the total number of bounding boxes for the sprite using the function skeleton_get_num_bounds()) and the function will return an array with the following elements:

draw_sprite_general.name: draw_sprite_general

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to draw.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

parameters.name: left
parameters.description: The x position on the sprite of the top left corner of the area to draw.

parameters.name: top
parameters.description: The y position on the sprite of the top left corner of the area to draw.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the area to draw.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the area to draw.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: rot
parameters.description: The rotation of the sprite. 0=normal, 90=turned 90 degrees counter-clockwise etc.

parameters.name: c1
parameters.description: The colour with which to blend the top left area of the sprite.

parameters.name: c2
parameters.description: The colour with which to blend the top right area of the sprite.

parameters.name: c3
parameters.description: The colour with which to blend the bottom right area of the sprite.

parameters.name: c4
parameters.description: The colour with which to blend the bottom left area of the sprite.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha of the sprite (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

draw_sprite_general.description: This function combines the function draw_sprite_ext() with the function draw_sprite_part(), adding in some additional blending options so that each corner of the final sprite part can be blended with an individual colour.

call_later.name: call_later

parameters.name: period
parameters.description: How long to wait before invoking the callback

parameters.name: units
parameters.description: The units that the period is measured in

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The callback to be invoked

parameters.name: repeat
parameters.description: Whether this should repeat indefinitely

call_later.description: Invokes a callback after the specified time. Returns a handle which can be used to cancel the call.

alarm_set.name: alarm_set

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The alarm index to set, from 0 to 11.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value (an integer) to set the alarm to.

alarm_set.description: This function can be used to set an alarm. You supply the alarm number from 0 to 11, and then the value to set the alarm to. The value must be an integer value, and you can set it to -1 to stop the alarm (non integer values will be rounded to the nearest integer). This is an alternative method to setting the alarm array directly.

buffer_create_from_vertex_buffer_ext.name: buffer_create_from_vertex_buffer_ext

parameters.name: vertex_buffer
parameters.description: The vertex buffer index to use.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of buffer to create (see the constants list below).

parameters.name: alignment
parameters.description: The byte alignment for the buffer

parameters.name: start_vertex
parameters.description: The starting vertex.

parameters.name: num_vertices
parameters.description: The total number of vertices to copy.

buffer_create_from_vertex_buffer_ext.description: You use this function to allocate a portion of memory as a buffer in your game filled with the data from a previously created vertex buffer. The function returns a unique buffer id that should be stored in a variable and used for all further function calls to the buffer. The function takes the id for the vertex buffer to use (as returned by the function vertex_create_buffer(), for example) with the following constants being used to define the buffer type:

draw_surface_part_ext.name: draw_surface_part_ext

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the surface to draw.

parameters.name: left
parameters.description: The left position in the surface of the part to be drawn.

parameters.name: top
parameters.description: The top position in the surface of the part to be drawn.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the part to be draw, from left.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height of the part to be drawn, from top.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling the part should be drawn with.

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling the part should be drawn with.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour blending the part should be drawn with.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha transparency the part should be drawn with.

draw_surface_part_ext.description: This function will draw a part of the chosen surface at the given position following the same rules as per draw_surface_part(), only now you can scale the part, blend a colour with it, or change its alpha when drawing it to the screen (the same as when drawing a surface with draw_surface_ext()).

matrix_build_projection_perspective_fov.name: matrix_build_projection_perspective_fov

parameters.name: fov
parameters.description: The angle of the field of view.

parameters.name: aspect
parameters.description: The aspect ratio of the field of view.

parameters.name: znear
parameters.description: The near clipping plane.

parameters.name: zfar
parameters.description: The far clipping plane.

matrix_build_projection_perspective_fov.description: This function builds a perspective projection matrix matrix based on field of view, using the specified parameters listed below.

is_undefined.name: is_undefined

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The argument to check.

is_undefined.description: This function returns whether a given variable is defined or not. In some cases you want to check and see what data type a variable holds in GameMaker and that's when you would use this function. It returns true or false depending on whether the value is defined or not.

texture_prefetch.name: texture_prefetch

parameters.name: tex_id
parameters.description: The texture page ID (an integer) or a texture group ID (a string)

texture_prefetch.description: This function can be used to "prefetch" a texture page or a group of texture pages, ie: load them into VRAM when required. You supply the unique texture page ID (as returned by the texturegroup_* functions) to prefetch a single page, or you can supply a texture group name (as defined in the Texture Group Editor) to prefetch all the texture pages in the group.

view_set_camera.name: view_set_camera

parameters.name: view_port
parameters.description: The view port to target (0 - 7)

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

view_set_camera.description: This function will set a camera to a specific view port. You give the view port to set (from 0 to 7), and supply the unique camera ID value (as returned by the camera_create() functions or when you use view_get_camera()). If you give a value of -1 as the camera ID then you are removing a camera from the view port and note that if that view port is enabled and visible you may get some unpredictable results.

mouse_check_button_pressed.name: mouse_check_button_pressed

parameters.name: numb
parameters.description: Which mouse button constant to check for.

mouse_check_button_pressed.description: This function will return true if the mouse button being checked has been pressed or false if it has not. This function will only be triggered once for any mouse button when it is first pressed and to trigger it again the button will need to have been released and pressed again. Note that it will be considered triggered for the duration of the step, and for all instances that have any mouse events or that use this same function.

get_integer.name: get_integer

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to show in the pop-up message.

parameters.name: def
parameters.description: The default value in the text box.

get_integer.description: This function has being deprecated and is now obsolete (use get_integer_async instead). Calls to this function will produce a warning message.

layer_background_get_visible.name: layer_background_get_visible

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to get the information from

layer_background_get_visible.description: This function can be used to get the visible state of the background element. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and the function will return either true if the element is currently visible, or false if it is not. Note that this return value is not affected by whether the layer the element is on is visible or not.

layer_sprite_get_blend.name: layer_sprite_get_blend

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to get the information from

layer_sprite_get_blend.description: This function can be used to get the blend colour of the sprite element. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and the function will return real value that represents the colour assigned.

string_trim_end.name: string_trim_end

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The input string.

parameters.name: substrs
parameters.description: An array of strings to be used during trimming.

string_trim_end.description: This function removes whitespace from the end of a string (right). You can optionally provide an array of strings to be used for trimming if you want to remove something other than whitespaces.

gpu_get_texrepeat.name: gpu_get_texrepeat
gpu_get_texrepeat.description: With this function you can check to see whether texture repeating is enabled (returns true) or not (returns false). For more information on texture repeating, see the function gpu_set_texrepeat().

tile_set_empty.name: tile_set_empty

parameters.name: tiledata
parameters.description: the tile-data to set

tile_set_empty.description: This function can be used to set a given set of tile-data to be an empty tile. You give the tile-data, which can be retrieved using the function tilemap_get(), and the function will return true if the tile is empty, or false if there is a tile index. The function will return a modified tile-data set which can then be applied using the tilemap_set() function.

gpu_set_tex_mip_filter_ext.name: gpu_set_tex_mip_filter_ext

parameters.name: sampler_index
parameters.description: The index of the shader sampler to get.

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description: The mip filter mode to use (a constant, default: tf_point).

gpu_set_tex_mip_filter_ext.description: With this function you can set the mip filter mode for a given shader sampler. You supply the index value for the shader sampler (as returned by the function shader_get_sampler_index(), and then one of the mode value constants listed below.

dbg_view.name: dbg_view

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: name of the debug view

parameters.name: visible
parameters.description: true if view is visible, false otherwise

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: x position to place the view window, -1 means position anywhere

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: y position to place the view window, -1 means position anywhere

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: width of the view window, default is 500

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: height of the view window, default is 400

dbg_view.description: Declare a new debug view that can be accessed from the debug overlay.

ds_priority_clear.name: ds_priority_clear

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to clear.

ds_priority_clear.description: With this function you can clear all data from the given priority queue data-structure. This does NOT destroy the data-structure (for that you should use ds_priority_destroy()) it only wipes all data from it and returns an empty priority queue.

array_map.name: array_map

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: function
parameters.description: The function to be executed for mapping the values. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return the mapped value.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_map.description: With this function you can create a new array by mapping the current array elements using the given predicate. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.

path_get_point_x.name: path_get_point_x

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to check.

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The point identity to check.

path_get_point_x.description: This function will return the x position (in room coordinates) of the point that you input for the path that you index. If the point is outside of the range of the path (ie: a path has 8 points and you ask for the x position of point 10) then a value of 0 will be returned.

layer_sprite_y.name: layer_sprite_y

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to change

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position for the sprite

layer_sprite_y.description: This function controls the position along the y-axis of the room of the asset sprite element on the layer. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and then set the y value to use (based on the room coordinates).

gesture_double_tap_time.name: gesture_double_tap_time

parameters.name: time
parameters.description: The time (in seconds) to set for double tap gesture event detection.

gesture_double_tap_time.description: This function is used to set the time it takes between two touches/clicks to trigger a Double Tap Gesture event. The time is measured in seconds and has a default value of 0.16.

ds_map_is_map.name: ds_map_is_map

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the ds_map to use.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to replace.

ds_map_is_map.description: With this function you can check to see if a DS map is stored in the given map key. If the given key contains a DS map ID, then the function will return true otherwise it will return false.

layer_background_get_vtiled.name: layer_background_get_vtiled

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to get the information from

layer_background_get_vtiled.description: This function can be used to find out if the background element is tiled vertically or not. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and the function will return either true if the element is currently tiled, or false if it is not.

audio_get_type.name: audio_get_type

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to check.

audio_get_type.description: When adding audio to GameMaker it can be either streamed or in memory. If you need to know whether a given sound index is for streamed audio or not you can use this function which will return 1 for streamed, 0 for sound in memory, and -1 if there is any error or the index does not point to a valid sound resource.

ds_priority_delete_min.name: ds_priority_delete_min

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the priority queue to use.

ds_priority_delete_min.description: This function will return the value that has the lowest priority in the queue and then remove the value (and priority) from the data structure. If more than one value has the same priority, then any one of them could be returned in any order, but all other values with the same priority will still be in the queue.

gpu_set_tex_max_mip.name: gpu_set_tex_max_mip

parameters.name: maxmip
parameters.description: The maximum mipmap level (default: 16)

gpu_set_tex_max_mip.description: With this function you can set the currently set maximum mipmap level which is to be used, where a value of 0 is the highest resolution, 1 is to use the first mipmap, 2 is the second etc... Note that this can be quite useful for avoiding bleeding artifacts when rendering textures, for example, setting the texture page border to 8px and then setting the max mipmap level to 3 will ensure you don't get any bleeding problems at greater render distances.

clickable_set_style.name: clickable_set_style

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the clickable icon to style.

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: The index of the DS Map to set the style from.

clickable_set_style.description: This function lets you set the CSS style properties for the given button via the key/value pairs in the provided DS Map. You need to have previously created the both the button element (using clickable_add()) and the DS Map and supply the stored indices to each as arguments.

buffer_load_async.name: buffer_load_async

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to load.

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The name of the file to load.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset within the buffer to load to (in bytes).

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the buffer area to load (in bytes).

buffer_load_async.description: With this function you can load a file that you have created previously using the buffer_save() function (or any of the other functions for saving buffers) into a buffer. The "offset" defines the start position within the buffer for loading (in bytes), and the "size" is the size of the buffer area to be loaded from that offset onwards (also in bytes). You can supply a value of -1 for the size argument and the entire buffer will be loaded. Note that the function will load from a "default" folder, which does not need to be included as part of the file path you provide. This folder will be created if it doesn't exist or when you save a file using buffer_save_async().

get_string.name: get_string

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to show in the pop-up message.

parameters.name: def
parameters.description: The default string in the text box.

get_string.description: This function has being deprecated and is now obsolete (use get_string_async instead). Calls to this function will produce a warning message.

layer_get_script_end.name: layer_get_script_end

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target (or the layer name as a string)

layer_get_script_end.description: This function returns the script function index of the function assigned to run at the end of rendering the given layer, or it will return -1 if no function is assigned. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact). You can assign script functions to a layer with layer_script_begin() and layer_script_end().

parameters.name: ident
parameters.description: The unique ID of the leaderboard as shown on the developer dashboard.

parameters.name: minindex
parameters.description: The starting index value to get the leaderboard data from.

parameters.name: maxindex
parameters.description: The maximum index value to get the leaderboard data from.

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description: Whether to filter the results to those that are on your friends list or to all players (see the Description below)

physics_particle_group_join.name: physics_particle_group_join

parameters.name: to
parameters.description: The first particle group to join.

parameters.name: from
parameters.description: The second particle group to join.

physics_particle_group_join.description: With this function you can join two particle groups together, and the joined groups will then behave as if they were both part of a single entity. The groups should have been created with over-lapping edges, as, if they are not already touching, they will not be joined. The function takes the unique group IDs of the groups to join, as returned by the function physics_particle_group_end(), and you can use the function any number of times for a single group to join various soft bodies together.

draw_enable_swf_aa.name: draw_enable_swf_aa

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable (true) or disable (false) AA for all SWF sprites.

draw_enable_swf_aa.description: With this function you can enable or disable anti-aliasing (AA) for SWF format vector sprites. AA simply smooths the edges of vector images to give them a nicer look. The amount of AA used will depend on the value set using the function draw_set_swf_aa_level(). By default this is disabled.

part_type_alpha3.name: part_type_alpha3

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: alpha1
parameters.description: The starting alpha of the particle.

parameters.name: alpha2
parameters.description: The halfway point alpha of the particle.

parameters.name: alpha3
parameters.description: The ending alpha of the particle.

part_type_alpha3.description: This function can be used to set a three alpha (transparency) value gradient for each particle created of the given type. The first alpha is that which all particles will start with, and the second alpha is the one that will be blended to half way through its lifetime and the third alpha is the one with which the particle will end with. A smooth gradient change will occur through the alphas over the particles lifetime from one to the other.

layer_create.name: layer_create

parameters.name: depth
parameters.description: The depth that the layer has to be created at.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name to give the layer (a string - optional)

layer_create.description: This function is used to create a new layer within the current room. You supply the depth that the new layer is to occupy and the function returns the unique Layer ID value that can then be used to access the layer in further functions. You can also supply an optional "name" argument, which will enable you to give the layer a specific name (as a string), and instead of using the layer ID to access the layer, you can use this name string instead, although it should be noted that using name strings will have a greater impact on performance than using just the ID value. If you do not specify the name of the layer, then the created layer will be assigned a name with the format "_layer_XXX", where "XXX" is a hex value used to give the layer a unique name.

script_execute.name: script_execute

parameters.name: scr
parameters.description: The name of the function/script that you want to call
The different arguments that you want to pass through to the function/script

script_execute.description: This function was originally designed for calling script assets in a dynamic way, but with the introduction of user-defined functions it can now be used in two ways:

view_get_xport.name: view_get_xport

parameters.name: view_port
parameters.description: The view port to target (0 - 7)

view_get_xport.description: This function can be used to retrieve the x position of the given view port.

radtodeg.name: radtodeg

parameters.name: rad
parameters.description: The radians to convert.

radtodeg.description: Once you have done your calculations using sin, or cos etc... the result is in radians. This may not always be what you want and so to turn the radians into degrees we use this function. For example, radtodeg(sin(180)) will return -45 degrees. This function translates radians into degrees using the formula:

matrix_stack_push.name: matrix_stack_push

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: The matrix index to use.

matrix_stack_push.description: This function pushes the specified matrix onto the matrix stack.

gpu_set_texrepeat_ext.name: gpu_set_texrepeat_ext

parameters.name: sampler_id
parameters.description: The sampler id from the shader.

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable or disable texture filtering (true / false)

gpu_set_texrepeat_ext.description: This function can be used to set whether a single sampler "slot" repeats the given texture when using Shaders in GameMaker . Setting it to true will repeat the texture if the uv coordinates are out with the 0-1 range, while a setting of false will mean no repeating. The likely use case for these functions is for repeating a texture in 3D but in order for it to work and not pull images from the rest of the texture page, the sprite used will need to be marked as being on a "Separate Texture Page" in the Sprite Editor.

mp_grid_draw.name: mp_grid_draw

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Index of the mp_grid that is to be drawn

mp_grid_draw.description: This function will draw the specified MP grid (as defined by mp_grid_create()), marking free cells as green and forbidden cells as red. This function is essential as a debug tool but it should be noted that it is very slow and only works when used in the draw event of the instance, and that you can set the draw alpha to change the opacity of the grid, permitting you to draw it as an overlay and see what is actually in the room at the same time.

view_set_wport.name: view_set_wport

parameters.name: view_port
parameters.description: The view port to target (0 - 7)

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The new width (in pixels)

view_set_wport.description: This function can be used to set the width of the given view port. You give the view port index (from 0 to 7) and the new width to use.

path_exists.name: path_exists

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to check for.

path_exists.description: his function returns whether a path with the given index exists or not. Note that if you check for the existence of a path through a variable that has yet to have been declared, this will throw an error.

ds_priority_delete_value.name: ds_priority_delete_value

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the priority queue to use.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to delete from the priority queue.

ds_priority_delete_value.description: This function will simply delete the given value, along with its priority, from the indexed priority queue.

struct_exists.name: struct_exists

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The struct reference to check

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the struct variable to check for (as a string)

struct_exists.description: With this function you can check whether a variable exists within the given struct or not. You supply the struct reference to use as well as the variable name to check for as a string (see example code below). The function will return true if a variable with the given name exists for the struct and false otherwise.

draw_arrow.name: draw_arrow

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the end of the line (where the arrowhead ends).

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the end of the line (where the arrowhead ends).

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The length of the arrow in pixels.

draw_arrow.description: This function will draw an arrow from point (x1,y1) to point (x2,y2). The stem of the arrow is drawn along these points with the actual arrow head being drawn at the end, where the size of the arrowhead is defined by the argument "size" and is calculated as being part of the stem so that the end point is always aligned with the position defined by x2,y2. The width of the arrow head is calculated automatically in proportion to the length.

animcurve_channel_evaluate.name: animcurve_channel_evaluate

parameters.name: channel_struct
parameters.description: The struct pointer for the channel to evaluate.

parameters.name: posx
parameters.description: The position in time to check (from 0 to 1).

animcurve_channel_evaluate.description: This function gets the value at a specific point in time from a channel struct.

achievement_show_leaderboards.name: achievement_show_leaderboards
achievement_show_leaderboards.description: This function will open the leaderboards page for the chosen platform. Please note that this is an asynchronous function, ie: your game will continue to run in the background while the leaderboards page is being shown. As such, you should be careful where you use this and make sure to pause the game or only permit it to be shown in areas of your game where it will not interfere with the game-play.

abs.name: abs

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The number to turn absolute.

abs.description: This function returns the absolute value of the input argument, so if it's a positive value then it will remain the same, but if it's negative it will be multiplied by -1 to make it positive.

fx_set_parameters.name: fx_set_parameters

parameters.name: filter_or_effect
parameters.description: The FX struct to modify

parameters.name: parameter_struct
parameters.description: A struct containing the parameters for the filter/effect

fx_set_parameters.description: This function is used to change the parameters of a filter/effect. You specify an FX struct (as returned from fx_create() or layer_get_fx()) and a struct containing its parameters (as returned from fx_get_parameters()).

rollback_get_info.name: rollback_get_info

parameters.name: player_id
parameters.description: The player id to get the info for

rollback_get_info.description: This function returns a struct containing player_name and avatar_url for the player.

ds_stack_clear.name: ds_stack_clear

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to clear.

ds_stack_clear.description: With this function you can clear all data from the given stack data-structure. This does NOT destroy the data-structure (for that you should use ds_stack_destroy()) it only wipes all data from it and returns an empty stack.

ds_stack_top.name: ds_stack_top

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to read from.

ds_stack_top.description: This function will only read the first value of the stack (that which is "on top"). It will not pop the value, meaning that it can still be read in the future by this function or the ds_stack_pop(). If the stack is empty then the function will return the constant undefined, otherwise it will return the real or string value contained in the stack.

audio_play_sound.name: audio_play_sound

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to play.

parameters.name: priority
parameters.description: Set the channel priority for the sound.

parameters.name: loop
parameters.description: Sets the sound to loop or not.

parameters.name: gain
parameters.description: Sets the gain of the sound played.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: Sets the start offset (in seconds) of the sound played.

parameters.name: pitch
parameters.description: Sets the pitch of the sound played.

parameters.name: listener_mask
parameters.description: Sets the listener mask of the sound played.

audio_play_sound.description: With this function you can play any sound resource in your game. You provide the sound index and assign it a priority, which is then used to determine how sounds are dealt with when the number of sounds playing is over the limit set by the function audio_channel_num(). Lower priority sounds will be stopped in favour of higher priority sounds, and the priority value can be any real number (the actual value is arbitrary, and can be from 0 to 1 or 0 to 100, as GameMaker will prioritize them the same). Note that when dealing with priority, the higher the number the higher the priority, such that a sound with priority 100 will be favoured over a sound with priority 1. The final argument is for making the sound loop and setting it to true will make the sound loop until it is stopped and setting it to false will play the sound once only.

tilemap_get_height.name: tilemap_get_height

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to get the height of

tilemap_get_height.description: Using this function you can retrieve the height (in cells) of the tile map element. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and the function will return the height (number of cells wide).

gamepad_button_check_released.name: gamepad_button_check_released

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

parameters.name: button
parameters.description: Which gamepad button constant to check for.

gamepad_button_check_released.description: This function will return true or false depending on whether the given gamepad button is detected as having been released or not. Note that this function will only trigger once for the button the moment it has been released. For it to trigger again the button must first be pressed and then released once more. If you are checking an analogue button, then the check will take into consideration the threshold setting and only return true when the raw input value goes under the given threshold (you can get this raw value using the function gamepad_button_value()).

audio_system_is_available.name: audio_system_is_available
audio_system_is_available.description: This function can be used to check and see if the audio system has been initialised, or if the audio context is running. On all platforms, this function will return true immediately after Game Start when the audio engine is initialised, except on the Opera GX and HTML5 targets. On Opera GX and HTML5, the audio context status can change at any time depending on user input, the browser being used, and its version, so this function can be used to check and see if audio can be played or not. If the function returns false (ie: the audio context status is not running), then only unstreamed sounds may play (but it's not guaranteed, and you should assume that no audio can be played), while if it returns true then all audio will play.

matrix_build.name: matrix_build

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x component of the translation vector.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y component of the translation vector.

parameters.name: z
parameters.description: The z component of the translation vector.

parameters.name: xrotation
parameters.description: The angle to rotate around the x-axis (in degrees °).

parameters.name: yrotation
parameters.description: The angle to rotate around the y-axis (in degrees °).

parameters.name: zrotation
parameters.description: The angle to rotate around the z-axis (in degrees °).

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The x scale amount.

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The y scale amount.

parameters.name: zscale
parameters.description: The z scale amount.

matrix_build.description: This function can be used to create your own custom matrix and will return an index value for this new matrix which should be stored in a variable for future reference and use. The matrix itself is created as 16 value array where the first 4 elements are row 1, the second 4 elements are row 2 etc... of a 4x4 matrix.

os_get_config.name: os_get_config
os_get_config.description: This function returns the name (as a string) of the currently selected configuration for your game. For more information on configurations please see the section Configurations.

device_is_keypad_open.name: device_is_keypad_open
device_is_keypad_open.description: This does a check of the device for a keypad and if one is available it returns true otherwise it returns false. Please note that this function is mainly for use with Android devices

sprite_add_ext.name: sprite_add_ext

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The name (a string file path) of the file to add.

parameters.name: imgnum
parameters.description: Use to indicate the number of sub-images (1 for a single image or for a *.gif).

parameters.name: xorig
parameters.description: Indicate the x position of the origin in the sprite.

parameters.name: yorig
parameters.description: Indicate the y position of the origin in the sprite.

parameters.name: prefetch
parameters.description: Indicates whether the sprite should be loaded to GPU memory.
