sprite_add_ext.description: With this function you can asynchronously add an image as a sprite, loading it from an external source where the image file to be loaded should always be in either *.png, *.gif, *.jpg/jpeg or *.json format (*json files are used for loading skeleton animation sprites made with Spine). The function returns the new sprite index which must then be used in all further code that relates to the sprite. This function will generate an Image Loaded asynchronous event when the sprite has been loaded. See this page for more information.

draw_set_lighting.name: draw_set_lighting

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: enable or disable all lighting (true or false)

draw_set_lighting.description: This function is used to enable all lighting effects. Default is disabled (false).

draw_sprite_part.name: draw_sprite_part

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to draw.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

parameters.name: left
parameters.description: The x position on the sprite of the top left corner of the area to draw.

parameters.name: top
parameters.description: The y position on the sprite of the top left corner of the area to draw.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the area to draw.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the area to draw.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

draw_sprite_part.description: With this function you can draw part of any sprite at a given position within the room. As with draw_sprite() you can specify a sprite and a sub-image for drawing, then you must give the relative coordinates within the sprite of the area to select for drawing. This means that a left position of 0 and a top position of 0 would be the top left corner of the sprite and all further coordinates should be taken from that position. The image below shows an example of how this works:

skeleton_animation_is_looping.name: skeleton_animation_is_looping

parameters.name: track
parameters.description: The animation track.

skeleton_animation_is_looping.description: This function will return true if the animation on the given track is looping.

cloud_file_save.name: cloud_file_save

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The file to be uploaded (as a string).

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: A brief description of the data being stored.

cloud_file_save.description: This function will commit a file to the chosen cloud service for storage. The function will return a unique id value that should then be used in the appropriate asynchronous event to identify the DS map that is returned as a "call back" from the cloud service. The file should contain all the information that you need to save for your game as you can only store one single "data blob" to the cloud, and running this function again will overwrite any previously stored values (as will using the cloud_string_save() function). The description should be a short string of information that describes the save, eg: "Level2, Stage2".

window_set_position.name: window_set_position

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to position the window.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to position the window.

window_set_position.description: With this function you can set the game window to a specific position within the display (on macOS, Linux(Ubuntu) and Windows) or within the browser (HTML5).

window_view_mouse_get_y.name: window_view_mouse_get_y

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the view to compare the mouse position to.

window_view_mouse_get_y.description: This function will return the mouse y position relative to the view selected.

matrix_build_identity.name: matrix_build_identity
matrix_build_identity.description: This will build a 4x4 identity matrix with the following structure:

place_snapped.name: place_snapped

parameters.name: hsnap
parameters.description: The horizontal snapping to check.

parameters.name: vsnap
parameters.description: The vertical snapping to check.

place_snapped.description: With this function you can check and see if the origin of an instance (its x and y position) is aligned to a grid with the hsnap and vsnap values specified by you.

sprite_get_speed_type.name: sprite_get_speed_type

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to get the animation type of

sprite_get_speed_type.description: This function can be used to retrieve the sprite animation type as defined for the sprite resource in the Sprite Editor. The value returned will be one of the following constants:

draw_vertex_colour.name: draw_vertex_colour

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the vertex.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the vertex.

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to draw this vertex with.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha to draw this vertex with (0-1).

draw_vertex_colour.description: This function defines the position of a vertex for a primitive, with its own colour and alpha setting. The final look of the primitive will depend on the primitive type chosen to draw and the order with which you add the vertexes to it (see draw_primitive_begin() for more information) and the vertexes with different colours and alphas will blend smoothly from one to the other. To end and draw the primitive you must call draw_primitive_end().

screen_save_part.name: screen_save_part

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The filename for the screenshot to save

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the top left corner of the area of the screen to capture

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top left corner of the area of the screen to capture

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the area of the screen to capture

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height of the area of the screen to capture

screen_save_part.description: With this function you can save a screenshot of a part of the game as it currently appears in the game display. The selection coordinates are based on the absolute size of the display (or window if not fullscreen), so (0,0) is always the top left hand corner of the screen (or window). Below is an image that shows how this function works:

texturegroup_get_status.name: texturegroup_get_status

parameters.name: groupname
parameters.description: The name of the texture group to check (a string)

texturegroup_get_status.description: With this function you can retrieve the load status of the specified texture group. You supply the texture group ID string (as defined in the texture Group Editor) and the function will return a value indicating the status.

arctan.name: arctan

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The angle (in radians) to return the inverse tangent of.

arctan.description: Returns the inverse tangent of x. This will accept any number as, unlike tan(), arctan() asymptotes are on the y axis so it just means you'll never get returned a number greater than pi/2 or less than -pi/2.

path_get_length.name: path_get_length

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to measure.

path_get_length.description: You can use this function to get the exact length of a path in pixels. this is not an approximate length from point to point, but rather an exact length along the shape of the path, even when the path is smooth with a high curved precision.

layer_sequence_play.name: layer_sequence_play

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

layer_sequence_play.description: With this function you can start the playback of the given sequence. You supply the sequence element ID as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions and the function will play the sequence, which you can then pause if required using the function layer_sequence_pause().

json_parse.name: json_parse

parameters.name: json
parameters.description: The JSON to parse (a string)

json_parse.description: This function can be used to parse a JSON string (either previously created using json_stringify or from any valid source), and convert it into a collection of arrays or structs, where an array is the equivalent of a JSON array and a struct is the equivalent of a JSON object. You supply the string to parse, and the function will return the top level array or struct which can then be checked in your code. If you are not sure of the contents of the JSON, you can use the different Variable Functions (like typeof() or variable_struct_get_names()) to check the returned contents. Note that trying to parse an invalid value (ie: not a string) will throw an exception error.

physics_world_update_speed.name: physics_world_update_speed

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: the number of times per second that the physics system updates

physics_world_update_speed.description: GameMaker updates things based on the room speed, so that if you set it to ,say, 30, GameMaker will run 30 steps in the course of a second. However, for the physics functions that may not be enough and you may want things to be updated at a slightly faster speed to increase stability or precision. To that end we use the function physics_world_update_speed() which sets the update speed for the physics system independently of the room speed. This means that you could have a room speed of 30, but set the physics to 60, effectively doubling the speed at which the physics system updates and performs its calculations compared to the speed at which the step are updated.

sprite_set_cache_size_ext.name: sprite_set_cache_size_ext

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to change the cache size of.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The sub-image of ind to change the cache size of.

parameters.name: max
parameters.description: The maximum number of cached copies of the sprite that can be stored.

sprite_set_cache_size_ext.description: When performing image blending, HTML5 cannot do it dynamically in the same way an executable could be performed. Therefore GameMaker has to temporarily save a blended copy of the image and load it in. This function sets how many blended copies of the given sprite can be cached before old ones are overwritten. Default is 4. This is applied to one single given sub-image of the sprite.

ds_grid_get_disk_max.name: ds_grid_get_disk_max

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: xm
parameters.description: The x position of the disk center in the grid.

parameters.name: ym
parameters.description: The y position of the disk center in the grid.

parameters.name: r
parameters.description: The radius of the disk in the grid.

ds_grid_get_disk_max.description: This function can be used to find the maximum value for all the cells found within the defined disk area of a grid, as shown in the image below:

gamepad_get_device_count.name: gamepad_get_device_count
gamepad_get_device_count.description: This function will tell you one of two things; Either the number of game pads connected, or the number of available "slots" for game pads to be connected to. The actual return value will depend on the platform and the internal configuration of that platform and as such this function should be used in conjunction with the function gamepad_is_connected() to make sure of the exact number of pads connected at any time.

array_reverse_ext.name: array_reverse_ext

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_reverse_ext.description: With this function you can mutate an existing array reversing the elements order. This function returns the number of reversed elements. This function allows a custom range definition.

tile_set_mirror.name: tile_set_mirror

parameters.name: tiledata
parameters.description: the tile-data to set

parameters.name: mirror
parameters.description: Set to true to mirror and false to leave it as-is

tile_set_mirror.description: This function can be used to set a given set of tile-data to mirror the tile or not. You give the tile-data, which can be retrieved using the function tilemap_get(), and then set the mirror argument to either true if you want the tile mirrored, or false if you want the tile to be in its default, un-mirrored state. The function will return a modified tile-data set which can then be applied using the tilemap_set() function.

array_shuffle.name: array_shuffle

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when shuffling the array. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: How many entries should be shuffled. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_shuffle.description: With this function you can shuffle an array (or subsection), a new array is returned that is a copy of the original with the entries shuffled.

clickable_delete.name: clickable_delete

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: Index of the clickable icon to remove.

clickable_delete.description: This function must be used to remove a clickable icon previously created with clickable_add() from the game window.

http_get_file.name: http_get_file

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The web address of the server that you wish to get file from

parameters.name: local_target
parameters.description: The local storage path to save the file to

http_get_file.description: With this function, you can connect to the specified URL in order to retrieve information in the form of a file. As this is an asynchronous function, GameMaker will not block while waiting for a reply, but will keep on running unless it gets callback information. This information will be in the form of a string and will trigger an Async Event in any instance that has one defined in their object properties.

instance_activate_object.name: instance_activate_object

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object or instance to activate (the keyword all can also be used).

instance_activate_object.description: With this function you can activate a single instance or all instances of a specific object from all those that have been deactivated previously. Note that if you have deactivated an instance or object that has been flagged as Persistent, then you will need to reactivate it again with this function before changing room, otherwise it will not be carried over and will be discarded instead. Note too that activation is not instantaneous, and an instance that has been activated in this way will not be considered to be active until the end of the event in which the function was called.

physics_particle_group_get_centre_x.name: physics_particle_group_get_centre_x

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The particle group to get.

physics_particle_group_get_centre_x.description: With this function you can retrieve the x component of the center of mass of an entire group of particles. The group value is that which was returned when you created the group of particles using the function physics_particle_group_end(), and the function will return a value which is the combined value of the currently set flags.

audio_sound_get_listener_mask.name: audio_sound_get_listener_mask

parameters.name: soundid
parameters.description: The unique ID of the sound to get the mask of

audio_sound_get_listener_mask.description: This function will return the bit-mask data that defines which audio listeners a sound should be played from. See the section on Audio Listeners for more information.

display_set_sleep_margin.name: display_set_sleep_margin

parameters.name: milliseconds
parameters.description: The number of milliseconds for the sleep margin

display_set_sleep_margin.description: This function can be used to set the sleep margin value used for the render timing of your game, and requires a millisecond value. The default values are as follows:

dbg_slider_int.name: dbg_slider_int

parameters.name: dbgref
parameters.description: reference to the variable to change

parameters.name: minimum
parameters.description: minimum value

parameters.name: maximum
parameters.description: maximum value

parameters.name: label
parameters.description: label to use.

dbg_slider_int.description: Creates a slider for an integer value within the current debug section, minimum and maximum values can be specified. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.

sprite_set_cache_size.name: sprite_set_cache_size

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to change the cache size of.

parameters.name: max
parameters.description: The maximum number of cached copies of the sprite that can be stored.

sprite_set_cache_size.description: When performing image blending, HTML5 cannot do it dynamically in the same way an executable could be performed. Therefore GameMaker has to temporarily save a blended copy of the image and load it in. This function sets how many blended copies of the given sprite can be cached before old ones are overwritten. Default is 4. This is applied to all sub-images of the sprite.

device_mouse_x.name: device_mouse_x

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.

device_mouse_x.description: This function returns the x position of a touch on the device. If you are running this on a the HTML5 or PC and Mac modules then this value is updated constantly, as long as the device (usually a mouse) is plugged in, however for mobile devices, this will only be updated while the screen is being touched and note that the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs. Also note that on HTML5 only "device 0" will function correctly and other devices may give wrong values.

move_contact_all.name: move_contact_all

parameters.name: dir
parameters.description: The direction to move in.

parameters.name: maxdist
parameters.description: The maximum distance the object can travel (-1 or 0 a default value of 1000 pixels).

move_contact_all.description: This function will move the instance running the code a set number of pixels in the specified direction until it meets any other instance with a valid mask. You can use -1 or 0 for the maxdist being a default 1000px, ie: GameMaker will move the instance continually up 1000 pixels until it is out of collision.

ds_stack_create.name: ds_stack_create
ds_stack_create.description: This function will create a new stack data-structure and return the index value. This value should be stored in a variable and used in all further function calls relating to the stack.

time_source_destroy.name: time_source_destroy

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

parameters.name: destroy_tree
parameters.description: Whether to destroy all of the children of the time source too

time_source_destroy.description: Destroys the time source, as long as it has no children.

draw_roundrect_color.name: draw_roundrect_color

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the rounded rectangle.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top of the rounded rectangle.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right of the rounded rectangle.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the rounded rectangle.

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The center colour.

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The outside edge colour.

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the rectangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

draw_roundrect_color.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rounded rectangle or a filled rounded rectangle where the (x1,y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2,y2) position is the bottom right corner. If it is filled you can define the individual colours for the centre and the edges, and if these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()).You can define how precise the drawing of the corners is with the function draw_set_circle_precision(), but the corners are always drawn with a fixed radius. Should you need to change the corner radius you should use the function draw_roundrect_colour_ext(). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

point_distance.name: point_distance

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first component of the vector

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the first component of the vector

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the second component of the vector

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the second component of the vector

point_distance.description: This function returns the length of a vector formed by the specified components [x1,y1] and [x2,y2]. For example, in the image below if we want to get the distance between the player ship position and the enemy position so that we can calculate if the enemy is close enough to shoot at then we would use this function (the exact code is in the example below the image):

time_source_get_units.name: time_source_get_units

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

time_source_get_units.description: Returns the units that the time source is measuring in.

layer_destroy_instances.name: layer_destroy_instances

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to set the depth of (or the layer name as a string)

layer_destroy_instances.description: This function can be used to destroy all the instances assigned to the given layer. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact), and then all instances that are on the layer will be removed from the game, triggering their Destroy and Clean Up events.

audio_create_stream.name: audio_create_stream

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The file (OGG only) to stream the audio from.

audio_create_stream.description: With this function you can create a new sound index which can then be used in the regular audio functions to stream audio directly from an external OGG file source. The function requires the filename (which can be an included file, for example) and will return the new sound index for use. Note that after you no longer need the sound you should call the function audio_destroy_stream() with the sound index to remove it from memory otherwise you may get a memory leak which will slow down and eventually crash your game.

sprite_save_strip.name: sprite_save_strip

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to change the transparency map of.

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The filename for the saved sprite strip.

sprite_save_strip.description: This function will create a strip image from all the sub-images in a sprite, saving it to disc with the specified filename. The sprite must have been added at runtime (you cannot save sprites added through the IDE) and the file must be saved with a *.png extension.

path_get_y.name: path_get_y

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to check.

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: How far through the path to check. Between 0 (start) and 1 (end).

path_get_y.description: With this function you can get the y coordinate of a position on any given path. 0 is the start of the path, 1 is the end of the path, and anything in between equates to the normalised distance along the length of the path. This value needn't be a defining point of the path, it can be anywhere on it.

draw_get_colour.name: draw_get_colour
draw_get_colour.description: This function returns the current draw colour which is used for drawing forms, text, primitives and un-textured 3D models. This can be set with the draw_set_colour() function.

vertex_update_buffer_from_buffer.name: vertex_update_buffer_from_buffer

parameters.name: dest_vbuff
parameters.description: The vertex buffer to copy to.

parameters.name: dest_offset
parameters.description: The offset (in bytes) within the vertex buffer to copy to.

parameters.name: src_buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to copy data from.

parameters.name: src_offset
parameters.description: The offset (in bytes) within the buffer to copy from.

parameters.name: src_size
parameters.description: The size (in bytes) of data to be copied.

vertex_update_buffer_from_buffer.description: This function updates contents of a vertex buffer using data from a regular buffer. The vertex buffer must not be frozen!

rollback_define_mock_input.name: rollback_define_mock_input

parameters.name: player_id
parameters.description: The player id to set the mock input for

parameters.name: input_struct
parameters.description: Struct containing the keycodes to mock

rollback_define_mock_input.description: This function defines the mocked input to be used by the rollback system during sync test.

array_pop.name: array_pop

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

array_pop.description: This function will remove the last element in the given array and return its value. If the array is empty undefined is returned.

skeleton_find_slot.name: skeleton_find_slot

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position in the room to check.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position in the room to check.

parameters.name: list
parameters.description: The ID of the DS list to populate with the DS maps.

skeleton_find_slot.description: With this function you can find which slots are at a specified room-space position in the Spine sprite associated with the current instance. You create a DS list and supply its ID along with an x/y position to check and the list will be populated with name string for each of the available attachment slots for the sprite (including any attachment modifications). Note that the list is always sorted in descending order starting from the top-most slot.

instance_place.name: instance_place

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to check for instances.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to check for instances.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for instances of.

instance_place.description: With this function you can check a position for a collision with another instance or all instances of an object using the collision mask of the instance that runs the code for the check. When you use this you are effectively asking GameMaker to move the instance to the new position, check for a collision, move back and tell you if a collision was found or not. This will work for precise collisions, but only if both the instance and the object being checked for have precise collision masks selected otherwise only bounding box collisions are applied. this function will return the unique instance id of the object being collided, but if that is not needed it is slightly faster to use the function place_meeting(). This function also accepts the special keywords all and other and will return the keyword noone if no collision occurs, or the unique instance ID value of the instance found if a collision does occur.

draw_roundrect_colour.name: draw_roundrect_colour

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the rounded rectangle.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top of the rounded rectangle.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right of the rounded rectangle.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the rounded rectangle.

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The center colour.

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The outside edge colour.

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the rectangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

draw_roundrect_colour.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rounded rectangle or a filled rounded rectangle where the (x1,y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2,y2) position is the bottom right corner. If it is filled you can define the individual colours for the centre and the edges, and if these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()).You can define how precise the drawing of the corners is with the function draw_set_circle_precision(), but the corners are always drawn with a fixed radius. Should you need to change the corner radius you should use the function draw_roundrect_colour_ext(). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

achievement_post_score.name: achievement_post_score

parameters.name: leaderboard
parameters.description: The name/ID of the leaderboard.

parameters.name: score
parameters.description: The score to be sent.

achievement_post_score.description: You can use this function to send your score to the chosen leaderboard and achievement service. On Android, you send the ID of the score table as a string (this is the unique leaderboard ID that got assigned when you set up the leaderboard), while on all other platforms you supply the defined leaderboard name as a string, and then you give the actual score value. The function will trigger a Social Asynchronous Event where the returned async_load DS map will have the following key/value pairs:

window_get_fullscreen.name: window_get_fullscreen
window_get_fullscreen.description: This function returns whether the game window is in fullscreen mode (true) or not (false).

gamepad_button_check.name: gamepad_button_check

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

parameters.name: button
parameters.description: Which gamepad button constant to check for.

gamepad_button_check.description: This function will return true or false depending on whether the given gamepad button is detected as being held down or not. If you are checking an analogue button, then the check will take into consideration the threshold setting and only return true while the raw input value is over the given threshold (you can get this raw value using the function gamepad_button_value()).

camera_get_view_x.name: camera_get_view_x

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_view_x.description: This function can be used to retrieve the x position of the view for a given camera. Note that this function is only valid for cameras created using camera_create_view() or for those added in the room editor.

audio_sync_group_get_track_pos.name: audio_sync_group_get_track_pos

parameters.name: group_index
parameters.description: The group index to get the position of.

audio_sync_group_get_track_pos.description: This function returns the current play position of the given sync group. The group index is the value returned when you created the group using the function audio_create_sync_group(), and the return value is the time in seconds that the tracks have been playing.

layer_set_fx.name: layer_set_fx

parameters.name: layer_name_or_id
parameters.description: The name or ID of the layer to modify

parameters.name: filter_or_effect
parameters.description: The FX struct to modify

layer_set_fx.description: This function is used to assign an FX struct to a Room Layer.

time_seconds_to_bpm.name: time_seconds_to_bpm

parameters.name: seconds
parameters.description: The value to be converted

time_seconds_to_bpm.description: Converts a period in seconds to its equivalent frequency in beats-per-minute.

variable_get_hash.name: variable_get_hash

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the variable to compute the hash of

variable_get_hash.description: With this function you can compute the hash of a given struct or instance member allowing for faster access (see 'struct_get_from_hash' and 'struct_set_from_hash').

ds_grid_read.name: ds_grid_read

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid to read.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to read into the DS grid.

parameters.name: legacy (optional)
parameters.description: Can be either true or false or omitted completely.

ds_grid_read.description: This function can be used to convert a string which has been created previously by the function ds_grid_write() back into a DS grid. The DS grid must have been created previously (see the example below).

draw_sprite_tiled.name: draw_sprite_tiled

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to draw.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

draw_sprite_tiled.description: This function will take a sprite and then repeatedly tile it across the whole view (or room if no view is defined), starting from the coordinates that you give in the function. Tiling is based on the width and height of the sprite as defined by the sprite variables of the instance running the code. This function is for 2D (orthographic) projections only, and will not work correctly when a 3D camera projection is used.

draw_roundrect_ext.name: draw_roundrect_ext

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the top left corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top left corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the bottom right corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom right corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).

parameters.name: xrad
parameters.description: The radius of the curve along the x axis from the rectangle corners.

parameters.name: yrad
parameters.description: The radius of the curve along the y axis from the rectangle corners.

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the rounded rectangle is drawn filled (false) or as a one pixel wide outline (true).

draw_roundrect_ext.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rounded rectangle or a filled rounded rectangle where the (x1,y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2,y2) position is the bottom right corner. You must also supply radius values for the x and y axis (in pixels) and the corners will be rounded by these amounts. You can define how precise the drawing of the corners is with the function draw_set_circle_precision(). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

draw_getpixel_ext.name: draw_getpixel_ext

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the pixel to check

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the pixel to check

draw_getpixel_ext.description: With this function you can get the full abgr 32bit value of any pixel that is being drawn to the current render target. This means that the results will depend on the event in which the function is called, and also on the target surface being used.

audio_start_recording.name: audio_start_recording

parameters.name: recorder_index
parameters.description: The index of the recorder source to use.

audio_start_recording.description: This function will start recording audio from the recorder source indexed. You can get the number of recorder sources using the function audio_get_recorder_count(), and once you start recording the audio will be stored in a temporary buffer and start triggering an Audio Recording Asynchronous Event. This event is triggered every step that recording takes place and will create the special DS map in the variable async_load with the following key/value pairs:

draw_get_valign.name: draw_get_valign
draw_get_valign.description: This function is used to get the text alignment setting along the vertical axis, and will return one of the constants listed below.

ini_section_delete.name: ini_section_delete

parameters.name: section
parameters.description: The section to delete.

ini_section_delete.description: With this function you can delete a whole section of an ini file, which will also remove all key-value pairs that are associated with it.

room_set_width.name: room_set_width

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the room to set the width of.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The new width of the room in pixels.

room_set_width.description: With this function you can change (or set) the width of any room in your game except the current one.

camera_create_view.name: camera_create_view

parameters.name: room_x
parameters.description: The x position (within the room) of the left side of the area the camera view captures.

parameters.name: room_y
parameters.description: The y position (within the room) of the top of the area the camera view captures.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the area the view captures.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the area the view captures.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle to set the for the camera view(from 0° - 360°, default is 0).

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The object ID (or instance ID) for the camera view to follow (default is -1, no object).

parameters.name: x_speed
parameters.description: The maximum horizontal speed the view can move at (set to -1 for "instant" following, default is -1).

parameters.name: y_speed
parameters.description: The maximum vertical speed the view can move at (set to -1 for "instant" following, default is -1).

parameters.name: x_border
parameters.description: The minimum horizontal space between the edge of the view area and the instance it is set to follow (before the view begins moving and if it is set to follow an instance, default is 0).

parameters.name: y_border
parameters.description: The minimum vertical space between the edge of the view area and the instance it is set to follow (before the view begins moving and if it is set to follow an instance, default is 0).

camera_create_view.description: This function will create a new camera and then set its view into the room, before return the unique ID value to identify the camera in future function calls. The camera will be created using the values that you set in this function for position, size and other details which correlate to the values you set in the Room Editor (see here). Note that this function can take a variable number of arguments with only the x/y position and width/height arguments being obligatory. Any arguments not supplied will use their default arguments.

keyboard_set_numlock.name: keyboard_set_numlock

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: Set this to true for "on" and false for "off"

keyboard_set_numlock.description: You can use this function to switch the keypad number-lock on or off (set to true for on, and false for off).

darcsin.name: darcsin

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to return the inverse sine of.

darcsin.description: Returns the inverse sine of x, in that if dsin(x)=n, darcsin(n)=x, and the resulting number will be between -90 and 90.

layer_sequence_get_x.name: layer_sequence_get_x

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

layer_sequence_get_x.description: With this function you supply the sequence element ID - as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions - and it will return the current X position in the game room for the sequence.

camera_set_begin_script.name: camera_set_begin_script

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera.

parameters.name: script
parameters.description: The script function to run each game frame

camera_set_begin_script.description: This function can be used to set a script function that will be called at the beginning of every game frame that the camera is assigned to a visible and active view port. You give the unique camera ID value (as returned by the different camera_create() functions) and the ID of the function to be called. The order in which scripts attached to cameras and the actual rendering of the camera view is as follows:

part_type_shape.name: part_type_shape

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to set.

parameters.name: shape
parameters.description: The shape to choose.

part_type_shape.description: With this function you can set the sprite shape to use for the particle type, with the following constants being acceptable:

method_get_index.name: method_get_index

parameters.name: method
parameters.description: The method variable to check

method_get_index.description: With this function you can retrieve the Script index for the script where the method was defined. If the method was not defined in a script then the function will return -1, otherwise it will return the index value for the script.

view_get_camera.name: view_get_camera

parameters.name: view_port
parameters.description: The view port to target (0 - 7)

view_get_camera.description: This function can be used to retrieve the unique camera ID value for the camera assigned to the given view port (from 0 - 7). If no camera is assigned, the function will return -1.

show_message.name: show_message

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to show in the pop-up message.

show_message.description: This function creates a pop-up message box which displays the given string and a button marked "Ok" to close it.

layer_background_speed.name: layer_background_speed

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to change

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed multiplier/value to use for the element

layer_background_speed.description: This function can be used to set the speed of an animating sprite that has been assigned to a background element. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and then set the animation speed. If the IDE has set the animation speed for the sprite used to be calculated as Frames Per Game Frame, then the speed value given is a multiplier, with 1 being the default value, and setting it to 0.5 will half the animation speed, while setting it to 2 will double it. However, if the IDE has set the animation speed for the sprite used to be calculated as Frames Per Second, then the speed value given is a literal frames per second value, so setting this to 5, for example, will set the animation to loop 5 frames every second that the game runs. If the background element has no sprite attached or the sprite used has no sub-images, this function will have no effect.

file_bin_seek.name: file_bin_seek

parameters.name: binfile
parameters.description: The ID of the file to read from.

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: The position in the file to move to.

file_bin_seek.description: This function moves the current read position within the file to the indicated position. You supply the file ID value, as returned by the function file_bin_open(), and to append a file, move the position to the size of the file before writing.

file_exists.name: file_exists

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The name of the file to check for.

file_exists.description: This function will return true if the specified file exists and false if it does not. Note that the function can only be used to check local files, but not any files stored on a remote server.

layer_sprite_get_speed.name: layer_sprite_get_speed

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to get the information from

layer_sprite_get_speed.description: This function can be used to get the current speed multiplier value of the sprite element. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and the function will return real value that represents the speed multiplier being used to animate the sprite. Default value is 1.

skeleton_animation_get_frame.name: skeleton_animation_get_frame

parameters.name: track
parameters.description: The animation track to get the frame of.

skeleton_animation_get_frame.description: This function will return the frame number of the animation on the specified animation track. The function will return -1 if no animation is assigned to the specific track given.

vertex_format_delete.name: vertex_format_delete
vertex_format_delete.description: This function must be called whenever you are finished using any created vector formats. You provide the format ID value (as returned by the function vector_format_end()), and this function will free the memory associated with it. Note that if you try to use this format again after calling this function, you will get an error.

is_instanceof.name: is_instanceof

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The struct reference to check.

parameters.name: constructor_name
parameters.description: The constructor reference to check against

is_instanceof.description: Returns true if "struct" has "constructor_name" as part of its inheritance hierarchy

md5_file.name: md5_file

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The file to generate the MD5 hash for.

md5_file.description: In cryptography, MD5 (Message-Digest algorithm 5) is a widely used cryptographic hash function with a 128-bit hash value and has been employed in a wide variety of security applications. It is also commonly used to check the integrity of files and strings. This function will take the given file and generate a unique MD5 for that file which can then be stored for later use.

animcurve_get.name: animcurve_get

parameters.name: curve_id
parameters.description: The asset ID (index) of the animation curve to get.

animcurve_get.description: This function returns a struct containing all the data for the given animation curve.

gesture_rotate_time.name: gesture_rotate_time
gesture_rotate_time.description: This function is used to set the time within which a pair of touches must be rotating in a consistent direction for a Rotate Start Gesture to be triggered. The time is measured in seconds and has a default value of 0.16s.

audio_sound_get_track_position.name: audio_sound_get_track_position

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to get the play position of.

audio_sound_get_track_position.description: This function will get the position (in seconds) within the sound file for the sound to play from. The sound can only be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions).

directory_destroy.name: directory_destroy

parameters.name: dname
parameters.description: The name of the directory to remove.

directory_destroy.description: This function will remove a directory with the given name in the save area.

file_bin_size.name: file_bin_size

parameters.name: binfile
parameters.description: The ID of the file to get the size of.

file_bin_size.description: This function will return the size (in bytes) of a file that has been opened for reading and/or writing. The File ID is the value returned by the function file_bin_open().

mp_linear_step_object.name: mp_linear_step_object

parameters.name: xgoal
parameters.description: The target x position.

parameters.name: ygoal
parameters.description: The target y position.

parameters.name: stepsize
parameters.description: The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object that is to block the path. Can be an object index, an instance id or the special keyword, all

mp_linear_step_object.description: With this function you tell an instance to take a "step" towards a specific point, specified by the xgoal and ygoal values. The size of the step (which is how many pixels the instance should move each step) is indicated by the stepsize, and if the instance is already at the position it will stop and not move any further, contrary to other, simpler functions like move_towards_point(). The stepsize is also the distance "ahead" that the object will check each step for a collision, and you can choose whether the instance stops at a collision with an object or instance of your choice.

layer_get_shader.name: layer_get_shader

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target (or the layer name as a string)

layer_get_shader.description: This function can be used to check if the given layer has a shader assigned to it. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact), and the function will return either the shader index of the shader assigned, or -1 if no shader is assigned.

rollback_define_player.name: rollback_define_player

parameters.name: player_object
parameters.description: The object type that should be used for players

parameters.name: layer_name
parameters.description: The layer name to assign the created instance to (default is "Instances")

rollback_define_player.description: This function defines the object to use for players in rollback multiplayer.

string_last_pos_ext.name: string_last_pos_ext

parameters.name: substr
parameters.description: The substring to look for in the string.

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string.

parameters.name: start_pos
parameters.description: The starting position to search from.

string_last_pos_ext.description: This function will return the character position of an instance of a sub-string within a string, searching backwards through the string from the position given as the starting position. The function will return 0 if the search string is not found, or the position of the first character of the search string if it is. Keep in mind that for legacy support strings are indexed from 1, so 1 is the first position in the string, not 0 as you may expect.

display_get_dpi_x.name: display_get_dpi_x
display_get_dpi_x.description: Dots per inch (DPI) is a measure of spatial printing or video dot density, in particular the number of individual dots that can be placed in a line within the span of 1 inch (2.54 cm). When working on mobile devices (in particular Android devices) this is an important factor to take into consideration as what may be appropriate for one display resolution, may not be appropriate for another. For example, you may have two displays with the same resolution of 400 x 800, but display 1 has a dpi of 60 and display 2 has a dpi of 30. In this case, any text or image displayed on display 2 will appear much larger, even though the actual resolution is the same.

font_replace_sprite.name: font_replace_sprite

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the font that shall be replaced (ie all references to this resource past this function will refer to the new font, not the original).

parameters.name: spr
parameters.description: The sprite to add a font based on.

parameters.name: first
parameters.description: The index of the first available character.

parameters.name: prop
parameters.description: Whether white space around each letter should be removed (if false, the created font will be monospaced, otherwise it'll be like most regular fonts).

parameters.name: sep
parameters.description: The space between each letter, 0 meaning the right of one letter just touches the left of the next one.

font_replace_sprite.description: With this function you can use a "sprite strip" to replace a previously created sprite font asset, where each sub-image would be an individual symbol or letter. The index is the UTF8 map number for the first character to use and the ranges to use are the same as you would for a normal font, starting with "!" but remember that you should only include what you need and that you should be using the ord() function to get the correct UTF8 value for the starting letter.

buffer_get_size.name: buffer_get_size

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to get the size of.

buffer_get_size.description: With this function you can get the size of the given buffer in bytes.

ds_list_read.name: ds_list_read

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to read into.

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to read from.

parameters.name: legacy (optional)
parameters.description: Can be either true or false or omitted completely.

ds_list_read.description: With this function you can recreate a saved DS list (one that has previously been written as a string using ds_list_write()). You must first create a new DS list to read the string into, and if the DS list already exists and has information stored in it, then this will be cleared before reading. This function is of vital importance when creating save/load mechanisms for your game.

filename_drive.name: filename_drive

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The file to use.

filename_drive.description: This function returns the drive information of the filename.

audio_listener_orientation.name: audio_listener_orientation

parameters.name: lookat_x
parameters.description: The x look vector (default 0).

parameters.name: lookat_y
parameters.description: The y look vector (default 0).

parameters.name: lookat_z
parameters.description: The z look vector (default 1000).

parameters.name: up_x
parameters.description: The x up vector (default 0).

parameters.name: up_y
parameters.description: The y up vector (default 1).

parameters.name: up_z
parameters.description: The z up vector (default 0).

audio_listener_orientation.description: With this function you can change the orientation of the listener within the 3D audio space. The look at direction and up direction are based on the vectors that are resolved from the given relative x, y and z positions, and default to (0, 0, 1000) for the look at direction and (0, 1, 0) for the up direction, as shown in the illustration below:

sprite_nineslice_create.name: sprite_nineslice_create
sprite_nineslice_create.description: Nine Slicing is a technique used to scale rectangular images for preserving details, making them retain their original form after scaling. See this page for information on Nine Slice.

url_get_domain.name: url_get_domain
url_get_domain.description: You can use this to get the domain where your HTML5 game is being played.

filename_dir.name: filename_dir

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The file to use.

filename_dir.description: This function returns the directory part of the indicated file name, which normally is the same as the path except for the final backslash.

int64.name: int64

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to convert.

int64.description: This function will attempt to convert a given value into a 64bit integer, where the value must be either a real, a string, an int64, an int32, or a ptr. Anything else will cause the game to crash with an error message. You can check to see if a variable holds an int64 using the function is_int64().

path_get_point_speed.name: path_get_point_speed

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to check.

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The point identity to check.

path_get_point_speed.description: With this function you can get the speed of the point (as defined in the Path Editor or when you dynamically add a path point using path_add_point()) expressed as a percentage. So, if you have a path point set to 50 in the path editor, this function would return 50 when used.

part_particles_count.name: part_particles_count

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system.

part_particles_count.description: With this function you can check to see if a particle system currently has any particles created in the room, and it will return the number of them too.

tilemap_x.name: tilemap_x

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to change

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position for the tile map

tilemap_x.description: This function controls the position along the x-axis of the room of the asset tile map element on the layer. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and then set the x value to use (based on the room coordinates).

draw_get_font.name: draw_get_font
draw_get_font.description: This function will get the font currently assigned for drawing text. The function will return -1 if no font is set, or the ID value (a positive integer) for the font resource assigned.

point_direction.name: point_direction

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first component of the vector

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the first component of the vector

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the second component of the vector

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the second component of the vector

point_direction.description: This function returns the direction of a vector formed by the specified components [x1,y1] and [x2,y2] in relation to the fixed x/y coordinates of the room. For example, in the image below if we want to get the direction from the player ship position to the enemy position so that we can fire a missile at the enemy then we would use this function (the exact code is in the example below the image):

font_enable_sdf.name: font_enable_sdf

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the font.

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Whether to enable (true) or disable (false) SDF rendering for the specified font.

font_enable_sdf.description: With this function you can enable or disable SDF rendering for the specified font. This only works on fonts added using font_add().

date_day_span.name: date_day_span

parameters.name: date1
parameters.description: The first datetime.

parameters.name: date2
parameters.description: The datetime to compare it to.

date_day_span.description: With this function you can get the number of days between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete days will be returned as a fraction.

layer_hspeed.name: layer_hspeed

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to set the horizontal speed of

parameters.name: hspd
parameters.description: The horizontal speed (in pixels per game frame) to set

layer_hspeed.description: You can use this function to set the horizontal speed (in pixels per game frame) of the layer within the currently scoped room. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the speed value to set, where a positive value is to the right and a negative value to the left.

ds_list_find_value.name: ds_list_find_value

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the list to use.

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: The position to look at, where 0 corresponds to the very beginning of the list and the final position is ds_list_size(id)-1.

ds_list_find_value.description: With this function you can check the given list position and the value held within the list for that position will be returned. Note that if you give a position that is outside of the given list size (ie: position 11 in a 10 value list) then the function may return undefined or 0. This is because when you create the list, internally the first few entries in the list are set to 0 to minimize performance issues when initially adding items to the list (although the ds_list_size() function will still return 0 on a newly created list). If you wish to ensure that the list is "truly" empty on create, then you should call ds_list_clear() after creating the list, which will then mean that any values returned for unpopulated list slots will be undefined, which you can then check consistently using the is_undefined() function.

is_ptr.name: is_ptr

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The argument to check.

is_ptr.description: This function returns whether a given variable is a pointer or not. In some cases you want to check and see what data type a variable holds in GameMaker and that's when you would use this function. It returns true or false depending on whether the value is a pointer or not.

keyboard_virtual_height.name: keyboard_virtual_height
keyboard_virtual_height.description: This function will return the current height in pixels of the virtual keyboard, based on the size of the display. If the keyboard is not visible, 0 will be returned.

audio_destroy_sync_group.name: audio_destroy_sync_group

parameters.name: group_index
parameters.description: The group index to be destroyed.

audio_destroy_sync_group.description: Audio sync groups need to be destroyed when not in use to free up the memory and sound resources associated with them using this function. It takes the group index as returned when the group was created using the function audio_create_sync_group(), and frees all resources used by the group.

tag_get_assets.name: tag_get_assets

parameters.name: tags
parameters.description: A single asset tag string or an array with various asset tags.

tag_get_assets.description:
This function retrieves the names of all assets that have been assigned the given tag or tags.
			
			You supply either a single tag string or an array, where each item in the array is a tag string. The function will return an array where each entry is the name (as a string) of the asset with the given tag. If you need the unique index for the asset, then you can use the function asset_get_index() along with the returned name. If there are no assets with the given tag(s), or if there is an error (e.g., the given tags do not exist), then an empty array will be returned.

network_connect.name: network_connect

parameters.name: socket
parameters.description: The id of the socket to use.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The URL or IP to connect to (a string).

parameters.name: port
parameters.description: The port to connect to.

network_connect.description: With this function you can send a request to connect to a server. The function takes the socket id to connect through (see network_create_socket()) and requires you to give the IP address to connect to (a string) as well as the port to connect through, and if the connection fails a value of less than 0 will be returned. The connection uses a special protocol that ensures only GameMaker games connect to each other, however if you need to connect to a server that is not a GameMaker game, you can use network_connect_raw(). Note that by default the function is synchronous, meaning that your game may appear to "hang" as the connection is made. You can set a timeout value for connection, or alternatively make the creation asynchronous, using the function network_set_config(), or alternatively use the function network_connect_async() instead.

font_get_bold.name: font_get_bold

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: Index of the font to check.

font_get_bold.description: With this function you can check any font asset to see if it has the bold flag or not. If it does the function will return true, otherwise it will return false.

is_infinity.name: is_infinity

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The argument to check.

is_infinity.description: This function returns whether a given variable is infinity (an infinite number) or not, returning true if it is, and false if it is not.

ds_priority_empty.name: ds_priority_empty

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to check.

ds_priority_empty.description: With this function you can check the given DS priority queue to see if it is empty (returns true) or not (returns false).

log2.name: log2

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The input value.

log2.description: This function basically asks "how many 2's do you need to multiply to get n?". A common example of use in programming would be to calculate the number of bits that are needed to represent a number. To do this we calculate the log2(x) of the number, round it down and add 1 - for example log2(100) returns 6.643856, which rounded down is 6, to which we add one and it gives us 7. So we need 7 bits to represent 100. It can also be used for describing exponential growth or decay, and is often called a binary logarithm.

colour_get_green.name: colour_get_green

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to check

colour_get_green.description: This function returns the amount of green used to make the given colour, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no green and 255 is all green. The following image illustrates this:

string_count.name: string_count

parameters.name: substr
parameters.description: The substring to check the string for.

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to check.

string_count.description: This function will return the amount of times the given substring appears within a specific string. In this way you can check for how many times a single letter or a phrase is repeated in a section of stored text.

window_set_min_height.name: window_set_min_height

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The minimum height in pixels for the game window.

window_set_min_height.description: This function can be used to set a minimum window height for your game. If you enable the window resize option in the Game Options for the target platform, then the player can resize the game window to any size they wish, however by using this function you can limit the minimum height to the size you specify. If you wish to go back to the default behaviour (ie: no minimum), then use a value of -1.

ds_map_add.name: ds_map_add

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map to add to.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key of the value to add.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to add to the map.

ds_map_add.description: This function should be used to add sets of key/value pairs into the specified DS map. You can check this function to see if it was successful or not (it will return true on success or false otherwise), as it may fail if there already exists the same key in the DS map or you specify a non-existent DS map as the ID of the map to add to. The keys and and values you supply can be made up of any combination of data types, so all of the following - and more - are acceptable (although, in practice, you would most commonly use a string for the key):

draw_text_ext_colour.name: draw_text_ext_colour

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to draw.

parameters.name: sep
parameters.description: The distance in pixels between lines of text.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The maximum width in pixels of the string before a line break.

parameters.name: c1
parameters.description: The colour for the top left of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c2
parameters.description: The colour for the top right of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c3
parameters.description: The colour for the bottom right of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c4
parameters.description: The colour for the bottom left of the drawn text.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha for the text.

draw_text_ext_colour.description: This function is a combination of the base draw_text() function with the draw_text_ext() and draw_text_colour() functions, permitting you to define gradient colours for text as well as the line spacing and maximum width per line all together.

mp_potential_path_object.name: mp_potential_path_object

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: index of the path that is to be used by the function

parameters.name: xgoal
parameters.description: The target x position.

parameters.name: ygoal
parameters.description: The target y position.

parameters.name: stepsize
parameters.description: The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.

parameters.name: factor
parameters.description: This number is used to prevent an infinite loop. It should be larger than 1. See the function description for more information.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object that is to block the path. Can be an object index, an instance id or the special keyword ,all

mp_potential_path_object.description: This function computes a path for the instance from its current position and orientation to the position specified by the xgoal, ygoal arguments. It uses the indicated step size while trying to avoid collision with instances of the object specified by the "obj" argument. Like in the function mp_potential_step() it uses potential field steps to accomplish this and the manner in which it does this can be modified through the function mp_potential_settings(). The indicated path must already exist and it will be overwritten by the new path. The function will return whether a path was found (true) or not (false).

gamepad_set_button_threshold.name: gamepad_set_button_threshold

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

parameters.name: threshold
parameters.description: The new threshold value (from 0 - 1, default 0.5).

gamepad_set_button_threshold.description: This function can be used to set the current threshold setting of the analogue buttons for a given device. The default threshold for all analogue buttons is 0.5, with the range being from 0 to 1. The threshold defines at what point the button is considered as being "pressed" for games that require them to act as a digital button. Note that this function will affect the check, pressed and released states for analogue buttons, but will not affect the value returned by the function gamepad_button_check(), which will always return the raw value for the button.

variable_struct_set.name: variable_struct_set

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The struct reference to set

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the variable to set (as a string)

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to set the variable to

variable_struct_set.description: With this function you can set the value of a given variable in a struct. You supply the struct reference as well as the name of the variable to set the value of as a string (see example code below), and then finally the value to set (can be any valid data type). If the variable does not exist already in the struct it will be created and then assigned the value.

script_exists.name: script_exists

parameters.name: scr
parameters.description: The name of the script that you want to check.

script_exists.description: This function will return true or false depending on whether the script or script function with the given index exists. Note, that this is not a string, but rather the asset name which holds the unique index for each script (as it would appear in the IDE) or the script function name variable, as defined within the script asset (note that this will not work for method variables). For more information on scripts, see The Script Editor.

sequence_create.name: sequence_create
sequence_create.description: With this function you can create a new sequence object which you can then add tracks to. The function returns a struct which you can then access to setup the new sequence you have created. The contents of this struct are detailed on this page. The sequence object struct can then be used to create instances of the sequence on a room layer using the function layer_sequence_create(). Note that when creating sequence objects in this way you should remove them again by calling the function sequence_destroy() when they are no longer required, otherwise you will have a memory leak which can slow down and eventually crash your game.

view_set_xport.name: view_set_xport

parameters.name: view_port
parameters.description: The view port to target (0 - 7)

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The new x position

view_set_xport.description: This function can be used to set the x position of the given view port. You give the view port index (from 0 to 7) and the new position to place it at.

draw_ellipse_colour.name: draw_ellipse_colour

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the ellipse.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top of the ellipse.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right of the ellipse.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the ellipse.

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The colour of the center.

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The colour of the edge.

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the ellipse is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

draw_ellipse_colour.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of an ellipse or a filled ellipse by defining a rectangular area that will then have the ellipse created to fit. If it is filled you can define the interior and exterior fill colours. If these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()). You can define how precise the drawing is with the function draw_set_circle_precision().

keyboard_get_numlock.name: keyboard_get_numlock
keyboard_get_numlock.description: You can use this function to find the status of the keypad number lock with true being returned for on, and false returned for off.

http_request.name: http_request

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The web address of the server that you wish to get information from

parameters.name: method
parameters.description: The request method (normally "POST" or "GET", but all methods are supported)

parameters.name: header_map
parameters.description: A ds_map with the required header fields

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The data to be transmitted following the headers (can be a binary buffer handle)

http_request.description: With this function, you can create an HTTP header request to define the operating parameters of an HTTP transaction, which can be used for many things like (for example) authentication via HTTP headers if you use RESTful APIs. The function requires the full IP address of the server to request from as well as the type of request to make (as a string, see the note below): "GET", "HEAD", "POST", "PUT", "DELETE", "TRACE", "OPTIONS", or "CONNECT". You will also need to supply a DS map of key/value pairs (as strings, where the key is the header field and the value is the required data for the header), and the final argument is an optional data string that you can add to the request, and if it's not needed then it can be either 0 or an empty string "". Note that you can also send a buffer (see the section on Buffers for more details), in which case the last argument would be the "handle" of the buffer to send.

physics_particle_set_damping.name: physics_particle_set_damping

parameters.name: damping
parameters.description: The linear damping to be applied to the particle fixture.

physics_particle_set_damping.description: With this function you can set the linear damping of particles in the simulation. Damping is used to reduce the physics simulation velocity of instances over time, much like air resistance in the real world. This function is global in scope, in that it will change the damping not just for new particles created after the change, but also for those already present in the simulation.

method_get_self.name: method_get_self

parameters.name: method
parameters.description: The method variable to check.

method_get_self.description: With this function you can retrieve the instance ID or struct reference which is the self context used when the method is called. If the variable is not a method then the function will return undefined. Please note that the function may also return the constant pointer_null, in which case the current self is being used at the time of the call.

draw_text_color.name: draw_text_color

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to draw.

parameters.name: c1
parameters.description: The colour for the top left of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c2
parameters.description: The colour for the top right of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c3
parameters.description: The colour for the bottom right of the drawn text.

parameters.name: c4
parameters.description: The colour for the bottom left of the drawn text.
