parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha for the text.

draw_text_color.description: This function will draw text in a similar way to draw_text() only now you can choose the colours to use for colouring the text as well as the alpha value, and these new values will be used instead of the base drawing colour and alpha.

game_set_speed.name: game_set_speed

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The new game speed (as either FPS or MPF).

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of method used to set the game speed (see the constants above).

game_set_speed.description: This function can be used to set the game speed. You can set this in one of two ways - as either game frames per second (FPS) or as microseconds per game frame (MPF) - using one of the following two constants:

date_get_second_of_year.name: date_get_second_of_year

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The date to check.

date_get_second_of_year.description: This function returns the second of the given datetime value within the year (from the total number of seconds for the year, taking into account leap years).

typeof.name: typeof

parameters.name: variable
parameters.description: The variable to get the data type of.

typeof.description: This function returns the data type of any given variable as a string. The possible return values are listed in the table below:

audio_stop_sync_group.name: audio_stop_sync_group

parameters.name: group_index
parameters.description: The group index to stop playing.

audio_stop_sync_group.description: This function will stop the given sync group if it is playing, with the group index being the value returned when you created the group using the function audio_create_sync_group().

gamepad_is_supported.name: gamepad_is_supported
gamepad_is_supported.description: With this function you can find out whether the target platform supports game pads (returns true) or not (returns false).

string_copy.name: string_copy

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to copy from.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The position of the first character in the string to copy from (numbered from 1)

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: The number of characters, starting from the position of the first, to copy

string_copy.description: With this function you can easily select a number of characters from within a string to be copied to another one. The first character in a string is always indexed as 1 and not 0 as you may expect, so to copy (for example) the first five characters of string you would have string_copy(str, 1, 5). A further example is provided below.

date_time_string.name: date_time_string

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to use.

date_time_string.description: With this function you can create a string containing the given time, formatted for the system or device that is running the game when the function is called.

tilemap_set_global_mask.name: tilemap_set_global_mask

parameters.name: mask
parameters.description: The mask value to use

tilemap_set_global_mask.description: This function can be used to set the tile bit mask for a all tile maps in the game. The idea is that if you have, for example, pretty small tile sets of 16 x 16 tiles will have a total of 256 different tiles in each tile set, which only uses up 8 bits of your index in the tile data "blob" (from an available 19 bits of data). These bits can be "masked" and then the rest of the tile data can be used to store additional values.

fx_set_parameter.name: fx_set_parameter

parameters.name: filter_or_effect
parameters.description: The FX struct to modify

parameters.name: parameter_name
parameters.description: The name of the parameter to change the value of (as a string)

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The new value(s) for that parameter as a real or array

fx_set_parameter.description: This function is used to change the value of a parameter in the given FX struct. You specify an FX struct (as returned from fx_create() or layer_get_fx()), a parameter name as a string, and its new value.

layer_get_all_elements.name: layer_get_all_elements

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to get the elements from (or the layer name as a string)

layer_get_all_elements.description: You can use this function to get the element IDs of the given layer. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the function will return an array of IDs, where each entry in the array is a unique ID for an element on that layer. For example, if the layer is an Asset Layer, the array will be populated with the ID values for each sprite asset that is assigned to the layer. Note that using code to work with layers means that you can assign different element types to the same layer - so you can have sprite assets along with instances, for example - in which case you can then use the function layer_get_element_type() to get the type of element the ID relates to.

effect_create_above.name: effect_create_above

parameters.name: kind
parameters.description: The kind of effect (use one of the constants listed above).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x positioning of the effect if relevant.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y positioning of the effect if relevant.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the effect.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour of the effect.

effect_create_above.description: With this function you can create a simple effect above all instances of your room (it is actually created at a depth of -15000). If the effect is anything other ef_rain or ef_snow then you can define an x/y position to create the effect, and the size can be a value of 0, 1, or 2, where 0 is small, 1 is medium and 2 is large.

string_last_pos.name: string_last_pos

parameters.name: substr
parameters.description: The substring to look for in the string.

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string.

string_last_pos.description: This function will return the character position of an instance of a sub-string within a string, searching from the end of the string to the beginning (so the reverse of string_pos(). The function will return 0 if the search string is not found, or the position of the first character of the search string if it is. Keep in mind that for legacy support strings are indexed from 1, so 1 is the first position in the string, not 0 as you may expect.

make_color_rgb.name: make_color_rgb

parameters.name: red
parameters.description: The red component of the colour

parameters.name: green
parameters.description: The green component of the colour

parameters.name: blue
parameters.description: The blue component of the colour

make_color_rgb.description: GameMaker provides this function (as well as others) to permit the user to make their own colours. This particular function takes three component parts, the red, the green and the blue components of the colour that you wish to make. These values are taken as being between 0 and 255 so you can make 16,777,216 (256*256*256) colours with this! Below you can see an image of how these components look when separated:

physics_particle_delete_region_poly.name: physics_particle_delete_region_poly

parameters.name: pointlist
parameters.description: A ds_list of points to use to create the polygon.

physics_particle_delete_region_poly.description: With this function you can delete (remove) all the particles that fall within the bounds of the defined polygonal area from the physics simulation in the current room. The function takes a (previously created) ds_list() containing the x/y position of each point of the polygon, with the even numbered positions in the list being the x coordinates, and odd numbered positions the y coordinates, ie: for a triangle, your list would have six entries, with entry 0, 2, and 4 being the x coordinates and 1, 3, and 5 being the y coordinates. The polygon will then be used to delete all the particles that fall within the defined area.

window_set_fullscreen.name: window_set_fullscreen

parameters.name: full
parameters.description: Whether to set the screen to fullscreen (true) or not (false).

window_set_fullscreen.description: With this function you can set the game window to be full screen (true) or not (false). Please note that for the macOS target, you must have unchecked the "Start In Fullscreen" option and checked the "Allow the player to resize the game window" option in the Game Options, otherwise this function will fail. Also note that this function will not work on HTML5 unless it's added in as a "clickable" callback (see here for more details).

layer_get_id.name: layer_get_id

parameters.name: layer_name
parameters.description: The name of the layer (a string)

layer_get_id.description: This function can be used to get the unique ID value for a given layer. In the IDE, all layers have a name and a type, and to be able to edit or change them through code you must give the layer ID value. This function is used to retrieve this ID by using the name (a string) of the layer (as written in the IDE). If you create a new layer through code using the function layer_create() then that function will return the unique ID value instead (dynamical created layers do not get names). Note that if you give the name of a layer that does not exist in the current room, then you will get an error and the project will crash.

buffer_set_surface.name: buffer_set_surface

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to use.

parameters.name: surface
parameters.description: The index of the surface to use.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The data offset value.

buffer_set_surface.description: With this function you can write information from a buffer to a given surface. Both the buffer being read from and the surface being written to must have been created previously, and you can provide an offset into the buffer to start reading from. Note that reading will always start at the beginning of the buffer plus the offset value and not at the current seek position plus the offset value.

ds_priority_write.name: ds_priority_write

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to check.

ds_priority_write.description: This function returns a string which can then be stored or transferred to another data structure using the ds_priority_read() function.

instance_position_list.name: instance_position_list

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to check for instances.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to check for instances.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for instances of.

parameters.name: list
parameters.description: The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.

parameters.name: ordered
parameters.description: Whether the list should be ordered by distance (true) or not (false).

instance_position_list.description: With this function you can check a position for a collision with all instances of another object. When you use this you are checking a single point in the room for all instances of an object, and the check will be done against the bounding box of the instances or against the mask of the instances if that object has precise collisions checked.

sprite_get_yoffset.name: sprite_get_yoffset

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to find the yoffset of.

sprite_get_yoffset.description: When you define a sprite in the sprite editor, you need to set the origin for that sprite. This is the point at which the sprite will be "attached" or "drawn" when used with an instance. This function returns the relative offset for the y-axis of the origin based on the upper left corner being the 0,0 position, with a +y being down and a -y being up from this. The following image illustrates this:

physics_world_update_iterations.name: physics_world_update_iterations

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: the iterations (per step) that the physics system will perform

physics_world_update_iterations.description: Everything in GameMaker is based around steps and, normally, each event will only happen once per step. However, to get the necessary precision with the physics functions they are made to do several calculations each step which are called "iterations" the number of which are controlled by this function. The default number for the physics system is 10, but this can be changed to higher or lower depending how many times you want the physics to calculate each step, but it is recommended that you set this no lower than 5 and no higher than 30. You should also be aware that this function is dependent on the physics_world_update_speed() function.

string_join_ext.name: string_join_ext

parameters.name: delimiter
parameters.description: The delimiter to use when joining the values.

parameters.name: values_array
parameters.description: An array of values be joined using the delimiter.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset of the range (allows negative values, from end of string).

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: The number of elements to join (allows negative values, reverse traversing).

string_join_ext.description: This function joins the elements of an array using the provided delimiter, non-string values will be converted to string.

draw_skeleton.name: draw_skeleton

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to draw.

parameters.name: animname
parameters.description: The name of the animation to get the frame from (a string).

parameters.name: skinname
parameters.description: The name of the skin to use (a string).

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: The animation frame to draw (from 0 to image_number - 1).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: rot
parameters.description: The rotation of the sprite. 0=normal, 90=turned 90 degrees counter-clockwise etc.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour with which to blend the sprite.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha of the sprite (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

draw_skeleton.description: This function is only for use with sprites that have been created using a skeletal animation program like Spine. While you can draw these sprites using the normal draw functions (like draw_self()), there are times when you may want to draw a single frame or show a change of skin texture without actually changing the sprite properties. In these cases you can draw the sprite with this function, where you give the sprite index and then the name of the animation to get the frame from (a string, as set within the program used to make the sprite). Next you give the name of the skin to use (again, as set when the sprite was made), and a frame value. The frame value is for telling GameMaker what part of the animation to show and is a value between 0 and the image_number. The rest of the arguments are the same as those used for normal sprite drawing and will change the scale, angle, blend colour and alpha of the final animation frame being drawn.

instance_activate_region.name: instance_activate_region

parameters.name: left
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the rectangular region to activate.

parameters.name: top
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top of the rectangular region to activate.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the region to activate.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the region to activate.

parameters.name: inside
parameters.description: Whether to activate instances on the inside of the region (true) or the outside (false).

instance_activate_region.description: With this function you can define a region within the room to activate instances that have previously been deactivated. This region can either be flagged as "inside" or "outside" as demonstrated in the following image:

effect_create_below.name: effect_create_below

parameters.name: kind
parameters.description: The kind of effect (use one of the constants listed above).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x positioning of the effect if relevant.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y positioning of the effect if relevant.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the effect.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour of the effect.

effect_create_below.description: With this function you can create a simple effect beneath all instances of your room (it is actually created at a depth of 50). If the effect is anything other ef_rain or ef_snow then you can define an x/y position to create the effect, and the size can be a value of 0, 1, or 2, where 0 is small, 1 is medium and 2 is large.

array_get_index.name: array_get_index

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value to search for.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when searching the array. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: How many entries should be searched. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_get_index.description: This function returns the first index at which a given element can be found in the array (or subsection). If the value is not found the function returns -1.

draw_clear_alpha.name: draw_clear_alpha

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour with which the screen will be cleared

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The transparency of the colour with which the screen will be cleared

draw_clear_alpha.description: This function can be used to clear the entire screen with a given colour and the alpha component of the destination is set to the value you have set - this function does not do any blending as it works but any subsequent blend operations can be set up to use the destination alpha that you have set. This is only for use in the draw event of an instance (it will not show if used in any other event), and it can also be very useful for clearing surfaces when they are newly created.

view_set_hport.name: view_set_hport

parameters.name: view_port
parameters.description: The view port to target (0 - 7)

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The new height (in pixels)

view_set_hport.description: This function can be used to set the height of the given view port. You give the view port index (from 0 to 7) and the new height to use.

variable_global_get.name: variable_global_get

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the global variable to get (as a string)

variable_global_get.description: With this function you can get the value from a given named global variable. You supply the name of the global variable to get the value of as a string (see example code below) and the function will return the value held by the global variable or undefined if the variable does not exist.

struct_remove.name: struct_remove

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The struct reference to remove the variable from

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the variable to remove (as a string)

struct_remove.description: With this function you can remove a variable from a struct. You supply the struct ID to remove the variable from and the string name of the variable to be removed.

vertex_format_begin.name: vertex_format_begin
vertex_format_begin.description: Before you can define your new vertex format you must tell GameMaker that you're doing so using this function. You must call this first, then define the format values using the appropriate functions, and finally call vertex_format_end() to finish the definition and return the new format "handle".

gesture_get_double_tap_time.name: gesture_get_double_tap_time
gesture_get_double_tap_time.description: This function is used to get the time it takes between two touches/clicks to trigger a Double Tap Gesture event. The time is measured in seconds and has a default value of 0.16.

file_bin_read_byte.name: file_bin_read_byte

parameters.name: binfile
parameters.description: The ID of the file to get the data from.

file_bin_read_byte.description: This function will return a byte of data from current position within the file with the given file ID. You supply the file ID value, as returned by the function file_bin_open().

audio_sound_get_pitch.name: audio_sound_get_pitch

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to get the pitch of.

audio_sound_get_pitch.description: This function can be used to get the get pitch of a given sound. The sound can either be one referenced from an index for an individual sound being played which has been stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions, or an actual sound asset from the Asset Browser.

achievement_post.name: achievement_post

parameters.name: achievement
parameters.description: The name/ID of the achievement.

parameters.name: percent
parameters.description: The percentage of the achievement completed.

achievement_post.description: You can use this function to send your achievements to the chosen leaderboard and achievement service. On Android you will need the the ID of the achievement as a string (this is the unique achievement ID that got assigned when you set up the achievement), while on all other platforms you supply the achievement name as a string, and then you give the percentage that you have completed towards getting the achievement (0 - None, 100 - Completed). The function will trigger a Social Asynchronous Event where the returned async_load DS map will have the following key/value pairs:

rollback_sync_on_frame.name: rollback_sync_on_frame
rollback_sync_on_frame.description: Synchronize the rollback game on the current frame. This means that we will only proceed past the current frame if all inputs are confirmed. Returns true if successful, false if the current frame will be rerun.

string_replace.name: string_replace

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to be copied.

parameters.name: substr
parameters.description: The substring within the string to be replaced.

parameters.name: newstr
parameters.description: The new substring to replace the previous one.

string_replace.description: You can use this function to parse a string looking for a specific part, which can then be replaced by the new string that you have specified.

gpu_set_tex_max_mip_ext.name: gpu_set_tex_max_mip_ext

parameters.name: sampler_index
parameters.description: The index of the shader sampler to get

parameters.name: maxmip
parameters.description: The maximum mipmap level value to use (default: 16)

gpu_set_tex_max_mip_ext.description: With this function you can get the currently set maximum mipmap level which is to be used for a given shader sampler. You supply the index value for the shader sampler (as returned by the function shader_get_sampler_index(), and the function will return the current maximum mipmap level, where a value of 0 is the highest resolution, 1 is to use the first mipmap, 2 is the second etc... Note that this can be quite useful for avoiding bleeding artifacts when rendering textures, for example, setting the texture page border to 8px and then setting the max mipmap level to 3 will ensure you don't get any bleeding problems at greater render distances.

camera_get_view_angle.name: camera_get_view_angle

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_view_angle.description: This function can be used to retrieve the angle of the given camera. The return value will be between 0 and 360. Note that this function is only valid for cameras created using camera_create_view() or for those added in the room editor.

ds_map_find_value.name: ds_map_find_value

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map to use.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to find.

ds_map_find_value.description: With this function you can get the value from a specified key. The input values of the function are the (previously created) DS map to use and the key to check for.

gpu_set_texfilter.name: gpu_set_texfilter

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable or disable texture filtering (true / false)

gpu_set_texfilter.description: This function can be used to set the texture filtering (linear interpolation) of all images drawn on the game screen. When this is enabled (true) all textures will be smoothed when drawn (this includes sprites as they too are considered textures), meaning that when scaled or moved if there is not a 1:1 pixel ratio then there will be a "smudging" across various pixels which may make images appear blurry depending on the art style used. If this is disabled (false) then images will be drawn based on the nearest pixel when scaled or moving which may lead to "blocky" images. The default value is false, and this can also be changed in the Global Game Options for individual target platforms.

part_type_colour_rgb.name: part_type_colour_rgb

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: rmin
parameters.description: The minimum the final colour's red component can be.

parameters.name: rmax
parameters.description: The maximum the final colour's red component can be.

parameters.name: gmin
parameters.description: The minimum the final colour's green component can be.

parameters.name: gmax
parameters.description: The maximum the final colour's green component can be.

parameters.name: bmin
parameters.description: The minimum the final colour's blue component can be.

parameters.name: bmax
parameters.description: The maximum the final colour's blue component can be.

part_type_colour_rgb.description: With this function you can set the mix of red, green and blue colours for all particles created of the given type. You supply a minimum value and a maximum value for each of the three components and the particles created will have a random colour based on the given range of parameters. All values must be between 0 and 255.

irandom.name: irandom

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The upper range from which the random number will be selected.

irandom.description: This very useful function only returns integers (whole numbers). So, for example, to get a random number from 0 to 9 you can use irandom(9) and it will return a number from 0 to 9 inclusive. Note that floats can also be used but the upper value after the point will be excluded, so irandom(9.7) will return a value from 0 to 9 only. The function has an upper bound of $7fffffffffffffffLL, so care should be taken if using very large numbers.

sequence_keyframedata_new.name: sequence_keyframedata_new

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of keyframe data to create, a constant, listed above.

sequence_keyframedata_new.description: With this function you can create a new keyframe data struct, supplying the type of track that the keyframe data will be applied to, which will be one of the following constants:

physics_particle_group_get_vel_x.name: physics_particle_group_get_vel_x

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The particle group to get.

physics_particle_group_get_vel_x.description: With this function you can retrieve the horizontal velocity of a group of particles. The group value is that which was returned when you created the group of particles using the function physics_particle_group_end(), and the function will return a value which is the combined value of the currently set flags.

filename_ext.name: filename_ext

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The file to use.

filename_ext.description: This function returns the extension part of the indicated file name, including the leading dot.

object_get_parent.name: object_get_parent

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The index of the object to check

object_get_parent.description: This function will get you the object_index of any parent that has been assigned to the specified object, or else return -100 to show that the object has no parent assigned to it, or -1 if the object being checked does not exist. For more information on parents see the section on the Object Editor.

zip_unzip.name: zip_unzip

parameters.name: zip_file
parameters.description: The zip file to open

parameters.name: target_directory
parameters.description: The target directory to extract the files to

zip_unzip.description: This function will open a stored zip file and extract its contents to the given directory. Note that if you do not supply a full path to the ZIP directory then the current drive root will be used, and if you want to place it in a relative path to the game bundle working directory then you should use the working_directory variable as part of the path (relative paths using "." or ".." will not work as expected so should be avoided). Note too that the zip must be either part of the game bundle (ie: an Included File) or have been downloaded to the storage area using http_get_file().

gamepad_get_button_threshold.name: gamepad_get_button_threshold

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

gamepad_get_button_threshold.description: This function can be used to detect the current threshold setting of the analogue buttons for a given device. The default threshold for all analogue buttons is 0.5, with the range being from 0 to 1. The threshold defines at what point the button is considered as being "pressed" for games that require them to act as a digital button.

network_set_timeout.name: network_set_timeout

parameters.name: socket
parameters.description: The id of the socket to use.

parameters.name: read_timeout
parameters.description: The milliseconds in which a transfer from a server will timeout.

parameters.name: write_timeout
parameters.description: The milliseconds in which a transfer to a server will timeout.

network_set_timeout.description: With this function you can set the timeout for reading and writing data to/from a server through the given socket. Note that the timeout does not generate any type of event, so you will need to deal with timeouts yourself using alarms (for example). Note that this value only affects the sending and receiving of data, and should you wish to change the connection timeout value then you should be using the function network_set_config().

rollback_define_extra_network_latency.name: rollback_define_extra_network_latency

parameters.name: latency
parameters.description: Number of ms of latency to add

rollback_define_extra_network_latency.description: This function sets an extra latency to be added to all sent and received network messages. This can be used to simulate worse network conditions for the local player.

array_shift.name: array_shift

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

array_shift.description: This function will remove the first element in the given array and return its value. If the array is empty undefined is returned.

physics_particle_get_gravity_scale.name: physics_particle_get_gravity_scale
physics_particle_get_gravity_scale.description: With this function you can find out what the current gravity scale factor is for particles in the physics simulation (you can set this value using physics_particle_set_gravity_scale()).

url_open_full.name: url_open_full

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The URL (website address) to link to.

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: This is the target area to open the URL in (see description).

parameters.name: options
parameters.description: Standard browser options (see description).

url_open_full.description: This will open the specified URL on the browser of the chosen target device, or, if you are using the HTML5 module, in the currently open browser. The "target" parameter that you specify is the same as the standard JavaScript "name" value when you use the open() method (be aware that all but "_self" may result in the browser blocking, or asking the user if they wish to allow it) and the "options" is the same as the JavaScript "specs" parameter for controlling what properties the new window/tab should display (not all browsers may support all features).

part_emitter_stream.name: part_emitter_stream

parameters.name: ps
parameters.description: The particle system that the emitter is in.

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to burst from.

parameters.name: parttype
parameters.description: The index (type) of the particles to be created.

parameters.name: number
parameters.description: The number of particles to create per step.

part_emitter_stream.description: This function allows you to set an emitter to stream a specific type of particle and is typically used the create event as it is a one off code that sets the emitter to generate the number of particles specified every step of the game there-after. The particles are emitted following the distribution, shape and position set by the function part_emitter_region(). You can set the number of particles being streamed to zero and call this function again to "switch off" the particle streaming, and the function will also accept negative numbers for the amount, in which case the emitter will produce particles based on random chance. For example, if you have the particle number set to -5, there is a 1:5 chance that a particle will be produced every step. Should you need the particles to appear all at once rather than every step, you should be using the function part_emitter_burst().

show_debug_message_ext.name: show_debug_message_ext

parameters.name: str_format
parameters.description: The custom debug message to show.
An array of values to be replaced on the format string (non-string elements will be converted to string).

show_debug_message_ext.description: This function will create a custom debug message that is shown in the compiler window at runtime. This function requires a format string using "{x}" (i.e. {0},{1},...) as placeholders and passing the correspondent values as and array of values.

draw_healthbar.name: draw_healthbar

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the healthbar

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top of the healthbar

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right of the healthbar

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the healthbar

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: The variable which defines total health (between 0 and 100)

parameters.name: backcol
parameters.description: The colour of the background for the bar

parameters.name: mincol
parameters.description: The colour of the bar when at no health (0)

parameters.name: maxcol
parameters.description: The colour of the bar when at full health (100)

parameters.name: direction
parameters.description: Where the bar is "anchored" (0 = left, 1 = right, 2 = top, 3 = bottom)

parameters.name: showback
parameters.description: Whether the bar's background is drawn (true) or not (false). If false, the backcol argument is disregarded.

parameters.name: showborder
parameters.description: Whether the bar's elements have a 1px wide black border (true) or not (false).

draw_healthbar.description: With this function you can draw a coloured bar to show a constant value. Although the function uses the word "healthbar" you can use this to display anything you wish as long as the amount to be displayed is a percentage value between 0 and 100 (a percentage of any value can be calculated with the formula (CURRENT_Value / MAXIMUM_value) * 100), so, for example, you can use this to display power, health, mana, time or anything else that would benefit from a bar display.

keyboard_check_pressed.name: keyboard_check_pressed

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to check the pressed state of.

keyboard_check_pressed.description: With this function you can check to see if a key has been pressed or not. Unlike the keyboard_check() function, this function will only run once for every time the key is pressed down, so for it to trigger again, the key must be first released and then pressed again. The function will take a keycode value as returned by the function ord() (only capital letters from A-Z or numbers from 0-9), or any of the vk_* constants listed on the main Keyboard Input page.

layer_get_name.name: layer_get_name

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to get the name of

layer_get_name.description: You can use this function to get the name of the given layer. You supply the unique layer ID value and if the layer is one of the named layers created in the room editor, then the function will return a string with the layer name. If the layer is not one of the room editor ones (ie: it was created using layer_create()) then an empty string will be returned.

audio_is_playing.name: audio_is_playing

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to check.

audio_is_playing.description: This function will check the given sound to see if it is currently playing. The sound can either be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions) or a sound asset, in which case all instances of the given sound will be checked and if any of them are playing the function will return true otherwise it will return false. Note that this function will still return true if the sound being checked has previously been paused using the audio_pause_sound() function.

array_any.name: array_any

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: function
parameters.description: The function used to perform the check. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return a boolean.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_any.description: With this function you can check if any of the elements returns true to the given predicate. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.

ds_map_add_list.name: ds_map_add_list

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map to use.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key for the added list.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The id of the list to add.

ds_map_add_list.description: With this function you can assign a (previously created) DS list to a key within the given DS map. This function is designed for creating JSON compatible maps which you would then encode using json_encode() and should only be used in conjunction with that functionality. If a DS map has a list added in this way, destroying the parent map will also destroy the contained lists and free their memory, and calling ds_map_clear() on the parent map will also destroy and clean up any flagged lists.

matrix_set.name: matrix_set

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of matrix to get the values of (see the constants listed above)

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: The matrix data as an array

matrix_set.description: This function takes an array of 16 values, corresponding to a given 4x4 matrix type, where elements [0 - 3] would be row 1, elements [4 -7] would be row 2, etc... (see the image on the main page). You can create such a matrix using the matrix_build() or matrix_get() functions or simply building the array yourself and passing that into the function. The available matrix types are view, projection and world, for which you would use one of the following constants:

video_get_format.name: video_get_format
video_get_format.description: This function will return the format of the surface

tile_set_flip.name: tile_set_flip

parameters.name: tiledata
parameters.description: the tile-data to set

parameters.name: flip
parameters.description: Set to true to flip and false to leave it as-is

tile_set_flip.description: This function can be used to set a given set of tile-data to flip the tile or not. You give the tile-data, which can be retrieved using the function tilemap_get(), and then set the flip argument to either true if you want the tile flipped, or false if you want the tile to be in its default, un-flipped state. The function will return a modified tile-data set which can then be applied using the tilemap_set() function.

vertex_format_add_normal.name: vertex_format_add_normal
vertex_format_add_normal.description: Tell GameMaker to accept surface normal data (nx, ny and nz) as part of the new vertex format being created.

keyboard_check_released.name: keyboard_check_released

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to check the released state of.

keyboard_check_released.description: With this function you can check to see if a key has been released or not. Unlike the keyboard_check() function, this function will only run once for every time the key is lifted, so for it to trigger again, the key must be first pressed and then released again. The function will take a keycode value as returned by the function ord() (only capital letters from A-Z or numbers from 0-9), or any of the vk_* constants listed on the main Keyboard Input page.

audio_effect_create.name: audio_effect_create

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of audio effect to create.

parameters.name: params
parameters.description: A struct containing any initial values for the effect's parameters.

audio_effect_create.description: This function creates and returns a new audio effect struct, which can be modified to configure the effect's properties.

audio_system_is_initialised.name: audio_system_is_initialised
audio_system_is_initialised.description: This function can be used to check if the audio engine has been initialised, after which all audio functions can be called normally. For all targets other than HTML5, this will return true on Game Start. On HTML5, this may only begin to return true after Game Start. While audio_system_is_available() reflects the ability to play audio, this function reflects the ability to call audio functions more generally.

ini_open.name: ini_open

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The filename for the .ini file.

ini_open.description: This opens an ini_file for reading and/writing. If the ini_file does not exist at the location you are checking, GameMaker may create one, but only if you write data to it. If you have only read information from the ini file, then the default values for the read function will be returned, but the ini file will not actually be created.

gamepad_get_guid.name: gamepad_get_guid

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: Which gamepad "slot" index to check

gamepad_get_guid.description: With this function you can retrieve the GUID for the gamepad connected to the given slot index. You supply the gamepad slot to check (from 0 - 11), and the function will return one of the following strings:

cos.name: cos

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The angle (in radians) to return the cosine of.

cos.description: In a right angled triangle cos(val) = Adjacent / Hypotenuse where val is one of the three angles. This function will always return a number between 1 and -1.

buffer_base64_decode.name: buffer_base64_decode

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The base64 encoded string to decode

buffer_base64_decode.description: With this function you can decode a base64 encoded string (created using the buffer_base64_encode() function) into a buffer. This function will create the buffer (as a 1 byte aligned "grow" buffer") and return the unique index for the buffer which should be used in all further function calls.

file_text_readln.name: file_text_readln

parameters.name: fileid
parameters.description: The id of the file to read from.

file_text_readln.description: With this function you can skip the remainder of the current line from a given opened text file and move to the start of the next one. The function will also return the full line as a string, making it an easy way to read complete "chunks" of data for parsing later.

array_contains.name: array_contains

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value to check inside the array.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when looking through the array. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: How many entries should be checked. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_contains.description: Determines whether an array includes a certain value among its entries, returning true or false as appropriate.

degtorad.name: degtorad

parameters.name: deg
parameters.description: The degrees to convert.

degtorad.description: In GM all the trigonometric functions work in radians, but most people work in degrees and this means that to convert your degrees into radians you need to use this function. For example, degtorad(180) returns 3.14159265 radians. This function translates degrees into radians using the formula:

layer_sprite_get_angle.name: layer_sprite_get_angle

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to get the information from

layer_sprite_get_angle.description: This function can be used to get the current angle for the sprite element. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and the function will return real value for the angle. This value will be between 0 and 360, where 0 represents right, 90 up, 180 left and 270 down.

gpu_get_alphatestenable.name: gpu_get_alphatestenable
gpu_get_alphatestenable.description: With this function you can check to see whether alpha testing is enabled (returns true) or not (returns false). For more information on alpha testing, see the function gpu_set_alphatestref().

achievement_load_progress.name: achievement_load_progress
achievement_load_progress.description: This function will send a request to the server for information on all available achievements. It will trigger a callback Social Asynchronous Event which contains the async_load map populated with the relevant key/value pairs. The id key of this DS Map is used to identify the correct callback (there can be more than one trigger function for any given asynchronous event), and will be paired with the constant achievement_achievement_info as well as a number of other key/value pairs for each player. The exact contents of the map are shown below:

array_contains_ext.name: array_contains_ext

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: values
parameters.description: An array of values to be search inside the provided array.

parameters.name: matchAll
parameters.description: Whether the match should be complete of partial.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when looking through the array. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: How many entries should be checked. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_contains_ext.description: Determines whether an array includes certain values among its entries, returning true or false as appropriate. Doesn't account for order.

date_days_in_month.name: date_days_in_month

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The date to use.

date_days_in_month.description: With this function you can get the number of days that the given month has, either 28, 29, 30 or 31.

camera_set_view_target.name: camera_set_view_target

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

parameters.name: instance_id/object_id
parameters.description: Instance or object to have the camera target for following

camera_set_view_target.description: You can use this function to set the follow target of the view camera within the room. You give the unique camera ID value (as returned by the different camera_create() functions) and then give the target instance or object ID that you wish to set the camera view to. Note that if you choose an object ID and there is more than one instance of that object in the room, there is no way for GameMaker to know which instance you wish to follow and so it could be any of them.

http_post_string.name: http_post_string

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The web address of the server that you wish to get information from

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string you wish to send to the specified URL

http_post_string.description: In computing, a post request is used when the client needs to send data to the server as part of the retrieval request, such as when uploading a file or submitting a completed form, and the same is true of this function in GameMaker. In contrast to the http_get() request method where only a URL is sent to the server, http_post_string() also includes a string that is sent to the server and may result in the creation of a new resource or the update of an existing resource or both. It should be noted that HTTP request parameters (the bits sometimes "tacked on" to the end of a URL when you submit a form on a web page) are perfectly acceptable when using this function too.

part_type_colour_hsv.name: part_type_colour_hsv

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: hmin
parameters.description: The minimum the final colour's hue component can be.

parameters.name: hmax
parameters.description: The maximum the final colour's hue component can be.

parameters.name: smin
parameters.description: The minimum the final colour's saturation component can be.

parameters.name: smax
parameters.description: The maximum the final colour's saturation component can be.

parameters.name: vmin
parameters.description: The minimum the final colour's value component can be.

parameters.name: vmax
parameters.description: The maximum the final colour's value component can be.

part_type_colour_hsv.description: With this function you can set a hue, saturation and value range for all particles of the given type. You supply a minimum value and a maximum value for each of the three components and the particles created will have a random colour based on the given range of parameters. In this way you can create particles of the same hue but different saturations, or of different hues but the same value (luminosity) etc... All values must be between 0 and 255.

rollback_define_input_frame_delay.name: rollback_define_input_frame_delay

parameters.name: delay
parameters.description: Number of frames to use for local input frame delay

rollback_define_input_frame_delay.description: This function sets a fixed local input frame delay.

ds_list_copy.name: ds_list_copy

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the list being copied to.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The id of the list to be copied from.

ds_list_copy.description: With this function you can copy the contents of one list into another. Both lists must have been created previously and if the list being copied to already has information within it, this list will be cleared first. The end result is two independent lists which contain the same information.

object_get_visible.name: object_get_visible

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The index of the object to check.

object_get_visible.description: This function will tell you whether the object you are checking has been flagged as "visible" (runs its draw event) or not (does not run its draw event). Please note that this is not an instance function! So, you can have a visible object and an invisible instance of the same object and vice-versa. You can set an individual instances visibility using the visible instance variable.

draw_sprite_stretched.name: draw_sprite_stretched

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to draw.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the area the stretched sprite will occupy.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height of the area the stretched sprite will occupy.

draw_sprite_stretched.description: This function simply takes a sprite resource and stretches it over the given width and height so that it occupies that area. As with draw_sprite() you can specify a sprite and a sub-image for drawing, then the x / y position in the room for the sprite to be drawn at and finally a width and a height (which must be pixel values). The image below shows the result of this function with different sets of arguments:

surface_get_texture.name: surface_get_texture

parameters.name: surface_id
parameters.description: The ID of the surface to get the width of.

surface_get_texture.description: This function returns a special pointer for the surface texture. This value can then be used in other draw functions, particularly in general 3D and some of the 2D primitive functions.

font_add_sprite.name: font_add_sprite

parameters.name: spr
parameters.description: The sprite to add a font based on.

parameters.name: first
parameters.description: The index of the first available character.

parameters.name: prop
parameters.description: Set as proportional font or not.

parameters.name: sep
parameters.description: The space to leave between each letter.

font_add_sprite.description: With this function you can use a "sprite strip" to create a new font asset, where each sub-image would be an individual symbol or letter. The index is the UTF8 map number for the first character to use and the ranges to use are the same as you would for a normal font, starting with "!" but remember that you should only include what you need and that you should be using the ord() function to get the correct UTF8 value for the starting letter. The created sprite font will then have the sub-images set to an individual glyph from the font, where the "first" glyph will have the image_index of 0. You can define "space" as being any character you want, for example a single line the size that you want the space to be, and all spaces in text will be rendered at that width (but the image chosen will never be rendered), or if you don't supply a sprite for space then the width of the widest character in the sprite font will be used instead.

room_previous.name: room_previous

parameters.name: numb
parameters.description: The index of the room to get the one before from.

room_previous.description: With this function you can retrieve the index of the room before the room input into the function. For example you can use the variable room to get the index of the current room and then use this function to find the room that comes before it, as listed in the Room Manager. If there is no room before the one you input then -1 is returned. Note that this function will not recognise or take into consideration rooms that have been added dynamically using room_add() or room_duplicate().

ds_list_add.name: ds_list_add

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the list to add to.
The value to add to the list.

ds_list_add.description: This function can be used to add a new value (real or string) to the list, which will be added on at the end. The function can take further optional arguments (as many as you require), permitting you to add multiple values consecutively to the list in a single call.

ds_grid_add.name: ds_grid_add

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of the cell in the grid.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of the cell in the grid.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to add to the cell.

ds_grid_add.description: This function can be used to add a given value (real or string) to the value of the given cell within the grid. The value to be added must be the same type as that held within the grid cell, ie: you cannot add a string to a real or vice-versa, and for strings this corresponds to concatenation.

window_get_colour.name: window_get_colour
window_get_colour.description: This function returns the background colour of the game window. This colour represents that which will be used for those areas of the game window that are not occupied by any views. The following image illustrates this:

physics_particle_get_data.name: physics_particle_get_data

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The (previously created) buffer to use to store the data.

parameters.name: flags
parameters.description: The flags to use to extract data about specific particle types.

physics_particle_get_data.description: This function returns various pieces of information about each particle in the physics simulation using the given flags checked. The buffer used must have been created previously using the function buffer_create(), and should be of the "grow" type, with the size being approximately that of the expected return data. The flags are set using any of the constants given below, and you would use the bitwise or "|" to create a single flag value to get the desired information.

gpu_set_blendenable.name: gpu_set_blendenable

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable or disable alpha blending value (true or false).

gpu_set_blendenable.description: This function can be used to toggle alpha-blending on and off. Basically, if you have this set to false, all images being drawn will be drawn 100% opaque, meaning that any transparent, or semi transparent, areas of a sprite or background will be visible as a solid colour. It is a good idea to have alpha blending off whenever possible (especially when developing for mobile devices) as this greatly increases the draw speed.

room_next.name: room_next

parameters.name: numb
parameters.description: The index of the room to get the next one after.

room_next.description: With this function you can retrieve the index of the room after the room input into the function. For example you can use the variable room to get the index of the current room and then use this function to find the room that follows it, as listed in the Room Manager. If there is no room after the one you input then -1 is returned. Note that this function will not recognise or take into consideration rooms that have been added dynamically using room_add() or room_duplicate().

scheduler_resolution_get.name: scheduler_resolution_get
scheduler_resolution_get.description: This function is used to retrieve the resolution of the Windows thread scheduler in milliseconds. If the scheduler's resolution is set to the default value (as set by Windows), the function will return -1.

audio_group_load.name: audio_group_load

parameters.name: groupid
parameters.description: The index of the audio group to load (as defined in the Audio Groups Window)

audio_group_load.description: This function will load all the sounds that are flagged as belonging to the given Audio Group into memory. The function will return true if loading is initiated and false if the group ID is invalid, or it has already been flagged for loading. The function is asynchronous so your game will continue to run while the audio is loaded in the background. This means that it will also trigger an Asynchronous Load/Save Event to inform you that the whole group has been loaded into memory and the sounds can now be used.

physics_fixture_set_sensor.name: physics_fixture_set_sensor

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the index of the fixture

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: whether a fixture is a sensor (true) or not (false)

physics_fixture_set_sensor.description: Some times you will want your game to detect and recognise when two instances with fixtures collide, but not have any physical reaction to the collision. This can be done by converting the fixture into a sensor, which basically means that they will generate a collision event but with no physical response so that you can use these instances as "triggers" for other events to happen in the game room. Any fixture can be flagged as a sensor, and it makes no difference if the instance it is bound to is static or in movement.

physics_apply_angular_impulse.name: physics_apply_angular_impulse

parameters.name: impulse
parameters.description: The impulse (in Newton metres) to be applied

physics_apply_angular_impulse.description: This function will give an angular impulse to a physics enabled instance. This impulse will set the angular rotation by the amount given, ignoring the current torque, essentially setting the amount of "spin" that a fixture has. If you wish to apply an angular force to an instance using torque, then you should be using the function physics_apply_torque().

font_get_fontname.name: font_get_fontname

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: Index of the font to check.

font_get_fontname.description: With this function you can get the actual system name of the selected font asset. This function returns a string and not an index, and the name returned will depend on the font being used. For example, you may have a font asset called "fnt_Main" in the GameMaker Asset Browser, and the font itself may be the Windows system font Arial. In this case the function will return "Arial" as that is the system name of the font. Should you need the name as it appears in the Asset Browser, you should use font_get_name().

view_get_visible.name: view_get_visible

parameters.name: view_port
parameters.description: The view port to target (0 - 7)

view_get_visible.description: This function can be used to check the visibility of the given view port. The function will return true if it is visible and false if it is not.

ds_grid_value_y.name: ds_grid_value_y

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x position of the left of the region in the grid, from 0 to (grid width - 1).

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y position of the top of the region in the grid, from 0 to (grid height - 1).

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x position of the right of the region in the grid, from 0 to (grid width - 1).

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y position of the bottom of the region in the grid, from 0 to (grid height - 1)

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to find.

ds_grid_value_y.description: With this function you can get the y coordinate (within the given rectangular grid region) of the value being searched for. You give the DS grid index (as returned by ds_grid_create()) along with the x/y positions for the top left and bottom right corners of the grid region to search, before supplying the value to search for. If the value being searched for does not exist, then the function will return -1.

draw_triangle_colour.name: draw_triangle_colour

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the triangle's first corner.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the triangle's first corner.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the triangle's second corner.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the triangle's second corner.

parameters.name: x3
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the triangle's third corner.

parameters.name: y3
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the triangle's third corner.

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The colour of the first corner.

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The colour of the second corner.

parameters.name: col3
parameters.description: The colour of the third corner.

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the triangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

draw_triangle_colour.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a triangle or a filled triangle. If it is filled you can define the individual colours for each corner point and if these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()).

physics_particle_create.name: physics_particle_create

parameters.name: flags
parameters.description: The flags to set on the particle.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to create the particle at.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to create the particle at.

parameters.name: xv
parameters.description: The initial horizontal velocity.

parameters.name: yv
parameters.description: The initial vertical velocity.

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The base colour to use for the particle.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The base alpha to use for the particle.

parameters.name: category
parameters.description: The user defined category to which the particle belongs.

physics_particle_create.description: With this function you can create a single particle anywhere within your game room, setting certain flags and properties. The "flags" are the return value of a combination of the following constants:

ds_grid_destroy.name: ds_grid_destroy

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: This index of the grid to destroy.

ds_grid_destroy.description: This function will remove the given grid data-structure from memory, freeing up the resources it was using and removing all values that it contained. This function should always be used when you are finished using the DS grid to prevent memory leaks that can slow down and crash your game.

audio_get_name.name: audio_get_name

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to check.

audio_get_name.description: This function will return the name of a given audio resource as a string. The "index" value can be that of the resource itself (as seen in the Asset Browser) or the unique ID value that is given when you play the sound using, for example, audio_play_sound(). Note that the string returned is not the same as the resource ID and cannot be used to access the resource itself, so should only be used for displaying or error checking.

audio_emitter_get_bus.name: audio_emitter_get_bus

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The emitter whose audio bus should be returned.

audio_emitter_get_bus.description: This function returns the audio bus that an emitter is linked to.

is_numeric.name: is_numeric

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The input to check.

is_numeric.description: This function returns whether a given variable is a numeric value (real, int32, int64 or boolean) or not. In some cases you want to check and see if a variable in GameMaker holds any numeric value, and that's when you would use this function. The function will return true if the given input is numeric, and false otherwise.

tilemap_set_height.name: tilemap_set_height

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to set the height of

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height value (in "cells")

tilemap_set_height.description: This function can be used to resize a tile map element. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and the new height of the tile map in tile cells.

rollback_set_player_prefs.name: rollback_set_player_prefs

parameters.name: default
parameters.description: Player preferences

rollback_set_player_prefs.description: This function is used to update the local player preferences. Preferences can only be set after joining or creating a game, but before starting the game.

physics_fixture_set_linear_damping.name: physics_fixture_set_linear_damping

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the index of the fixture

parameters.name: damping
parameters.description: the damping of the fixture, usually between 0 and 1

physics_fixture_set_linear_damping.description: Damping is used to reduce the physics world velocity of instances, and differs from friction in that friction only occurs when two instances with fixtures are in contact. Damping is also much cheaper to simulate than friction, but please note that damping is not a replacement for friction; the two effects can, and should, be used together. Here is an image to illustrate damping:

display_set_ui_visibility.name: display_set_ui_visibility

parameters.name: flags
parameters.description: The Android SYSTEM flags to use (as an integer value).

display_set_ui_visibility.description: This function can be used to show or hide the system UI on Android only. The function requires you to supply one or more system flags as an integer value. When using more than a single flag, these need to be merged using the bitwise "or", as shown in the example below. You can find a list of Android system flags here.

audio_free_buffer_sound.name: audio_free_buffer_sound

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the buffered sound to free.

audio_free_buffer_sound.description: With this function you can free up the pointer index value associated with the sound ID. Freed sounds will not be available for playing, and if multiple instances of the sound are being played they will all be stopped. Note that before you can delete the buffer itself, you must first free all sound ID's associated with it.

mp_grid_add_rectangle.name: mp_grid_add_rectangle

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Index of the mp_grid that is to be used

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the rectangle to check.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top side of the rectangle to check.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right side of the rectangle to check.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the bottom side of the rectangle to check.

mp_grid_add_rectangle.description: This function asks you to define a rectangle within the room, and then it marks all MP grid cells "touch" that rectangle as being forbidden, meaning that the path-finding functions cannot cross them. The image below illustrates how this works:

ds_list_insert.name: ds_list_insert

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the list to add to.

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: The position to add the value, where 0 corresponds to the very beginning of the list and the final position is ds_list_size(id)-1.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to add to the list.

ds_list_insert.description: This function will add the given value into the list at the given position. if the list contains more values after the given position, their position will be shifted up one to make room making the list larger by one.

ds_map_secure_load_buffer.name: ds_map_secure_load_buffer

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer ID of the buffer to load the map data from.

ds_map_secure_load_buffer.description: This function will load a secure saved DS map from a buffer. You must previously have loaded the buffer into memory (using buffer_load()) and then passing that into this function will return a DS map populated with the contents of the buffer. Note that the buffer must have been created using the function ds_map_secure_save_buffer() for this to work correctly, and also note that if the DS map being loaded contained an array, this will be converted into a DS list instead on load.

ds_map_destroy.name: ds_map_destroy

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map to destroy.

ds_map_destroy.description: DS maps take up space in memory, which is allocated to them when they are created. This means that you also need to free this memory when the DS map is not needed to prevent errors, memory leaks and loss of performance when running your game. This function does just that. Note that destroying a map will de-reference any data structures stored in the map giving a memory leak, so you would need to go through the map and destroy all data structure items manually before destroying it to prevent this. The only time this is not required is when you have flagged any items in the map as a DS list or as another DS map, in which case these items will be destroyed and their memory cleaned up automatically as well.

sprite_get_xoffset.name: sprite_get_xoffset

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to find the xoffset of.

sprite_get_xoffset.description: When you define a sprite in the sprite editor, you need to set the origin for that sprite. This is the point at which the sprite will be "attached" or "drawn" when used with an instance. This function returns the relative offset for the x-axis of the origin based on the upper left corner being the 0,0 position, with a +x being right and a -x being left of this. The following image illustrates this:

push_get_first_local_notification.name: push_get_first_local_notification

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: The DS Map ID to use.

push_get_first_local_notification.description: This function will populate a pre-made DS map with a series of key/value pairs for the first local push notification in the queue to be shown. It returns -1 if there are no notifications queued, or a real value otherwise representing the ID for the notification. This ID can then be used to cancel the notification using the function push_cancel_local_notification().

instance_place_list.name: instance_place_list

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to check for instances.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to check for instances.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for instances of.

parameters.name: list
parameters.description: The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.

parameters.name: ordered
parameters.description: Whether the list should be ordered by distance (true) or not (false).

instance_place_list.description: With this function you can check a position for a collision with all instances of an object using the collision mask of the instance that runs the code for the check. When you use this you are effectively asking GameMaker to move the instance to the new position, check for a collision, then move back and tell you if a collision was found or not. This will work for precise collisions, but only if both the instance and the instances of the object being checked for have precise collision masks selected, otherwise only bounding box collisions are applied. The function will populate a (previously created) DS list with the unique id values of all instances of the object that are considered to be in collision with the calling instance, and you have the option to order the list based on the distance from the origin of the instance doing the checking to the origin of the instances found to be in collision. Note that the function also accepts the special keyword all, in which case all instances found to be in collision will be listed. The function returns the number of instances found, or 0 if none are found.

physics_fixture_set_restitution.name: physics_fixture_set_restitution

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: The index of the fixture

parameters.name: restitution
parameters.description: The restitution of the fixture (usually between 0 and 1)

physics_fixture_set_restitution.description: In physics, restitution is defined as "the return of an object or system to its original state after elastic deformation", but as the fixtures in the GameMaker are really rigid bodies and cannot be deformed, restitution is really a way of saying how "bouncy" the fixture is. This setting will affect how much an object "bounces" when it collides with other objects and is co-dependent on other forces that act on the instance like gravity and friction, and is usually a value between 0 and 1 (higher values can be used but may give unpredictable results). Here is an illustration of how it works:

highscore_value.name: highscore_value

parameters.name: place
parameters.description: The place on the table (1-10).

highscore_value.description: With this function you can clear the internal global high score list, resetting all names to the default value of "Unknown" and all scores to the default value of 0.

md5_string_unicode.name: md5_string_unicode

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to hash.

md5_string_unicode.description: In cryptography, MD5 (Message-Digest algorithm 5) is a widely used cryptographic hash function with a 128-bit hash value and has been employed in a wide variety of security applications. It is also commonly used to check the integrity of files and strings. This function will take an input unicode string (which is 16bits for each char) and return the 32-character hexadecimal MD5 hash that is unique to that string. In this way you can generate a secure key which can be stored and used to check the integrity of the information being sent to (or received from) an external server (for example).

display_set_timing_method.name: display_set_timing_method

parameters.name: method
parameters.description: The timing method to use (see the list of constants, above)

display_set_timing_method.description: This function can be used to set the timing method to be used for rendering your game. The method can be one of the following constants:

draw_line_colour.name: draw_line_colour

parameters.name: x1
