parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The colour of the start of the line.

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The colour of the end of the line.

draw_line_colour.description: With this function you can draw a 1 pixel wide line with the colour blended between colour 1 at the first point and colour 2 at the second point. The colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour(). Please note that the line being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

layer_tilemap_get_id.name: layer_tilemap_get_id

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target (or the layer name as a string)

layer_tilemap_get_id.description: This function can be used to retrieve the unique ID value of the tile map element on a layer. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the function will return the ID value associated with the tile map element on the layer. Note that this function is specifically designed for use with tile maps that have been added in the IDE, as if you add a tile map to a layer through code using the function layer_tilemap_create(), then it will return the unique ID for the tile map element added. If the given tilemap ID is incorrect or the tilemap doesn't exist, the function will return -1.

darctan.name: darctan

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to return the inverse tangent of.

darctan.description: Returns the inverse tangent of x. This will accept any number as, unlike dtan(), darctan() asymptotes are on the y axis so it just means you'll never get returned a number greater than 90 or less than -90.

surface_copy_part.name: surface_copy_part

parameters.name: destination
parameters.description: The ID of the surface to copy the other surface to.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to copy to.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to copy to.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The ID of the surface to be copied.

parameters.name: xs
parameters.description: The x position in the source surface to copy from.

parameters.name: ys
parameters.description: The y position in the source surface to copy from.

parameters.name: ws
parameters.description: The width of the area in the source surface to copy from.

parameters.name: hs
parameters.description: The height of the area in the source surface to copy from.

surface_copy_part.description: This function simply takes the image from one surface and copies it onto another one at the specified local position within that surface (where the (0,0) position is the top left corner of the destination surface). You can specify a local x and y position to copy from as well as the width and height of the section. Please note that these are coordinates based on the surface size and not on the position at which the surface is being drawn in the room. If the destination surface already has information this will be overwritten by the copy, and the function does not change the source surface in any way.

date_get_year.name: date_get_year

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to check.

date_get_year.description: This function returns the year of the given datetime.

path_start.name: path_start

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The path index to start.

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed of which to follow the path in pixels per step, negative meaning going backwards.

parameters.name: endaction
parameters.description: What to do when the end of the path is reached (see the constants listed below).

parameters.name: absolute
parameters.description: Whether the calling instance should follow the absolute path as it is in the editor (true) or a relative path to its current position (false).

path_start.description: A path is created from a series of defining points that are linked together and then used to plan the movements of an instance. They can be created with code, or in the Path Editor and they are assigned to an instance to use in the game. You would then use this function to tell your instance which path to follow, what speed to follow the path (measured in pixels per step), how to behave when it reaches the end of the path, and whether to follow the absolute or relative path position. This last part means that it either starts and follows the path exactly as you designed and placed it in the Path Editor (absolute), or it starts and follows the path from the position at which the instance was created (relative).

audio_listener_set_velocity.name: audio_listener_set_velocity

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The listener to get the data for (default 0).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x velocity of the listener (default 0).

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y velocity of the listener (default 0).

parameters.name: z
parameters.description: The z velocity of the listener (default 0).

audio_listener_set_velocity.description: This function can be used to give the given listener Doppler effects and simulate audio motion based on the vector that is resolved from the given relative x, y and z positions. The default listener index is 0, but you can use the function audio_get_listener_info() to get the different indices available for the target platform.

camera_copy_transforms.name: camera_copy_transforms

parameters.name: dest_camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value for the camera the values will be copied to.

parameters.name: src_camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value for the camera the values will be copied from.

camera_copy_transforms.description: This function will copy the transforms from one camera to another.

layer_sprite_get_y.name: layer_sprite_get_y

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to get the information from

layer_sprite_get_y.description: This function can be used to get the y position of the sprite element in the room. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and the function will return the y position value.

window_get_x.name: window_get_x
window_get_x.description: With this function you can get the x position (in pixels) within the browser if it is an HTML5 game or within the display if it is a Windows, Ubuntu (Linux) or macOS game.

draw_surface_stretched.name: draw_surface_stretched

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the surface to draw.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width at which to draw the surface.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height at which to draw the surface.

draw_surface_stretched.description: This function simply takes a surface and stretches it over the given width and height so that it occupies the area. As with draw_surface() you can specify a surface and then the x / y position in the room for the surface to be drawn at and finally a width and a height (which must be pixel values).

game_save_buffer.name: game_save_buffer

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer id to save to.

game_save_buffer.description: This is a variant of the game_save() function, so please read its page first as it contains important information related to its use and to this function's as well.

font_cache_glyph.name: font_cache_glyph

parameters.name: font
parameters.description: The font to cache a character or glyph from

parameters.name: glyph_index
parameters.description: The index (or character code) of the glyph to cache (see ord/string_ord_at)

font_cache_glyph.description: This function lets you pre-cache a character glyph from a font. If you don't pre-cache a character using this function, it's automatically cached before it's drawn for the first time.

path_change_point.name: path_change_point

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to change a point of.

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The defining point to change the attributes of.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The new x coordinate (relative to the path) of the point.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The new y coordinate (relative to the path) of the point.

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The new speed factor of the point.

path_change_point.description: With this function you can change the position and/or the speed factor of any point previously defined for a path (the path can have been created in the path editor or through code using path_add()). If used on a path from the Asset Browser, note that the function will change the actual asset, and so will permanently affect how the path is used by all instances in the game from the moment the function is used until the end of the game. If this is not what you require, then you should use a function like path_duplicate() to create a copy of the path first, then call this function on the duplicated asset (don't forget to call path_delete() on the asset when it is no longer required).

draw_line.name: draw_line

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the end of the line.

draw_line.description: With this function you can draw a 1 pixel wide line between any two points in the game room. Please note that the line being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

collision_point.name: collision_point

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the point to check.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the point to check.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for instance collisions.

parameters.name: prec
parameters.description: Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).

parameters.name: notme
parameters.description: Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).

collision_point.description: Collision_point checks the point specified by the arguments x1,y1 for a collision with any instance of the object specified by the argument "obj". this check can be either precise or not, but for precise collisions to be enabled, the object or instance that you are checking for must also have precise collisions enabled for their sprite. If not, the default check is based on bounding boxes. The following image illustrates how this works:

move_outside_solid.name: move_outside_solid

parameters.name: dir
parameters.description: The direction to move in.

parameters.name: maxdist
parameters.description: The maximum distance the object can travel (-1 or 0 a default value of 1000 pixels).

move_outside_solid.description: With this function you can tell an instance to move out of a collision with any instance flagged as solid in any direction and any number of pixels each step, with a value of -1 or 0 for the maxdist being a default 1000px, ie: GameMaker will move the instance continually up 1000 pixels until it is out of collision.

layer_background_get_xscale.name: layer_background_get_xscale

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to get the information from

layer_background_get_xscale.description: This function can be used to get the current scale multiplier value of the background element. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and the function will return real value that represents the scale multiplier being used to draw the sprite. Default value is 1.

font_get_texture.name: font_get_texture

parameters.name: font
parameters.description: The index of the font to use.

font_get_texture.description: This function returns a special pointer for the font texture page. This value can then be used in other draw functions, particularly in general drawing when using primitives as well as the Shader functions. You can get more information about the returned texture page using the different texture_ functions found here.

part_type_life.name: part_type_life

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: life_min
parameters.description: The minimum lifespan of the particles.

parameters.name: life_max
parameters.description: The maximum lifespan of the particles.

part_type_life.description: This is the function that governs how long each individual particle of the indicated type remains on the screen. As with other particle functions, you provide a minimum and a maximum value (in steps)and each particle lifespan will be a random number of steps from within the specified range. To have all particles with the same lifetime, set the two values to be the same.

gamepad_set_vibration.name: gamepad_set_vibration

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

parameters.name: left_motor
parameters.description: The amount of vibration from the left motor from 0 to 1.

parameters.name: right_motor
parameters.description: The amount of vibration from the right motor from 0 to 1.

gamepad_set_vibration.description: With this function you can set the vibration of the gamepad motors, with either motor using a value from 0 (no vibration) to 1 (full vibration). Note that there is no time limit on this function, so you will need to use a variable or an alarm to switch off the vibration (set motors to 0) after a given time has passed otherwise the gamepad will continue to vibrate indefinitely.

physics_apply_local_force.name: physics_apply_local_force

parameters.name: xlocal
parameters.description: The x coordinate relative to the origin where the force will be applied

parameters.name: ylocal
parameters.description: The y coordinate relative to the origin where the force will be applied

parameters.name: xforce
parameters.description: the x component of the force vector

parameters.name: yforce
parameters.description: the y component of the force vector

physics_apply_local_force.description: Another way to use force in the physics world is to apply it locally to an instance. What this means is that the strength and direction of the force are calculated based on the origin (or the position if it has no sprite) of the instance, without taking into consideration the direction or rotation it may have in the game room or physics world. It should be noted that with this function, forces are not applied to the center of mass of the object, but rather at a point relative to the instance and they will not be instantly applied as they are dependent on any other forces that are working on the object (like gravity). This illustration demonstrates how a local force works:

keyboard_virtual_status.name: keyboard_virtual_status
keyboard_virtual_status.description: This function can be used to get the status of the virtual keyboard on the device running the game. The function will return true if the OS virtual keyboard is visible/being shown or false if it is hidden/hiding.

part_system_layer.name: part_system_layer

parameters.name: ps
parameters.description: The particle system ID

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The new layer ID

part_system_layer.description: This function can be used to switch a particle system from its current layer to a new one. You supply the particle system ID value (as returned by the function part_system_create_layer()) and then the unique layer ID (as returned by the function layer_create() or the name of the layer to use as a string - for example "instance_layer" - as defined in the room editor), and the system will be moved to the new layer.

os_is_paused.name: os_is_paused
os_is_paused.description: When developing for mobile devices, you need to have a way to check that the device is still focused on your game or not, especially as if your game is on an iOS, Android or Windows Phone device then it can be interrupted by phone calls and other apps. You can use this function to check if the device is paused or not.

clickable_add_ext.name: clickable_add_ext

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position within the window.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position within the window.

parameters.name: tpe
parameters.description: The texture page entry for the sprite to be used.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The URL (website address) to link to, or the script to be run.

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: This is the target area to open the URL in (see description).

parameters.name: params
parameters.description: The various parameters for the icon (see description).

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The image alpha of the icon (default 1).

parameters.name: scale
parameters.description: The scale of the icon (default 1).

clickable_add_ext.description: With this function you can create a custom, clickable, icon that acts as a "button" outside of the game canvas, but within the browser window itself. The function will return an id value which must be stored in a variable to be used in all further button functions that reference the new icon. This function is very useful to prevent the browser creating a pop-up window when clicking on the button as it is all done through GameMaker itself.

skeleton_slot_colour_get.name: skeleton_slot_colour_get

parameters.name: slot
parameters.description: The slot name to check, a string

skeleton_slot_colour_get.description: With this function you can get an attachment slot colour. You supply the slot name (a string) and the function will return an integer value for the colour.

dot_product.name: dot_product

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the second vector.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the second vector.

dot_product.description: The dot product is a value expressing the angular relationship between two vectors and is found by taking two vectors, multiplying them together and then adding the results. The name "dot product" is derived from the centered dot "·" that is often used to designate this operation (the alternative name "scalar product" emphasizes the scalar rather than vector nature of the result).

os_is_network_connected.name: os_is_network_connected

parameters.name: attempt_connection
parameters.description: OPTIONAL! For Nintendo Switch Target only. Set to true to attempt an OS level connection when called.

os_is_network_connected.description: With this function you can check and see if your device currently has an internet connection and it will return true if it does, or false if it does not, and depending on the OS, it may attempt to make a connection before returning a value.

angle_difference.name: angle_difference

parameters.name: ang1
parameters.description: The first angle to use.

parameters.name: ang2
parameters.description: The second angle to use.

angle_difference.description: This function will return the smallest angle difference between two angles as a value between -180 and 180 degrees (where a positive angle is anti-clockwise and a negative angle clockwise).

vertex_texcoord.name: vertex_texcoord

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to write the information to.

parameters.name: u
parameters.description: The first texture coordinate to use (0 - 1).

parameters.name: v
parameters.description: The second texture coordinate to use (0 - 1).

vertex_texcoord.description: This function will set the texture coordinates to use for the vertex currently being defined for the custom primitive. You supply the buffer to write the data into as well as the UV position within the texture to use.

texture_is_ready.name: texture_is_ready

parameters.name: tex_id
parameters.description: The texture page ID (an integer) or a texture group ID (a string)

texture_is_ready.description: This function can be used to check if a specific texture page has been unpacked and is ready for use, or if a group of texture pages have been unpacked and are ready for use. You supply the unique texture page ID (as returned by the texturegroup_* functions) or the texture group ID string (as defined in the Texture Group Editor), and the function will return true if they have been unpacked, or false otherwise.

window_set_color.name: window_set_color

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour to set the region.

window_set_color.description: This function can set the background colour of the game window. This colour represents that which will be used for those areas of the game window that are not occupied by any views. The following image illustrates this:

part_emitter_burst.name: part_emitter_burst

parameters.name: ps
parameters.description: The particle system that the emitter is in.

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to burst from.

parameters.name: parttype
parameters.description: The index (type) of the particles to be created.

parameters.name: number
parameters.description: The number of particles to create.

part_emitter_burst.description: This function allows you to set an emitter to burst a specific type of particle and is typically used in alarms and destroy events as it is a one off code that creates the number of particles specified all at once following the distribution, shape and position set by the function part_emitter_region(). Should you need the particles to appear every step, you should be using the function part_emitter_stream() rather than calling this function every step.

ds_queue_empty.name: ds_queue_empty

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to check.

ds_queue_empty.description: With this function you can check the given DS queue to see if it is empty (returns true) or not (returns false).

script_get_name.name: script_get_name

parameters.name: scr
parameters.description: The index of the script that you want to get the name of.

script_get_name.description: This function will return the name as a string of the specified script. This name is the one that has been specified for the script in the Asset Browser of the main GameMaker window. For more information about scripts, see The Script Editor.

md5_string_utf8.name: md5_string_utf8

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to hash.

md5_string_utf8.description: In cryptography, MD5 (Message-Digest algorithm 5) is a widely used cryptographic hash function with a 128-bit hash value and has been employed in a wide variety of security applications. It is also commonly used to check the integrity of files and strings. This function will take an input UTF-8 string (which has a variable number of bytes per character) and return the 32-character hexadecimal MD5 hash that is unique to that string. In this way you can generate a secure key which can be stored and used to check the integrity of the information being sent to (or received from) an external server (for example).

lerp.name: lerp

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The first value.

parameters.name: b
parameters.description: The second value.

parameters.name: amt
parameters.description: The amount to interpolate.

lerp.description: With this function you can find the value that equates to the position between two other values for a given percentage. So if you do, for example:

gpu_get_blendmode_ext_sepalpha.name: gpu_get_blendmode_ext_sepalpha
gpu_get_blendmode_ext_sepalpha.description: This function can be used to retrieve the current extended blend mode being used for drawing, separating out the blend modes into two parts - the RGB component and the Alpha component. The function returns a 4 element 1D array with the following elements in it:

string_delete.name: string_delete

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to copy and delete from.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The position of the first character to remove.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: The number of characters to remove.

string_delete.description: You can use this function to remove a specific part of a string. So, you supply the input string and the start and end position within that string to remove characters (index starts at 1) and the function will return a new string without that section in it.

audio_stop_recording.name: audio_stop_recording

parameters.name: channel_index
parameters.description: The index of the recorder channel to stop.

audio_stop_recording.description: This function will stop recording on the given recorder channel (the channel index is returned when you call the function audio_start_recording()). When you stop recording, no further Audio Recording Asynchronous Events will be triggered for the given recorder channel, so you would normally use this function in the actual asynchronous event to ensure that you have captured all the data.

make_color_hsv.name: make_color_hsv

parameters.name: hue
parameters.description: The hue of the colour

parameters.name: sat
parameters.description: How saturated the colour is

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: How dark the colour is

make_color_hsv.description: GameMaker provides this function (as well as others) to permit the user to make their own colours. This particular function takes three component parts, the hue, the saturation and the value (also know as "luminosity") to create the colour desired. These values are taken as being between 0 and 255 so you can make 16,777,216 (256*256*256) colours with this! Below you can see an image of how these components look when separated:

date_inc_minute.name: date_inc_minute

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to add to.

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: The number of minutes (must be an integer) to add.

date_inc_minute.description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of minutes, and it will return the new datetime value.

skeleton_attachment_replace_colour.name: skeleton_attachment_replace_colour

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name (as a string) of the attachment to create.

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The sprite_index to get the attachment image from.

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The image_index to get the attachment image from.

parameters.name: xorigin
parameters.description: The x origin for the image being used.

parameters.name: yorigin
parameters.description: The y origin for the image being used.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling of the image, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling of the image, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: rot
parameters.description: The rotation of the image: 0 = normal, 90 = turned 90° counter-clockwise etc.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour value to use (A constant, integer or hex value).

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha value to use (from 0 to 1).

skeleton_attachment_replace_colour.description: When you create you skeletal animation sprite, you can assign attachment slots and attachments to go in them. These are simply images (sprites) that are separate from the animation but when attached will move along with the bone they are attached to. Normally you would assign these attachments in your animation program (Spine), but with this function you can create/replace your own at run-time using a sprite asset from your game. the function requires that you give the attachment a name (as a string) and then set the sprite_index and image_index to use, as well as the x and y origin (which can be different to that defined by the sprite in the sprite properties), and you can also set any transforms that you wish to be applied to the image when attached, as well as the colour to be blended with the image and it's alpha (transparency) value. If the attachment was successfully created the function will return 1 and if it was not (you supplied an invalid sprite index, or the base sprite is not a Spine sprite) then it will return -1.

time_source_exists.name: time_source_exists

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

time_source_exists.description: Returns true if the given index corresponds to an existing time source.

date_get_hour_of_year.name: date_get_hour_of_year

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to check.

date_get_hour_of_year.description: This function returns the hour of the given datetime value within the year (from the total number of hours for the year, taking into account leap years).

audio_exists.name: audio_exists

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to check the existence of.

audio_exists.description: This function returns whether a sound exists (true) or not (false). Note that if the index you search for has not been initialised previously, this function will cause an error as it is searching for non-existent asset indices. The sound to check can either be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions) or a sound asset.

vertex_float3.name: vertex_float3

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to write the information to.

parameters.name: float
parameters.description: The first input value.

parameters.name: float
parameters.description: The second input value.

parameters.name: float
parameters.description: The third input value.

vertex_float3.description: This function will add three floating point values to the vertex data. The vertex must have been formatted correctly to accept this using the vertex_format_add_custom() function.

dot_product_3d.name: dot_product_3d

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: z1
parameters.description: The z coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the second vector.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the second vector.

parameters.name: z2
parameters.description: The z coordinate of the second vector.

dot_product_3d.description: The dot product is a value expressing the angular relationship between two vectors and is found by taking two vectors, multiplying them together and then adding the results. The name "dot product" is derived from the centered dot "·" that is often used to designate this operation (the alternative name "scalar product" emphasizes the scalar rather than vector nature of the result).

physics_particle_group_get_inertia.name: physics_particle_group_get_inertia

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The particle group to get.

physics_particle_group_get_inertia.description: With this function you can retrieve the inertia of an entire group of particles. The group value is that which was returned when you created the group of particles using the function physics_particle_group_end(), and the function will return a value which is the combined value of the currently set flags.

gesture_get_pinch_distance.name: gesture_get_pinch_distance
gesture_get_pinch_distance.description: This function is used to get the distance within which you have to touch/click the screen and move with two fingers before you trigger a Pinch Gesture. The distance is measured in inches and has a default value of 0.1.

device_mouse_y.name: device_mouse_y

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.

device_mouse_y.description: This function returns the y position of a touch on the device. If you are running this on a the HTML5 or PC and Mac modules then this value is updated constantly, as long as the device (usually a mouse) is plugged in, however for mobile devices, this will only be updated while the screen is being touched and note that the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs. Also note that on HTML5 only "device 0" will function correctly and other devices may give wrong values.

ds_exists.name: ds_exists

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The variable index to check for the data structure

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of data structure to check for (see the list of constants below)

ds_exists.description: With this function you can check to see if a data structure of the given type exists. You supply the "index" value (as held in a variable) and the DS "type", which can be any of the constants listed below, and the function will return true if the data structure exists and false otherwise.

ds_map_add_map.name: ds_map_add_map

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map to use.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key for the added map.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The id of the map to add.

ds_map_add_map.description: With this function you can assign a (previously created) DS map to a key within the given DS map . This function is designed for creating JSON compatible maps which you would then encode using json_encode() and should only be used in conjunction with that functionality. If a DS map has another map added in this way, then destroying the parent map will also destroy the contained maps and free their memory, and calling ds_map_clear() on the parent map will also destroy and clean up any flagged maps.

skeleton_skin_get.name: skeleton_skin_get
skeleton_skin_get.description: With skeletal animation sprites, you can assign separate textures (called "skins") to the animation, thereby using one animation for multiple different things. This function will return the name of the skin (as a string) that is currently assigned to the skeletal animation sprite your instance is using. The name returned is that which you set when you created the sprite in your animation program.

gesture_pinch_angle_towards.name: gesture_pinch_angle_towards
gesture_pinch_angle_towards.description: This function is used to set the angle within which a touch must be moving towards another touch before a Pinch In Gesture may potentially be started. The angle is measured in degrees and has a default value of 45°.

layer_sequence_get_xscale.name: layer_sequence_get_xscale

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

layer_sequence_get_xscale.description: With this function you supply the sequence element ID - as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions - and it will return the current scale along the X axis of the sequence element in the game room.

is_int64.name: is_int64

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The argument to check.

is_int64.description: This function returns whether a given variable is a 64bit integer or not. In some cases you want to check and see what data type a variable holds in GameMaker and that's when you would use this function. It returns true or false depending on whether the value is an int64 or not.

view_get_wport.name: view_get_wport

parameters.name: view_port
parameters.description: The view port to target (0 - 7)

view_get_wport.description: This function can be used to retrieve the width of the given view port.

draw_sprite_stretched_ext.name: draw_sprite_stretched_ext

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to draw.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the area the stretched sprite will occupy.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height of the area the stretched sprite will occupy.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour with which to blend the sprite. c_white is to display it normally.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha of the sprite (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

draw_sprite_stretched_ext.description: This function does exactly the same as the draw_sprite_stretched() function with the added ability to set the colour blending and alpha value for the sprite when it is drawn (similar to the function draw_sprite_ext()).

display_get_width.name: display_get_width
display_get_width.description: This function will return the width of the display (in pixels). Note that on the HTML5 target, this value is the width of the browser window, rather than the physical display size.

audio_emitter_get_z.name: audio_emitter_get_z

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to use.

audio_emitter_get_z.description: This function returns the current z position of the given audio emitter.

instance_activate_layer.name: instance_activate_layer

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The layer ID string (or value) to be used

instance_activate_layer.description: With this function you can activate a layer that has been deactivated previously. You need to supply the layer ID, which can either be the name of the layer as written in the code editor (as a string) or the actual layer ID value as returned by the layer_create() and all deactivated instances on that layer will activated once again. Note that if you have deactivated a layer that has persistent instances, you will need to reactivate the layer again with this function before changing room, otherwise any persistent instances will not be carried over and will be discarded. Note too that activation is not instantaneous, and an instance that has been activated in this way will not be considered to be active until the end of the event in which the function was called.

layer_sequence_is_finished.name: layer_sequence_is_finished

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

layer_sequence_is_finished.description: With this function you supply the sequence element ID - as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions - and it will check if the sequence is finished playing or not, returning true if it is, and false if it is not. Note that this is only applicable when the sequence is not set to loop or ping-pong in the playback mode.

rectangle_in_triangle.name: rectangle_in_triangle

parameters.name: sx1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the source rectangle.

parameters.name: sy1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top side of the source rectangle.

parameters.name: sx2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right side of the source rectangle.

parameters.name: sy2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom side of the source rectangle.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first side of the triangle to check.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the first side of the triangle to check.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the second side of the triangle to check.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the second side of the triangle to check.

parameters.name: x3
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the third side of the triangle to check.

parameters.name: y3
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the third side of the triangle to check.

rectangle_in_triangle.description: This function will check a rectangular area that you define to see if it is either not in collision, completely within the destination bounds, or if it is simply touching, a defined triangular area. If they are not touching at all the function will return 0, if the source is completely within the destination it will return 1, and if they are simply overlapping then it will return 2. The image below illustrates this:

array_set.name: array_set

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the array to set the value for.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value to set.

array_set.description: With this function you can set the value of an index in an array to a value. The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array as well as the index to set and the value to set it to. This function can also be used for multi-dimension arrays, as long as you specify which dimension you want to set when you supply the array index, following this pattern:

gesture_get_drag_distance.name: gesture_get_drag_distance
gesture_get_drag_distance.description: This function is used to get the distance it takes for a Dragging Gesture event to be triggered by the movement of a touch or click. The distance is measured in inches and has a default value of 0.1.

font_sdf_spread.name: font_sdf_spread

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the font.

parameters.name: spread
parameters.description: The SDF spread value to set for the specified font.

font_sdf_spread.description: With this function you can set the SDF spread value for the specified font. This only works on fonts added using font_add(), and its effect is only visible if the font is using SDF rendering.

draw_surface_general.name: draw_surface_general

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the surface to draw.

parameters.name: left
parameters.description: The left position in the surface of the part to be drawn.

parameters.name: top
parameters.description: The top position in the surface of the part to be drawn.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the part to be draw, from left.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height of the part to be draw, from top.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling to draw the surface with.

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling to draw the surface with.

parameters.name: rot
parameters.description: The rotation or angle to draw the surface with.

parameters.name: c1
parameters.description: The colour of the top left corner of the surface.

parameters.name: c2
parameters.description: The colour of the top right corner of the surface.

parameters.name: c3
parameters.description: The colour of the bottom right corner of the surface.

parameters.name: c4
parameters.description: The colour of the bottom left corner of the surface.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha transparency to draw the surface with..

draw_surface_general.description: This function combines the function draw_surface_ext() with the function draw_surface_part(), adding in some additional blending options so that each corner of the final surface part can be blended with an individual colour.

keyboard_virtual_show.name: keyboard_virtual_show

parameters.name: keyboard_type
parameters.description: Determines the keyset available on the virtual keyboard.

parameters.name: return_key_type
parameters.description: Determines what is shown on the return/action key of the virtual keyboard.

parameters.name: autocapitalization_type
parameters.description: Determines how/if the words typed via the virtual keyboard will be autocapitalized.

parameters.name: predictive_text_enabled
parameters.description: Set to true/false to enable/disable predictive text input.

keyboard_virtual_show.description: This function can be used to show the virtual keyboard on the device running the game. When you call this function you need to provide one of the following constants for each of the first three arguments:

draw_light_enable.name: draw_light_enable

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index number of the light (from 0 to 7)

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable or disable all lighting (true or false)

draw_light_enable.description: This function is used to enable a defined light. When you define a positional or a directional light you must assign it an index number which is then used by this function to switch the light on or off. Default is disabled (false).

device_mouse_check_button_pressed.name: device_mouse_check_button_pressed

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: The device (from 0 - n) that is being checked.

parameters.name: button
parameters.description: The button of the device that is being checked.

device_mouse_check_button_pressed.description: This function returns true or false depending on whether the device that you specify has been "touched" (clicked) or not. The device argument refers to the touch number, which can be from 0 to n and the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs (most devices will support at least 4 simultaneous touches). This function is only triggered once by the actual pressing action, and the constants listed on this page can be used to check for the mouse buttons. Note that mb_right will only be detected if a double tap touch is detected and held on the second tap (this behavior can be disabled using the function device_mouse_dbclick_enable()).

instance_furthest.name: instance_furthest

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to check for instances far from.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to check for instances far from.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for instances of.

instance_furthest.description: This function will check all the instances of the given object to see which is furthest from the given x/y point. All checks will be from the given x/y position to the origin (the x/y position) of instances of the object specified. If no instances of the object exist, the function will return the keyword noone, but if there are instances then it will return the id of the instance found. Please note that if the instance running the code has the same object index as the object being checked, then it will be included in the check (this includes checks for parent objects if the calling instance is also a child of the parent).

is_method.name: is_method

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The variable to check.

is_method.description: This function can be used to check and see if a variable is a method variable (it will return true) or not (in which case it will return false).

layer_background_get_yscale.name: layer_background_get_yscale

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to get the information from

layer_background_get_yscale.description: This function can be used to get the current scale multiplier value of the background element. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and the function will return real value that represents the scale multiplier being used to draw the sprite. Default value is 1.

skeleton_animation_clear.name: skeleton_animation_clear

parameters.name: track
parameters.description: The animation track to clear.

skeleton_animation_clear.description: This function will clear the specified animation track of all animations, ready to be re-assigned.

camera_set_proj_mat.name: camera_set_proj_mat

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera.

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: The unique matrix ID returned when you created the matrix.

camera_set_proj_mat.description: This function will set the projection matrix for a given camera. You give the unique camera ID value (as returned by the different camera_create() functions) and a projection matrix to be applied. You can find out more about creating projection matrices from the section Matrix Functions, specifically matrix_build_projection_perspective() and matrix_build_projection_ortho().

draw_button.name: draw_button

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the button

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top of the button

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right of the button

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the button

parameters.name: up
parameters.description: Whether the button is up (true) or down (false)

draw_button.description: This function will draw a very simple, rectangular "button" using the currently selected draw colour and alpha where the up argument defines how the beveled edge effect looks, as shown in the image below:

vertex_end.name: vertex_end

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to end writing to.

vertex_end.description: With this function you end the building of the custom primitive. Once you call this command the primitive can be used in the vertex_submit() function for use in a shader or you can freeze the buffer (making the vertex buffer used read-only and much faster) using vertex_freeze().

physics_fixture_set_circle_shape.name: physics_fixture_set_circle_shape

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the index of the fixture

parameters.name: rad
parameters.description: radius of the circle

physics_fixture_set_circle_shape.description: This function defines a circle shape for your fixture with a radius defined by the argument "rad".

draw_skeleton_collision.name: draw_skeleton_collision

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to draw.

parameters.name: animname
parameters.description: The name of the animation to get the frame from (a string).

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: The animation frame to draw (from 0 to image_number - 1).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: rot
parameters.description: The rotation of the sprite. 0=normal, 90=turned 90 degrees counter-clockwise etc.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour with which to blend the sprite.

draw_skeleton_collision.description: This function will draw the collision masks associated with the given skeletal animation. You supply the base sprite, the animation set to use and the frame to get the information from, and you can also set the transform properties to suit.

asset_get_type.name: asset_get_type

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the game asset to get the type of (a string).

asset_get_type.description: This function gets the type of asset being referenced from its name (a string).

audio_group_get_assets.name: audio_group_get_assets

parameters.name: group_index
parameters.description: The index of the audio group whose asset indices should be retrieved.

audio_group_get_assets.description: This function will return an array containing the asset index of each audio asset in the given audio group.

date_year_span.name: date_year_span

parameters.name: date1
parameters.description: The first datetime.

parameters.name: date2
parameters.description: The datetime to compare it to.

date_year_span.description: With this function you can get the number of years between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete years will be returned as a fraction.

shader_get_name.name: shader_get_name

parameters.name: shader
parameters.description: The index of the shader to get the name of.

shader_get_name.description: With this function you can retrieve the name of a shader resource. You supply the unique ID value for the shader to get the name of and the function will return the name of the resource as a string.

physics_joint_pulley_create.name: physics_joint_pulley_create

parameters.name: inst1
parameters.description: The first instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: inst2
parameters.description: The second instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: w_anchor1_x
parameters.description: The x coordinate where the first part of joint is anchored, within the game world

parameters.name: w_anchor1_y
parameters.description: The y coordinate where the first part of the joint is anchored, within the game world

parameters.name: w_anchor2_x
parameters.description: The x coordinate where the second part of the joint is anchored, within the game world

parameters.name: w_anchor2_y
parameters.description: The y coordinate where the second part of the joint is anchored, within the game world

parameters.name: l_anchor1_x
parameters.description: The local x coordinate where joint 1 is anchored to the first instance

parameters.name: l_anchor1_y
parameters.description: The local y coordinate where joint 1 is anchored to the first instance

parameters.name: l_anchor2_x
parameters.description: The local x coordinate where joint 2 is anchored to the second instance

parameters.name: l_anchor2_y
parameters.description: The local y coordinate where joint 2 is anchored to the second instance

parameters.name: ratio
parameters.description: Set the velocity ratio between two instances

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

physics_joint_pulley_create.description: The pulley joint is used to connect two instances within the physics world in such a way that moving one will directly influence the movement of the other. These joints are first anchored in the world space at two points, each one connected to an instance at its center of mass. This can be changed by setting the local anchor x/y coordinates relative to the origin of the instance, meaning that the actual connection from the instance to the physics world anchor point can be offset somewhere other than its origin. The following image illustrates this:

ds_list_replace.name: ds_list_replace

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the list to change.

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: The position to replace the value, where 0 corresponds to the very beginning of the list and the final position is ds_list_size(id)-1.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The new value to replace the given value with.

ds_list_replace.description: This function will replace the value at the given position for another one.

part_particles_create.name: part_particles_create

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to create the particles.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to create the particles.

parameters.name: parttype
parameters.description: The index (type) of the particles to be created.

parameters.name: number
parameters.description: The number of particles to create.

part_particles_create.description: This function is ideal for those effects that do not require any of the functionality offered by particle emitters (for example, to create smoke from a missile, or a simple explosion effect) as it permits you to quickly and easily create particles at any position in the game room. Note that you must have created the particle system and the particle type previously for this function to be used.

buffer_sha1.name: buffer_sha1

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to use.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The data offset value.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the buffer.

buffer_sha1.description: In cryptography, SHA-1 is a cryptographic hashing function designed by the United States National Security Agency and is employed in several widely used applications and protocols like the popular Git where it is used to check for file changes. This function will take input data from a buffer and returns a 160 bit message digest in ASCII format. In this way you can generate a secure key which can be stored and used to check the integrity of the information being sent to (or received from) an external server (for example). When applying this to buffers using this function you must specify the buffer id of the buffer to use, then an offset value (in bytes) for where to begin, and then a size (again in bytes) for the region to be hashed.

ds_map_secure_load.name: ds_map_secure_load

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The name of the file to load the map data from.

ds_map_secure_load.description: This function will load a previously saved DS map from the given file. This file must have been previously created using the ds_map_secure_save() function, and, when loaded, the function will return the index of the DS map that has been created from the loaded data. This DS map index should be stored in a variable and used for all further function calls to this map. Note that if the DS map being loaded was saved with an array as one of the key values, this array will have been converted into a DS list on load.

array_copy_while.name: array_copy_while

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: function
parameters.description: The function to be executed for each array entry. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return a boolean.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_copy_while.description: With this function you can create a new array from elements of the current array while the predicate is matched. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.

date_inc_year.name: date_inc_year

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to add to

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: The number of years (must be an integer) to add.

date_inc_year.description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of years, and it will return the new datetime value.

move_random.name: move_random

parameters.name: hsnap
parameters.description: The horizontal snapping (the size in pixels between 'cells').

parameters.name: vsnap
parameters.description: The vertical snapping (the size in pixels between 'cells').

move_random.description: With this function you can set the instance to a position anywhere in the room, but aligned to an "invisible" grid. So a value of 32 for the hsnap and vsnap will set the instance to a random position that is aligned to a grid of 32x32 squares. you can set these values to 1 to get a position anywhere in the room.

vertex_create_buffer_ext.name: vertex_create_buffer_ext

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The initial size of the buffer (in bytes).

vertex_create_buffer_ext.description: As with the function vertex_create_buffer(), this function will create a new vertex buffer. This is a special grow buffer created by GameMaker which is pre-formatted for use when building primitives for use with shaders. You can specify an initial starting size for the buffer (in bytes) and it will return a "handle" (index) for the buffer which should then be used in all further calls to the buffer.

audio_sync_group_debug.name: audio_sync_group_debug

parameters.name: group_index
parameters.description: The group index to debug, or -1 to switch off the debugging.

audio_sync_group_debug.description: his function can be used to display debug information about any given sync group (the group index is the value returned when the group was created using the function audio_create_sync_group()). You can call the function with a value of -1 to switch off the overlay.

layer_background_index.name: layer_background_index

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to change

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The image index to use for the background

layer_background_index.description: This function can be used to set the image index of the background sprite which has multiple sub-images. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and then set the image index to use. If you set a value outside of the range of sub-images, then the image index will loop around.

get_integer_async.name: get_integer_async

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The message to show in the dialog.

parameters.name: default
parameters.description: The default value.

get_integer_async.description: This function opens a window and displays message as well as a space for the user to input a value (which will contain the supplied default value to start with). This is an asynchronous function, and as such GameMaker does not block the device it is being run on while waiting for an answer, but rather keeps on running events as normal. Once the user has typed out their string and pressed the "Okay" button, an asynchronous Dialog event is triggered which, for the duration of that event only, will have a DS map stored in the variable async_load.

draw_surface_part.name: draw_surface_part

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the surface to draw.

parameters.name: left
parameters.description: The left position in the surface of the part to be drawn.

parameters.name: top
parameters.description: The top position in the surface of the part to be drawn.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the part to be draw, from left.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height of the part to be drawn, from top.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of where to draw the surface.

draw_surface_part.description: With this function you can draw part of any surface at a given position within the room. As with draw_surface() you can specify a surface, but you then need to specify the relative coordinates within the surface of an area to select for drawing. This means that a left position of 0 and a top position of 0 would be the top left corner of the surface and all further coordinates should be taken from that position.

color_get_hue.name: color_get_hue

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The color to check

color_get_hue.description: This function will return the hue of the given color. This is the "pure" color tone which is part of the hue, saturation and value (luminosity) method for defining a color. The following image illustrates how this value corresponds to the HSV scale of color:

audio_create_buffer_sound.name: audio_create_buffer_sound

parameters.name: bufferId
parameters.description: The ID of the buffer to use.

parameters.name: bufferFormat
parameters.description: The format of the data in the buffer (buffer_u8 or buffer_s16).

parameters.name: bufferRate
parameters.description: The sample rate of the data in the buffer.

parameters.name: bufferOffset
parameters.description: The offset into the buffer to read the sample data from (in bytes).

parameters.name: bufferLength
parameters.description: The length of the buffer (the number of bytes of audio data, excluding the header).

parameters.name: bufferChannels
parameters.description: The channels to use (audio_mono, audio_stereo or audio_3D).

audio_create_buffer_sound.description: With this function you can create a new sound from the contents of a buffer. The buffer will have been created previously (see the buffer functions for details on how to do this), and have had data added or loaded into it. You then pass it to this function with the data format (only buffer_u8 or buffer_s16 are currently supported), the sample rate (which can be between 1000hz and 48000hz), and an offset into the buffer to get the data from. You also need to supply the number of samples in the buffer and the channels that the sound requires. These channels are defined by one of the following constants:

debug_get_callstack.name: debug_get_callstack

parameters.name: maxdepth
parameters.description: The maximum depth of the callstack

debug_get_callstack.description: This function generates an array of strings as the "callstack" where the current script is listed first, and then all the other scripts that were run in order for the current script to be executed. The exact string format will vary depending on the target platform chosen, but it will mostly have the script/event name, then a colon : and the line number, similar to this:

audio_emitter_get_vx.name: audio_emitter_get_vx

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to use.

audio_emitter_get_vx.description: This function returns the current velocity along the x axis for the given audio emitter.

ini_close.name: ini_close
ini_close.description: This function should be called the moment you are finished reading or writing to any open ini file. If you do not use the function after you have used any of the ini write functions, then nothing will be written to disk, as the file information is held in memory until this function is called, which forces the write. If you try to open an ini without having previously closed another one (or the same one) you will get an error too.

file_text_read_string.name: file_text_read_string

parameters.name: fileid
parameters.description: The id of the file to read from.

file_text_read_string.description: With this function you can read a string from a text file and the function returns that value to be used or stored in a variable.

camera_get_view_height.name: camera_get_view_height

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_view_height.description: This function can be used to retrieve the height (in pixels) of the given camera. Note that this function is only valid for cameras created using camera_create_view() or for those added in the room editor.

part_system_get_layer.name: part_system_get_layer

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The particle system ID value to get the layer ID of

part_system_get_layer.description: This function can be used to retrieve the unique layer ID value for the given particle system. You supply the particle system ID value (as returned by the function part_system_create_layer()) and the function will return the ID value of the layer.

sprite_get_nineslice.name: sprite_get_nineslice

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite from which the Nine Slice struct will be retrieved

sprite_get_nineslice.description: This function returns the Nine Slice struct for a sprite, containing all its Nine Slice properties as set in the Sprite Editor or using sprite_set_nineslice(). The contents of this struct are detailed on this page.

part_type_exists.name: part_type_exists

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to check for.

part_type_exists.description: With this function you can check to see if the given particle type indexed exists in the game or not. Note that if the variable being checked is an uninitialised variable (that a particle type would otherwise have its index assigned to) this will throw an error.

part_emitter_destroy_all.name: part_emitter_destroy_all

parameters.name: ps
parameters.description: The particle system to destroy all emitters from.

part_emitter_destroy_all.description: This function will remove all defined emitters from the given system and clear them from memory (this will also stop any particles from being produced by the given emitter, but it does NOT remove them from the room). This function should always be called when the emitters are no longer needed for the system to prevent memory leaks and errors.

extension_get_version.name: extension_get_version

parameters.name: extension_name
parameters.description: The name of the extension

extension_get_version.description: This functions gets the version of an Extension Asset with the given name, and returns it as a string formatted as "major.minor.revision".

matrix_get.name: matrix_get

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of matrix to get the values of (see the constants listed above)

matrix_get.description: This function returns an array of 16 values, corresponding to the given 4x4 matrix type, where row 1 is elements [0 - 3], row 2 is elements [4 -7], etc... (see the image on the main page). The available matrices are view, projection and world, for which you would use one of the following constants:

physics_joint_wheel_create.name: physics_joint_wheel_create

parameters.name: inst1
parameters.description: The first instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: inst2
parameters.description: The second instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: anchor_x
parameters.description: The x coordinate where the joint is anchored, within the game world

parameters.name: anchor_y
parameters.description: The y coordinate where the joint is anchored, within the game world

parameters.name: axis_x
parameters.description: The x component of the wheel axis vector

parameters.name: axis_y
parameters.description: The y component of the wheel axis vector

parameters.name: enablemotor
parameters.description: Whether the motor should be active (true) or not (false)

parameters.name: max_motor_torque
parameters.description: Sets the maximum motor torque used to achieve the desired motor speed (in Newtons per meter)

parameters.name: motor_speed
parameters.description: This is the speed at which the motor should rotate

parameters.name: freq_hz
parameters.description: This is the oscillation frequency for the joint, in hertz

parameters.name: damping_ratio
parameters.description: This damping ratio for the joint

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

physics_joint_wheel_create.description: A wheel joint simply combines a piston and a revolute joint, like a wheel mounted on the shock absorber of a car. You specify the anchor point for the joint well as the two physics enabled instances to joint, and the first instance will act as the "body" for the joint, while the second will be the "wheel", and be permitted to move freely around the joint axis. You can also set an axis vector, which is the imaginary line along which the joint will act as a "spring" permitting the wheel to bounce up and down along it as it encounters obstacles (much like the piston joint). The following image illustrates this:

is_struct.name: is_struct

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to check.

is_struct.description: This function checks if the supplied value is a struct. It returns true if it is, otherwise it returns false.

tilemap_tileset.name: tilemap_tileset

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to change

parameters.name: tileset_index
parameters.description: The new tile set index to use

tilemap_tileset.description: Using this function you can change the tile set resource assigned to a given tile map element on a layer. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and then supply a tile set index and the tile map will be given the new sprite.

audio_sound_get_loop.name: audio_sound_get_loop

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound whose loop section state is retrieved.

audio_sound_get_loop.description: This function will return the state of a playing sound's loop section.

date_get_day.name: date_get_day

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The date to check.

date_get_day.description: This function returns the day (from 1 to 31) of the given datetime.

display_mouse_get_y.name: display_mouse_get_y
display_mouse_get_y.description: This function will return the mouse y position within the screen. It should be noted that this function only works properly when used on the Windows target. It can be used for HTML5 too, but will only return a value relative to the 0,0 of the canvas itself, and will not return any value while the mouse is outside of the canvas. For other devices it will return 0, and you should use the device_mouse_raw_x() and device_mouse_raw_y() functions instead.

motion_set.name: motion_set

parameters.name: dir
parameters.description: The new direction.

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The new speed.`

motion_set.description: This function sets a new direction of movement and a new speed to the instance running the code. Note that this does not add to the instances current speed and direction (for that you would use motion_add()) but rather forces it to the new settings.

gpu_get_blendmode_destalpha.name: gpu_get_blendmode_destalpha
gpu_get_blendmode_destalpha.description: This function can be used to retrieve the current destination extended blend mode alpha factor. The value returned will be one of the following constants ("s" denotes a value taken from the source while a "d" denotes a value from the destination) with only the "A" component being used when drawing:

ds_grid_get_disk_mean.name: ds_grid_get_disk_mean

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: xm
parameters.description: The x position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: ym
parameters.description: The y position of the disk on the grid.

parameters.name: r
parameters.description: The radius of the disk on the grid.

ds_grid_get_disk_mean.description: This function can be used to find the mean value for all the cells found within the defined disk area of a grid (all cell values are added together and then divided by the total number of cells that make up the disk), as shown in the image below:

draw_triangle.name: draw_triangle

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the triangle's first corner.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the triangle's first corner.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the triangle's second corner.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the triangle's second corner.

parameters.name: x3
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the triangle's third corner.

parameters.name: y3
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the triangle's third corner.

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the triangle is drawn filled (false) or as a one pixel wide outline (true).

draw_triangle.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a triangle or a filled triangle.

audio_destroy_stream.name: audio_destroy_stream

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The file to stream the audio from.

audio_destroy_stream.description: If you have previously created an audio stream from a file using the function audio_create_stream() and no longer need that sound, you can call this function to delete it from memory. Any further calls to the sound index after it has been destroyed will give an error. It should be noted that this will free up the stream but on the target platform this may not show up in a memory manager. This is because GameMaker pools memory resources to prevent memory allocation overhead, and so the memory will remain allocated until required for something else or re-used for a new stream.

layer_get_script_begin.name: layer_get_script_begin

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target (or the layer name as a string)

layer_get_script_begin.description: You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and this function will return the script function index of the function assigned to run at the beginning of rendering for that layer, or it will return -1 if no function is assigned. You can assign script functions to a layer with layer_script_begin() and layer_script_end().

room_get_camera.name: room_get_camera

parameters.name: rm
parameters.description: The index of the room to get the view camera of

parameters.name: vind
parameters.description: The index of the view port to get the camera of

room_get_camera.description: With this function you can get the unique index ID of the camera assigned to a specific view in a room other than the current one. You give the room to use, the view port to use (from 0 to 7) and the function will return a camera index.

video_close.name: video_close
video_close.description: This function is used to close the video file and free up any memory associated with it.

audio_sound_loop.name: audio_sound_loop

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to change.

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: The state that the loop section should be set to.

audio_sound_loop.description: This function will set the state of a playing sound's loop section.

window_set_cursor.name: window_set_cursor
