parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: The cursor to set for the game window.

window_set_cursor.description: With this function you can set the cursor for the game window to any one of the constants listed below (to find the current cursor being used you can use the function window_get_cursor() which will also return one of these constants):

font_get_info.name: font_get_info

parameters.name: font
parameters.description: The font for which information should be retrieved.

font_get_info.description: This function is used to retrieve information for the given font. You supply a font index (which can be an asset added through the Asset Browser or a font added at runtime) and the function returns a struct with the following variables:

achievement_show_achievements.name: achievement_show_achievements
achievement_show_achievements.description: This function will open the achievements page for the chosen platform. Please note that this is an asynchronous function, ie: your game will continue to run in the background while the achievements page is being shown. As such, you should be careful where you use this and make sure to pause the game or only permit it to be shown in areas of your game where it will not interfere with the game-play.

vertex_ubyte4.name: vertex_ubyte4

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to write the information to.

parameters.name: byte
parameters.description: The first input value.

parameters.name: byte
parameters.description: The second input value.

parameters.name: byte
parameters.description: The third input value.

parameters.name: byte
parameters.description: The fourth input value.

vertex_ubyte4.description: This function will add four unsigned byte values (0 - 255) to the vertex data. The vertex must have been formatted correctly to accept this using the vertex_format_add_custom() function.

gesture_flick_speed.name: gesture_flick_speed

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed (in inches per second) to set for flick gesture event detection.

gesture_flick_speed.description: This function is used to set the speed required for a Flick Gesture event to be triggered when a touch or click is released. The speed is measured in inches per second and has a default value of 2.0.

mp_grid_clear_rectangle.name: mp_grid_clear_rectangle

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Index of the mp_grid that is to be used

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the rectangle to check.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top side of the rectangle to check.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right side of the rectangle to check.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the bottom side of the rectangle to check.

mp_grid_clear_rectangle.description: With this function you can define an area in room coordinates which will then clear the corresponding cells in the specified MP grid. Even if a cell partially falls within the defined rectangular region it will be cleared.

video_set_volume.name: video_set_volume

parameters.name: volume
parameters.description: The volume is a linear value from 0 to 1.

video_set_volume.description: This function will set the volume for any video that you play

date_inc_week.name: date_inc_week

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to add to.

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: The number of weeks (must be an integer) to add.

date_inc_week.description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of weeks, and it will return the new datetime value.

physics_particle_get_max_count.name: physics_particle_get_max_count
physics_particle_get_max_count.description: With this function you can find out what the current cap value is on particles permitted in the physics simulation (you can set this value using physics_particle_set_max_count()).

get_open_filename_ext.name: get_open_filename_ext

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description: The file type filter and/or name.

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The suggested filename to use.

parameters.name: directory
parameters.description: The directory to start the search from.

parameters.name: caption
parameters.description: The caption for the window.

get_open_filename_ext.description: This function opens a dialogue and asks the player for a filename to open with the given filter. The filter has the form "name1|mask1|name2|mask2|...", where the mask may contain the different options with a semicolon between them and you can also use a "*" to mean any string. For example: "bitmaps|*.bmp;*.wmf", would ask the user to select the name of a bitmap file from the system, but only those that have the two specified extensions (bmp and png). this function does not open the file itself! It only returns a string with the full name and path of the file. If the user presses "Cancel" an empty string "" is returned. You may also add in a directory to start the search from, and a caption to be shown at the top of the window instead of the default one.

sequence_exists.name: sequence_exists

parameters.name: sequence_struct_or_id
parameters.description: The sequence object struct or ID to check for

sequence_exists.description: With this function you can check to see if a sequence object exists or not. You supply either the sequence object struct (as returned by the function sequence_create() or sequence_get()) or the sequence ID (as returned by the function layer_sequence_get_sequence() or from the sequence instance struct property sequence, or the index from the asset browser) and the function will return true if the sequence object exists or false if it does not.

buffer_get_address.name: buffer_get_address

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to use.

buffer_get_address.description: With this function you can get the a pointer to the raw, aligned buffer address. This is primarily for use with extensions as you can pass this value through to them, allowing them to access the buffer data. Note that there are a few things you cannot do with the buffer when accessing from an extension:

layer_background_get_htiled.name: layer_background_get_htiled

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to get the information from

layer_background_get_htiled.description: This function can be used to find out if the background element is tiled horizontally or not. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and the function will return either true if the element is currently tiled, or false if it is not.

ds_grid_multiply_grid_region.name: ds_grid_multiply_grid_region

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the destination grid.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The index of the source grid.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The left position of the region of cells to copy from the source grid.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The top position of the region of cells to copy from the source grid.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The right position of the region of cells to copy from the source grid.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The bottom position of the region of cells to copy from the source grid.

parameters.name: xpos
parameters.description: The x position on the destination grid to multiply the source region with.

parameters.name: ypos
parameters.description: The y position on the destination grid to multiply the source region with.

ds_grid_multiply_grid_region.description: With this function you can define an area within a given DS grid, then take those values and multiply them with those found in a separate region of either the same DS grid, or another one (which has been previously created). The original region will remain unchanged, while the region that they have been multiplied with will now store the new values for each cell.

texturegroup_get_tilesets.name: texturegroup_get_tilesets

parameters.name: tex
parameters.description: The name of the texture group to check (a string)

texturegroup_get_tilesets.description: With this function you can retrieve the tileset index of each of the tilesets assigned to texture pages within the given texture group. You supply the texture group ID string (as defined in the texture Group Editor) and the function will return a 1D array where each entry contains the tileset index for a tileset resource. If the function fails - ie: an invalid group is given, or the group has no texture assigned to it - then the array will be empty (0 length).

gpu_get_state.name: gpu_get_state
gpu_get_state.description: This function will get the current GPU state, returning it as a DS Map. This can then be manipulated or even saved, and you can return this map to the GPU using the function gpu_set_state().

struct_get_names.name: struct_get_names

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The struct reference to check.

struct_get_names.description: With this function you can retrieve an array populated with the variable names from a struct. You pass in the struct reference to check, and each entry in the array will be a string of the variable names that the struct contains.

layer_background_get_index.name: layer_background_get_index

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to get the information from

layer_background_get_index.description: This function can be used to get the current image index value of the background element. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and the function will return real value that represents the image index being shown for the sprite. The function will return -1 if either the background element doesn't exist or the element doesn't have a valid sprite assigned to it.

room_add.name: room_add
room_add.description: This function will create a new, empty, room and add it to your game, returning its index to be stored in a variable for all further codes that deal with this room. Note that each room is permanently added to the game until the executable is closed, ie: rooms added through code cannot be deleted again. This has important implications for memory use and so you should use this function with care.

layer_sequence_destroy.name: layer_sequence_destroy

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

layer_sequence_destroy.description: With this function you can destroy (remove from the room) a sequence element. You supply the sequence element ID as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions and the sequence will be destroyed.

ds_priority_add.name: ds_priority_add

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the priority queue to add to.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to add to the priority queue.

parameters.name: priority
parameters.description: The priority of the value to add.

ds_priority_add.description: With this function you can add a value (either a real number or a string) to a priority queue, at the same time assigning it a priority value.

surface_depth_disable.name: surface_depth_disable

parameters.name: disable
parameters.description: If set to true the depth buffer will be disabled for created surfaces.

surface_depth_disable.description: This function disables the automatic depth buffer generation for all surfaces that are created after it has been disabled. Normally all surfaces have depth buffers so if you draw 3D objects to them then it'll sort them properly by depth in order to maintain functional parity between rendering to surfaces and rendering to the back buffer, however allocating depth buffers essentially doubles the amount of memory required for surfaces, which could be an excessive and unnecessary overhead especially if your game is very memory intensive, and for 2D games they aren't generally required.

video_resume.name: video_resume
video_resume.description: This function will resume the video

darccos.name: darccos

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The value to return the inverse cosine of.

darccos.description: Returns the inverse cosine of x, in that if dcos(val)=n, darccos(n)=val, and the resulting number will be between 180 and 0.

struct_names_count.name: struct_names_count

parameters.name: struct_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the struct to check.

struct_names_count.description: With this function you can find the total number number of variables defined for a struct. You supply the struct ID to check, and the function will return an integer value for the number of variables encountered, or (if no struct of the given ID exists) -1.

sprite_get_bbox_mode.name: sprite_get_bbox_mode

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to check.

sprite_get_bbox_mode.description: This function will return the current "mode" for the bounding box calculations. You supply the sprite index of the sprite to check, and the function will return one of the constants shown below.

part_system_clear.name: part_system_clear

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system to clear.

part_system_clear.description: With this function you can clear the indexed system to its default state, removing all emitters and resetting the depth and position (if they had been changed). Be careful using this function as if you have any instance setting or bursting or any other action using an emitter associated with this system, you will get an error unless you are using the part_emitter_exists() function to check. There is also no need to call the part_emitter_destroy() function as this is taken care of automatically too.

audio_emitter_get_x.name: audio_emitter_get_x

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to use.

audio_emitter_get_x.description: This function returns the current x position of the given audio emitter.

sprite_get_speed.name: sprite_get_speed

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to get the speed of

sprite_get_speed.description: This function can be used to retrieve the sprite speed as defined for the sprite resource in the Sprite Editor. The value returned can then be used, for example, to calculate how many frames may be drawn for different image_speed. Note that the return value will be very different depending on the type of speed that was applied in the Sprite Editor, either Frames Per Second, or Frames Per Game Frame. The following two examples illustrate this:

asset_get_ids.name: asset_get_ids

parameters.name: asset_type
parameters.description: The type of assets to retrieve an array of.

asset_get_ids.description: This function returns an array containing IDs of all existing assets of given type.

vertex_begin.name: vertex_begin

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to be written to.

parameters.name: format
parameters.description: The vertex format to use.

vertex_begin.description: With this function you begin the definition of a custom primitive. You assign a buffer to write the primitive to, and the vertex format to use (previously defined using the vertex format functions). You would then define the necessary points for each vertex of the primitive before calling vertex_end() to finalise the primitive creation.

draw_get_swf_aa_level.name: draw_get_swf_aa_level
draw_get_swf_aa_level.description: This function can be used to get the anti-aliasing (AA) level for SWF format vector sprites. The return value will between 0 and 1 and shows how "smooth" the edges of these sprites will be drawn. You can set the AA level using the function draw_set_swf_aa_level().

surface_get_height.name: surface_get_height

parameters.name: surface_id
parameters.description: The ID of the surface to get the height of.

surface_get_height.description: This function simply returns the height, in pixels, of the indexed surface. It should be noted that if you call this to check the application_surface immediately after having changed its size using surface_resize() it will not return the new value as the change needs a step or two to be fully processed. After waiting a step it should return the new size correctly.

file_copy.name: file_copy

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The name of the file to copy.

parameters.name: newname
parameters.description: The name of the new, copied, file.

file_copy.description: This function will copy the specified file, giving it the new name that you choose. If you are copying a file on Android from within your Included Files area (which will be inside your APK) it will copy into memory first, so, be aware that copying very large files from the APK may cause devices to run out of memory. On the HTML5 target, we use the HTML5 Local Storage API for client side saving, and the functions does not support binary file operations, so assumes you are copying a text file.

date_leap_year.name: date_leap_year

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to use.

date_leap_year.description: This function will return true if the year component of the given datetime value is a leap year or false otherwise. This can be a handy function for things like Easter Eggs in your games, or for unlocking special content.

animcurve_point_new.name: animcurve_point_new
animcurve_point_new.description: This function creates a new points struct (posx, value) to be added to an animation curve channel.

round.name: round

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The number to round.

round.description: Just as it says, round() takes a real number and rounds it up or down to the nearest integer. In the special case where the number supplied is exactly a half-integer (1.5, 17.5, -2.5, etc), the number will be rounded to the nearest even value, for example, 2.5 would be rounded to 2, while 3.5 will be rounded to 4. This type of rounding is called bankers rounding and over large numbers of iterations or when using floating point maths, it gives a statistically better rounding than the more traditional "round up if over .5 and round down otherwise" approach.

window_device.name: window_device
window_device.description: This function will return the current d3d device pointer, which you can then (for example) pass through to a DLL or Dylib on Windows and macOS.

draw_sprite_pos.name: draw_sprite_pos

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to draw.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The first x coordinate.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The first y coordinate.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The second x coordinate.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The second y coordinate.

parameters.name: x3
parameters.description: The third x coordinate.

parameters.name: y3
parameters.description: The third y coordinate.

parameters.name: x4
parameters.description: The fourth x coordinate.

parameters.name: y4
parameters.description: The fourth y coordinate.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha of the sprite (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

draw_sprite_pos.description: With this function you can draw a sprite distorted over the area defined by the four corner coordinates. The first two arguments are the sprite to draw and the sub-image of the sprite (the same as in the function draw_sprite()) but the next ones are those that define the position of each of the four corners of the bounding box of the given sprite. These should be given in clockwise order, so the first coordinate is the top left, then the top right, then bottom right and finally the bottom left. You can also set a value for the alpha of the sprite to draw it with transparency. The image below illustrates how this function works:

gpu_set_texrepeat.name: gpu_set_texrepeat

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable or disable texture filtering (true / false)

gpu_set_texrepeat.description: This function can be used to indicate to GameMaker whether textures should repeat (true) or not (false) when used for models and primitives. Normally texture widths and heights lie in the range 0 - 1, but if you specify a value larger than 1 by default the rest is not drawn (the entire texture will be drawn with an "empty" section corresponding to the percentage over 1 that is used. So a value of 2 for a texture width or height would draw the texture in half the space and leave the other half empty). However, by using this function to set repeat to true the texture is repeated automatically over all models and primitives. The likely use case for these functions is for repeating a texture in 3D but in order for it to work and not pull images from the rest of the texture page, the sprite used will need to be marked as being on a "Separate Texture Page" in the Sprite Editor.

physics_fixture_set_friction.name: physics_fixture_set_friction

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the index of the fixture

parameters.name: friction
parameters.description: the friction of the fixture

physics_fixture_set_friction.description: Friction is the force that resists the relative motion of material elements sliding against each other, which in the GameMaker physics world, translates as the loss of momentum caused by the collision of two instances with fixtures bound to them. So, when two instances collide, their motion is affected by this value, with a high friction causing a larger loss of momentum than a lower value. Note that the friction is usually set to a value between 0 and 1, but you can use any non-negative value if required.

array_first.name: array_first

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

array_first.description: With this function you can return the first element of the array or undefined if the array is empty.

gpu_set_texfilter_ext.name: gpu_set_texfilter_ext

parameters.name: sampler_id
parameters.description: The sampler id from the shader.

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable or disable texture filtering (true / false)

gpu_set_texfilter_ext.description: This function can be used to set the linear interpolation for a single sampler "slot" when using Shaders in GameMaker. When this is enabled (true) the sampler texture will be smoothed and if this is disabled (false) then images will be drawn based on the nearest pixel. The default value is that set by the Global Game Options for your game, or that set using the function gpu_set_texfilter().

audio_emitter_free.name: audio_emitter_free

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to free.

audio_emitter_free.description: With this function you can remove the given emitter from memory. This should always be done whenever the emitter is not going to be used further in the room or the game, ie: in the Destroy Event of the instance or in the Room End Event, otherwise you may end up with a memory leak that will slow down and eventually crash your game.

string_height_ext.name: string_height_ext

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to measure the height of.

parameters.name: sep
parameters.description: The distance in pixels between lines of text as if the string was being drawn.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The maximum width (in pixels) of the string before a line break as if the string was bring drawn.

string_height_ext.description: This function will return the height (in pixels) of the input string, taking into account the line separation and line-break width (which is defined as the number of pixels that the string can occupy before a line break is inserted). It is very handy for calculating distances between text elements based on the tallest of the letters that make up the string as well as the actual string length itself when spread over several lines as it would be drawn with draw_text_ext() using the currently defined font. Separation and width can be set to -1 to get the default spacing.

display_mouse_get_x.name: display_mouse_get_x
display_mouse_get_x.description: This function will return the mouse x position within the screen. It should be noted that this function only works properly when used on the Windows target. It can be used for HTML5 too, but will only return a value relative to the 0,0 of the canvas itself, and will not return any value while the mouse is outside of the canvas. For other devices it will return 0, and you should use the device_mouse_raw_x()and device_mouse_raw_y() functions instead.

array_reverse.name: array_reverse

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_reverse.description: With this function you can create a new array with the elements in reverse order. This function allows a custom range definition.

font_get_sdf_spread.name: font_get_sdf_spread

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the font.

font_get_sdf_spread.description: With this function you can query the SDF spread value for the specified font

view_set_surface_id.name: view_set_surface_id

parameters.name: view_port
parameters.description: The view port to target (0 - 7)

view_set_surface_id.description: With this variable you can set the contents of a view port to draw to a surface. When working with surfaces, it is often required to capture the whole visible region of the screen to the surface, and so you would assign it to a view port using this function. This means that everything that is shown in the chosen view port will now be drawn to the assigned surface and the contents of that view port will no longer be displayed, meaning that you will need to either:

audio_listener_velocity.name: audio_listener_velocity

parameters.name: vx
parameters.description: The x velocity component of the listener (default 0).

parameters.name: vy
parameters.description: The y velocity component of the listener (default 0).

parameters.name: vz
parameters.description: The z velocity component of the listener (default 0).

audio_listener_velocity.description: This function can be used to give the listener Doppler effects and simulate audio motion based on the vector that is resolved from the given relative x, y and z positions. If the listener itself is not ever going to move, or the movement is not a constant motion, you would normally not need to set these values, but, for example, if you are making a scrolling game where the player has a constant bottom to top movement and the enemies a constant top to bottom movement, you would set the listener and emitter velocities (for emitters you would use audio_emitter_velocity()) to the appropriate vectors to simulate the correct Doppler effect as they move past the player instance.

layer_sequence_get_speedscale.name: layer_sequence_get_speedscale

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

layer_sequence_get_speedscale.description: With this function you supply the sequence element ID - as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions - and it will return the current playback speed scale. This is the multiplier value used to slow down or speed up the playback speed. A value of 1 is the default value, and values lower than 1 mean that playback is slowed down and values greater than 1 mean that playback is sped up.

real.name: real

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to be converted to a real value.

real.description: This function can be used to turn a given string into a real number. When using this function, numbers, minus signs, decimal points and exponential parts in the string are taken into account, while other characters (such as letters) will cause an error to be thrown. If you know, or suspect, that a string may have other characters then you can use string_digits() to remove all non-numeric characters, before using this function to turn the resulting string into a real number.

camera_set_end_script.name: camera_set_end_script

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera.

parameters.name: script
parameters.description: The script to run each game frame

camera_set_end_script.description: This function can be used to set a script function that will be called at the end of every game frame that the camera is assigned to a visible and active view port, after everything for that view camera has been rendered. You give the unique camera ID value (as returned by the different camera_create() functions) and the ID of the function to be called. The order in which functions attached to cameras and the actual rendering of the camera view is as follows:

ds_grid_clear.name: ds_grid_clear

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: This index of the grid to clear.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The new value for all grid cells.

ds_grid_clear.description: This function can be used to clear a given DS grid to a specific value. All cells within the grid will then contain this value, which can be a real number or a string. The image below illustrates how this works:

highscore_name.name: highscore_name

parameters.name: place
parameters.description: The place on the table (1-10).

highscore_name.description: With this function you can retrieve the name string that has been stored in the high score list at the given position. If no name has been entered, the string "Unknown" will be returned.

mp_grid_to_ds_grid.name: mp_grid_to_ds_grid

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: Index of the mp_grid that is to be used

parameters.name: destination
parameters.description: Index of the ds_grid that is to be used to copy the grid data to.

mp_grid_to_ds_grid.description: With this function you can copy the given MP grid into a DS grid. The DS grid should be the same size as the MP grid, although it doesn't have to be (data will be lost if it is smaller, and if it is larger all extra grid cells will be 0). The DS grid cells will contain the value -1 if the MP grid cell was flagged as occupied, or it will be 0 if not.

ds_grid_set.name: ds_grid_set

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: This index of the grid.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of the cell to set.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of the cell to set.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value with which to set the cell.

ds_grid_set.description: This function can be used to set a given cell within the given DS grid to any value, which can be a real number or a string. The image below illustrates this:

keyboard_check.name: keyboard_check

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to check the down state of.

keyboard_check.description: With this function you can check to see if a key is held down or not. Unlike the keyboard_check_pressed() or keyboard_check_released() functions which are only triggered once when the key is pressed or released, this function is triggered every step that the key is held down for. The function will take a keycode value as returned by the function ord() (only capital letters from A-Z or numbers from 0-9), or any of the vk_* constants listed on the main Keyboard Input page.

physics_particle_group_end.name: physics_particle_group_end
physics_particle_group_end.description: This function is used to end the definition of a particle group shape. Calling this function will create the particles within the given shape parameters, and also return an ID value which can be stored and used in further functions for interactions with the particle group.

ds_stack_copy.name: ds_stack_copy

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the NEW stack.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The ORIGINAL stack to copy to id.

ds_stack_copy.description: This function can be used to copy the contents of one stack into another. Note that this does NOT remove the contents from the original stack, nor does it destroy the original stack. When using this function the stack being copied to must have been previously created and if it contained any items before the copy, then these will be cleared first (meaning this information will be lost).

rollback_define_input.name: rollback_define_input

parameters.name: input_struct
parameters.description: Struct containing the keycodes to track

rollback_define_input.description: This function defines the input to be used by the rollback system.

part_system_global_space.name: part_system_global_space

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system.

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable (true) or disable (false) global space particles.

part_system_global_space.description: This function can be used to enable global space particles. When enabled, particles keep their position and direction when the particle system is moved or rotated. This is by default disabled.

layer_get_target_room.name: layer_get_target_room
layer_get_target_room.description: This function will return the current room being targeted by the layer functions. See layer_set_target_room() for more information.

layer_sprite_speed.name: layer_sprite_speed

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to change

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed multiplier/value to use for the element

layer_sprite_speed.description: This function can be used to set the speed of an animating image that has been assigned to a sprite element. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and then set the animation speed. If the IDE has set the animation speed for the sprite used to be calculated as Frames Per Game Frame, then the speed value given is a multiplier, with 1 being the default value, and setting it to 0.5 will half the animation speed, while setting it to 1.5 will double it. However, if the IDE has set the animation speed for the sprite used to be calculated as Frames Per Second, then the speed value given is a literal frames per second value, so setting this to 5, for example, will set the animation to loop 5 frames every second that the game runs. If the sprite used has no sub-images, this function will have no effect.

surface_get_target.name: surface_get_target
surface_get_target.description: With this function you can get the ID of the current surface being targeted for drawing to. If you created that surface using surface_create(), then this will be the positive integer which is the unique ID for that surface

os_get_region.name: os_get_region
os_get_region.description: This function returns a string with the two or three letter Regional Code for the OS that is running the game, as set by the ISO3166-1 standard. If the information is not available, it will hold simply an empty string "".

physics_test_overlap.name: physics_test_overlap

parameters.name: xpos
parameters.description: The x position in the room to check

parameters.name: ypos
parameters.description: The y position in the room to check

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle to check (of the calling instance)

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for

physics_test_overlap.description: This function can be used to check and see if a physical body (ie: the fixture of an instance) overlaps, or will overlap, when rotated and placed at a given position in the room. the "angle" argument is the angle of rotation that the calling instance has (or will have) at the position to be checked, and the "obj" argument can be either a single instance id, and object index or the keywords all or other.

audio_group_is_loaded.name: audio_group_is_loaded

parameters.name: groupid
parameters.description: The index of the audio group to check (as defined in the Audio Groups Window)

audio_group_is_loaded.description: This function will check a specific audio group to see if it has been loaded into memory, ready for use.

part_type_create.name: part_type_create
part_type_create.description: With this function you can create a new particle type and the return value should be stored in a variable for use in all subsequent particle functions.

tileset_get_info.name: tileset_get_info

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the tile set to get the name of.

tileset_get_info.description: This function is used to retrieve information for the given tileset. You supply a tileset index and the function returns a struct.

dot_product_normalised.name: dot_product_normalised

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the second vector.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the second vector.

dot_product_normalised.description: The dot product is a value expressing the angular relationship between two vectors and is found by taking two vectors, multiplying them together and then adding the results. The name "dot product" is derived from the centered dot "·" that is often used to designate this operation (the alternative name "scalar product" emphasizes the scalar rather than vector nature of the result).

room_set_camera.name: room_set_camera

parameters.name: rm
parameters.description: The index of the room to set the view camera of

parameters.name: vind
parameters.description: The index of the view port to assign the camera to

parameters.name: camera
parameters.description: The index of the camera to assign

room_set_camera.description: With this function you can assign a camera to a specific viewport in a room other than the current one. You supply the room index, the view index (from 0 to 7) and then the index of the camera to use.

struct_get_from_hash.name: struct_get_from_hash

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The struct reference to use

parameters.name: hash
parameters.description: The hash of the variable to get (returned from 'variable_get_hash')

struct_get_from_hash.description: With this function you can get the value from a given named variable within a struct. You supply the struct reference as well as the hash of the variable to get the value of (returned from 'variable_get_hash'). The function will return the value held by the variable or undefined if the named variable does not exist.

path_delete_point.name: path_delete_point

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to delete a point from.

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The defining point to delete.

path_delete_point.description: With this function you can remove a point from the specified path. Path points are numbered from 0 so the first point is always the 0th point and the last path point will be path_get_number() - 1. If you call this function on a path asset, then the removal of the point will be permanent and all instances assigned the path in the future will be missing the point that was removed. If this is not what you require, then you should use a function like path_duplicate() to create a copy of the path first, then call this function on the duplicated asset (don't forget to call path_delete() on the asset when it is no longer required).

ds_grid_add_grid_region.name: ds_grid_add_grid_region

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the destination grid.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The index of the source grid.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The left position of the region of cells to copy from the source grid.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The top position of the region of cells to copy from the source grid.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The right position of the region of cells to copy from the source grid.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The bottom position of the region of cells to copy from the source grid.

parameters.name: xpos
parameters.description: The x position on the destination grid to add the source region to.

parameters.name: ypos
parameters.description: The y position on the destination grid to add the source region to.

ds_grid_add_grid_region.description: This function can be used to add all the values of all the cells found within the source area of a grid to the values within the destination grid, as illustrated below:

layer_sequence_get_instance.name: layer_sequence_get_instance

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

layer_sequence_get_instance.description: With this function you supply the sequence element ID - as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions - and it will return the sequence instance struct. You can find out more about the format of the sequence instance struct on this page.

view_set_yport.name: view_set_yport

parameters.name: view_port
parameters.description: The view port to target (0 - 7)

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The new y position

view_set_yport.description: This function can be used to set the y position of the given view port. You give the view port index (from 0 to 7) and the new position to place it at.

dbg_slider.name: dbg_slider

parameters.name: dbgref
parameters.description: reference to the variable to change

parameters.name: minimum
parameters.description: minimum value

parameters.name: maximum
parameters.description: maximum value

parameters.name: label
parameters.description: label to use.

dbg_slider.description: Creates a slider for a real value within the current debug section, minimum and maximum values can be specified. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.

draw_light_get_ambient.name: draw_light_get_ambient
draw_light_get_ambient.description: This function will return the current colour used for ambient lighting.

draw_text_transformed.name: draw_text_transformed

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to draw.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scale (default 1).

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scale(default 1).

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle of the text.

draw_text_transformed.description: This function will draw text in a similar way to draw_text() only now you can choose to scale the text along the horizontal or vertical axis (effectively stretching or shrinking it) and also have GameMaker draw it at an angle (where 0 is normal and every degree over 0 rotates the text anti-clockwise).

alarm_get.name: alarm_get

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The alarm index to get, from 0 to 11.

alarm_get.description: This function can be used to get the current value of the given alarm. You supply the alarm number from 0 to 11 and this function will return the value that the alarm is currently on. This is an alternative method to getting the alarm array value directly.

gamepad_set_colour.name: gamepad_set_colour

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to set.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour to use.

gamepad_set_colour.description: This function can be used to set the colour of the LEDs within a PlayStation controller. You specify the device slot to set, and then give a colour, which can be any of the colour constants or a colour value created using the specific colour functions or a HEX value(like $FFFFFFF).

skeleton_slot_data.name: skeleton_slot_data

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The sprite index of the Spine skeletal animation to get the data from.

parameters.name: list
parameters.description: The ID of the DS list to populate with the DS maps.

skeleton_slot_data.description: With this function you can populate a (pre-created) DS list with data for each of the available attachment slots that an animation contains. This data is returned in the forum of a DS map which contains the following key/value pairs:

string_trim_start.name: string_trim_start

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The input string.

parameters.name: substrs
parameters.description: An array of strings to be used during trimming.

string_trim_start.description: This function removes whitespace from the beginning of a string (left). You can optionally provide an array of strings to be used for trimming if you want to remove something other than whitespaces.

draw_set_colour.name: draw_set_colour

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to set for drawing.

draw_set_colour.description: With this function you can set the base draw colour for the game. This value will affect all further drawing where appropriate, including fonts, forms, primitives and 3D. If any of those assets are drawn with their own colour value changed, this value will be ignored.

device_get_tilt_z.name: device_get_tilt_z
device_get_tilt_z.description: This function returns a value between -1 and 1 depending upon the angle of "tilt" of the device. The actual correlation between degrees of tilt and the value returned depends on the device and OS that it uses, but generally a value of 1 or -1 is the same as +/-90°. The image below shows how each if the available functions relates to the device:

url_open_ext.name: url_open_ext

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The URL (website address) to link to.

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: This is the target area to open the URL in.

url_open_ext.description: This will open the specified URL on the browser of the chosen target device, or, if you are using the HTML5 module, in the currently open browser. The "target" parameter that you specify is the same as the standard JavaScript "name" value when you use the open() method, and you should be aware that all but "_self" may result in the browser blocking, or asking the user if they wish to allow it.

vertex_colour.name: vertex_colour

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to write the information to.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour for this vertex (can be a constant or a hex value).

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha value for the vertex (from 0 to 1).

vertex_colour.description: If your defined vertex format takes a colour value you can use this function to add that data to the vertex being defined for the current primitive. The function needs a buffer to store the data in and will take either a colour constant, or a hex value (using the standard GameMaker format of BGR, eg: $FF0000 for blue) as well as an alpha value from 0 (transparent) to 1 (fully opaque).

sprite_exists.name: sprite_exists

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to check.

sprite_exists.description: This function returns whether a sprite with the specified index exists or not in the project being run.

window_view_mouse_get_x.name: window_view_mouse_get_x

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the view to compare the mouse position to.

window_view_mouse_get_x.description: This function will return the mouse x position relative to the view selected.

highscore_add.name: highscore_add

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string (name) to attribute the score to

parameters.name: numb
parameters.description: The number (score) to add.

highscore_add.description: With this function you can add a name and a score to the internal global high score list. There is no need to check the value to see if it is high enough to enter into the score list as GameMaker will only store those values that are greater than the tenth position stored.

surface_get_width.name: surface_get_width

parameters.name: surface_id
parameters.description: The ID of the surface to get the width of.

surface_get_width.description: This function simply returns the width, in pixels, of the indexed surface. It should be noted that if you call this to check the application_surface immediately after having changed its size using surface_resize() it will not return the new value as the change needs a step or two to be fully processed. After waiting a step it should return the new size correctly.

ini_read_string.name: ini_read_string

parameters.name: section
parameters.description: The section of the .ini to read from.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key within the relevant section of the .ini to read from.

parameters.name: default
parameters.description: The string to return if a string is not found in the defined place (or the .ini file does not exist). Must be a string.

ini_read_string.description: You can use this function to read a string (text) from an ini data file. Ini Files are split into sections and then each section is subsequently split into key - value pairs. So a typical ini file would look something like this:

is_callable.name: is_callable

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The argument to check.

is_callable.description: This function returns whether a given variable can be called (either beeing a method or a valid function index).

colour_get_saturation.name: colour_get_saturation

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to check

colour_get_saturation.description: This function will return the saturation of the given colour. This is the amount of the colour tone that is mixed into the final colour and is part of the hue, saturation and value (luminosity) method for defining a colour. The following image illustrates how this value corresponds to the HSV scale of colour:

part_emitter_region.name: part_emitter_region

parameters.name: ps
parameters.description: The particle system that the emitter is in.

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to set.

parameters.name: xmin
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the region.

parameters.name: xmax
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right side.

parameters.name: ymin
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top of the region.

parameters.name: ymax
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the region.

parameters.name: shape
parameters.description: The shape of the region.

parameters.name: distribution
parameters.description: The distribution style of the particles.

part_emitter_region.description: This function is used to set their position of a particle emitter within the current room. You specify the bounding box of the area within the function and then use any of a series of constants to define the final emitter shape within this bounding box as well as the distribution of particles within the shape. The available constants for distribution shapes are listed below:

vertex_get_number.name: vertex_get_number

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The vertex buffer to check.

vertex_get_number.description: With this function you can find out the number of individual vertices defined in any given vertex buffer.

gpu_get_blendmode_srcalpha.name: gpu_get_blendmode_srcalpha
gpu_get_blendmode_srcalpha.description: This function can be used to retrieve the current source extended blend mode alpha factor. The value returned will be one of the following constants ("s" denotes a value taken from the source while a "d" denotes a value from the destination) with only the "A" component being used when drawing:

physics_mass_properties.name: physics_mass_properties

parameters.name: mass
parameters.description: The new mass that you want the fixture to have.

parameters.name: local_center_x
parameters.description: The local x coordinate of the new center of mass.

parameters.name: local_center_y
parameters.description: The local y coordinate of the new center of mass.

parameters.name: inertia
parameters.description: Set the inertia for the fixture.

physics_mass_properties.description: This function can be used to set custom mass and inertia values for a physics enabled instance. Normally the mass, center of mass, and inertia for an instance is calculated using a combination the surface area of the bound fixtures and their density. However in very special occasions you may need to offset the center of mass or change the inertia and that is when you would use this function. Bear in mind that the mass is calculated in real world weight (ie:kilograms) and you should always try and keep values realistic for what you are modelling. So if your physics object is meant to represent a person, their mass would be approximately 70 kilos.

physics_particle_group_get_vel_y.name: physics_particle_group_get_vel_y

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The particle group to get.

physics_particle_group_get_vel_y.description: With this function you can retrieve the vertical velocity of a group of particles. The group value is that which was returned when you created the group of particles using the function physics_particle_group_end(), and the function will return a value which is the combined value of the currently set flags.

surface_getpixel.name: surface_getpixel

parameters.name: surface_id
parameters.description: The ID of the surface.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position on the surface from which to get the pixel.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position on the surface from which to get the pixel.

surface_getpixel.description: This function can be used to get the colour of a specific pixel from a surface, using the local coordinates of the surface where (0,0) is the top left corner. This function should not be used very often as it is extremely slow and may cause a pause in your game.

buffer_load_partial.name: buffer_load_partial

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to load.

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The name of the file to load.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset within the buffer to load to (in bytes).

parameters.name: src_len
parameters.description: The length of the part of the buffer to load (in bytes).

parameters.name: dest_offset
parameters.description: The offset where to start putting the partial data in the new buffer (in bytes).

buffer_load_partial.description: This function will load some of the buffer data that was previously saved using the buffer_save() functions into an already created buffer. You give the id of the previously created buffer to load into, then the saved buffer file to load, and then the offset from the start of the buffer (in bytes) that you wish to load the data from. The following arguments are for setting the length of the buffer data (in bytes) from the initial offset point that you wish to load and the offset point to load the data to in the buffer (again, in bytes).

mp_grid_clear_all.name: mp_grid_clear_all

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Index of the mp_grid that is to be used

mp_grid_clear_all.description: With this function you can clear an MP grid of all "forbidden" cells.

draw_point.name: draw_point

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the point to be drawn.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the point to be drawn.

draw_point.description: With this function you can draw a single pixel anywhere on the screen, using the currently set draw colour and alpha.

ds_queue_create.name: ds_queue_create
ds_queue_create.description: This function will create a new queue data-structure and return the index value. This value should be stored in a variable and used in all further function calls relating to the queue.

layer_sprite_x.name: layer_sprite_x

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to change

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position for the sprite

layer_sprite_x.description: This function controls the position along the x-axis of the room of the asset sprite element on the layer. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and then set the x value to use (based on the room coordinates).

tile_get_mirror.name: tile_get_mirror

parameters.name: tiledata
parameters.description: the tile-data to check

tile_get_mirror.description: This function can be used to check whether in a given set of tile-data the tile has been mirrored or not. You give the tile-data, which can be retrieved using the function tilemap_get(), and the function will return true if the tile is mirrored, or false if not.

ds_list_size.name: ds_list_size

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to check.

ds_list_size.description: This function will return the "size" of the list, ie: the number of items that have been added into it.

gpu_get_tex_min_mip.name: gpu_get_tex_min_mip
gpu_get_tex_min_mip.description: With this function you can get the minimum mipmap level which is currently used, where a value of 0 is the highest resolution, 1 is to use the first mipmap, 2 is the second etc...

instance_deactivate_all.name: instance_deactivate_all

parameters.name: notme
parameters.description: Whether to keep the calling instance activated (true) or not (false).

instance_deactivate_all.description: This function will deactivate all instances that are in the room at the moment that the code is run. This may include the instance running the code if the "notme" flag is set to false, but normally you would want that instance to be active, in which case the "notme" flag should be set to true. Note that deactivation is not instantaneous, and an instance that has been deactivated in this way will not be considered to be inactive until the end of the event in which the function was called.

gpu_set_tex_min_mip.name: gpu_set_tex_min_mip

parameters.name: minmip
parameters.description: The minimum mipmap level to use

gpu_set_tex_min_mip.description: With this function you can set the minimum mipmap level which is currently used, where a value of 0 is the highest resolution, 1 is to use the first mipmap, 2 is the second etc...

font_set_cache_size.name: font_set_cache_size

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the font to change the cache size of.

parameters.name: max
parameters.description: The maximum number of cached copies of the font that can be stored.

font_set_cache_size.description: When performing image blending and colouring, HTML5 cannot do it dynamically in the same way an executable could be performed. Therefore GameMaker has to temporarily save a blended copy of the images and load them in when needed. This function sets how many blended copies of the given font can be cached before old ones are overwritten. The default value is 4.

parameter_string.name: parameter_string
parameter_string.description: Command-line parameters are those extra commands that you can add to an exe to change how the program is run and with this function you can get the chosen command-line parameter as a string. You can find the number of parameters for the current game using the function parameter_count(), where the first parameter has index 1 and the last one has the index returned by the function (a value of 0 is special on that it is the filename of the game executable, including the path). It should be noted that this function will work for on the HTML5 platform, retrieving the url parameters.

sqr.name: sqr

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The number to square.

sqr.description: Multiplies a number by itself and so returns the square of that number. EG: sqr(5) would return 25 since 5*5=25.

gpu_get_fog.name: gpu_get_fog
gpu_get_fog.description: This function can be used to retrieve the fog settings. The function returns a 4 element 1D array with the following information:

physics_fixture_set_polygon_shape.name: physics_fixture_set_polygon_shape

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the index of the fixture

physics_fixture_set_polygon_shape.description: This function sets a polygon shape for your fixture, but you will need to use physics_fixture_add_point() to actually define the shape of this polygon relative to the origin of the fixture. The polygon is closed when the fixture is bound to an instance. You should note too that this function must be called before defining any points, and you must also have at least three points defined for your polygon before binding it to an instance or you will get an error.

instance_activate_all.name: instance_activate_all
instance_activate_all.description: With this function you can tell GameMaker to activate all instances that have been previously deactivated in a room. Note that activation is not instantaneous, and an instance that has been activated in this way will not be considered to be active until the end of the event in which the function was called.

dot_product_normalized.name: dot_product_normalized

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the second vector.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the second vector.

dot_product_normalized.description: The dot product is a value expressing the angular relationship between two vectors and is found by taking two vectors, multiplying them together and then adding the results. The name "dot product" is derived from the centered dot "·" that is often used to designate this operation (the alternative name "scalar product" emphasizes the scalar rather than vector nature of the result).

path_mirror.name: path_mirror

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to mirror.

path_mirror.description: This function takes all the path points and mirrors them along the vertical axis. This function changes the actual path asset, and so will permanently affect how the path is used by all instances in the game from the moment the function is used until the end of the game. If this is not what you require, then you should use a function like path_duplicate() to create a copy of the path first, then call this function on the duplicated asset (don't forget to call path_delete() on the asset when it is no longer required).

display_get_gui_width.name: display_get_gui_width
display_get_gui_width.description: With this function you can get the height (in pixels) of the GUI as used in the Draw GUI Event.

font_get_size.name: font_get_size

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: Index of the font to get the size of.

font_get_size.description: With this function you can get the size of any font resource, which is the point value shown by the font resource dialogue.

skeleton_slot_alpha_get.name: skeleton_slot_alpha_get

parameters.name: slot
parameters.description: The slot name to check, a string

skeleton_slot_alpha_get.description: With this function you can get an attachment slot alpha value. You supply the slot name (a string) and the function will return an real value for the alpha between 0 and 1.

layer_sprite_get_xscale.name: layer_sprite_get_xscale

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to get the information from

layer_sprite_get_xscale.description: This function can be used to get the current scale multiplier along the x axis for the sprite element. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and the function will return real value for the x scale, where 1 is no scaling.

part_type_scale.name: part_type_scale

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling of the base particle.

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling of the base particle.

part_type_scale.description: This function will set the horizontal and vertical scale of the particle before any other size changes are made. This function works on the ratio of the sprite size, so a value of 1 (the default value) is a 1:1 ratio, meaning that 0.5 would be half and 2 double.

show_debug_log.name: show_debug_log

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: switch on (true) or off (false) the debug overlay.

show_debug_log.description: This function can be used to switch on and off the standard debug log and console when testing your game and is disabled by default.

layer_reset_target_room.name: layer_reset_target_room
layer_reset_target_room.description: This function is used to reset the layer target to the current room. See the function layer_set_target_room() for further information.

texturegroup_get_textures.name: texturegroup_get_textures

parameters.name: tex_id
parameters.description: The name of the texture group to check (a string)

texturegroup_get_textures.description: This function can be used to retrieve the texture page IDs of the individual pages that make up a texture group. You supply the texture group ID string (as defined in the Texture Group Editor), and the function will return a 1D array, where each entry in the array is a single texture page ID. If the function fails - ie: an invalid group is given, or the group has no texture assigned to it - then the array will be empty (0 length).

window_views_mouse_get_y.name: window_views_mouse_get_y
window_views_mouse_get_y.description: This function returns the y-coordinate of the mouse with respect to all the active views and returns the same value mouse_y.

ds_list_is_map.name: ds_list_is_map

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the list to check.

parameters.name: pos
parameters.description: The position within the list to check.

ds_list_is_map.description: With this function you can check to see if a DS map is stored at the given position within a DS list. If the given position contains a DS map ID, then the function will return true otherwise it will return false.

layer_background_get_sprite.name: layer_background_get_sprite

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to get the information from

layer_background_get_sprite.description: This function can be used to get the current sprite index value of the background element. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and the function will return a real value that represents the sprite index being shown. If the element has no sprite assigned, the function will return -1.

gpu_get_zfunc.name: gpu_get_zfunc
gpu_get_zfunc.description: This function can be used to retrieve the z comparison mode. The value returned will be one of the following constants (the default value is cmpfunc_lessequal):

font_get_italic.name: font_get_italic

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: Index of the font to check.

font_get_italic.description: With this function you can check any font asset to see if it has the italic flag or not. If it does the function will return true, otherwise it will return false.

skeleton_slot_data_instance.name: skeleton_slot_data_instance

parameters.name: list
parameters.description: The ID of the DS list to populate with the DS maps.

skeleton_slot_data_instance.description: With this function you can populate a (pre-created) DS list with data for each of the available attachment slots for the Spine sprite associated with the current instance (including any attachment modifications). This data is returned in the forum of a DS map which contains the following key/value pairs:

camera_get_view_target.name: camera_get_view_target

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_view_target.description: This function can be used to retrieve the follow target of the given camera. The return value can be an object index, an instance ID or -1 if no follow target has been set.

skeleton_attachment_get.name: skeleton_attachment_get

parameters.name: slot
parameters.description: The slot name (a string) to get the attachment of.

skeleton_attachment_get.description: A skeletal animation sprite may have other sprites added as attachments, with these sprites being added to a named slot (the name is given when you create the attachment slot in your animation program) and they will be drawn along with the animation of the current sprite. With this function you can get the name (as a string) of the attachment for the given slot of the currently assigned sprite. Note that attached sprites are referenced through their name string as assigned in Spine, or when you called skeleton_attachment_create().

audio_emitter_create.name: audio_emitter_create
audio_emitter_create.description: This function creates a new audio emitter and returns the index for it. This index should be stored in a variable for all further functions that relate to this emitter, and then when it is no longer needed it should be removed from memory using the function audio_emitter_free() to prevent memory leaks which may eventually crash your game.

random.name: random

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The upper range from which the random number will be selected.

random.description: This function is good for probabilities where returning an integer (whole number) is not necessary. For example, random(100) will return a value from 0 to 99, but that value can be 22.56473! You can also use real numbers and not integers in this function like this - random(0.5), which will return a value between 0 and 0.4999999.

gpu_pop_state.name: gpu_pop_state
gpu_pop_state.description: This function pops the previous GPU state from the stack and applies it. See gpu_push_state() for more information.

array_equals.name: array_equals

parameters.name: array1
parameters.description: The index of the first array.

parameters.name: array2
parameters.description: The index of the second array.

array_equals.description: With this function you can check to see if two arrays are equal (equivalent or the same). You give the two arrays to check, and the function will return true if they are equal (either equivalent or the same) or false if they are not. Note that this is not the same as checking if two arrays are the same using ==, which will not check to see if the two arrays hold equivalent values, but only to see if the arrays are referencing the same initial array. For example:

zip_unzip_async.name: zip_unzip_async

parameters.name: zip_file
parameters.description: The zip file to open

parameters.name: target_directory
parameters.description: The target directory to extract the files to

zip_unzip_async.description: This function will open a stored zip file and extract its contents to the given directory asynchronously. Note that if you do not supply a full path to the ZIP directory then the current drive root will be used, and if you want to place it in a relative path to the game bundle working directory then you should use the working_directory variable as part of the path (relative paths using "." or ".." will not work as expected so should be avoided). Note too that the zip must be either part of the game bundle (ie: an Included File) or have been downloaded to the storage area using http_get_file().

display_mouse_set.name: display_mouse_set

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate in the display.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate in the display.

display_mouse_set.description: With this function you can change or set the position of the mouse within the game display which can be useful for FPS games, for example. The function will only work while the game is in focus and using ALT + Tab will unlock the mouse.

view_get_surface_id.name: view_get_surface_id

parameters.name: view_port
parameters.description: The view port to target (0 - 7)

view_get_surface_id.description: This function can be used to retrieve the unique ID value for the surface assigned to the given view port (will return -1 if no surface has been assigned).

dbg_drop_down.name: dbg_drop_down

parameters.name: dbgref
parameters.description: reference to the variable to change

parameters.name: specifierOrArrayOfValues
parameters.description: dropdown specifier or array of values

parameters.name: labelOrArrayOfLabels
parameters.description: label to use or aarray of Labels

parameters.name: label
parameters.description: label to use.

dbg_drop_down.description: Creates a drop down for a value within the current debug section, Either use an array of values (with an optional array of labels for those names) OR the values and names  are declared as a comma delimited string - where integer values can be specified after a colon symbol so "Zero,One:10,Two:20" will create a 3 entry drop down that will set the variable to the value 0, 10 or 20 depending on which is selected. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.

gpu_set_ztestenable.name: gpu_set_ztestenable

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable or disable z-buffer testing (true or false).

gpu_set_ztestenable.description: This function can be used to toggle z-buffer testing on or off, affecting how things will be drawn (in general only of use when working with 3D projects). Essentially, by default when z-testing is off and you have two objects drawing to the same space, both objects will be rendered regardless of whether one will over-draw the other, resulting in unnecessary draw calls. If you switch this on then the z-buffer is tested to see whether an object will be "visible" and not drawn if it's not. Note that this is the default behaviour, but you can change this by changing the type of comparison used for z-buffer testing (see the function gpu_set_zfunc().

layer_background_get_stretch.name: layer_background_get_stretch

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to get the information from

layer_background_get_stretch.description: This function can be used to get the stretched state of the background element sprite. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and the function will return either true if the element sprite is currently stretched to fit the room, or false if it is not.

part_type_size.name: part_type_size

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: size_min
parameters.description: The minimum size the particle can start at.

parameters.name: size_max
parameters.description: The maximum size the particle can start at.

parameters.name: size_incr
parameters.description: How much the particle should increase or decrease per step.

parameters.name: size_wiggle
parameters.description: How much should randomly be added or subtracted from the particles size per step.

part_type_size.description: This function is used to determine the size of the particle when it is created and can also be used to make the particle increase or decrease in size over its lifetime. The minimum and maximum size values default at 1 (meaning that the size is the same ratio as the base particle after the part_type_scale() scale has been set) and if they are set to the same value, the initial size for all particles will be the same, but if set to different values, each particle will start with a random size from within the range, for example if you have a minimum of 0.5 and a maximum of 2, all particles will be created with a size between half and double the base scale.

skeleton_skin_create.name: skeleton_skin_create

parameters.name: skin_name
parameters.description: The name of the skin to create.

parameters.name: base_skins
parameters.description: Array of skin names defined in the sprite to combine.

skeleton_skin_create.description: Creates a new skin by combining one or more skins defined in the sprite. This can be used (for example) to combine multiple skins defining different pieces of clothing or accessories on a character sprite.

ds_list_shuffle.name: ds_list_shuffle

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the list to shuffle.

ds_list_shuffle.description: With this function you can shuffle a list, which will re-order all the component values into random positions from those in which they were originally added to the list.

texture_debug_messages.name: texture_debug_messages

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable or disable the texture debug messages

texture_debug_messages.description: This function can be used to enable or disable texture debug messages. When enabled (set to true), additional information about texture page use will be sent to the output window. Set to false to disable this output again.

json_decode.name: json_decode

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The JSON format string that you are passing to the function for decoding

json_decode.description: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a lightweight data-interchange format which is easy for to read and write, for both people and machines. It is built on two basic structures:

physics_particle_draw_ext.name: physics_particle_draw_ext

parameters.name: typemask
parameters.description: The mask to compare the particles flags with.

parameters.name: category
parameters.description: The user defined category to draw (use 0 to draw all categories).

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The sprite to use for each particle.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The image_index of the sprite to draw.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The scale factor to apply to the sprite along the x axis.

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The scale factor to apply to the sprite along the y axis.

parameters.name: ang
parameters.description: The angle (in degrees) to draw the sprite at.

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to blend with the sprite (default is c_white).
