parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha value to use when drawing (0 - 1).

physics_particle_draw_ext.description: This function will draw a sprite at the position of all the particles that share the same user defined category value, and that have flags which coincide with those set for the mask. The mask value is defined in the same way as you would define the flags when creating the particles (see the functions physics_particle_create() for an example), ie: using the bitwise or "|" to mask off the appropriate bits for each flag.

gpu_get_tex_max_aniso.name: gpu_get_tex_max_aniso
gpu_get_tex_max_aniso.description: With this function you can get the current maximum level of anisotropy when using the tf_anisotropic filter mode (see gpu_get_tex_mip_filter() for more information). The returned value will range between 1 and 16.

keyboard_unset_map.name: keyboard_unset_map
keyboard_unset_map.description: With this function you can clear all re-mapped keys so that they return to their default state, ie: all keys to map to themselves.

ds_map_size.name: ds_map_size

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to check.

ds_map_size.description: With this function you can find how many key/values pairs the (previously created) DS map contains.

gpu_get_cullmode.name: gpu_get_cullmode
gpu_get_cullmode.description: This function can be used to retrieve the backface culling mode. The returned value will be one of the following constants (the default value is cull_noculling):

ds_grid_to_mp_grid.name: ds_grid_to_mp_grid

parameters.name: src
parameters.description: The source DS grid.

parameters.name: dest
parameters.description: The destination MP grid.

parameters.name: func
parameters.description: A predicate function (that is passed the: grid value, cell x and cell y) and should return true (cell is ocupied) or false (cell is empty)

ds_grid_to_mp_grid.description: This function can be used to convert a DS grid into an MP grid. You can also provide an optional predicate function argument to map the DS grid value to the corresponding MP grid value. If you don't provide a predicate function, the function will treat zero values as empty and non-zero values as occupied.

collision_ellipse.name: collision_ellipse

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the ellipse to check.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top side of the ellipse to check.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right side of the ellipse to check.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom side of the ellipse to check.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for instance collisions.

parameters.name: prec
parameters.description: Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).

parameters.name: notme
parameters.description: Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).

collision_ellipse.description: Collision_ellipse uses the first four arguments (x1,y1,x2,y2) to define the width and height of an ellipse within the current room and then checks to see if any object that is defined by the "obj" argument is in collision with that area. This collision can be checked as precise or not, and you may also choose to check for the instance running the code itself or not. Consider this image:

dot_product_3d_normalized.name: dot_product_3d_normalized

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: z1
parameters.description: The z coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the second vector.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the second vector.

parameters.name: z2
parameters.description: The z coordinate of the second vector.

dot_product_3d_normalized.description: The dot product is a value expressing the angular relationship between two vectors and is found by taking two vectors, multiplying them together and then adding the results. The name "dot product" is derived from the centered dot "·" that is often used to designate this operation (the alternative name "scalar product" emphasizes the scalar rather than vector nature of the result).

weak_ref_create.name: weak_ref_create

parameters.name: struct_to_track
parameters.description: The struct that you want to create a weak reference for

weak_ref_create.description: With this function you can check the weak reference to a struct to see if it is still "alive" or not. You supply the weak reference to check (as returned by the function weak_ref_create()), and the function will return true if the struct is still being referenced somewhere or false if it's not and has been garbage collected. Note that if you supply a value that is not a weak reference, the function will return undefined.

layer_sequence_headpos.name: layer_sequence_headpos

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The position within the sequence (in frames) to set the playhead position to (can be a decimal value)

layer_sequence_headpos.description: With this function you can set the playhead position of a sequence element to a specific frame. You supply the sequence element ID as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions along with the new position to set. Note that the position is in frames and if you set a value greater than the total number of frames (or less than 0) then the actual final playhead position will depend on the type of sequence playback that has been selected, following these rules:

asset_get_tags.name: asset_get_tags

parameters.name: name_or_index
parameters.description: The name of the asset (a string) or its index value (an integer).

parameters.name: asset_type
parameters.description: OPTIONAL! The type of asset to get the tags for, only used when supplying an index for the first argument.

asset_get_tags.description:
This function retrieves all tags assigned to an asset from the Asset Browser.
			
			You supply either the asset name (as a string) or its asset index, and the function will return an array of tags for that asset. If no tags are found or there is an error (ie: the name string given doesn't exist) then the returned array will be empty. If you supply an asset index value, then you will need to supply the optional asset type argument (a constant), as assets of different types can have the same index, even though they cannot have the same name.

tilemap_clear.name: tilemap_clear

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to change

parameters.name: tiledata
parameters.description: The tile data to use to clear the layer

tilemap_clear.description: Using this function you can clear/set all the tiles on a given tile-map. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and then supply the tile data that you wish to clear the layer with. A default value of 0 will clear all the tiles from the layer (essentially making all tiles "empty"), while you can use the dedicated tile_* functions to create your own tile data to clear the tile map with.

sprite_get_number.name: sprite_get_number

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite.

sprite_get_number.description: A sprite has to have at least one sub-image and this function will return just how many it has. Remember, a sprite sub-image starts being numbered from 0, so if this function returns 3 (the sprite being checked has 3 sub-images) they will be numbered 0, 1 and 2.

object_is_ancestor.name: object_is_ancestor

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object that is being checked as the child.

parameters.name: par
parameters.description: The object that is being checked as the ancestor (parent).

object_is_ancestor.description: This function can be used to check an object and see if it is an ancestor or not of another object. So, both arguments need to be object indices and not the instance ids, and the first one is always the object that you want to find out if it is a child of the second argument, which is always the object that want to check as the ancestor (parent).

clipboard_get_text.name: clipboard_get_text
clipboard_get_text.description: This function will return a string of the text contained on the clipboard. if no text is stored it will return an empty string "".

application_get_position.name: application_get_position
application_get_position.description: When you have "maintain aspect ratio" ticked in the Game Options for a target platform, GameMaker will automatically set the draw position for the application surface so that it is displayed correctly centered and scaled on the given display. However if you are manipulating this surface and wish to draw it yourself, then this function gives you an easy way to find exactly where within the display or window that the surface was being drawn so that you can then draw it there yourself, or align GUI images or post draw images to it.

physics_fixture_set_kinematic.name: physics_fixture_set_kinematic

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the index of the fixture

physics_fixture_set_kinematic.description: There will be certain instances in a physics based game which you want to move around but do not wish to be acted on by forces such as gravity, nor forces incurred by collisions with dynamic objects (think of moving platforms in a platform game, for example). For such objects simply setting the density of a fixture to 0 will mean that the physics will assume that the object is intended to be static. However, should you set the phy_speed_x, phy_speed_y or phy_angular_velocity variables for an instance that has had such a fixture bound to it, it will be converted into a kinematic object and begin movement. Change the instance from static to kinematic mid-simulation can be expensive in terms of processing (depending on the state of the instances in the physics world) and therefore it is recommended to set the fixture to be kinematic using this function prior to binding it to an instance, so that it will be unaffected by collisions and forces (such as gravity) but may move with constant linear and/or angular velocity.

part_particles_burst.name: part_particles_burst

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to burst the particles.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to burst the particles.

parameters.name: partsys
parameters.description: The particle system resource to burst.

part_particles_burst.description: This function allows you to burst all particles defined in a particle system resource at any position in the room. The final area, distribution and number of the particles created depends on the configuration of emitters inside of the particle system resource.

rollback_chat.name: rollback_chat

parameters.name: message
parameters.description: The content of the message (maximum of 128 bytes allowed).

parameters.name: to
parameters.description: The player which the message is sent to. If left unspecified the message will be sent to everyone in the game.

rollback_chat.description: This function sends a chat message.

gamepad_hat_count.name: gamepad_hat_count

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

gamepad_hat_count.description: This function will return the total number of hats available for the gamepad connected to the given device "slot". Hats generally refer to up/down/left/right buttons, and note that on the Windows target, hats are only available on DirectInput controllers (so, from slot 4 upwards).

audio_emitter_get_pitch.name: audio_emitter_get_pitch

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to use.

audio_emitter_get_pitch.description: This function returns the current pitch value set for the given audio emitter.

draw_sprite_part_ext.name: draw_sprite_part_ext

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to draw.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

parameters.name: left
parameters.description: The x position on the sprite of the top left corner of the area to draw.

parameters.name: top
parameters.description: The y position on the sprite of the top left corner of the area to draw.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the area to draw.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the area to draw.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour with which to blend the sprite. c_white is to display it normally.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha of the sprite (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

draw_sprite_part_ext.description: This function will draw a part of the chosen sprite at the given position following the same rules as per draw_sprite_part(), only now you can scale the part, blend a colour with it, or change its alpha when drawing it to the screen (the same as when drawing a sprite with draw_sprite_ext()). You should note that if the texture page permits automatic cropping then this function may not work as expected, since the extra "empty" space around the sprite will have been removed for creating the texture page. To resolve this issue, you will need to set the texture page settings (in the Texture Group Editor) to disable the Automatic Crop.

matrix_stack_pop.name: matrix_stack_pop
matrix_stack_pop.description: This function pops the current top matrix off the stack.

video_open.name: video_open

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Set the path or url to the video.

video_open.description: With this function you can open a video from the specified path or url

string_width_ext.name: string_width_ext

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to measure the width of.

parameters.name: sep
parameters.description: The distance in pixels between lines of text as if the string was being drawn.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The maximum width (in pixels) of the string before a line break as if the string was bring drawn.

string_width_ext.description: This function will return the maximum width (in pixels) of the input string, taking into account the line separation and line-break width (which is defined as the number of pixels that the string can occupy before a line break is inserted). It is very handy for calculating distances between text elements based on the maximum width of a string that is split over several lines as it would be drawn with draw_text_ext() using the currently defined font. Separation and width can be set to -1 to get the default spacing.

buffer_decompress.name: buffer_decompress

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to decompress.

buffer_decompress.description: With this function you can decompress a previously compressed buffer using zlib compression. You supply the buffer ID to decompress, and the function will return a new buffer ID that contains the uncompressed data. If the decompression has failed (for example, you are supplying a buffer that hasn't been compressed) then the function will instead return a value less than 0.

get_open_filename.name: get_open_filename

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description: The file type filter and/or name.

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The suggested filename to use.

get_open_filename.description: This function opens a dialogue and asks the player for a filename to open with the given filter. The filter has the form "name1|mask1|name2|mask2|...", where the mask may contain the different options with a semicolon between them and you can also use a "*" to mean any string. For example: "bitmaps|*.bmp;*.wmf", would ask the user to select the name of a bitmap file from the system, but only those that have the two specified extensions (bmp and png). this function does not open the file itself! It only returns a string with the full name and path of the file. If the user presses "Cancel" an empty string "" is returned.

date_valid_datetime.name: date_valid_datetime

parameters.name: year
parameters.description: The year to check.

parameters.name: month
parameters.description: The month to check.

parameters.name: day
parameters.description: The day to check.

parameters.name: hour
parameters.description: The hour to check.

parameters.name: minute
parameters.description: The minute to check.

parameters.name: second
parameters.description: The second to check.

date_valid_datetime.description: With this function you can check a datetime value to see if it is valid (returns true) or not (returns false). Note that this function will only consider a valid datetime as being after 1/1/1970 and anything before that will return false, so the earliest you can check would be:

file_text_open_from_string.name: file_text_open_from_string

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to create the file from.

file_text_open_from_string.description: This function will create a text file from a string and open it for reading, returning the file "handle" that should be used in all further file function calls to read from this file. Note that this file is temporary and read only, and as such it will be removed from memory the moment it is closed.

gpu_get_texfilter_ext.name: gpu_get_texfilter_ext

parameters.name: sampler_id
parameters.description: The sampler id from the shader.

gpu_get_texfilter_ext.description: With this function you can check to see whether texture interpolation (linear interpolation) is enabled (returns true) or not (returns false) for a given shader sampler texture.

layer_tilemap_destroy.name: layer_tilemap_destroy

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map to be destroyed

layer_tilemap_destroy.description: This function will destroy the given tile map element. You supply the tile map ID (which you get when you create the tile map using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the layer ID along with layer_get_tilemap_id()) and this will remove it. Note that this does not remove the layer, only the tile map from it, and if the tile map is one that has been added in the room editor, then the next time you leave the room and then return, the tile map will be recreated again. However if the room is persistent, the tile map will be removed unless room persistence is switched off again.

string_byte_at.name: string_byte_at

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to check.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The position to get the byte from.

string_byte_at.description: Returns the raw byte value as a real value at a given position in the given string.

string_split.name: string_split

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The input string.

parameters.name: delimiter
parameters.description: The delimiter string to search for.

parameters.name: remove_empty
parameters.description: Removes empty entries from the output array.

parameters.name: max_splits
parameters.description: The maximum number of splits that are allowed.

string_split.description: This function splits string into an ordered list of substrings by searching for the delimiter, puts these substrings into an array, and returns the array.

array_length.name: array_length

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The index of the array to check.

array_length.description: With this function you can get the length (number of entries) of an array dimension. You supply the array index value and the function will return an integer value representing the number of entries the array contains. This function can also be used for multi-dimension arrays, as long as you specify which dimension you want to get the length of when you supply the array index, following this pattern:

part_emitter_interval.name: part_emitter_interval

parameters.name: ps
parameters.description: The particle system that the emitter is in.

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the emitter.

parameters.name: interval_min
parameters.description: The minimum length of the interval.

parameters.name: interval_max
parameters.description: The maximum length of the interval.

parameters.name: interval_unit
parameters.description: The units that the interval is measured in.

part_emitter_interval.description: With this function you can configure the interval between individual particle bursts when an emitter is in a stream mode.

get_save_filename.name: get_save_filename

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description: The file type filter and/or name.

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The suggested filename to use.

get_save_filename.description: This function opens a dialogue and asks the player for a filename to save to with the given filter. The filter has the form "name1|mask1|name2|mask2|...", where the mask may contain the different options with a semicolon between them and you can also use a "*" to mean any string. For example: "bitmaps|*.bmp;*.wmf", would ask the user to select the name of a bitmap file from the system, but only those that have the two specified extensions (bmp and png). this function does not save the file itself! It only returns a string with the full name and path of the file. If the user presses "Cancel" an empty string "" is returned.

physics_fixture_set_edge_shape.name: physics_fixture_set_edge_shape

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the index of the fixture

parameters.name: local_x1
parameters.description: start x position for the edge

parameters.name: local_y1
parameters.description: start y position for the edge

parameters.name: local_x2
parameters.description: end x position for the edge

parameters.name: local_y2
parameters.description: end y position for the edge

physics_fixture_set_edge_shape.description: This function defines an "edge" fixture shape. An edge shape is simply a line that will generate a collision when other fixtures over lap it, and can be very useful for generating (for example) terrain, or for creating borders around a room. The position of the edge is defined using local space, ie: the x/y position of the instance is considered (0,0), so this should be taken into consideration when creating them (in the code example below, the instance would have been placed at (0,0) in the room to avoid complications).

cloud_synchronise.name: cloud_synchronise
cloud_synchronise.description: This function would normally be called at the start of a new game and is used to retrieve the current status of the cloud service at game start up. The function returns a unique id value which would then be used in the Asynchronous Cloud Event to retrieve the relevant information from the DS map that is created.

object_set_sprite.name: object_set_sprite

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the object to change.

parameters.name: spr
parameters.description: The sprite to assign to the object.

object_set_sprite.description: With this function you can set the sprite index of a specific object. This means that all instances of this object that are created after the sprite_index has been changed will be created with this new sprite_index, while instances that are already in the room may not be affected.

camera_set_view_pos.name: camera_set_view_pos

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to place the view at (in the room)

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to place the view at (in the room)

camera_set_view_pos.description: You can use this function to update the position of the camera view within the room. You give the unique camera ID value (as returned by the different camera_create() functions) and then give the x and y positions to set the camera to.

path_add.name: path_add
path_add.description: With this function you can create a path in GameMaker without using the path editor. this function will return the index of the path which should be stored in a variable and used as the reference for that path from then on. Please note that the created path is empty ie: it has no points defined, so you will then have to use the other available functions to add points to the path or be using MP grids to generate the path. Once you have finished using the path, or wish to create a new one and store its index in the same variable you should first delete the old path with path_delete to prevent memory leaks which can eventually crash your game.

method_call.name: method_call

parameters.name: method
parameters.description: method/function that you want to call

parameters.name: array_args
parameters.description: The array containing the arguments for the function/script

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: OPTIONAL! The offset into the argument array

parameters.name: num_args
parameters.description: OPTIONAL! The number of arguments to (from the offset onwards)

method_call.description: This function works similarly to the function script_execute_ext() only you can supply an array that contains the arguments required for the function/script being called. You may also supply two optional arguments to the function to specify an offset into the array to get the arguments from, as well as the number of arguments to use from the array (this must be a maximum of array_length - offset).

physics_fixture_delete.name: physics_fixture_delete

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the fixture that is to be deleted from memory

physics_fixture_delete.description: Since once a fixture has been bound to an instance that instance maintains the fixtures properties, we can remove the fixture from memory with this function, particularly if we no longer plan to use it again. Please note that failure to remove fixtures after they are no longer needed may cause a memory leak which will slow down and eventually crash your game, so you should take care to clean up properly after defining and binding fixtures.

font_add_sprite_ext.name: font_add_sprite_ext

parameters.name: spr
parameters.description: The sprite to add a font based on.

parameters.name: string_map
parameters.description: String from which sprite sub-image order is taken.

parameters.name: prop
parameters.description: Set as proportional font or not.

parameters.name: sep
parameters.description: The space to leave between each letter.

font_add_sprite_ext.description: With this function you can use a "sprite strip" (the sprite itself must be a sprite asset from the Asset Browser, or a sprite you have added to the game resources using sprite_add) to create a new font asset, where each sub-image would be an individual symbol or letter. Unlike the normal font_add_sprite() which has a specific order for the sub-images of the sprite, this function will map the sprite sub-images based on the argument "string_map" of the function. This argument is a string that you can use to tell GameMaker what order the sub-images of the sprite font are and it will map these automatically when writing text. So, for example, if you have a string-map of "AaBbCcDdEeFfGgHh", your sprite font must have the sub-images ordered in this way. You can define "space" as being any character you want, for example a single line the size that you want the space to be, and all spaces in text will be rendered at that width (but the image chosen will never be rendered), or if you don't supply a sprite for space then the width of the widest character in the sprite font will be used instead.

room_goto_previous.name: room_goto_previous
room_goto_previous.description: With this function you can make your game go to the previous one as listed in the Room Manager at the time the game was compiled. If this room does not exist, an error will be thrown and the game will be forced to close. Note that the room will not change until the end of the event where the function was called, so any code after this has been called will still run if in the same event. This function will also trigger the Room End event.

time_source_start.name: time_source_start

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

time_source_start.description: Starts/Resumes the time source and all of its children.

skeleton_attachment_create_color.name: skeleton_attachment_create_color

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name (as a string) of the attachment to create.

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The sprite_index to get the attachment image from.

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The image_index to get the attachment image from.

parameters.name: xorigin
parameters.description: The x origin for the image being used.

parameters.name: yorigin
parameters.description: The y origin for the image being used.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling of the image, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling of the image, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: rot
parameters.description: The rotation of the image: 0 = normal, 90 = turned 90° counter-clockwise etc.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour value to use (A constant, integer or hex value).

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha value to use (from 0 to 1).

skeleton_attachment_create_color.description: When you create you skeletal animation sprite, you can assign attachment slots and attachments to go in them. These are simply images (sprites) that are separate from the animation but when attached will move along with the bone they are attached to. Normally you would assign these attachments in your animation program (Spine), but with this function you can create your own at run-time using a sprite asset from your game. the function requires that you give the attachment a name (as a string) and then set the sprite_index and image_index to use, as well as the x and y origin (which can be different to that defined by the sprite in the sprite properties), and you can also set any transforms that you wish to be applied to the image when attached, as well as the colour to be blended with the image and it's alpha (transparency) value. If the attachment was successfully created the function will return 1 and if it was not (you supplied an invalid sprite index, or the base sprite is not a Spine sprite) then it will return -1.

part_system_update.name: part_system_update

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system to update.

part_system_update.description: With this function you can force a particle system to draw all the current particles on the screen. If part_system_automatic_draw() is switched off then this function will show the particles when used in the draw event of an instance, or it can be used when the drawing target is set to a surface (using surface_set_target()) to draw the particles in the system to that surface.

gesture_drag_distance.name: gesture_drag_distance

parameters.name: distance
parameters.description: The distance (in inches) to set for drag gesture event detection.

gesture_drag_distance.description: This function is used to set the distance it takes for a Dragging Gesture event to be triggered by the movement of a touch or click. The distance is measured in inches and has a default value of 0.1.

sprite_create_from_surface.name: sprite_create_from_surface

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the surface to create from.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to copy from.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to copy from.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the area to be copied (from the x position).

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height of the area to be copied (from the y position).

parameters.name: removeback
parameters.description: Indicates whether to make all pixels with the background colour (left-bottom pixel) transparent.

parameters.name: smooth
parameters.description: Indicates whether to smooth the edges.

parameters.name: xorig
parameters.description: Indicates the x position of the origin in the sprite.

parameters.name: yorig
parameters.description: Indicates the y position of the origin in the sprite.

sprite_create_from_surface.description: With this function you can create a sprite from a previously initialised surface (the surface index ID value is returned when you create the surface using surface_create()). The x and y coordinates that you then input in the function should be relative to the (0,0) position of the surface (the top left corner) and not the game window (nor the view if you have one active). The width and height arguments are in pixels and define the width and height of the part of the surface to use.

ds_grid_get_min.name: ds_grid_get_min

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The left cell column of the region.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The top cell row of the region.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The right cell column of the region.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The bottom cell row of the region.

ds_grid_get_min.description: This function can be used to find the minimum value for all the cells found within the defined region of a grid, as shown in the image below:

time_source_get_children.name: time_source_get_children

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

time_source_get_children.description: Returns an array containing all of the indexes of the children of this time source.

audio_bus_clear_emitters.name: audio_bus_clear_emitters

parameters.name: bus
parameters.description: The audio bus whose emitters should be cleared.

audio_bus_clear_emitters.description: This function relinks all of the emitters linked to the given bus back to the main bus.

window_mouse_set.name: window_mouse_set

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate in the window.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate in the window.

window_mouse_set.description: With this function you can change or set the position of the mouse within the game window which can be useful for FPS games, for example. The function will only work while the game is in focus and using alt + tab will unlock the mouse.

application_surface_draw_enable.name: application_surface_draw_enable

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: The flag will be either true (enabled, the default value) or false (disabled).

application_surface_draw_enable.description: You can use this function to enable or disable the automatic drawing of the application surface. By default this is enabled, but in many cases you will want to take over when and how the surface is drawn (when using shaders for example), in which case you would use this function to set it to false so that you can draw it yourself when and how you require. It's important to note that when you switch off automatic drawing and draw the application surface yourself, that you may see certain issues with the alpha component of sprites and the surface itself. This is because GameMaker will draw the application surface without alpha blending when the automatic drawing is on. If you switch off automatic drawing then you need to handle this yourself, using the following code (for example):

layer_background_create.name: layer_background_create

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target (or the layer name as a string)

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The sprite index to be used

layer_background_create.description: With this function you can assign a sprite resource to a layer to be used as a background in your project. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and a sprite index (which would be the name of the sprite as shown in the Asset Browser), and it will be added to the layer. The function returns the unique ID value for the element, which can then be used in further layer functions for backgrounds.

file_text_open_read.name: file_text_open_read

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The name of the file to read from.

file_text_open_read.description: This function opens the text file with the indicated filename for reading only, returning the unique id of the file that which should be stored in a variable as it will be used for all further actions to do with that file. If the file does not exists then the function will return the value -1.

game_restart.name: game_restart
game_restart.description: With this function you can restart the game. This is essentially the same as running the game for the first time and so the Game Start Event will be triggered, as well as the Game End Event.

sprite_replace.name: sprite_replace

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to permanently replace.

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The filename of the image to make the new sprite.

parameters.name: imgnumb
parameters.description: The number of frames the sprite will be cut up into horizontally. 1 = one single image / *.gif.

parameters.name: removeback
parameters.description: Indicates whether to make all pixels with the background colour (left-bottom pixel) transparent.

parameters.name: smooth
parameters.description: Indicates whether to smooth the edges.

parameters.name: xorig
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the origin, relative to the sprite's top left corner.

parameters.name: yorig
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the origin, relative to the sprite's top left corner.

sprite_replace.description: This function works in almost the exact same manner as sprite_add(), only instead of returning the index of the sprite you are importing, it overwrites a previously created sprite index. When using this function you should use a sprite index that has been created and stored in a variable using other functions like sprite_add() or sprite_create_from_surface(), or even sprite_duplicate(), rather than a resource tree sprite asset. You can replace a sprite from the game assets using this function, but doing so means that you will lose the reference ID for the sprite that you are replacing, regardless of whether you call game_restart() or not, and so is not recommended. Regardless of the sprite being replaced, this function will create a new texture page for the sprite and so care should be taken when using it as it may adversely affect performance by increasing the number of required texture swaps for rendering.

room_get_name.name: room_get_name

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the room to check the name of.

room_get_name.description: This function can be used to return the name of the specified room as a string. Please note that this is only a string and cannot be used to reference the room directly - for that you would need the room index. You can, however, use this string to get the room index using the returned string along with the function asset_get_index().

gpu_set_fog.name: gpu_set_fog

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable or disable fog

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The fog colour

parameters.name: start
parameters.description: The distance to start applying fog from

parameters.name: end
parameters.description: The distance to end the fog

gpu_set_fog.description: This function can be used to enable or disable fog drawing. Fog can be used in 3D games to make instances in the distance look blurred or even disappear, which helps in creating atmosphere as well as masking the fact that you are not drawing instances that are far away. You set whether it is enabled (true) or disabled (false), the colour that the fog should use for blending, as well as the start and end draw distances. Note that the fog start indicates the radius relative to the view camera where the fog starts, and the fog end indicates at which radius (also relative) instances will be completely invisible.

audio_emitter_velocity.name: audio_emitter_velocity

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to change.

parameters.name: vx
parameters.description: The x vector value (default 0).

parameters.name: vy
parameters.description: The y vector value (default 0).

parameters.name: vz
parameters.description: The z vector value (default 0).

audio_emitter_velocity.description: This function can be used to give an emitter Doppler effects and simulate audio motion based on the vector that is resolved from the given relative x, y and z positions. If the emitter itself is not ever going to move you would normally not need to set these values, but, for example, if you are making a scrolling shooter game where the enemies come from the right and scroll to the left, you would set this to have a velocity of (hspeed, 0, 0) in the create event of the enemies (and update the emitter of each instance in the step event using audio_emitter_position()) to give any sounds emitted by the enemy instances the correct Doppler as they pass the player instance (which in turn would be using the function audio_listener_position() to set the listener to the correct position).

ds_stack_push.name: ds_stack_push

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to push onto.
The value to push onto the stack.

ds_stack_push.description: This function will push (add) a value, which can be of any data type, onto the top of the stack. The function can take a further 14 optional arguments (making a total of 15 possible additions), permitting you to push multiple values consecutively to the stack in a single call.

audio_get_recorder_count.name: audio_get_recorder_count
audio_get_recorder_count.description: This function will return the number of audio recording sources (like microphones, etc...) currently available to your game. So, if you have a return value of, for example, four, then you will have audio input on the sources 0, 1, 2 and 3, with one of these values being that which you use to start recording from using the function audio_start_recording(). This value can change at any time as people plug/unplug microphones or other input sources to the device. Note that you can use the function audio_get_recorder_info() to get information on each device connected.

layer_background_yscale.name: layer_background_yscale

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to change

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed multiplier/value to use for the element

layer_background_yscale.description: This function can be used to set the scale along the y-axis of a background element. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and then set the scale value. The scale value you give is a multiplier that will be used to change the way the background element is displayed, where a value of 0.5 would display the element at half scale, and a value of 2 would display at double scale. Note that negative values are valid, and will "flip" the element around the (0,0) position, so an x scale of -1 would show the image reversed.

timeline_clear.name: timeline_clear

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the time line to clear.

timeline_clear.description: With this function you can clear a specific time line of "moments", removing all codes and actions for that time line and leaving it empty.

audio_free_play_queue.name: audio_free_play_queue

parameters.name: queueindex
parameters.description: The index of the queue to free.

audio_free_play_queue.description: This function is used to free up the memory associated with the given audio queue. The queue index is the value returned when you created the queue using the function audio_create_play_queue(), and this function should be called when the queue is no longer required to prevent memory leaks. Freeing the queue will stop any sound that is be playing, and you cannot delete the buffer that a sound is being streamed from until the queue it is assigned to has been freed. This function will trigger an Audio Playback Asynchronous Event, and in this event a special DS map will be created in the variable async_load with the following key/value pairs:

skeleton_animation_get_frames.name: skeleton_animation_get_frames

parameters.name: anim_name
parameters.description: The animation name to get the frames of.

skeleton_animation_get_frames.description: This function can be used to retrieve the number of frames that any given skeleton animation has. You supply the skeleton animation name (as a string, as defined in the program used to make the animation, or as returned by using the function skeleton_animation_get, and the function returns the frames that it has as an integer value. The function will return 0 if the specified animation does not exist.

vertex_format_get_info.name: vertex_format_get_info

parameters.name: format_id
parameters.description: The vertex format for which information should be retrieved.

vertex_format_get_info.description: This function is used to retrieve information for the given vertex format. You supply a vertex format index and the function returns a struct with the following variables:

sprite_add_from_surface.name: sprite_add_from_surface

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to add the new image to.

parameters.name: surface
parameters.description: The index of the surface from which the get the image.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to copy from.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to copy from.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the area to be copied (from the x position).

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height of the area to be copied (from the y position).

parameters.name: removeback
parameters.description: Indicates whether to make all pixels with the background colour (left-bottom pixel) transparent.

parameters.name: smooth
parameters.description: Indicates whether to smooth the edges.

sprite_add_from_surface.description: This function works in exactly the same way as sprite_create_from_surface() only instead of creating a new sprite from the area of the indexed surface that you select, it adds the defined area of the surface as a new sub-image to a previously created sprite (this means that you cannot add it directly to a sprite from the resource tree, but rather only to one previously created from a surface, or one that has been duplicated from a resource sprite using sprite_duplicate()).

draw_vertex.name: draw_vertex

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the vertex.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the vertex.

draw_vertex.description: This function defines the position of a vertex for a primitive. The final look of the primitive will depend on the primitive type chosen to draw and the order with which you add the vertexes to it. See draw_primitive_begin() for more information. To end and draw the primitive you must call draw_primitive_end().

audio_get_recorder_info.name: audio_get_recorder_info

parameters.name: recorder_index
parameters.description: The index of the recorder source to get the information from.

audio_get_recorder_info.description: This function will return a DS Map with information about the given recorder source index. You can find out how many recorder sources are available using the function audio_get_recorder_count(), and the map returned will contain the following key/value pairs:

animcurve_exists.name: animcurve_exists

parameters.name: curve_struct_or_id
parameters.description: The Animation Curve asset or struct that will be checked.

animcurve_exists.description: This function returns if the given Animation Curve Asset or Animation Curve Struct exists and is a valid Animation Curve.

layer_background_destroy.name: layer_background_destroy

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background to be destroyed

layer_background_destroy.description: This function will destroy the given background element. You supply the background ID (which you get when you create the background using layer_background_create() or when you use the layer ID along with layer_get_background_id()) and this will remove it. Note that this does not remove the layer, only the background from it, and if the background is one that has been added in the room editor, then the next time you leave the room and then return, the background will be recreated again. However if the room is persistent, the background will be removed unless room persistence is switched off again.

draw_surface_tiled.name: draw_surface_tiled

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the surface to draw.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of where to draw the surface.

draw_surface_tiled.description: This function will take a surface and then repeatedly tile it across the whole room, starting from the coordinates that you give in the function.

layer_background_visible.name: layer_background_visible

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to change

parameters.name: visible
parameters.description: The visibility toggle, which can be true or false

layer_background_visible.description: Using this function you can toggle a background elements visibility. You supply the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and then set the visible argument to true or false. When set to true the element will be displayed, and when set to false, the element will not be displayed. Note that this is dependent on the layer visibility, and even if the background element is flagged as visible, it will not be drawn if the layer it is on is flagged as not visible.

surface_get_target_ext.name: surface_get_target_ext

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The render target index to check (from 0 to 3).

surface_get_target_ext.description: This function will retrieve the surface ID assigned to one of the 4 render targets available to surfaces. You supply the index of the render target to check, and the function will return -1 if no surface is assigned, or an integer value >= 0, representing the ID of the surface assigned (as returned by the function surface_create()).

draw_skeleton_time.name: draw_skeleton_time

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to draw.

parameters.name: animname
parameters.description: The name of the animation to get the frame from (a string).

parameters.name: skinname
parameters.description: The name of the skin to use for drawing (a string).

parameters.name: time
parameters.description: The time-frame to draw the animation at (from 0 to the end duration, in seconds).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: rot
parameters.description: The rotation of the sprite. 0=normal, 90=turned 90 degrees counter-clockwise etc.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour with which to blend the sprite.

draw_skeleton_time.description: This function will draw the given animation using the given skin at a specific time in the animation. The time value should be between 0 (the beginning) and the end duration of the animation, which you can find using the function skeleton_animation_get_duration(). You can set the time value to values higher than the total duration of the animation and the animation will loop back to the beginning, but you run the risk of losing floating point accuracy as the accumulated time gets larger.

rollback_use_random_input.name: rollback_use_random_input

parameters.name: enabled
parameters.description: Flag to enable random input for other players in sync test

rollback_use_random_input.description: This function switches random input for other players in sync test.

part_emitter_create.name: part_emitter_create

parameters.name: ps
parameters.description: The particle system to create the emitter in.

part_emitter_create.description: This function must be used to create a new emitter and assign it to a given particle system. The function will return the index value for the new emitter which must be stored in a variable and used in all further functions that reference the emitter, and the emitter itself must be destroyed when no longer being used to prevent memory leaks (this can be achieved using the specific emitter destroy functions or by destroying the whole particle system that the emitter belongs to).

device_mouse_dbclick_enable.name: device_mouse_dbclick_enable

parameters.name: bool
parameters.description: Set double-click detection on (true) or off (false).

device_mouse_dbclick_enable.description: This function can be used to set the device to detect a double tap of the mb_left (left mouse button) as an mb_right (right mouse button) tap or not. By default this is set to true, meaning that every time the user taps the device screen twice quickly and consecutively, the return value is the same as if the right mouse button had been clicked. When this is on, the first tap will be detected as mb_left, and the second as mb_right, so make sure that any code you use takes this into account.

dcos.name: dcos

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The angle (in degrees) to return the cosine of.

dcos.description: In a right angled triangle cos(val) = Adjacent / Hypotenuse where val is one of the three angles. This function will always return a number between 1 and -1.

particle_get_info.name: particle_get_info

parameters.name: partsys
parameters.description: The particle system for which information should be retrieved.

particle_get_info.description: This function is used to retrieve information for the given particle system asset or instance. You supply either a particle system asset added through the Asset Browser or an instance created with part_system_create() and the function returns a struct with the following variables:

buffer_tell.name: buffer_tell

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to use.

buffer_tell.description: When you read or write data to a buffer using the buffer_read() or buffer_write() the current "seek" position is advanced by the bytes written or read, and with this function you can get the current "seek" position for use in other buffer functions. For example, if your buffer alignment is set to 4 bytes and you write a single piece of data which is 1 byte in size then do a buffer_tell(), you'll get an return value of 1. However, if you write another piece of data, also 1 byte in size, then do a buffer_tell(), you'll get a return value of 5 as the alignment has "padded" the data to that position.

vertex_format_end.name: vertex_format_end
vertex_format_end.description: This function must be called after defining any new vertex format. It returns the new format "handle" (index) which must be used in all further vertex functions that refer to this new format.

external_define.name: external_define

parameters.name: dll
parameters.description: The name of the dll file (string)

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the function (string)

parameters.name: calltype
parameters.description: The calling convention used

parameters.name: restype
parameters.description: The type of the result to expect

parameters.name: argnumb
parameters.description: The number of arguments (0 - 10)
The different types of arguments being used

external_define.description: This function can be used to define an external function call to a specific dll (for Windows) or dylib (for Mac). This file can be either an included file or part of an extension. You supply the name (and path) of the file, then the name of the function that you wish to define. Next you need to define the calling convention to be used (see the constants list below) as well as the type of result to be expected (also a constant, as listed below). Finally you must give the number arguments that the function can take (from 0 to 15) and for each of the arguments you must specify its type too. Please note that for functions with 4 or more arguments, all of them must be of type ty_real.

sprite_get_bbox_left.name: sprite_get_bbox_left

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to check.

sprite_get_bbox_left.description: This function returns the relative position of the left of the sprite bounding box. This value is given as a relative value based on the upper left corner of the base sprite asset being (0,0). it is the same value as can be found in the sprite editor for the collision mask properties. The image below shows how it is calculated:

date_get_minute.name: date_get_minute

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to check.

date_get_minute.description: This function returns the minute of the given datetime value.

array_unique_ext.name: array_unique_ext

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_unique_ext.description: With this function you can mutate an existing array with only unique value. This function returns the number of unique elements. The mapped elements will be padded to offset and order by the traversing direction. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.

network_send_broadcast.name: network_send_broadcast

parameters.name: socket
parameters.description: The id of the socket to use.

parameters.name: port
parameters.description: The port that the server will use.

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The id of the buffer to get the data from.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size (in bytes) of the data.

network_send_broadcast.description: With this function you can broadcast the data from a buffer locally to a range of IP addresses (for more information on buffers see Reference - Buffers). The range is limited to that of the device running the server, such that if the device has an IP of 92.168.11.130, then the data will be broadcast over the range 92.168.11.*. The function will return the number of bytes of data sent, or a number less than 0 if the send has failed.

ds_grid_get_max.name: ds_grid_get_max

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The left cell column of the region.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The top cell row of the region.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The right cell column of the region.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The bottom cell row of the region.

ds_grid_get_max.description: This function can be used to find the maximum value for all the cells found within the defined region of a grid, as shown in the image below:

audio_play_sound_at.name: audio_play_sound_at

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to play.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position.

parameters.name: z
parameters.description: The z position.

parameters.name: falloff_ref
parameters.description: The falloff reference relative to the listener (clamp).

parameters.name: falloff_max
parameters.description: The maximum falloff distance relative to the listener.

parameters.name: falloff_factor
parameters.description: The falloff factor (default 1).

parameters.name: loop
parameters.description: Flags the sound as looping or not.

parameters.name: priority
parameters.description: Set the channel priority for the sound.

parameters.name: gain
parameters.description: Sets the gain of the sound played.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: Sets the start offset (in seconds) of the sound played.

parameters.name: pitch
parameters.description: Sets the pitch of the sound played.

parameters.name: listener_mask
parameters.description: Sets the listener mask of the sound played.

audio_play_sound_at.description: With this function you can play any sound resource at a given position within the audio space. You provide the sound index and then assign it a position within the 3D space. The default listener position is (0, 0, 0) so this means that if the listener has not been moved and you want the sound to come from the left (for example), you should set the x position to a negative value (for more information on setting the listener position see audio_listener_position()).

part_type_size_y.name: part_type_size_y

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: size_min
parameters.description: The minimum size the particle can start at on the y axis.

parameters.name: size_max
parameters.description: The maximum size the particle can start at on the y axis.

parameters.name: size_incr
parameters.description: How much the particle should increase or decrease on the y axis per step.

parameters.name: size_wiggle
parameters.description: How much should randomly be added or subtracted from the particles size on the y axis per step.

part_type_size_y.description: This function is used to configure particle size similarly to part_type_size(), except only for the y axis. You can use function part_type_size_x() to configure the size on the x axis separately as well.

gesture_double_tap_distance.name: gesture_double_tap_distance

parameters.name: distance
parameters.description: The distance (in inches) to set for double tap gesture event detection.

gesture_double_tap_distance.description: This function is used to set the distance within which you have to touch/click the screen again after a single tap in order to trigger a Double Tap Gesture. The distance is measured in inches and has a default value of 0.1.

timeline_moment_clear.name: timeline_moment_clear

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the time line to clear.

parameters.name: step
parameters.description: The moment to clear.

timeline_moment_clear.description: With this function you can clear a specific moment of any previously defined time line of all codes and actions.

gamepad_set_color.name: gamepad_set_color

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to set.

parameters.name: color
parameters.description: The color to use.

gamepad_set_color.description: This function can be used to set the colour of the LEDs within a PlayStation controller. You specify the device slot to set, and then give a colour, which can be any of the colour constants or a colour value created using the specific colour functions or a HEX value(like $FFFFFFF).

part_type_color3.name: part_type_color3

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: colour1
parameters.description: The colour the particle will start at.

parameters.name: colour2
parameters.description: The colour the particle will be halfway through its lifespan.

parameters.name: colour3
parameters.description: The colour the particle will end at.

part_type_color3.description: This function can be used to set a three colour gradient for each particle created of the given type. The first colour is that which all particles will start with, and the second colour is the one that will be blended to half way through its lifetime and the third colour is the one with which the particle will end with. A smooth gradient change will occur through the colours over the particles lifetime from one colour to the other.

extension_get_option_value.name: extension_get_option_value

parameters.name: extension_name
parameters.description: The name of your extension asset as a string

parameters.name: option_name
parameters.description: The name of the option to read

extension_get_option_value.description:
This function returns the value of the given option in the extension with the given name.
			
			The function will return undefined if the provided extension name is invalid.

struct_set_from_hash.name: struct_set_from_hash

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The struct reference to set

parameters.name: hash
parameters.description: The hash of the variable to set (returned from 'variable_get_hash')

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to set the variable to

struct_set_from_hash.description: With this function you can set the value of a given variable in a struct. You supply the struct reference as well as the hash of the variable to set the value of (returned from 'variable_get_hash'), and then finally the value to set (can be any valid data type). If the variable does not exist already in the struct it will be created and then assigned the value.

merge_color.name: merge_color

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The first colour to merge

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The second colour to merge

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: How much of each colour should be merged. For example, 0 will return col1, 1 will return col2, and 0.5 would return a merge of both colours equally

merge_color.description: With this function you can take two colours and then merge them together to make a new colour. The amount of each of the component colours can be defined by changing the "amount" argument, where a value of 0 will return the first colour (col1), a value of 1 will return the second colour (col2) and a value in between will return the corresponding mix. For example, a value of 0.5 will mix the two colours equally. The following image illustrates how this works by merging the colours red and blue together:

sprite_get_height.name: sprite_get_height

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to find the height of.

sprite_get_height.description: With this function you can find the height of the base sprite asset, with no transforms, in pixels.

camera_get_view_mat.name: camera_get_view_mat

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_view_mat.description: This function can be used to retrieve the view matrix. The function returns the matrix ID value which can then be used in other matrix functions or to set the view matrix of another camera (using camera_set_view_mat()). Note that this function is generally for use with cameras created using camera_create(), but it can also be used on those created in the room editor (or with camera_create_view()) - in which case the returned matrix will only be valid after the given camera is used in a view port for the first time.

external_call.name: external_call

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The name of the function that you want to call
The different arguments that you want to pass through to the external function

external_call.description: If you have created an external function call to a dll or dylib using external_define(), you can use this function to then call it. You supply the name of the previously defined function as well as each of the arguments it requires (each argument must be of the correct type, either real or string) and the function returns the result of the external call.

gamepad_hat_value.name: gamepad_hat_value

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

parameters.name: hatindex
parameters.description: Which gamepad hat (or hats) to check for.

gamepad_hat_value.description: With this function you can get the current value of a gamepad "hat". Each hat value is a bit-mask for the different directions where:

network_destroy.name: network_destroy

parameters.name: socket
parameters.description: The id of the socket to remove.

network_destroy.description: With this function you can remove a network socket connection from your game.

date_second_span.name: date_second_span

parameters.name: date1
parameters.description: The first datetime.

parameters.name: date2
parameters.description: The datetime to compare it to.

date_second_span.description: With this function you can get the number of seconds between two dates. The return value is always positive and will be a whole number.

texture_get_width.name: texture_get_width

parameters.name: tex
parameters.description: The texture page asset pointer to use

texture_get_width.description: Returns the width of the texture with the given id, which is always a value within the range 0 - 1. This can then be used when mapping textures to models or primitives.

part_type_clear.name: part_type_clear

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to clear.

part_type_clear.description: With this function you can "reset" a particle, returning all the values for each of the functions relating to the particle (life, colour, alpha, orientation etc...) to their default values. Note that this function does not remove any particles currently visible in the room from the screen, for that you should be using part_particles_clear().

physics_joint_delete.name: physics_joint_delete

parameters.name: joint
parameters.description: The index of the joint that you wish to delete

physics_joint_delete.description: Once two instances with physics representations have been bound by a joint, this can be deleted again at any time. Normally this will happen automatically when one of the two instances is destroyed, or when the room ends, but there are times when you may wish to do this manually. In those cases you would use this function.

texture_get_texel_width.name: texture_get_texel_width

parameters.name: tex
parameters.description: The texture page asset pointer to use

texture_get_texel_width.description: A texel, or texture element is the fundamental unit of texture space used in computer graphics. Textures are represented by arrays of texels, just as pictures are represented by arrays of pixels, and this function returns the width of a single texel from the texture page of the image asset used.

string_lettersdigits.name: string_lettersdigits

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to convert to letters and digits.

string_lettersdigits.description: This function will return a copy of a given string with everything but its letters and digits removed, which means it can be used to remove any unwanted characters (like "#" or "?") from, for example, a login name or a password.

font_add.name: font_add

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The path of the font file in the Included Files (*.ttf or *.otf).

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the font - points for Web Fonts, pixels for file fonts.

parameters.name: bold
parameters.description: Whether the font is bold (true) or not (false).

parameters.name: italic
parameters.description: Whether the font is italic (true) or not (false).

parameters.name: first
parameters.description: The first character to include (if you're unsure, go for 32).

parameters.name: last
parameters.description: The last character to include (if you're unsure, go for 128).

font_add.description: This function can be used to add a font to your game from a font file present in the Included Files. You can define the size of the font (in points), as well as whether the font should be bold or italic, and you can also define the range of characters to include. The function returns an index value that should be stored in a variable as this will be needed in all further code that refer to this font, or it will return -1 if the function fails for any reason.

merge_colour.name: merge_colour

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The first colour to merge

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The second colour to merge

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: How much of each colour should be merged. For example, 0 will return col1, 1 will return col2, and 0.5 would return a merge of both colours equally

merge_colour.description: With this function you can take two colours and then merge them together to make a new colour. The amount of each of the component colours can be defined by changing the "amount" argument, where a value of 0 will return the first colour (col1), a value of 1 will return the second colour (col2) and a value in between will return the corresponding mix. For example, a value of 0.5 will mix the two colours equally. The following image illustrates how this works by merging the colours red and blue together:

gpu_get_blendmode_ext.name: gpu_get_blendmode_ext
gpu_get_blendmode_ext.description: This function can be used to retrieve the current extended blend mode being used for drawing. The function returns a 2 element 1D array with the following elements in it:

gamepad_set_axis_deadzone.name: gamepad_set_axis_deadzone

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

parameters.name: deadzone
parameters.description: The dead zone value from 0 to 1.

gamepad_set_axis_deadzone.description: This function can be used to set the "dead zone" of the joystick axis. You specify the device slot to set, and then set a value from 0 to 1 and if the input amount is lower than the given value, the joystick axis is considered to be at 0. Note that this is a global setting that will affect all axis of all joysticks connected to the device slot specified.

arccos.name: arccos

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The angle (in radians) to return the inverse cosine of.

arccos.description: Returns the inverse cosine of x, in that if cos(val)=n, arccos(n)=val, and the resulting number will be between pi and 0.

ds_set_precision.name: ds_set_precision

parameters.name: prec
parameters.description: The precision value (default 0.0000001)

ds_set_precision.description: When comparing values, for example when searching in a map or sorting a list, GameMaker must decide when two values are equal. For strings and integer values this is clear but for real numbers, due to floating point round-off errors, seemingly equal numbers can easily become unequal. For example, it's possible that (5 / 3) * 3 will not be equal to 5! To help avoid this, a precision value is used on all real number functions, and when the difference between two numbers is smaller than this precision they are considered equal. The default a precision of 0.0000001 is used for all data structure functions unless changed by this function.

sequence_destroy.name: sequence_destroy

parameters.name: sequence_struct_or_id
parameters.description: The sequence object struct or ID to destroy

sequence_destroy.description: With this function you can destroy a sequence object that has been created dynamically. You supply either the sequence object struct (as returned by the function sequence_create()) or the sequence ID (as returned by the function layer_sequence_get_sequence() or from the sequence instance struct property sequence). This function should be used whenever a dynamically created sequence is no longer required to free up the memory associated with it.

shader_set.name: shader_set

parameters.name: shader
parameters.description: The index of the shader to use.

shader_set.description: With this function you can set the drawing target to the given shader and all further drawing will be done using that. You can end shader use with function shader_reset().

filename_change_ext.name: filename_change_ext

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The file to use.

parameters.name: newext
parameters.description: The new extension to use.

filename_change_ext.description: This function returns the indicated file name with the extension (including the dot) changed to the new extension. By using an empty string as the new extension you can remove the extension part all together.

gpu_set_tex_mip_bias_ext.name: gpu_set_tex_mip_bias_ext

parameters.name: sampler_index
parameters.description: The index of the shader sampler to get

parameters.name: bias
parameters.description: The mipmap bias value to use (default: 0)

gpu_set_tex_mip_bias_ext.description: With this function you can set the mipmap bias value for a given shader sampler. You supply the index value for the shader sampler (as returned by the function shader_get_sampler_index(), and then the bias value, where 0 is for no bias, 1 equals the first mipmap, 2 equals the second mipmap etc... This controls the rate at which the mip map is swapped and will generally make the shader textures blurrier the higher the value and the greater the "distance" being viewed. Note that this function can also take negative values too, in which case shader textures will be sharper over a greater distance the lower the value.

part_system_position.name: part_system_position

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system to change.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The new x coordinate of the particle system.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The new y coordinate of the particle system.
