part_system_position.description: With this function you can set the base position for the particle system relative to the (0,0) position of the room, meaning that all further particle functions relating to this system will now be drawn relative to the new position. By default this position is always (0,0), but in some very special circumstances you may wish to change this to something else.

layer_enable_fx.name: layer_enable_fx

parameters.name: layer_name_or_id
parameters.description: The name or ID of the layer to modify

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enabled

layer_enable_fx.description: This function is used to enable FX for a specified layer.

db_to_lin.name: db_to_lin

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The value to convert.

db_to_lin.description: Converts a gain in decibels (dB) to a linear gain.

path_get_point_y.name: path_get_point_y

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to check.

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The point identity to check.

path_get_point_y.description: This function will return the y position (in room coordinates) of the point that you input for the path that you index. If the point is outside of the range of the path (ie: a path has 8 points and you ask for the y position of point 10) then a value of 0 will be returned.

window_get_y.name: window_get_y
window_get_y.description: With this function you can get the y position (in pixels) within the browser if it is an HTML5 game or within the display if it is a Windows, Ubuntu (Linux) or macOS game.

camera_get_active.name: camera_get_active
camera_get_active.description: This function can be used to retrieve the unique camera ID value of the currently active camera.

sprite_get_bbox_right.name: sprite_get_bbox_right

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to check.

sprite_get_bbox_right.description: This function returns the relative position of the right of the sprite bounding box. This value is given as a relative value based on the upper left corner of the base sprite asset being (0,0). it is the same value as can be found in the sprite editor for the collision mask properties. The image below shows how it is calculated:

part_type_colour2.name: part_type_colour2

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: colour1
parameters.description: The colour the particle will start at.

parameters.name: colour2
parameters.description: The colour the particle will end at.

part_type_colour2.description: This function can be used to set a two colour gradient for each particle created of the given type. The first colour is that which all particles will start with, and the second colour is the one on which the particle will end with, and a smooth gradient change will occur to the colour over the particles lifetime from one colour to the other.

layer_set_visible.name: layer_set_visible

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target (or the layer name as a string)

parameters.name: visible
parameters.description: Whether the layer should be visible (true) or not (false)

layer_set_visible.description: With this function you can toggle the visibility of a layer. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) as well as the toggle value for the layer where visible is true and invisible is false.

room_get_info.name: room_get_info

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the room.

parameters.name: views
parameters.description: Add room view information to the struct (defaults to true)

parameters.name: instances
parameters.description: Add instance information to the struct (defaults to true)

parameters.name: layers
parameters.description: Add room layer information to the struct (defaults to true)

parameters.name: layer_elements
parameters.description: Add layer element information to the struct (defaults to true), NOTE: you must have layers enabled to get any layer_elements

parameters.name: tilemap_data
parameters.description: Add tilemap data information to the struct (defaults to true), NOTE: you must have layers and layer_elements enabled to get any tilemap_data (if present)

room_get_info.description: This function can be used to get all the information on a room. It returns a struct that contains data that has been requested, a room can be very large so this can take a long time to complete, and optionally some data can be omitted to speed it up. NOTE: Tilemap data is an array of all the tilemap indices stored as a one dimensional array of width * height, where an x, y entry is indexed as (y*width)+x

load_csv.name: load_csv

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The name of the file to open (as a string)

load_csv.description: This function will load a CSV format file and convert it into a DS grid, returning the unique ID value for the grid created.

path_get_kind.name: path_get_kind

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to check.

path_get_kind.description: Paths can be either smooth or straight (a smooth path calculates a curved path around the defining points, whereas a straight path just goes straight from one point to another). This function can be used to find out whether the given path is smooth (true) or not (false).

floor.name: floor

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The number to floor.

floor.description: Returns the floor of n, that is, n rounded down to an integer. This is similar to the round() function, but it only rounds down, no matter what the decimal value, so floor(5.99999) will return 5, as will floor(5.2), floor(5.6457) etc...

gml_pragma.name: gml_pragma

parameters.name: command
parameters.description: A string with one of the commands listed below.

parameters.name: optional
parameters.description: Some of the available commands require an optional argument or arguments. These are explained below for each command.

gml_pragma.description: The gml_pragma function affects how the given target compiles your code and should be called with the different commands to further optimise the final compilation of your project. These commands are effectively pre-processed before the game is compiled and so the function can be placed anywhere in your project and it will still be processed before the game is fully compiled. The available commands are as follows:

ord.name: ord

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string with which to find the Unicode code.

ord.description: This function takes a single character input string and returns the Unicode (UTF8) value for that character. Note that when used with the keyboard_check* functions, the input string can only be one character in length and can only be a number from 0 to 9 or a capitalised Roman character from A to Z.

skeleton_attachment_set.name: skeleton_attachment_set

parameters.name: slot
parameters.description: The slot name (a string) to get the attachment of.

parameters.name: attachment
parameters.description: The name (as a string or a sprite_index) of the attachment image.

skeleton_attachment_set.description: A skeletal animation sprite may have other images added as attachments, with these images being added to a named slot (the name is given when you create the attachment slot in your animation program) and they will be drawn along with the animation of the current sprite. With this function you can set an attachment to a given slot, where you are required to give the names (as strings) of the slot and the attachment. These names are defined by the animation program used, or (in the case of the attachment) when you call skeleton_attachment_create().

time_source_get_reps_completed.name: time_source_get_reps_completed

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

time_source_get_reps_completed.description: Returns the number of repetitions the time source has completed so far.

ds_stack_destroy.name: ds_stack_destroy

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to remove.

ds_stack_destroy.description: This function will remove the given stack data-structure from memory, freeing up the resources it was using and removing all values that it contained. This function should always be used when you are finished using the DS stack to prevent memory leaks that can slow down and crash your game.

audio_listener_position.name: audio_listener_position

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of the listener (default 0).

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of the listener (default 0).

parameters.name: z
parameters.description: The z position of the listener (default 0).

audio_listener_position.description: With this function you can change the position of the listener within the 3D audio space. The example image below shows the default position for the listener in the audio space:

physics_joint_get_value.name: physics_joint_get_value

parameters.name: joint
parameters.description: The index of the joint that you wish to test

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The constant for the joint property that you wish to test

physics_joint_get_value.description: By using a series of predefined constants, you can ask GameMaker to tell you a number of things about the state of any given joint. This is very useful as it gives you the ability to delete joints or change an instances behaviour depending on whatever your needs are at the time. There are a number of constants that can be used in this function and they can be found here: Physics Joint Constants, but be aware that complex calculations are done when you call these, so they should be used with care and only when necessary and note that many are unique to a specific type of joint.

buffer_compress.name: buffer_compress

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to compress.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset within the buffer to compress (in bytes).

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the buffer area to compress (in bytes).

buffer_compress.description: With this function you can compress part (or all) of a buffer using zlib compression. You supply the ID of the buffer to compress (as returned by buffer_create()), the offset within the buffer to use in bytes, and the size of the buffer data to compress (also in bytes). The function will return a new buffer ID value for the compressed buffer, or a value less than 0 if it has failed for any reason. This function will not alter the original buffer.

ds_queue_tail.name: ds_queue_tail

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to read from.

ds_queue_tail.description: This function will only read the last value of the queue (that which is "at the tail"). It will not dequeue the value, meaning that it can still be read in the future by this function or the ds_queue_dequeue().

layer_background_get_speed.name: layer_background_get_speed

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to get the information from

layer_background_get_speed.description: This function can be used to get the current speed multiplier value of the background element. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and the function will return real value that represents the speed multiplier being used to animate the sprite. Default value is 1.

layer_sequence_is_paused.name: layer_sequence_is_paused

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

layer_sequence_is_paused.description: With this function you supply the sequence element ID - as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions - and it will check if the sequence is currently paused or not, returning true if it is paused, and false if it is not.

date_date_of.name: date_date_of

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to extract the date from.

date_date_of.description: Returns the date value of the given datetime.

audio_play_in_sync_group.name: audio_play_in_sync_group

parameters.name: group_index
parameters.description: The group index to assign the sound to.

parameters.name: sound_index
parameters.description: The sound index to be assigned to the group.

audio_play_in_sync_group.description: With this function you can assign a sound to a previously create sync group. The group index is the value returned when you created the group using the function audio_create_sync_group(), and the sound index is the index of any compressed sound (*.ogg or *.mp3) from the Asset Browser. This function only adds the sound to the group, but it does not play the sound, and will be a value > -1 if it succeeds and -1 if it fails, where a successful value indicates the sounds order in the sync group (so 0 would be the first sound added, 1 would be the second, etc...).

dbg_colour.name: dbg_colour

parameters.name: dbgref
parameters.description: reference to the variable to change

parameters.name: label
parameters.description: label to use.

dbg_colour.description: Creates a colour entry within the current debug section, variable will be a colour RGB value, no alpha. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.

date_days_in_year.name: date_days_in_year

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The date to use.

date_days_in_year.description: With this function you can get the number of days that the given year has, returning 365 for a normal year, and 366 for a leap year.

sprite_flush_multi.name: sprite_flush_multi

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: Array with the sprite indices to flush

sprite_flush_multi.description: With this function you can remove the any number of texture pages for the given sprites from texture memory. You supply the sprite indices as an array and the texture pages they are assigned to will be removed from texture memory. Note that if one of the texture pages is used elsewhere in the room (by another instance sprite or a background, etc...) you may get a minor performance hit as the page is immediately reloaded back into memory again, so care should be taken when using this function. Note that the function will return -1 if flush is not supported for the chosen resources, or it will return 0 if all worked correctly.

ds_map_clear.name: ds_map_clear

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to clear.

ds_map_clear.description: This function will clear the (previously created) DS map of all key/value pairs, but it will not delete the DS map itself from memory. For that you should use the function ds_map_destroy(). Note that clearing a map will de-reference any data structures stored in the map giving a memory leak, so you would need to go through it and destroy all data structure items manually before clearing the map to prevent this. The only time this is not required is when you have flagged any items in the map as a DS list or as another DS map, in which case these items will be destroyed (not cleared!) and their memory cleaned up automatically when the parent map is cleared.

layer_sequence_create.name: layer_sequence_create

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the instance layer to target

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position in the room to create the sequence at

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position in the room to create the sequence at

parameters.name: sequence_id
parameters.description: The sequence ID to create, as defined in the Asset Browser

layer_sequence_create.description: With this function you can create an instance of a sequence asset on the given layer. You supply the layer ID which can be a string of the layer name - as defined in the room editor - or the unique layer ID - as returned by the function layer_get_id(), as well as the X and Y position in the room to create the sequence at, and finally the ID of the sequence to create. The sequence ID is the name constant that you defined in the Asset Browser for the sequence. The function will return the unique ID of the sequence element, which can then be used in all further layer functions for sequences, or it can be used to retrieve the sequence instance struct using the function layer_sequence_get_instance().

timeline_max_moment.name: timeline_max_moment

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the timeline to get the last moment of.

timeline_max_moment.description: This function will return the value of the moment in which the timeline performs its final action. So, if you have a timeline with 8 different actions placed 20 moments apart, this function would return the moment value of the last action in that timeline, which would be 160. This function is a good way to test whether a timeline has passed the last active moment when running, since the timeline position will continue incrementing every step of the game whether there are further actions or not.

camera_get_view_width.name: camera_get_view_width

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_view_width.description: This function can be used to retrieve the width (in pixels) of the given camera. Note that this function is only valid for cameras created using camera_create_view() or for those added in the room editor.

string_split_ext.name: string_split_ext

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The input string.

parameters.name: delimiter_array
parameters.description: An array of delimiter strings to search for.

parameters.name: remove_empty
parameters.description: Removes empty entries from the output array.

parameters.name: max_splits
parameters.description: The maximum number of splits that are allowed.

string_split_ext.description: This function splits string into an ordered list of substrings by searching from an array of delimiters, puts these substrings into an array, and returns the array.

ini_write_string.name: ini_write_string

parameters.name: section
parameters.description: The section of the .ini to write to.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key within the relevant section of the .ini to write to.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The string to write to the relevant destination.

ini_write_string.description: You can use this function to write a string (text) to an ini data file. Ini Files are split into sections and then each section is subsequently split into key - value pairs. So a typical ini file would look something like this:

string_pos.name: string_pos

parameters.name: substr
parameters.description: The substring to look for in the string.

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string.

string_pos.description: This function will return the character position of an instance of a sub-string within a string, searching from the beginning of the string (to search from the end, use the function string_last_pos()). The function will return 0 if it's not found at all, or the position of the first character of the sub-string if it is found. Keep in mind that for legacy support strings are indexed from 1, so 1 is the first position in the string, not 0 as you may expect. One use for this is for filtering words that may be considered offensive, or for finding the correct place to insert some text into another string.

ds_list_empty.name: ds_list_empty

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to check.

ds_list_empty.description: With this function you can check the given DS list to see if it is empty (returns true) or not (returns false).

physics_joint_prismatic_create.name: physics_joint_prismatic_create

parameters.name: inst1
parameters.description: The first instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: inst2
parameters.description: The second instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: w_anchor_x
parameters.description: The x coordinate where the joint is anchored, within the game world

parameters.name: w_anchor_y
parameters.description: The y coordinate where the joint is anchored, within the game world

parameters.name: w_axis_x
parameters.description: The x component of the axis vector

parameters.name: w_axis_y
parameters.description: The y component of the axis vector

parameters.name: lower_trans_limit
parameters.description: The lower permitted limit for the joint movement

parameters.name: upper_trans_limit
parameters.description: The lower permitted limit for the joint movement

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Whether to limit the movement of the joint (true) or not (false)

parameters.name: max_motor_force
parameters.description: Sets the maximum movement speed for the motor

parameters.name: motor_speed
parameters.description: This is the speed at which the motor should move

parameters.name: motor
parameters.description: Whether the motor should be active (true) or not (false)

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

physics_joint_prismatic_create.description: Like a revolute joint, the prismatic joint only has one degree of freedom, but with this joint it is directional relative to an axis rather than rotational and actually prevents any form of rotation. Here is an image to help you visualise how this works:

camera_get_view_border_y.name: camera_get_view_border_y

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_view_border_y.description: This function can be used to retrieve the border value for object/instance following of the given camera along the y axis (vertical border). The return value will be in pixels.

draw_line_width.name: draw_line_width

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the line in pixels.

draw_line_width.description: With this function you can draw a line of a specified width between any two points in the game room. Please note that the line being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

rollback_join_game.name: rollback_join_game

parameters.name: dry_run
parameters.description: Flag to only check if you should join without actually doing it

rollback_join_game.description: This function checks if the game was started via an invite to a GXC game and if so joins it.

ds_grid_set_region.name: ds_grid_set_region

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x position of the left of the region in the grid.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y position of the top of the region in the grid.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x position of the right of the region in the grid.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y position of the bottom of the region in the grid.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to set the region cells to.

ds_grid_set_region.description: This function can be used to set a rectangular region of a given grid to a specified value (which can be either a real or a string) as illustrated by the image shown below:

room_duplicate.name: room_duplicate

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the original room to be duplicated.

room_duplicate.description: This will duplicate a given room and return the duplicates index to be used in all further calls to reference the new room.

physics_joint_revolute_create.name: physics_joint_revolute_create

parameters.name: inst1
parameters.description: The first instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: inst2
parameters.description: The second instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: w_anchor_x
parameters.description: The x coordinate for the joint, within the game world

parameters.name: w_anchor_y
parameters.description: The y coordinate for the joint, within the game world

parameters.name: ang_min_limit
parameters.description: The lower permitted limit for the joint angle

parameters.name: ang_max_limit
parameters.description: The upper permitted limit for the joint angle

parameters.name: ang_limit
parameters.description: Whether the to limit the angle of the joint (true) or not (false)

parameters.name: max_motor_torque
parameters.description: Sets the maximum motor torque used to achieve the desired motor speed (in Newtons per meter)

parameters.name: motor_speed
parameters.description: This is the speed at which the motor should rotate

parameters.name: motor
parameters.description: Whether the motor should be active (true) or not (false)

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

physics_joint_revolute_create.description: A revolute joint forces two bodies to share a common anchor point (often called a hinge point) and the joint has a single degree of freedom - the relative rotation of the two bodies around this point. To specify a revolute you need to provide two instances and a single anchor point in the room, as you can see in the image provided:

physics_particle_set_radius.name: physics_particle_set_radius

parameters.name: radius
parameters.description: The radius (in pixels) of the particle fixture.

physics_particle_set_radius.description: With this function you can set the radius (in pixels) for the particles in a physics simulation. This function is global in scope, in that it will change the radius not just for new particles created after the change, but also for those already present in the simulation.

sprite_add.name: sprite_add

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The name (a string file path) of the file to add.

parameters.name: imgnum
parameters.description: Use to indicate the number of sub-images (1 for a single image or for a *.gif).

parameters.name: removeback
parameters.description: Indicates whether to make all pixels with the background colour (left-bottom pixel) transparent.

parameters.name: smooth
parameters.description: Indicates whether to smooth the edges if transparent.

parameters.name: xorig
parameters.description: Indicate the x position of the origin in the sprite.

parameters.name: yorig
parameters.description: Indicate the y position of the origin in the sprite.

sprite_add.description: With this function you can add an image as a sprite, loading it from an external source where the image file to be loaded should always be in either *.png, *.gif, *.jpg/jpeg or *.json format (*json files are used for loading skeleton animation sprites made with Spine). The function returns the new sprite index which must then be used in all further code that relates to the sprite. If you use this function with HTML5 or are getting an image from a URL, this function will also generate an Image Loaded asynchronous event. See this page for more information.

audio_sound_loop_start.name: audio_sound_loop_start

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to change.

parameters.name: time
parameters.description: The offset (in seconds) to set the start of the loop section to.

audio_sound_loop_start.description: This function will set the offset (in seconds) of the start of a sound's loop section.

virtual_key_add.name: virtual_key_add

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate (left side) of the virtual key on the screen

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate (top side) of the virtual key on the screen

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the virtual key

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height of the virtual key

parameters.name: keycode
parameters.description: Which keyboard key event should be triggered by touching this area

virtual_key_add.description: This function enables you to map "touches" of a screen area to keyboard events. This means that once you have assigned an area to a virtual key, all touches on that area will trigger the keyboard event corresponding to the key you have mapped to the area. You can assign each virtual key you define to a variable too, which can then be used in the further virtual key functions to show, hide and delete them. These keys are assigned on a per room basis and will be automatically removed by GameMaker when changing rooms.

json_stringify.name: json_stringify

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The reference value for a struct or array to convert into a JSON string

parameters.name: prettify
parameters.description: Whether of not the result JSON string should be prettified. Defaults to false.

json_stringify.description: With this function you can convert single or nested structs and arrays into a valid JSON string. You supply the initial value to use (an array index or a struct reference) and then the function will "stringify" it, converting it into a JSON string, converting GameMaker arrays into JSON arrays, and GameMaker structs in to JSON objects.

position_change.name: position_change

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to change colliding instances.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to change colliding instances.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The new object the calling object will change into.

parameters.name: perf
parameters.description: Whether to perform that new object's Create event (true) or not (false).

position_change.description: This function will check a position for a collision with any instances at the given point, and if there is one, it will change all instances in collision to be instances of the chosen object. You can set the "perf" argument to true which will force GameMaker to perform the Destroy and Clean Up events of the found instance as well as the Create event of the new instance, or false to not perform any of these events. Please note, that if you choose not to perform the Destroy, Clean Up and Create events, any instance created that uses a variable normally defined in the create event will crash the game as that variable will no longer exist.

layer_sprite_blend.name: layer_sprite_blend

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to change

parameters.name: blend
parameters.description: The colour to blend with the sprite sprite (default is c_white)

layer_sprite_blend.description: This function controls the blending (or "tinting") of the sprite sprite and the default value is -1 (which represents the constant c_white, which can also be used). Any other value (including internal colour constants like c_red, or c_aqua) will blend the specified colour with the original sprite. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and then set the blending colour to use. Below you can see an example of a sprite that has been blended with different colours:

window_views_mouse_get_x.name: window_views_mouse_get_x
window_views_mouse_get_x.description: This function returns the x-coordinate of the mouse with respect to all the active views and returns the same value mouse_x.

mp_potential_step_object.name: mp_potential_step_object

parameters.name: xgoal
parameters.description: The target x position.

parameters.name: ygoal
parameters.description: The target y position.

parameters.name: stepsize
parameters.description: The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object that is to block the path of the instance running the function. Can be an object index, an instance id or the special keyword ,all.

mp_potential_step_object.description: This function lets the instance take a step towards a particular position defined by xgoal/ygoal, all the while trying to avoid obstacles. When the instance would run into an instance of the object specified by the "obj" argument it will change the direction of motion to try to avoid that instance and move around it. This approach is not guaranteed to work but in most easy cases it will effectively move the instance towards the goal. The function returns whether the goal was reached or not.

part_type_destroy.name: part_type_destroy

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to destroy.

part_type_destroy.description: With this function you can remove the specified particle type from the game. When you use this function, all particles of the given type will disappear from the room and the particle itself is removed form memory, so this function should be used only when you no longer need the particle.

move_wrap.name: move_wrap

parameters.name: hor
parameters.description: Whether to wrap horizontally (true) or not (false).

parameters.name: vert
parameters.description: Whether to wrap vertically (true) or not (false).

parameters.name: margin
parameters.description: How far outside the room, in pixels, the object must be to initiate wrapping.

move_wrap.description: This function will automatically "wrap" an instance that has left the room on either the horizontal or vertical (or both) axis. You can specify a margin outside the edges of the room for this to occur, and when the instance has travelled outside of that margin GameMaker will automatically wrap it back into the room at the other side. Note that the instance must have a speed for wrapping to work, because the direction of wrapping is based on the direction of the motion.

push_get_next_local_notification.name: push_get_next_local_notification

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: The DS Map ID to use.

push_get_next_local_notification.description: This function will populate a pre-made DS map with a series of key/value pairs for the next local push notification in the queue to be shown. It returns -1 if there are no further notifications queued, or a real value otherwise representing the ID for the notification. This ID can then be used to cancel the notification using the function push_cancel_local_notification(). You should call the function push_get_first_local_notification() to get the first notification in the queue and then use this function to continue through it.

physics_joint_friction_create.name: physics_joint_friction_create

parameters.name: inst1
parameters.description: The first instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: inst2
parameters.description: The second instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: anchor_x
parameters.description: The x coordinate for the joint, within the game world

parameters.name: anchor_y
parameters.description: The y coordinate for the joint, within the game world

parameters.name: max_force
parameters.description: The maximum frictional force that will be applied

parameters.name: max_torque
parameters.description: The maximum rotational force that will be applied

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

physics_joint_friction_create.description: The friction joint is a bit different to all other joints in the physics simulation in that the connection created will not constrain the instances position or movement, but rather its speed and rotation. This works by taking the maximum input values for force and torque and applying those to the second fixture to bring the speed and angular momentum down to the same values as that of the first instance. So, if you have a stationary instance and a moving instance then connect them with a friction joint, the moving instance will gradually slow down until it too is stationary. If both instances were moving then the second instance will have its movement speed modified to match that of the first instance.

audio_group_get_gain.name: audio_group_get_gain

parameters.name: groupid
parameters.description: The index of the audio group to check (as defined in the Audio Groups window)

audio_group_get_gain.description: This function will return the group gain of a given audio group.

texturegroup_set_mode.name: texturegroup_set_mode

parameters.name: explicit
parameters.description: If false, indicates that texture pages are automatically loaded if a sprite is rendered from an unloaded texture group

parameters.name: debug
parameters.description: If true, enables a debug view

parameters.name: default_sprite
parameters.description: Specifies default sprite which is used for drawing when a texture group hasn't been loaded

texturegroup_set_mode.description: With this function you can configure how texture group loading is handled as well as set debug options

gpu_get_ztestenable.name: gpu_get_ztestenable
gpu_get_ztestenable.description: This function can be used to retrieve whether z-testing is enabled (the function returns true) or not (the function returns false). The default value is that z-testing is disabled, so the function will return false.

gc_collect.name: gc_collect
gc_collect.description: With this function you can trigger the garbage collector, forcing it to run at the end of the current frame (step). It is worth noting that the garbage collector does not need to be active for this to work. Calling this function after disabling the garbage collector (using the function gc_enable()) will enable the garbage collector for one frame in which all objects that have been flagged for collection will be removed from memory before the garbage collector is disabled again.

physics_particle_set_gravity_scale.name: physics_particle_set_gravity_scale

parameters.name: scale
parameters.description: The scaling factor to be applied to gravity for all particles.

physics_particle_set_gravity_scale.description: With this function you can set the gravity scale factor for particles in the physics simulation. The function is designed to help prevent instability in the physics simulation, especially when using very small particles which may behave unpredictably (i.e. break conservation of momentum) in scenarios such as explosions. Slowing these particles down by reducing gravity scale can stabilize their behaviour. This function is global in scope, in that it will change the gravity scale not just for new particles created after the change, but also for those already present in the simulation.

physics_particle_group_get_x.name: physics_particle_group_get_x

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The particle group to get.

physics_particle_group_get_x.description: With this function you can retrieve the x position in the room of a group of particles. The group value is that which was returned when you created the group of particles using the function physics_particle_group_end(), and the function will return a value which is the combined value of the currently set flags.

vertex_freeze.name: vertex_freeze

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to freeze.

vertex_freeze.description: This function can be used to "freeze" a vertex buffer. this buffer becomes read-only, meaning that should you need to change it, you would have to delete the whole buffer and re-create it. A frozen buffer can be submitted to the shader faster than a normal, dynamic buffer and is recommended for those effects that require an unchanging custom primitive for the duration of a level or the game.

sprite_get_name.name: sprite_get_name

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to get the name of.

sprite_get_name.description: This function will return the name as a string of the specified sprite. This name is the one that has been specified for the sprite in the resource tree of the main GameMaker window. Please note that this is only a string and cannot be used to reference the sprite directly - for that you would need the sprite index. You can, however, use this string to get the sprite index using the returned string along with the function asset_get_index().

browser_input_capture.name: browser_input_capture
browser_input_capture.description: With this function you can set whether the browser window should capture all input (set it to false) or whether the game should capture the input (set it to true). Note that this function is for use with the HTML5 module only.

layer_background_alpha.name: layer_background_alpha

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to change

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha for background sprite, from 0 to 1 (default is 1)

layer_background_alpha.description: This function controls the alpha (transparency) of the background sprite. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and then set the alpha value to use. Alpha can be between 0 (fully transparent) and 1 (fully opaque) with the default alpha value for the background element being 1. Note that if the layer the background element has been assigned to is not visible - or the element itself has been made invisible - you will not see any difference with this function until the layer or element has been made visible again.

object_get_sprite.name: object_get_sprite

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The index of the object to check

object_get_sprite.description: This function will tell you whether the object you are checking has a sprite or not, and if it does then it will return the index of that sprite, or -1 if it does not. Please note that this is not an instance function! You can have an object with no sprite while an instance of that same object can have one and vice-versa, or they can even have different sprites. You can set an individual instances sprite using the sprite_index instance variable.

layer_get_depth.name: layer_get_depth

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to get the depth of (or the layer name as a string)

layer_get_depth.description: You can use this function to get the depth value associated with a given layer. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the function will return that layers depth as a real number. Note that depth is defined as being higher the "further away" from the camera and lower the "closer" to the camera, so if you have three layers with depths -100, 0, 100, the layers will draw in the order 100, 0, -100, so that the "top" layer (ie, the closest to the camera view and so drawn over everything else) will be the layer with the -100 depth.

tile_set_rotate.name: tile_set_rotate

parameters.name: tiledata
parameters.description: the tile-data to set

parameters.name: rotate
parameters.description: Set to true to rotate and false to leave it as-is

tile_set_rotate.description: This function can be used to set a given set of tile-data to rotate the tile 90 degrees or not. You give the tile-data, which can be retrieved using the function tilemap_get(), and then set the rotate argument to either true if you want the tile rotated, or false if you want the tile to be in its default, un-rotated state. The function will return a modified tile-data set which can then be applied using the tilemap_set() function.

sprite_get_width.name: sprite_get_width

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to find the width of.

sprite_get_width.description: With this function you can find the width of the base resource sprite, with no transforms, in pixels.

path_reverse.name: path_reverse

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to change.

path_reverse.description: With this function you can reverse the order in which the individual path points are numbered, so, for example, if the path has 5 points, point 0 would become point 4, point 1 would be point 3 and point 2 would not be changed. The actual position of the points remains the same, only the order in which they are processed is changed. This function changes the actual path asset, and so will permanently affect how the path is used by all instances in the game from the moment the function is used until the end of the game. If this is not what you require, then you should use a function like path_duplicate() to create a copy of the path first, then call this function on the duplicated asset (don't forget to call path_delete() on the asset when it is no longer required).

is_bool.name: is_bool

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The argument to check.

is_bool.description: This function returns whether a given variable is a boolean (true ior false) or not. In some cases you want to check and see if a variable in GameMaker holds a boolean value, and that's when you would use this function.

matrix_stack_set.name: matrix_stack_set

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: The matrix index to use.

matrix_stack_set.description: This function overwrites the current top of the matrix stack with the specified matrix.

audio_stop_sound.name: audio_stop_sound

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to stop.

audio_stop_sound.description: This function will stop the given sound if it is currently playing. The sound can either be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions) or a sound asset, in which case all instances of the given sound will be stopped.

sprite_set_alpha_from_sprite.name: sprite_set_alpha_from_sprite

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to change the transparency map of.

parameters.name: spr
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to take the transparency map data from.

sprite_set_alpha_from_sprite.description: This function uses the value/saturation of one sprite and multiplies it with the alpha of the target sprite. Ideally the sprite being used to generate the new alpha map should be grey-scale, with the white areas having an equivalent alpha value of 1 (opaque), the black areas being equivalent to alpha 0 (transparent), and the grey areas being an alpha in between 0 and 1. The sprite that you are setting the alpha of cannot be a permanent resource, nor can the sprite you use to set the alpha, as this will give an error. This means that you must create two completely new sprites "on the fly" in some way for the function to work correctly. This can be achieved by using surfaces, or by creating a sprite from the screen (the code example below shows how the effect can be achieved with surfaces).

buffer_save_async.name: buffer_save_async

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to save.

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The name of the file to save as.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset within the buffer to save from (in bytes).

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the buffer area to save (in bytes).

buffer_save_async.description: With this function you can save part of the contents of a buffer to a file, ready to be read back into memory using the buffer_load() function (or any of the other functions for loading buffers). The "offset" defines the start position within the buffer for saving (in bytes), and the "size" is the size of the buffer area to be saved from that offset onwards (also in bytes). This function works asynchronously, and so the game will continue running while being saved, and all files saved using this function will be placed in a "default" folder. This folder does not need to be included in the filename as it is added automatically by GameMaker. For example the filename path "Data\Player_Save.sav" would actually be saved to "default\Data\Player_Save.sav". However, if you then load the file using the function buffer_load_async(), you do not need to supply the "default" part of the path either (but any other file function will require it, except on consoles Xbox One, PS4 and Nintendo Switch).

texture_get_texel_height.name: texture_get_texel_height

parameters.name: tex
parameters.description: The texture page asset pointer to use

texture_get_texel_height.description: A texel, or texture element is the fundamental unit of texture space used in computer graphics. Textures are represented by arrays of texels, just as pictures are represented by arrays of pixels, and this function returns the height of a single texel from the texture page of the image asset used.

audio_emitter_gain.name: audio_emitter_gain

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to change.

parameters.name: gain
parameters.description: The maximum gain (default 1).

audio_emitter_gain.description: This function sets the maximum gain (volume) for the sound. The perceived volume for a sound can change depending on the fall-off value and the position it has relative to the listener, but by setting the gain with this function, the full volume will never exceed the specified gain value. The image below illustrates how gain affects the volume of the emitter when fall-off is greater than 0:

vertex_position_3d.name: vertex_position_3d

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to write the information to.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position.

parameters.name: z
parameters.description: The z position.

vertex_position_3d.description: This function will add 3D position data to the vertex currently being defined for the custom primitive. You supply the buffer to write the data into as well as the x, y and z position for drawing.

power.name: power

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The number to change.

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: How many times to multiply x by itself.

power.description: This will return the value of a number multiplied by itself "n" number of times. For example, power(5,3) will multiply 5 by itself 3 times and return 125, which is the same as saying 5*5*5=125. Please note that the "x" value (the number to change) cannot be a negative value.

randomise.name: randomise
randomise.description: This function sets the seed to a random value. Should you need to keep a consistent value over a number of runs of a game, you should be using random_set_seed(). Please note, that when using the random number functions in GameMaker the initial seed is always the same, as this makes tracing errors and debugging far easier. Should you wish to test with true random, you should call this function at the start of your game. The function will return the new randomised seed value (an unsigned 32bit integer).

part_type_colour1.name: part_type_colour1

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: colour1
parameters.description: The single colour to make the particle type.

part_type_colour1.description: This function is used to set a particle type to be a single colour for the total duration of the lifetime of each individual particle.

struct_get.name: struct_get

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The struct reference to use

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the variable to get (as a string)

struct_get.description: With this function you can get the value from a given named variable within a struct. You supply the struct reference as well as the name of the variable to get the value of as a string (see example code below). The function will return the value held by the variable or undefined if the named variable does not exist.

part_type_color_rgb.name: part_type_color_rgb

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: rmin
parameters.description: The minimum the final colour's red component can be.

parameters.name: rmax
parameters.description: The maximum the final colour's red component can be.

parameters.name: gmin
parameters.description: The minimum the final colour's green component can be.

parameters.name: gmax
parameters.description: The maximum the final colour's green component can be.

parameters.name: bmin
parameters.description: The minimum the final colour's blue component can be.

parameters.name: bmax
parameters.description: The maximum the final colour's blue component can be.

part_type_color_rgb.description: With this function you can set the mix of red, green and blue colours for all particles created of the given type. You supply a minimum value and a maximum value for each of the three components and the particles created will have a random colour based on the given range of parameters. All values must be between 0 and 255.

draw_light_define_ambient.name: draw_light_define_ambient

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to use (either a constant, a real or a hex value).

draw_light_define_ambient.description: This function is used to control the ambient light of a scene, which is the light that you have in a scene even without having defined any point or directional light sources. It is effectively the overall colour and brightness (or darkness) of a scene. The default colour is c_black.

gesture_drag_time.name: gesture_drag_time

parameters.name: time
parameters.description: The time (in seconds) to set for drag gesture event detection.

gesture_drag_time.description: This function is used to set the time it takes for a Drag Gesture event to be triggered by a touch or click. This time will also affect how the Tap Event is triggered as a touch/click and release before this time is up will be considered a Tap. The time is measured in seconds and has a default value of 0.16.

audio_sound_set_listener_mask.name: audio_sound_set_listener_mask

parameters.name: soundid
parameters.description: The unique ID of the sound to set the mask of

parameters.name: mask
parameters.description: The bitmask data to set for the sound

audio_sound_set_listener_mask.description: This function can be used to set the the bit-mask for a sound so that it will play only from those listeners specified. You can create a bit-mask by using the audio_get_listener_info() and then using the bitwise or ("|") to create a custom mask with those listeners that you require the sound to play from, and then apply this custom mask to the sound after you have played it. This mask will over-ride the default mask or that which you may have set using the function audio_set_listener_mask().

shader_set_uniform_i.name: shader_set_uniform_i

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: The handle of the shader constant to set.

parameters.name: value1
parameters.description: The integer value (or values) to set the shader constant to.

parameters.name: value2
parameters.description: The integer value (or values) to set the shader constant to.

parameters.name: value3
parameters.description: The integer value (or values) to set the shader constant to.

parameters.name: value4
parameters.description: The integer value (or values) to set the shader constant to.

shader_set_uniform_i.description: With this function you can set the value (or values) of a shader constant. You must previously have gotten the "handle" of the constant using the function shader_get_uniform(), and you will have to know what type of constant it is to pass the correct number of integer values through to it, ie: if you have a vec2 you will need to pass two values to the function.

time_source_pause.name: time_source_pause

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

time_source_pause.description: Pauses the time source and all of its children.

time_source_reset.name: time_source_reset

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

time_source_reset.description: Resets the time source and all of its children.

audio_get_listener_mask.name: audio_get_listener_mask
audio_get_listener_mask.description: This function will return the bit-mask data that defines the current default (global) mask for the audio listeners.

mean.name: mean

parameters.description: The values to compare.

mean.description: This function works by adding up all the input values and then dividing them by their own number. You can have as many arguments as you require (note that more arguments will mean that the function will be slower to parse). So, mean(2, 6, 9, 32) returns 12.25 as 2+6+9+32=49 and 49/4=12.25.

effect_clear.name: effect_clear
effect_clear.description: This will clear all particles that are currently visible in the room which have been made using either effect_create_above() or effect_create_below().

ds_map_write.name: ds_map_write

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to use

ds_map_write.description: This function will turn the DS map data of the specified map into string format which can then be written to an *.ini or a *.txt file for easy storage. This string can then be later read back into a new ds_map using ds_map_read().

draw_vertex_texture_color.name: draw_vertex_texture_color

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the vertex.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the vertex.

parameters.name: xtex
parameters.description: The x coordinate within the texture.

parameters.name: ytex
parameters.description: The y coordinate within the texture.

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to blend with the texture at this vertex (-1 or c_white for no blending).

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha to draw this vertex with (0-1).

draw_vertex_texture_color.description: This function defines the position of a textured vertex for a primitive. The final look of the primitive will depend on the primitive type chosen to draw (See draw_primitive_begin() for more information), the order with which you add the vertices to it, the position of the start and end points that you give for the texture sample and the colour and alpha values that you have set. To maintain the texture appearance while changing only the alpha, a value of -1 (or c_white) may be used for the colour argument. To end and draw the primitive you must call draw_primitive_end().

animcurve_destroy.name: animcurve_destroy

parameters.name: curve_struct
parameters.description: The pointer to the curve struct to destroy.

animcurve_destroy.description: This function destroys an animation curve previously created with the function animcurve_create().

audio_get_master_gain.name: audio_get_master_gain

parameters.name: listenerindex
parameters.description: The index of the listener to get the gain of.

audio_get_master_gain.description: With this function you can get the absolute value for the global volume of all sounds and music for a specific listener. The default listener index is 0, but you can use the function audio_get_listener_info() to get the different indices available for the target platform. The gain value returned is based on a linear scale from 0 (silent) to 1 (full volume). Note that on some platforms you can have a gain of greater than 1, although a value of 1 is considered "full volume" and anything greater may introduce audio clipping.

audio_emitter_falloff.name: audio_emitter_falloff

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to change.

parameters.name: falloff_ref
parameters.description: The falloff reference relative to the listener (clamp).

parameters.name: falloff_max
parameters.description: The maximum falloff distance relative to the listener.

parameters.name: falloff_factor
parameters.description: The falloff factor (default 1).

audio_emitter_falloff.description: With this function you can set the fall-off distance for an emitter. This is the distance from the listener the emitter has to be before the sound will have "fallen off" to a volume of 0. The default value for this is 100, but beware of setting this to any value lower than 1 as that will make any sound played through this emitter inaudible to the listener, however any other value will cause the sound to fade away the further that the emitter is from the listener.

ds_list_sort.name: ds_list_sort

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the list to sort.

parameters.name: ascend
parameters.description: Whether the values should be ascending (true) or descending (false) order.

ds_list_sort.description: With this function you can sort all the values within a list, either in ascending or descending order. If the list contains strings, these will be sorted alphabetically, based on the English 26 letter alphabet.

rollback_display_events.name: rollback_display_events

parameters.name: enabled
parameters.description: Flag to enable default display of events

rollback_display_events.description: This function sets if the default display of rollback events should be used or not. Default value is true.

gpu_get_tex_mip_filter.name: gpu_get_tex_mip_filter
gpu_get_tex_mip_filter.description: With this function you can get the current mip filter mode. The mode value returned by the function will be one of the constants listed below.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling factor (use -1 to reset to default).

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling factor (use -1 to reset to default).

parameters.name: xoffset
parameters.description: The x offset position for drawing.

parameters.name: yoffset
parameters.description: The y offset position for drawing.

camera_destroy.name: camera_destroy

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera.

camera_destroy.description: With this function you can destroy any camera. When calling the function you supply the unique camera ID value, which you get from the camera_create_* functions or from the view_camera array if using the Room Editor to set up the view port and view. You should never destroy a camera that is currently assigned to a visible view, unless you are assigning a new camera to that view in the same step, and you should always destroy any cameras that you have created through code when no longer required by your game to prevent memory leaks, and you can also destroy the default cameras if you have any assigned in the Room Editor, but you should assign a new camera to the view port (or disable it) otherwise you will get odd results.

array_filter_ext.name: array_filter_ext

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: function
parameters.description: The function to be executed as filter. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return a boolean.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_filter_ext.description: With this function you can mutate an existing array to filter the elements that return true to the given predicate. This function returns the number of filtered elements. The filtered elements will be padded to offset and order by the traversing direction. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.

ds_grid_get.name: ds_grid_get

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of the cell you want to find the value of.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of the cell you want to find the value of.

ds_grid_get.description: This function can be used to get the value (either a real number or a string) from any cell within the given DS grid. If you pass invalid grid coordinates to the function, then the value returned will be undefined and an error will be shown in the output window.

buffer_write.name: buffer_write

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to write to.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of data that is to be written to the buffer (see the list of constants above).

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The data to write.

buffer_write.description: This function can be used to write data to a previously created buffer. The data you write must be in agreement with the "type" argument of this function, meaning that you can't try to write a string as an unsigned 16bit integer, for example. The following constants can be used to define the data type:

draw_sprite.name: draw_sprite

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to draw.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The sub-image (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

draw_sprite.description: This function draws the given sprite and sub-image at a position within the game room. For the sprite you can use the instance variable sprite_index to get the current sprite that is assigned to the instance running the code, or you can use any other sprite asset. The same goes for the sub-image, as this can also be set to the instance variable image_index which will set the sub-image to that selected for the current instance sprite (note, that you can draw a different sprite and still use the sub-image value for the current instance), or you can use any other value for this to draw a specific sub-image of the chosen sprite. If the value is larger than the number of sub-images, then GameMaker will automatically loop the number to select the corresponding image (for example, if the sprite being drawn has 5 sub-images numbered 0 to 4 and we set the index value to 7, then the function will draw sub-image 3, numbered 0). Finally, the x and y position is the position within the room that the sprite will be drawn, and it is centered on the sprite x offset and y offset.

part_type_colour_mix.name: part_type_colour_mix

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: colour1
parameters.description: The first colour the blend will take from.

parameters.name: colour2
parameters.description: The second colour the blend will take from.

part_type_colour_mix.description: With this function you can set the given particle type to be a random blend of two colours.

mouse_check_button.name: mouse_check_button

parameters.name: numb
parameters.description: Which mouse button constant to check for.

mouse_check_button.description: This function will return true if the mouse button being checked is held down or false if it is not. You supply the mouse button to check from one of the following constants:

path_insert_point.name: path_insert_point

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to insert the point into.

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The defining point to insert the new point BEFORE.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate (relative to the path) of the new point.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate (relative to the path) of the new point.

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed factor of the point.

path_insert_point.description: With this function you can insert a new point into a path (the path can have been created in the path editor or through code using path_add()). The point will be added into the path before the point "n" that is specified in the function.

date_date_string.name: date_date_string

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The date to use.

date_date_string.description: With this function you can create a string containing the given date, formatted as day/month/year.

position_empty.name: position_empty

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to check.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to check.

position_empty.description: This function will check to see if a given position enters into collision with any instance with a valid collision mask at the given position.

audio_sync_group_is_paused.name: audio_sync_group_is_paused

parameters.name: group_index
parameters.description: The group index to check.

audio_sync_group_is_paused.description: This function can be used to check if any audio in a synchronised group is paused. You are required to supply the sync group ID as returned by the function audio_create_sync_group().

sprite_set_bbox_mode.name: sprite_set_bbox_mode

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to change the mode of.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: The mode to set (a constant).

sprite_set_bbox_mode.description: This function can be used to set the bounding box mode for a sprite. You supply the sprite index and the mode to use, which should be one of the following constants:

window_get_color.name: window_get_color
window_get_color.description: This function returns the background colour of the game window. This colour represents that which will be used for those areas of the game window that are not occupied by any views. The following image illustrates this:

gamepad_button_check_pressed.name: gamepad_button_check_pressed

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to check.

parameters.name: button
parameters.description: Which gamepad button constant to check for.

gamepad_button_check_pressed.description: This function will return true or false depending on whether the given gamepad button is detected as having been pressed or not. Note that this function will only trigger once for the button the first time it is pressed. For it to trigger again the button must first be released and then re-pressed. If you need to check a continuous press of the button you should be using the function gamepad_button_check().

audio_group_stop_all.name: audio_group_stop_all

parameters.name: groupid
parameters.description: The index of the audio group to stop (as defined in the Audio Groups Window)

audio_group_stop_all.description: This function will stop all sounds from the given audio group that are currently playing.

application_surface_enable.name: application_surface_enable

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Set to enable (true) or disable (false) the application surface.

application_surface_enable.description: With this function you can enable or disable the application surface. By default the application surface is enabled and all drawing for the Draw events will be done to that and the surface drawn to the screen. However on some older devices and specific chipsets this may result in poorer performance. In those cases you can switch off drawing to the application surface and all Draw event drawing will then be done directly to the screen buffer.

draw_rectangle_colour.name: draw_rectangle_colour

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the rectangle.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top of the rectangle.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right of the rectangle.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the rectangle.

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The colour of the top left corner.

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The colour of the top right corner.

parameters.name: col3
parameters.description: The colour of the bottom right corner.

parameters.name: col4
parameters.description: The colour of the bottom left corner.

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the rectangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

draw_rectangle_colour.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rectangle or a filled rectangle by defining an area where the (x1,y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2,y2) position is the bottom right corner. If it is filled you can define the individual colours for each corner point and if these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

date_week_span.name: date_week_span

parameters.name: date1
parameters.description: The first datetime.

parameters.name: date2
parameters.description: The datetime to compare it to.

date_week_span.description: With this function you can get the number of weeks between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete weeks will be returned as a fraction.

file_text_open_write.name: file_text_open_write

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The name of the file to write to.

file_text_open_write.description: This function opens the text file with the indicated filename for writing only (if the file does not exist, it is created), returning the unique id of the file that which should be stored in a variable as it will be used for all further actions to do with that file. Note that if the file can't be created (because of an illegal filename, for example) the function will return -1.

zip_save.name: zip_save

parameters.name: zip_object
parameters.description: The zip object to be saved.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The path the zip should be saved to.

zip_save.description: This function will save a zip object to the specified path.

physics_world_gravity.name: physics_world_gravity

parameters.name: xg
parameters.description: The x component of the gravity vector

parameters.name: yg
parameters.description: The y component of the gravity vector

physics_world_gravity.description: As with all the physics functions, physics_world_gravity() will only work on an instance if the room has a physics world defined for it in the room editor or using physics_world_create(). It will then use the 0,0 defining point of the physics world to calculate the direction and strength of gravity based on the vector calculated from the xg and yg inputs. Here are some images to illustrate...

array_create.name: array_create

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the array to create.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value to use to initialise all array indices (optional).

array_create.description: With this function you can create a 1D array of a given size. You tell the function the length of the array to create, and it will return the "handle" for the array which you can then assign to a variable. Arrays created in this way will have each entry initialised to 0 unless you specify an (optional) initialisation value. If you do supply the extra value for initialising the array, then all indices within the new array will be set to that instead of 0, but note that the function will have a greater performance overhead in this case.

display_reset.name: display_reset

parameters.name: aa
parameters.description: The level of anti-aliasing filtering (0, 2, 4 or 8).

parameters.name: vsync
parameters.description: Toggle vertical synchronisation to on (true) or off (false).

display_reset.description: This function Resets the display settings to the ones that were set when the game was started, but also allows you to change the current level of full screen anti-aliasing being used and whether to use vertical synchronisation. The available anti-aliasing levels are 0,2,4 and 8, with the default startup value being set to 0, and the default v-sync setting is false (off). Switching v-sync on may give a smoother gaming experience but it will also need more processing power and so its impact must be considered careful before use, and the same goes for the anti-aliasing where the higher the number the more processing that is required.

draw_sprite_tiled_ext.name: draw_sprite_tiled_ext

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to draw.

parameters.name: subimg
parameters.description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling of the sprite. A multiplier ' 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc.

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling of the sprite. A multiplier ' 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour with which to blend the sprite. c_white is to display it normally.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha of the sprite (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

draw_sprite_tiled_ext.description: This function will take a sprite and then repeatedly tile it across the whole view (or room if no view is defined), starting from the coordinates that you give in the function and with each tile scaled, colour blended and with the alpha that you define (these properties are the same as those used in draw_sprite_ext()). This function is for 2D (orthographic) projections only, and will not work correctly when a 3D camera projection is used.

matrix_stack_clear.name: matrix_stack_clear
matrix_stack_clear.description: This function clears the matrix stack.

clipboard_has_text.name: clipboard_has_text
clipboard_has_text.description: This function will return true if the clipboard contains text or false if it does not.

window_center.name: window_center
window_center.description: With this function you can center the game window in the display when the target module is Windows, Ubuntu (Linux) or macOS, or you can center it in the browser if the target module is HTML5. This function has no effect on any other device.

buffer_get_type.name: buffer_get_type

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to check.

buffer_get_type.description: With this function you retrieve the type of buffer that is being referenced by a buffer ID value. The return value will be one of the following constants:

physics_joint_distance_create.name: physics_joint_distance_create

parameters.name: inst1
parameters.description: The first instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: inst2
