parameters.description: The second instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: w_anchor1_x
parameters.description: The first x coordinate for the joint, within the game world

parameters.name: w_anchor1_y
parameters.description: The first y coordinate for the joint, within the game world

parameters.name: w_anchor2_x
parameters.description: The second x coordinate for the joint, within the game world

parameters.name: w_anchor2_y
parameters.description: the second y coordinate for the joint, within the game world

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

physics_joint_distance_create.description: One of the simplest joint is a distance joint which says that the distance between two points on two instances must be constant. When you specify a distance joint the two instances should already be created and have a fixture assigned, then you define the two anchor points in room coordinates. The first anchor point is connected to instance 1, the second anchor point is connected to instance 2 and the distance between these points imply the length of the distance constrain. The image below shows how this works:

get_login_async.name: get_login_async

parameters.name: username
parameters.description: The default user name

parameters.name: password
parameters.description: The default password

get_login_async.description: This function opens a window that asks the user to input a username and password. These arguments can be set as an empty string or you can store previously entered values to use if you wish. This is an asynchronous function, and as such GameMaker does not block the device it is being run on while waiting for an answer, but rather keeps on running events as normal. Once the user has input the details and pressed the "Okay" button, an asynchronous User Interaction event is triggered which, for the duration of that event only, will have a DS map stored in the variable async_load.

dot_product_3d_normalised.name: dot_product_3d_normalised

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: z1
parameters.description: The z coordinate of the first vector.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the second vector.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the second vector.

parameters.name: z2
parameters.description: The z coordinate of the second vector.

dot_product_3d_normalised.description: The dot product is a value expressing the angular relationship between two vectors and is found by taking two vectors, multiplying them together and then adding the results. The name "dot product" is derived from the centered dot "·" that is often used to designate this operation (the alternative name "scalar product" emphasizes the scalar rather than vector nature of the result).

physics_joint_weld_create.name: physics_joint_weld_create

parameters.name: inst1
parameters.description: The first instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: inst2
parameters.description: The second instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: anchor_x
parameters.description: The x coordinate for the joint, within the game world

parameters.name: anchor_y
parameters.description: The y coordinate for the joint, within the game world

parameters.name: ref_angle
parameters.description: The joint angle to maintain

parameters.name: freq_hz
parameters.description: This is the oscillation frequency for the joint, in hertz

parameters.name: damping_ratio
parameters.description: This damping ratio for the joint

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: Whether the two instances can collide (true) or not (false)

physics_joint_weld_create.description: The weld joint is designed to attach two fixtures together in a strong, yet flexible bond. The weld joint will permit flexing between the two joined fixtures but without the stretching associated with, for example, a distance joint, and will always try to "spring" back to the reference angle when put under any stress or load. You define the point in the room where the joint should be created, as well as the angle that you wish the joint to try and maintain at all times, as shown in the image below:

skeleton_attachment_create.name: skeleton_attachment_create

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name (as a string) of the attachment to create.

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The sprite_index to get the attachment image from.

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The image_index to get the attachment image from.

parameters.name: xorigin
parameters.description: The x origin for the image being used.

parameters.name: yorigin
parameters.description: The y origin for the image being used.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling of the image, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling of the image, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

parameters.name: rot
parameters.description: The rotation of the image. 0=normal, 90=turned 90 degrees counter-clockwise etc.

skeleton_attachment_create.description: When you create you skeletal animation sprite, you can assign attachment slots and attachments to go in them. These are simply images that are apart from the animation but when attached will move along with the bone they are attached to. Normally you would assign these attachments in your animation program (Spine), but with this function you can create your own at run-time using a sprite asset from your game. the function requires that you give the attachment a UNIQUE name (as a string) and then set the sprite_index and image_index to use, as well as the x and y origin (which can be different to that defined by the sprite in the sprite properties), and you can also set any transforms that you wish to be applied to the image when attached. If the attachment was successfully created the function will return 1 and if it was not (you supplied an invalid sprite index, or the base sprite is not a Spine sprite) then it will return -1.

move_outside_all.name: move_outside_all

parameters.name: dir
parameters.description: The direction to move in.

parameters.name: maxdist
parameters.description: The maximum distance the object can travel (-1 or 0 a default value of 1000 pixels).

move_outside_all.description: With this function you can tell an instance to move out of a collision in any direction and any number of pixels each step, with a value of -1 or 0 for the maxdist being a default 1000px, ie: GameMaker will move the instance continually up 1000 pixels until it is out of collision.

code_is_compiled.name: code_is_compiled
code_is_compiled.description: This function will return true if the platform compiles outside of the virtual machine, such as for the YYC and JS platforms.

vertex_position.name: vertex_position

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to write the information to.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position.

vertex_position.description: This function will add 2D position data to the vertex currently being defined for the custom primitive. You supply the buffer to write the data into as well as the x and y position for drawing.

part_particles_create_color.name: part_particles_create_color

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to create the particles.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to create the particles.

parameters.name: parttype
parameters.description: The index (type) of the particles to be created.

parameters.name: colour
parameters.description: The colour blending for the particles.

parameters.name: number
parameters.description: The number of particles to create.

part_particles_create_color.description: This function is ideal for those effects that do not require any of the functionality offered by particle emitters (for example, to create smoke from a missile, or a simple explosion effect) as it permits you to quickly and easily create particles at any position in the game room. You can also colour the particles "on the fly" as they are created with this function, and this colour will over-ride the predefined colour of the particle, but it does not blend this colour over the particles lifetime. Note that you must have created the particle system and the particle type previously for this function to be used.

array_resize.name: array_resize

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The index of the array to resize.

parameters.name: new_size
parameters.description: The new size for the array (an integer, starting from 0).

array_resize.description: With this function you can resize an existing array dimension to a new size. You supply the array to be resized as well as the new number of indices for the array, and the function will resize that array. Note that this function is designed for resizing an array down to a smaller length as you can resize up by simply setting a new index in the array. That said, if you do use it to size up an array, any new indices will be set to the default value of 0.

tilemap_get_cell_y_at_pixel.name: tilemap_get_cell_y_at_pixel

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to get the cell y position of

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position within the room to use for getting the cell

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position within the room to use for getting the cell

tilemap_get_cell_y_at_pixel.description: Using this function you can retrieve the y-axis position of an individual tile map cell by giving the relative y-axis position within the room. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), as well as the x and y position within the room and the function will return the y position of the cell within the tile map for that point. Note that if the value is outside of the tile map area, and no cell is available, it will return -1.

collision_point_list.name: collision_point_list

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the point to check.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the point to check.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for instance collisions.

parameters.name: prec
parameters.description: Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).

parameters.name: notme
parameters.description: Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).

parameters.name: list
parameters.description: The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.

parameters.name: ordered
parameters.description: Whether the list should be ordered by distance (true) or not (false).

collision_point_list.description: This function is the same as the collision_point() function, only instead of just detecting one instance in collision at a time, it will detect multiple instances. You supply the x/y position of the point to check and you can set the check to be precise (in which case all instances being checked will need to have precise collision masks) and whether the check should include the calling instance or not.

part_emitter_relative.name: part_emitter_relative

parameters.name: ps
parameters.description: The particle system that the emitter is in.

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the emitter.

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable (true) or disable (false) relative mode.

part_emitter_relative.description: With this function you can enable relative mode for an emitter, which means that the number of particles it burst or streams becomes relative to its area.

physics_get_restitution.name: physics_get_restitution

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the id of the bound fixture

physics_get_restitution.description: When you bind a fixture to an instance using physics_fixture_bind() this returns an "id" for the bound fixture. You can use this id to get the restitution (the "bounciness" property) value of the bound fixture, not the "base" fixture, at any time using this function.

audio_falloff_set_model.name: audio_falloff_set_model

parameters.name: model
parameters.description: The constant used to set the falloff model.

audio_falloff_set_model.description: To add more versatility to the audio engine, GameMaker permits you to select the falloff model that suits your game. This model will be used for all the audio functions in the game or app, and so you should make sure that the model you choose is the correct one, as each one will affect how the listener perceives the sounds you play through emitters or with the function audio_play_sound_at.

vertex_format_add_texcoord.name: vertex_format_add_texcoord
vertex_format_add_texcoord.description: Tell GameMaker to accept texture position data (u and v) as part of the new vertex format being created.

audio_play_sound_ext.name: audio_play_sound_ext

parameters.name: params
parameters.description: A struct containing a set of playback parameters.

audio_play_sound_ext.description: With this function you can play any sound resource in your game. You provide a struct which contains a set of required parameters as well as any additional playback parameters. Parameters not specified will fall back to their default values/behaviour.

draw_text_ext.name: draw_text_ext

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to draw.

parameters.name: sep
parameters.description: The distance in pixels between lines of text.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The maximum width in pixels of the string before a line break.

draw_text_ext.description: This function will draw text in a similar way to draw_text() only now you can set the space between each line of text - should the text occupy more than one line - and limit the width (in pixels) of the string per line so that should any line exceed this value, GameMaker will automatically split the text to the next line at the nearest available white-space (if the text has no white-spaces then it will overrun this maximum width value). Note that any white space placed at the start of the string will be stripped out before being parsed for drawing because of this. Also note that a value of -1 for the line separation argument will default to a separation based on the height of the "M" character in the chosen font.

date_get_hour.name: date_get_hour

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The datetime to check.

date_get_hour.description: This function returns the hour of the given datetime value.

keyboard_clear.name: keyboard_clear

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to clear.

keyboard_clear.description: With this function you can clear the current keyboard state, which essentially means that if the key is being held down, it will no longer be recognised until it is released again (which won't trigger the Keyboard Key Released event either on this occasion) and pressed again. The function will take a keycode value as returned by the function ord() (only capital letters from A-Z or numbers from 0-9), or any of the vk_* constants listed on the main Keyboard Input page.

buffer_async_group_end.name: buffer_async_group_end
buffer_async_group_end.description: This function finishes the definition of a buffer save group. You must have previously called the function buffer_async_group_begin() to initiate the group, then call the function buffer_save_async() for each file that you wish to save out. Finally you call this function, which will start the saving of the files. The function will return a unique ID value for the save, which can then be used in the Asynchronous Save / Load event to parse the results from the async_load DS map.

gamepad_test_mapping.name: gamepad_test_mapping

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: Which gamepad index "slot" to set.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The map string to use (see the description for more information).

gamepad_test_mapping.description: This function can be used to set the gamepad mapping on those targets that permit it. You supply the "slot" index for the gamepad to set, and then the map string, which should have been created using the SDL format with the following fields:

collision_rectangle.name: collision_rectangle

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the rectangle to check.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top side of the rectangle to check.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right side of the rectangle to check.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom side of the rectangle to check.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for instance collisions.

parameters.name: prec
parameters.description: Whether the check is based on precise collisions (true, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (false, faster).

parameters.name: notme
parameters.description: Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (true) or not (false).

collision_rectangle.description: Collision_rectangle uses the first four arguments (x1,y1,x2,y2) to define an area within the current room and then checks to see if any object that is defined by the "obj" argument is in collision with that area. This collision can be checked as precise or not, and you may also choose to check for the instance running the code itself or not. Consider this image:

sprite_set_speed.name: sprite_set_speed

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to get the animation type of

sprite_set_speed.description: This function can be used to set the base animation speed and type as for the sprite resource. This is normally set in the Sprite Editor, but there may be moments when you are required to set this manually for a given sprite resource. You need to supply the sprite index to set, the animation speed and the type of animation speed to apply. The animation speed type can be any one of the following constants:

view_set_visible.name: view_set_visible

parameters.name: view_port
parameters.description: The view port to target (0 - 7)

parameters.name: visible
parameters.description: Visibility toggle (true is visible and false is invisible)

view_set_visible.description: This function can be used to set the visibility of the given view port. The function takes the view port index (from 0 to 7) and a boolean true if it is visible and false if it is not.

audio_sound_get_loop_end.name: audio_sound_get_loop_end

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound whose loop-end is retrieved.

audio_sound_get_loop_end.description: This function will return the offset (in seconds) of the end of a sound's loop section.

move_contact_solid.name: move_contact_solid

parameters.name: dir
parameters.description: The direction to move in.

parameters.name: maxdist
parameters.description: The maximum distance the object can travel (-1 or 0 a default value of 1000 pixels).

move_contact_solid.description: This function will move the instance running the code a set number of pixels in the specified direction until it meets an instance with solid flagged as true. You can use -1 or 0 for the maxdist being a default 1000px, ie: GameMaker will move the instance continually up 1000 pixels until it is out of collision.

sequence_instance_override_object.name: sequence_instance_override_object

parameters.name: sequence_instance_struct
parameters.description: The sequence instance struct to modify.

parameters.name: object_id
parameters.description: The object index of the object within the sequence to override.

parameters.name: instance_or_object_id
parameters.description: The object index or instance ID to use to override the sequence objects.

sequence_instance_override_object.description: With this function you can override (replace) all instances of an object used in a sequence with another one. You supply the sequence instance struct ID (as returned when the sequence instance was created in the room or by using one of the room layer functions - see here), as well as the object index (as defined in the asset browser) for the object that you want to override. Finally you give an object index or an instance ID to use as the object that is going to override the sequence (supplying an instance ID will simply use the object that the instance was created from as the override). Note that this can only be done on sequence instances (not sequence objects) and must be done before the sequence starts to play, otherwise it won't work.

mp_potential_path.name: mp_potential_path

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: index of the path that is to be used by the function

parameters.name: xgoal
parameters.description: The target x position.

parameters.name: ygoal
parameters.description: The target y position.

parameters.name: stepsize
parameters.description: The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.

parameters.name: factor
parameters.description: This number is used to prevent an infinite loop. It should be larger than 1. See the function description for more information.

parameters.name: checkall
parameters.description: Whether to check all instances (true) or just solid ones (false).

mp_potential_path.description: This function computes a path for the instance from its current position and orientation to the position specified by the xgoal,ygoal arguments. It uses the indicated step size while trying to avoid collision with either all instances or only those flagged as solid. Like in the function mp_potential_step() it uses potential field steps to accomplish this and the manner in which it does this can be modified through the function mp_potential_settings(). The indicated path must already exist and it will be overwritten by the new path. The function will return whether a path was found (true) or not (false).

ds_grid_shuffle.name: ds_grid_shuffle

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid to shuffle.

ds_grid_shuffle.description: This function can be used to randomise the positions of all values in all cells within a grid.

ds_queue_dequeue.name: ds_queue_dequeue

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the queue to dequeue from.

ds_queue_dequeue.description: This function will dequeue the head value off of the DS queue, removing it from the queue and returning the value to be stored in a variable. If the queue is empty then the function will return the constant undefined, otherwise it will return the real or string value contained in the queue.

camera_set_update_script.name: camera_set_update_script

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera.

parameters.name: script
parameters.description: The script function to run each game frame

camera_set_update_script.description: This function can be used to set a script function that will be called every game frame that the camera is assigned to a visible and active view port. You give the unique camera ID value (as returned by the different camera_create functions) and the ID of the function to be called. The order in which functions attached to cameras and the actual rendering of the camera view is as follows:

draw_highscore.name: draw_highscore

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the highscore rectangle.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top of the highscore rectangle.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right of the highscore rectangle.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the highscore rectangle.

draw_highscore.description: This simple function will draw the current list of internally stored high scores using the currently set font, colour and alpha values within the specified rectangle. You provide the coordinates for the upper left corner and lower right corner of the rectangular area to draw the text, and GameMaker will take care of the rest, with spacing and position being done automatically.

tilemap_get_tile_width.name: tilemap_get_tile_width

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to get the tile cell width of

tilemap_get_tile_width.description: Using this function you can retrieve the width (in pixels) of each tile cell of the tile map element. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and the function will return the tile set cell width.

texture_global_scale.name: texture_global_scale

parameters.name: pow2integer
parameters.description: The scale factor to use (1, no scale, 2, half scale, 4, quarter scale, etc...)

texture_global_scale.description: This function allows you to control the scaling of the texture pages on load from the WAD file that is part of your final game executable. The input value must be a power of two value and will work such that:

base64_encode.name: base64_encode

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to encode.

base64_encode.description: This function will convert a string into a base64 format encoded string. This is a commonly used encoding scheme that is often used for any media that needs to be stored or transferred over the internet as text, and renders the output unreadable to the human eye.

room_get_viewport.name: room_get_viewport

parameters.name: rm
parameters.description: The index of the room to get viewport data from

parameters.name: vind
parameters.description: The index of the view port to get

room_get_viewport.description: With this function you can retrieve the details of a view port in a room other than the current one. You give the room ID and the index of the view port to retrieve (from 0 to 7) and the function will return an array of 5 indices, where:

method.name: method

parameters.name: struct_ref_or_instance_id
parameters.description: The unique reference or ID value of the struct or instance to use (or undefined for self)

parameters.name: function
parameters.description: The ID of the function to use

method.description: With this function you can bind any function that has previously been defined to a given instance or struct, creating a method variable that can be used later. You supply the instance ID to use (it must be an instance that is active and in the room, and can't be an object ID) or a struct reference, as well as the ID of the function that you want to bind. The function will return a method which can be called from the variable it is assigned to (see the code example below). It is worth noting that you can bind built-in functions as well as user defined functions, and you can also supply undefined as the instance/struct argument meaning that the current self scope will be used for the binding.

part_type_alpha1.name: part_type_alpha1

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: alpha1
parameters.description: The alpha of the particle.

part_type_alpha1.description: This function is used to set a particle type to have a single alpha value (transparency) for the total duration of the lifetime of each individual particle, and this can be from 0 (transparent) to 1 (opaque).

file_bin_close.name: file_bin_close

parameters.name: binfile
parameters.description: The ID of the file to close.

file_bin_close.description: Closes a previously opened binary file. You supply the file ID value, as returned by the function file_bin_open().

shaders_are_supported.name: shaders_are_supported
shaders_are_supported.description: This function will do a check to see if the chosen target platform supports shaders, returning true if they do, and false if they do not. It is important to note that on Android, if the project does not have any shader resources defined, then the function will always return false, regardless of whether the device supports shaders or not.

surface_free.name: surface_free

parameters.name: surface_id
parameters.description: The ID of the surface to be freed.

surface_free.description: When you are working with surfaces, you should always use this function whenever you are finished using them. Surfaces take up space in memory and so need to be removed, normally at the end of a room, but it can be done at any time depending on the use you put them to. Failure to do so can cause memory leaks which will eventually slow down and crash your game.

dbg_add_font_glyphs.name: dbg_add_font_glyphs

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: filename of a TTF file to use

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: size of the font in pixels(default is 13)

parameters.name: fontRange
parameters.description: fontRange type (default is -1 - Latin range)

dbg_add_font_glyphs.description: Adds TTF font to be used in the debug rendering, font should be added to the included files, size of the font can be specified in pixels, and a font range can be selected (glyphs must be present in the given TTF font) * -1 - Default Latin range, * 0 - Greek, * 1 - Korean, * 2 - Japanese, * 3 - Chinese Full, * 4 - Chinese Simplified Common, * 5 - Cyrillic, * 6 - Thai, * 7 - Vietnamese

point_distance_3d.name: point_distance_3d

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first component of the vector

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the first component of the vector

parameters.name: z1
parameters.description: The z coordinate of the first component of the vector

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the second component of the vector

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the second component of the vector

parameters.name: z2
parameters.description: The z coordinate of the second component of the vector

point_distance_3d.description: This function takes the supplied components of the vector and returns the length (distance) of the vector. It works in exactly the same way as point_distance() but with the addition of factoring in the z value (depth) for use in 3D space.

physics_particle_group_add_point.name: physics_particle_group_add_point

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position in the room for the point.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position in the room for the point.

physics_particle_group_add_point.description: This function sets a point in the room to define the shape of a polygon which will be used to create a group of soft body particles. You must have previously signaled to GameMaker that you are going define a polygon shape using the function physics_particle_group_polygon() and then use this function to define the individual points of the polygon. You must give at least three points when defining the polygon shape, but can give up to eight, and the function will permit the definition of concave polygons. However, if you generate a polygon with any cavities, the points within will be ignored and a convex shape will be created for the particle group.

sprite_assign.name: sprite_assign

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to be copied to (ie: overwritten).

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The sprite to be copied from.

sprite_assign.description: This function takes two previously created (or included) sprite indexes, and copies the image from one to the other. In this way you can copy (or "clone") one sprite into another index. Note that you cannot copy to a game resource. You have to have created the sprite to be copied to previously using the sprite_add() or sprite_duplicate() functions.

layer_get_fx.name: layer_get_fx

parameters.name: layer_name_or_id
parameters.description: The name or ID of the layer to modify

layer_get_fx.description: This function is used to retrieve the FX struct for a layer.

physics_particle_set_max_count.name: physics_particle_set_max_count

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: The maximum number of particles to permit.

physics_particle_set_max_count.description: This function will set the total permitted number of particles in a physics simulation. If you set this value to 0, then there is no cap the particles created, and setting it to any other value will stop any further particles being created when the total number of particles is equal to the value. Note that the minimum number of particles you can create in a simulation is 128, so setting this value any lower will have no effect (unless set to 0).

dbg_color.name: dbg_color

parameters.name: dbgref
parameters.description: reference to the variable to change

parameters.name: label
parameters.description: label to use.

dbg_color.description: Creates a color entry within the current debug section, variable will be a color RGB value, no alpha. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.

variable_struct_get.name: variable_struct_get

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The struct reference to use

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the variable to get (as a string)

variable_struct_get.description: With this function you can get the value from a given named variable within a struct. You supply the struct reference as well as the name of the variable to get the value of as a string (see example code below). The function will return the value held by the variable or undefined if the named variable does not exist.

tilemap_set_at_pixel.name: tilemap_set_at_pixel

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to change

parameters.name: tiledata
parameters.description: The tile set data to set

parameters.name: xcell
parameters.description: The x position (in the room)

parameters.name: ycell
parameters.description: The y position (in the room)

tilemap_set_at_pixel.description: This function can be used to set a cell within the tile map element on the layer to a new tile using the actual position of the tile to change within the room. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and then the tile data to set as well as the position within the room. You can retrieve tile data using the function tilemap_get_at_pixel() and then use the tile_ functions to change it before setting it again using this function. The function will return true if the tile was successfully set and false if there was an issue and it wasn't set.

audio_master_gain.name: audio_master_gain

parameters.name: gain
parameters.description: Value for the global volume (0 to 1).

audio_master_gain.description: With this function you can set the absolute value for the global volume of all sounds and music. It is based on a linear scale from 0 (silent) to any value greater than 0, although normally you'd consider the maximum volume as 1. Anything over 1 can be used but, depending on the sound used and the platform being compiled to, you may get distortion or clipping when the sound is played back. This function will affect the relative volume of all sounds and music played from within your game.

date_get_timezone.name: date_get_timezone
date_get_timezone.description: Gets the base time zone being used for all the rest of the date and time functions. This time zone can either be local (as set by the system) or UTC, and the function will return one of the following constants:

timeline_add.name: timeline_add
timeline_add.description: With this function you can add a new (empty) time line into your game. the function returns the index of this new time line which should be stored in a variable for use in all further function calls that involve this new time line. You should also be sure to use the function timeline_delete() whenever you no longer wish to use the time line (like at the end of the room) so as to prevent any possible memory leaks that could slow down or crash your game. To add moments to a timeline created in this way, see the function timeline_moment_add_script().

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling factor (use -1 to reset to default).

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling factor (use -1 to reset to default).

parameters.name: xoffset
parameters.description: The x offset position for drawing.

parameters.name: yoffset
parameters.description: The y offset position for drawing.

path_rotate.name: path_rotate

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to flip.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle of rotation degrees.

path_rotate.description: You can use this function to rotate a given path around its center. Remember that in GameMaker (unless you are using physics) the angles are calculated counter-clockwise, so rotating the path by 90 degrees would rotate the path to the left. This function changes the actual path resource, and so will permanently affect how the path is used by all instances in the game from the moment the function is used until the end of the game. If this is not what you require, then you should use a function like path_duplicate() to create a copy of the path first, then call this function on the duplicated asset (don't forget to call path_delete() on the asset when it is no longer required).

object_set_persistent.name: object_set_persistent

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the object to change.

parameters.name: pers
parameters.description: Whether the object should be flagged as persistent (true) or not (false).

object_set_persistent.description: With this function you can set the persistence of a specific object. A persistent object is "carried over" from room to room and maintains its properties at all times (for more information on persistence see the section on the Object Editor). Setting the persistence of the object means that all instances of this object that are created after the persistence has been changed will be created persistent, while instances that are already in the room may not be affected.

filename_name.name: filename_name

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The file to use.

filename_name.description: Using this function returns the name part of the indicated file, with the extension but without the path

achievement_available.name: achievement_available
achievement_available.description: This function will return true if the user is currently connected to the internet and the chosen leaderboard and achievement system is available, otherwise it will return false.

directory_exists.name: directory_exists

parameters.name: dname
parameters.description: The name of the directory to look for.

directory_exists.description: This function will return true if the indicated directory exists or false if it does not. The specified name must include the full path, not a relative path and by default you cannot access any directories from out-with the game bundle as all games are sandboxed (see the section on the File System for more information).

buffer_create_from_vertex_buffer.name: buffer_create_from_vertex_buffer

parameters.name: vertex_buffer
parameters.description: The vertex buffer index to use.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of buffer to create (see the constants list above).

parameters.name: alignment
parameters.description: The byte alignment for the buffer

buffer_create_from_vertex_buffer.description: You use this function to allocate a portion of memory as a buffer in your game filled with the data from a previously created vertex buffer. The function returns a unique buffer id that should be stored in a variable and used for all further function calls to the buffer. The function takes the id for the vertex buffer to use (as returned by the function vertex_create_buffer(), for example) with the following constants being used to define the buffer type:

room_set_height.name: room_set_height

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the room to set the height of.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The new height of the room in pixels.

room_set_height.description: With this function you can change (or set) the height of any room in your game except the current one.

draw_text.name: draw_text

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to draw.

draw_text.description: With this function you can draw any string at any position within the room (for drawing real numbers you should use the string() function to convert them into text). To combine strings you can use + (see example below) and you can also use \n within a string to add a line break so it is drawn over multiple lines (for information on how to properly format a string and what escape characters you can use, please see here). The colour of the text and the alpha are governed by the current base alpha and colour values as set by draw_set_alpha() and draw_set_colour().

mp_grid_path.name: mp_grid_path

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Index of the mp_grid that is to be used

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: index of the path that is to be used by the function

parameters.name: x start
parameters.description: Starting x coordinate of the new path

parameters.name: y start
parameters.description: Starting y coordinate of the new path

parameters.name: xgoal
parameters.description: Finishing x coordinate of the new path

parameters.name: ygoal
parameters.description: Finishing y coordinate of the new path

parameters.name: allowdiag
parameters.description: Indicates whether diagonal moves are allowed instead of just horizontal or vertical

mp_grid_path.description: With this function you can create a path that will navigate from a start point to a finish point using an mp_grid that you have previously defined, avoiding any obstacles that have already been added into the grid. The xstart and ystart arguments indicate the start of the path in room coordinates, while xgoal, ygoal arguments indicate the destination. You can also select either horizontal/vertical movement only, or allow full diagonal movements by specifying true in the allowdiag argument. The function returns either true (it succeeded in finding a path) or false (it failed) as well as setting the chosen path. In the following image, you can see how this all works together:

physics_particle_set_group_flags.name: physics_particle_set_group_flags

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The particle group to set.

parameters.name: flags
parameters.description: The flags to set on the particle.

physics_particle_set_group_flags.description: With this function you can change the group flags for a group of particles. The group value is that which was returned when you created the group of particles using the function physics_particle_group_end(), while the flags are the return value of a combination of the following constants:

gpu_set_cullmode.name: gpu_set_cullmode

parameters.name: cullmode
parameters.description: The cull mode to use (see list above)

gpu_set_cullmode.description: This function can be used to set the backface culling mode. A polygon (primitive) has a front and a back side. The front side is said to be the side where the vertices are defined in counter-clockwise order. Normally both sides are drawn, but if you make a closed shape (like a pyramid) then this is a waste of processing power because the back side of the triangle can never be seen. It's in these cases that you can switch on backface culling, as this saves about half the amount of drawing time, although it means you have the task of defining your polygons in the correct way to prevent issues.

position_meeting.name: position_meeting

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to check.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to check.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object (or instance id, or the keywords "all" or "other") to check for a collision with.

position_meeting.description: With this function you can check a position for a collision with another instance or all instances of an object. When you use this you are checking a single point in the room for an instance or an object. This check will be done against the bounding box of the instance or against the mask of the instance if that instance has precise collisions checked. If you need to get the unique instance id if the object being collided with you should use instance_position(). This function also accepts the special keywords all and other.

string_char_at.name: string_char_at

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to check.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The position to get the character from.

string_char_at.description: You can use this function to return a specific character at a specific position within a string, with the index starting at 1 for the first character. If no character is found or the string is shorter than the given index value, an empty string "" is returned, however if the given index is equal to or smaller than 0, then the first character of the string is returned.

draw_tilemap.name: draw_tilemap

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tilemap element to get the cell y position of

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position within the room to draw at

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position within the room to draw at

draw_tilemap.description: This function can be used to draw a given tilemap anywhere in the room. You give the tilemap element ID (which you get when you create a tilemap element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), then give the x/y position for drawing (in the room). Note that this will simply draw the tilemap at the specified point, using the layer depth of the instance that is calling the function. It does not move the tilemap - nor change it in any way - and does it matter if the tilemap is flagged as visible or not.

array_push.name: array_push

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.
The value to push onto the end of the array

array_push.description: With this function you can push a value (or values) onto the end of an array without having to know the length of the array. The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array as well as at least one value to push, although you can optionally provide further arguments and they will all be pushed onto the array in consecutive order.

audio_debug.name: audio_debug

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable (set to true) or disable (false) audio debugging.

audio_debug.description: This function can be used to display debug information about the audio system, with true switching it on and false to switch it off. When you are debugging audio in this way, the overlay will show the following information:

ds_map_secure_save_buffer.name: ds_map_secure_save_buffer

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The DS map ID value.

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer ID value.

ds_map_secure_save_buffer.description: This function will save a previously created DS map to a buffer. You supply the DS map ID value (as returned by the function ds_map_create()) and the ID of the buffer to write to (as returned by the function buffer_create()). Note that if the DS map being saved contains an array, this will be converted into a DS list instead when saved.

virtual_key_hide.name: virtual_key_hide

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the virtual key to hide.

virtual_key_hide.description: Once you have created your virtual key for your devices, you may need to debug and test that it is correctly positioned and working properly and for that you would call the function virtual_key_show(). However, you may need to toggle this view on and off, so you can also hide the virtual key with this function, using the index of the virtual key that you want to hide (previously created and stored using virtual_key_add()). Once you are happy with things it is recommended that you create and place your own graphic in its area.

gamepad_set_option.name: gamepad_set_option

parameters.name: device
parameters.description: Which gamepad device "slot" to set.

parameters.name: option_name
parameters.description: The name of the option to set (a string, see the table above)

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value to set the option to (can be boolean, real, integer or string - see the table above)

gamepad_set_option.description: This function can be used to set any of the available gamepad options. You supply the gamepad "slot" to set the option on, as well as the option string to set and the value to use. The available option string will depend on the platform that the project is being run on, as listed below:

audio_sound_pitch.name: audio_sound_pitch

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to change.

parameters.name: pitch
parameters.description: The pitch multiplier (default 1).

audio_sound_pitch.description: This function can be used to change the pitch of a given sound. The sound can either be one referenced from an index for an individual sound being played which has been stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions, or an actual sound asset from the Asset Browser. If it is an index of a playing sound, then only that instance will be changed, however when using a sound asset from the Asset Browser, all further instances being played of that sound will be changed.

rollback_create_game.name: rollback_create_game

parameters.name: num_players
parameters.description: The number of players to request space for

parameters.name: sync_test
parameters.description: Flag to enable sync test for development (optional, default is true)

parameters.name: region
parameters.description: Name of a region to connect to

rollback_create_game.description: This function connects to GXC and creates a game instance of the specified size. The user needs to be signed in to GXC.

camera_get_view_border_x.name: camera_get_view_border_x

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera

camera_get_view_border_x.description: This function can be used to retrieve the border value for object/instance following of the given camera along the x axis (horizontal border). The return value will be in pixels.

rollback_use_player_prefs.name: rollback_use_player_prefs

parameters.name: default
parameters.description: Default player preferences

rollback_use_player_prefs.description: This function is used to enable player preferences and needs to be called before joining or creating a rollback game. When using this feature the game won't autostart and instead require rollback_start_game to be called after all players have set their preferences.

layer_background_exists.name: layer_background_exists

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to target (or the layer name as a string)

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to check

layer_background_exists.description: You can use this function to check and see if a background element exists on any given layer. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()) and the function will return either true if the element exists, or false if it does not.

is_array.name: is_array

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The variable to check.

is_array.description: This function can be used to check and see if a variable holds an array (it will return true) or not (in which case it will return false).

physics_particle_group_circle.name: physics_particle_group_circle

parameters.name: radius
parameters.description: The radius (in pixels) of the circle to create.

physics_particle_group_circle.description: This function will set the shape of the particle group that is being created. You must first have begun the group definition using the function physics_particle_group_begin(), and then you would use this function to set the approximate radius of the group in pixels - approximate because the exact radius will depend on the size of the base particles, as defined by the physics_particle_set_radius() function, as the physics simulation tries to "fit" as many of the particles as possible into the defined shape. Finally you need to call physics_particle_group_end() to create the group of particles in the room.

buffer_seek.name: buffer_seek

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to use.

parameters.name: base
parameters.description: The base position to seek.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The data offset value.

buffer_seek.description: This function can be used to move through a buffer, finding the start, the end, or a position relative to that which was last used when reading or writing data. The "offset" value is the offset (in bytes) to add to the given seek position, for example, if the base is relative and the offset is 4, then the buffer position will move along 4 bytes from its current position. Please note the following:

object_get_name.name: object_get_name

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The index of the object to check.

object_get_name.description: This function will return the name as a string of the specified object. This name is the one that has been specified for the object in the Asset Browser of the main GameMaker window. Please note that this is only a string and cannot be used to reference the object directly - for that you would need the object index. You can, however, use this string to get the object index using the returned string along with the function asset_get_index().

draw_get_alpha.name: draw_get_alpha
draw_get_alpha.description: This function returns the current value of the draw alpha, which will range between 0 (fully transparent) and 1 (fully opaque). The draw alpha affects the transparency of all draw functions, and can be set with the draw_set_alpha() function.

layer_sprite_index.name: layer_sprite_index

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to set

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The image index to use for the sprite

layer_sprite_index.description: This function can be used to set the image index of a sprite asset which has multiple sub-images on a layer. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and then set the image index to use. If you set a value outside of the range of sub-images, then the image index will loop around.

draw_vertex_texture.name: draw_vertex_texture
draw_vertex_texture.description: This function defines the position of a textured vertex for a primitive. The final look of the primitive will depend on the primitive type chosen to draw (See draw_primitive_begin() for more information), the order with which you add the vertexes to it and the position of the start point you set for the texture. To end and draw the primitive you must call draw_primitive_end().

vertex_argb.name: vertex_argb

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to write the information to.

parameters.name: argb
parameters.description: The ARGB value to set.

vertex_argb.description: This function will set the ARGB values for the vertex currently being defined for the custom primitive. You supply the buffer to write the data into as well as the red, green, blue and alpha values that you wish to use as a single 32-bit unsigned integer - alpha sample in the highest 8 bits, followed by the red sample, green sample and finally the blue sample in the lowest 8 bits. You can use hex notation ($AARRGGBB) a real number or use any of the make_colour_*() functions to define the colour value.

mp_potential_step.name: mp_potential_step

parameters.name: xgoal
parameters.description: The target x position.

parameters.name: ygoal
parameters.description: The target y position.

parameters.name: stepsize
parameters.description: The speed the instance moves in pixels per step.

parameters.name: checkall
parameters.description: Whether to check all instances (true) or just solid ones (false).

mp_potential_step.description: This function lets the instance take a step towards a particular position defined by xgoal/ygoal, all the while trying to avoid obstacles. When the instance would run into a solid instance (or any instance when checkall is true) it will change the direction of motion to try to avoid that instance and move around it. This approach is not guaranteed to work but in most easy cases it will effectively move the instance towards the goal. The function returns whether the goal was reached or not.

gpu_get_colourwriteenable.name: gpu_get_colourwriteenable
gpu_get_colourwriteenable.description: This function can be used to retrieve the current colour write-enable values. The function returns a 4 element 1D array with the following elements in it which will be either true (enabled) or false (disabled). By default all colour writing is set to true:

camera_get_default.name: camera_get_default
camera_get_default.description: This function can be used to retrieve the unique camera ID value of the default camera (the camera that GameMaker uses when no camera views or ports are active in a game room).

gif_save.name: gif_save

parameters.name: gif_index
parameters.description: The ID of gif to save

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The filename to use for the gif

gif_save.description: With this function you can save out a GIF animation. You supply the GIF index (as returned by the function gif_open()) as well as a filename to save it with. Note that GameMaker does not automatically append the .gif file extension, so you should include this as part of the filename string if you wish the saved file to be identified as a GIF. The created GIF will be palletized using the Universal 884 Palette (see here for more information).

sha1_string_unicode.name: sha1_string_unicode

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to hash.

sha1_string_unicode.description: In cryptography, SHA-1 is a cryptographic hash function designed by the United States National Security Agency and is employed in several widely used applications and protocols like the popular Git where it is used to check for file changes. This function will take an input unicode string and returns a 160 bit message digest in ASCII format, for example:

vertex_format_add_position_3d.name: vertex_format_add_position_3d
vertex_format_add_position_3d.description: Tell GameMaker to accept 3D positional data (x, y and z) as part of the new vertex format being created.

layer_sequence_pause.name: layer_sequence_pause

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

layer_sequence_pause.description: With this function you can pause the playback of the given sequence. You supply the sequence element ID as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions and the function will pause the sequence until you begin playback again using the function layer_sequence_play().

ds_grid_add_region.name: ds_grid_add_region

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x position of the left of the region in the grid.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y position of the top of the region in the grid.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x position of the right of the region in the grid.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y position of the bottom of the region in the grid.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to add to the region cells.

ds_grid_add_region.description: This function can be used to add a given value (real or string) to all the values of the cells found within the defined area of a grid. The value to be added must be of the same type as that held within the grid cells, ie: you cannot add a string to a real or vice-versa, and for strings this corresponds to concatenation.

sprite_get_uvs.name: sprite_get_uvs

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to use.

parameters.name: subimage
parameters.description: The sub-image of the sprite to use.

sprite_get_uvs.description: This function returns an array with the UV coordinates and other data for the texture of the sprite sub-image on the texture page. The function returns an array with the following 8 elements:

file_bin_rewrite.name: file_bin_rewrite

parameters.name: binfile
parameters.description: The ID of the file to rewrite.

file_bin_rewrite.description: This function takes the filename handle as returned by the function file_bin_open() and then rewrites the file, clearing it of all previous data to start writing from the beginning of the file.

array_all.name: array_all

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: function
parameters.description: The function used to perform the check. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return a boolean.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_all.description: With this function you can check if all of the elements return true to the given predicate. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.

vertex_create_buffer.name: vertex_create_buffer
vertex_create_buffer.description: With this function you can create a new vertex buffer. This is a special grow buffer created by GameMaker which is pre-formatted for use when building primitives (for use with shaders, for example). The function will return a "Pointer" (index) for the buffer which should then be used in all further calls to it.

is_nan.name: is_nan

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The argument to check.

is_nan.description: This function returns whether a given variable is NaN (not a number) or not, returning true if it is, and false if it is not.

skeleton_animation_set_frame.name: skeleton_animation_set_frame

parameters.name: track
parameters.description: The animation track to set the frame of.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The new index for the animation frame.

skeleton_animation_set_frame.description: This function will set the animation assigned to the given track to the frame you supply. The frame index should be an real value between 0 and the number of frames for the animation (which you can get using the function skeleton_animation_get_frames). If you supply a value outside of this range, the animation will be looped to make up the difference, for example if the animation has 5 frames and you set the frame to 8, the actual frame shown will be 3.

draw_circle.name: draw_circle

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the center of the circle.

parameters.name: r
parameters.description: The circle's radius (length from its center to its edge)

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the circle is drawn filled (false) or as a one pixel wide outline (true).

draw_circle.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a circle or a filled circle. You can define how precise the drawing is with the function draw_set_circle_precision().

base64_decode.name: base64_decode

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to decode.

base64_decode.description: This function will convert a string encoded previously using base64 format, into standard text. Base64 is a commonly used encoding scheme that is often used for any media that needs to be stored or transferred over the internet as text, and renders the output unreadable to the human eye.

audio_sync_group_is_playing.name: audio_sync_group_is_playing

parameters.name: group_index
parameters.description: The group index to check.

audio_sync_group_is_playing.description: This function can be used to check if any audio in a synchronised group is playing. You are required to supply the sync group ID as returned by the function audio_create_sync_group().

get_string_async.name: get_string_async

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The message to show in the dialog.

parameters.name: default
parameters.description: The default string.

get_string_async.description: This function opens a window and displays message as well as a space for the user to input a string (which will contain the supplied default string to start with). This is an asynchronous function, and as such GameMaker does not block the device it is being run on while waiting for an answer, but rather keeps on running events as normal. Once the user has typed out their string and pressed the "Okay" button, an asynchronous Dialog event is triggered which, for the duration of that event only, will have a DS map stored in the variable async_load.

draw_get_halign.name: draw_get_halign
draw_get_halign.description: This function is used to get the text alignment setting along the horizontal axis, and will return one of the constants listed below.

physics_fixture_create.name: physics_fixture_create
physics_fixture_create.description: The first step in setting up a fixture is creating it with this function. The returning index should be stored in a variable to be used in all further functions that are used to define and use this fixture.

ds_priority_create.name: ds_priority_create
ds_priority_create.description: This function will create a new priority queue data-structure and return the index value. This value should be stored in a variable and used in all further function calls relating to the priority queue.

font_replace_sprite_ext.name: font_replace_sprite_ext

parameters.name: font
parameters.description: The font to replace.

parameters.name: spr
parameters.description: The sprite to add a font based on.

parameters.name: string_map
parameters.description: String from which sprite sub-image order is taken.

parameters.name: prop
parameters.description: Set as proportional font or not.

parameters.name: sep
parameters.description: The space to leave between each letter.

font_replace_sprite_ext.description: This function will replace a sprite font that you created previously using the function font_add_sprite_ext(). It uses a "sprite strip", where each sub-image is be an individual symbol or letter, and the images are mapped to letters based on the argument "string_map" of the function. This argument is a string that you can use to tell GameMaker what order the sub-images of the sprite font are and it will map these automatically when writing text. So, for example, if you have a string-map of "AaBbCcDdEeFfGgHh", your sprite font must have the sub-images ordered in this way.

draw_primitive_begin.name: draw_primitive_begin

parameters.name: kind
parameters.description: The kind of primitive you are going to draw.

draw_primitive_begin.description: This function must be called before you can define any primitives. There are 6 types of primitives you can define with the following constants:

time_source_get_reps_remaining.name: time_source_get_reps_remaining

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The index of the time source

time_source_get_reps_remaining.description: Returns the number of repetitions the time source has left to complete.

gpu_get_tex_max_mip_ext.name: gpu_get_tex_max_mip_ext

parameters.name: sampler_index
parameters.description: The index of the shader sampler to get

gpu_get_tex_max_mip_ext.description: With this function you can get the currently set maximum mipmap level which is to be used for a given shader sampler. You supply the index value for the shader sampler (as returned by the function shader_get_sampler_index(), and the function will return the current maximum mipmap level, where a value of 0 is the highest resolution, 1 is to use the first mipmap, 2 is the second etc... Note that this can be quite useful for avoiding bleeding artifacts when rendering textures, for example, setting the texture page border to 8px and then setting the max mipmap level to 3 will ensure you don't get any bleeding problems at greater render distances.

colour_get_blue.name: colour_get_blue

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour to check

colour_get_blue.description: This function returns the amount of blue used to make the given colour, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no blue and 255 is all blue. The following image illustrates this:

path_delete.name: path_delete

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the path to delete.

path_delete.description: You can use this code to remove a path from memory. If this path has been created dynamically using path_add(), the variable that holds the path index will no longer be valid for accessing the path as it no longer exists, and if the path was created using the Path Editor that path can no longer be accessed in the whole game as you are permanently deleting it.

physics_apply_impulse.name: physics_apply_impulse

parameters.name: xpos
parameters.description: The x coordinate in the room where the impulse will be applied

parameters.name: ypos
parameters.description: The y coordinate in the room where the impulse will be applied

parameters.name: ximpulse
parameters.description: the x component of the impulse vector

parameters.name: yimpulse
parameters.description: the y component of the impulse vector

physics_apply_impulse.description: Not only can you apply force and gravity to an object with the physics in GameMaker but you can also apply an impulse. This is slightly different to a force in that when it is applied it will immediately affect the speed, and, potentially the torque (or "spin") of the object, particularly if the point chosen to apply the impulse is not aligned with the center of mass (note: the center of mass is not necessarily the same as the origin!). Here is an illustration:

ds_map_replace_list.name: ds_map_replace_list

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map to use.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to replace.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The id of the ds_list to use to replace the one previously stored in the given key.

ds_map_replace_list.description: With this function you can replace a DS list that has been stored in the given "key" with another list that has been created previously. This function is designed for creating JSON compatible maps which you would then encode using json_encode() and should only be used in conjunction with that functionality.

draw_surface_tiled_ext.name: draw_surface_tiled_ext

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the surface to draw.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scaling of the surface.

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scaling of the surface.

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour with which to blend the surface.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha of the surface.

draw_surface_tiled_ext.description: This function will take a surface and then repeatedly tile it across the whole room, starting from the coordinates that you give in the function and with each tile scaled, colour blended and with the alpha that you define (these properties are the same as those used in draw_surface_ext()).

window_get_caption.name: window_get_caption
window_get_caption.description: This function returns the caption of the window (this is the text that appears on the top of the window, beside its icon) and by default this shows the caption of the room you're currently in.

physics_particle_delete_region_circle.name: physics_particle_delete_region_circle

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of the center of the area to delete.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of the center of the area to delete.

parameters.name: radius
parameters.description: The radius (in pixels) of the circular area to delete.

physics_particle_delete_region_circle.description: With this function you can delete (remove) all the particles that fall within the bounds of the defined circular area from the physics simulation in the current room. The function takes the x and y position for the center of the area to delete as well as the radius (in pixels) which defines the circular area.

surface_get_depth_disable.name: surface_get_depth_disable
surface_get_depth_disable.description: This function checks to see if the automatic depth buffer generation for surfaces is enabled. Normally all surfaces have depth buffers so if you draw 3D objects to them then it'll sort them properly by depth, however allocating depth buffers essentially doubles the size of surfaces, which could be an excessive and unnecessary overhead especially if your game is very memory intensive or predominantly 2D. In these cases you can check this using this function and disable the depth buffer for surfaces if required using the function surface_depth_disable().

dbg_checkbox.name: dbg_checkbox

parameters.name: dbgref
parameters.description: reference to the variable to change

parameters.name: label
parameters.description: label to use.

dbg_checkbox.description: Creates a check box entry within the current debug section, variable will be a boolean value true or false. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.

camera_set_view_border.name: camera_set_view_border

parameters.name: camera_id
parameters.description: The unique camera ID value returned when you created the camera.

parameters.name: x_border
parameters.description: The border (in pixels) for the view camera along the horizontal axis

parameters.name: y_border
parameters.description: The border (in pixels) for the view camera along the vertical axis

camera_set_view_border.description: You can use this function to set the follow border of the view camera within the room. You give the unique camera ID value (as returned by the different camera_create functions) and then give the x border size and the y border size (horizontal and vertical). These values will only be used when the view camera has been assigned an instance target to follow (either in the Room Editor or using the function camera_set_view_target()) and relate to how far from the border of the view the instance needs to be before the view will update its position to follow.

color_get_red.name: color_get_red

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The color to check

color_get_red.description: This function returns the amount of red used to make the given color, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no red and 255 is all red. The following image illustrates this:

audio_emitter_exists.name: audio_emitter_exists

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to check the existence of.

audio_emitter_exists.description: This function returns whether an audio emitter exists (true) or not (false). Note that if the index you search for has not been initialised previously, this function will cause an error as it is searching for non-existent indices.

draw_ellipse.name: draw_ellipse

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the ellipse.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top of the ellipse.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the right of the ellipse.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the ellipse.

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the ellipse is drawn filled (false) or as a one pixel wide outline (true).

draw_ellipse.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of an ellipse or a filled ellipse by defining a rectangular area that will then have the ellipse created to fit. You can define how precise the drawing is with the function draw_set_circle_precision().

audio_set_master_gain.name: audio_set_master_gain

parameters.name: listenerindex
parameters.description: The index of the listener to set the gain on.

parameters.name: gain
parameters.description: Value for the global volume (0 to 1).

audio_set_master_gain.description: With this function you can set the absolute value for the global volume of all sounds and music for a specific listener. The default listener index is 0, but you can use the function audio_get_listener_info() to get the different indices available for the target platform. The gain value is based on a linear scale from 0 (silent) to 1 (full volume) and will affect the relative volume of all sounds and music played from within your game through that listener.

physics_joint_gear_create.name: physics_joint_gear_create

parameters.name: inst1
parameters.description: The first instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: inst2
parameters.description: The second instance to connect with the joint

parameters.name: joint_1
parameters.description: A previously defined revolute joint

parameters.name: joint_2
parameters.description: A previously defined revolute or prismatic joint

parameters.name: ratio
parameters.description: Set the velocity ratio between the two joints

physics_joint_gear_create.description: If you want to create a sophisticated mechanical contraption you might want to use gears.
