In principle you can create gears in GameMaker by using compounding instances to model gear teeth, but this is not very efficient and might be tedious to author! Thankfully there is a simpler method, and that is to use a gear joint. To make one you need to have previously defined your fixtures and created the two basic joints that are going to comprise your gear - these must be made up of one revolute joint and either a prismatic joint or another revolute joint. The image below shows how a gear would typically be created in a game:

audio_resume_sound.name: audio_resume_sound

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to resume.

audio_resume_sound.description: With this function you can resume any sound that is currently paused (after using the function audio_pause_sound()). The sound can either be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions) or a sound asset, in which case all instances of the given sound will be re-started.

instance_deactivate_region.name: instance_deactivate_region

parameters.name: left
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the rectangular region to deactivate.

parameters.name: top
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top of the rectangular region to deactivate.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the region to deactivate.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the region to deactivate.

parameters.name: inside
parameters.description: Whether to deactivate instances on the inside of the region (true) or the outside (false).

parameters.name: notme
parameters.description: Whether to exclude the calling instance from deactivation (true) or not (false).

instance_deactivate_region.description: With this function you can define a region within the room to deactivate instances that have previously been activated. This region can either be flagged as "inside" or "outside" as demonstrated in the following image:

physics_particle_delete.name: physics_particle_delete

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index (ID) of the particle to delete.

physics_particle_delete.description: With this function you can delete (remove) a particle from the physics simulation in the current room. The function takes the unique ID of the particle to delete, as returned by the function physics_particle_create().

ds_grid_width.name: ds_grid_width

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: This index of the grid to find the width of.

ds_grid_width.description: This function will return the width of the given grid. This value is the number of cells the grid has along the x-axis and is always an integer, as shown in the image below:

draw_set_alpha.name: draw_set_alpha

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha to set (between 0 and 1)

draw_set_alpha.description: With this function you can set the base draw alpha for the game. This value can be set from 0 to 1 with 0 being fully transparent and 1 being fully opaque (the default value), and will affect all further drawing, including backgrounds, sprites, fonts, primitives and 3D.

display_get_dpi_y.name: display_get_dpi_y
display_get_dpi_y.description: Dots per inch (DPI) is a measure of spatial printing or video dot density, in particular the number of individual dots that can be placed in a line within the span of 1 inch (2.54 cm). When working on mobile devices (in particular Android devices) this is an important factor to take into consideration as what may be appropriate for one display resolution, may not be appropriate for another. For example, you may have two displays with the same resolution of 400 x 800, but display 1 has a dpi of 60 and display 2 has a dpi of 30. In this case, any text or image displayed on display 2 will appear much larger, even though the actual resolution is the same.

extension_get_options.name: extension_get_options

parameters.name: extension_name
parameters.description: The name of your extension asset as a string

extension_get_options.description:
This function returns a struct containing all the options, and their values, for the extension with the given name.
			
			The function will return undefined if the provided extension name is invalid.

part_system_draw_order.name: part_system_draw_order

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system to change.

parameters.name: oldtonew
parameters.description: Whether old particles should be drawn behind newer ones (true) or vice versa (false).

part_system_draw_order.description: With this function you can set the way in which particles are drawn when created on the screen. The default system uses an old > new look (the function is set to true), where old particles are drawn at a higher depth than newer ones and so appear "beneath" them new particles, but by setting this function to false you can reverse this order and have the new particles drawn higher and so appear "beneath" the older ones. The images below illustrate this, with the image on the left being the default value of true and the image on the right being false:

physics_particle_group_count.name: physics_particle_group_count

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The group index (ID) of the particle group to count.

physics_particle_group_count.description: This function will return the number of particles that are active in a single group. The group index (ID) is the value that is returned when you call the function physics_particle_group_end().

draw_clear.name: draw_clear

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour with which the screen will be cleared

draw_clear.description: This function can be used to clear the entire screen (with no alpha blend) to the given colour, and is only for use in the draw event of an instance (it will not show if used in any other event). It can also be useful for clearing surfaces when they are newly created.

draw_surface_ext.name: draw_surface_ext

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the surface to draw.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position of where to draw the surface.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scale.

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scale.

parameters.name: rot
parameters.description: The rotation or angle to draw the surface.

parameters.name: col
parameters.description: The colour with which to blend the surface.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha transparency for drawing the surface.

draw_surface_ext.description: This function will draw the given surface as in the function draw_surface() but with additional options to change the scale, blending, rotation and alpha of the surface being drawn. Changing these values does not modify the resource in any way (only how it is drawn).

device_get_tilt_x.name: device_get_tilt_x
device_get_tilt_x.description: This function returns a value between -1 and 1 depending upon the angle of "tilt" of the device. The actual correlation between degrees of tilt and the value returned depends on the device and OS that it uses, but generally a value of 1 or -1 is the same as +/-90°. The image below shows how each if the available functions relates to the device:

gesture_tap_count.name: gesture_tap_count

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Enable (set to true) or disable (set to false) tap counting.

gesture_tap_count.description: This function is used to set whether tap counting is enabled or disabled. When set to true tap counting is enabled, and when set to false it is disabled, although you can check which state it is in using the function gesture_get_tap_count(). When enabled, each tap event will have an additional "tapcount" DS map entry which will have registered the number of taps, and when enabled it means that all tap events will be triggered, ie: two taps will trigger both the single tap event and the double tap event, with the single tap event tap count being 1 and the double tap event tap count being 2. The tap count value will be reset to 0 after the time set for a double-tap detection has passed (see the function gesture_double_tap_time()). If tap counting is disabled, then the initial tap won't be registered until the double-tap time has passed and no second tap has been detected. Note that this is enabled by default.

part_system_get_info.name: part_system_get_info

parameters.name: partsys
parameters.description: The particle system for which information should be retrieved.

part_system_get_info.description: This function is used to retrieve information for the given particle system instance. You supply a particle system instance created with part_system_create() and the function returns a struct with the following variables:

os_get_info.name: os_get_info
os_get_info.description: This function returns a DS Map with detailed information about the OS that the game is running on. The exact information returned will depend on the OS and the device, so it is recommended that you test this function on all platforms that you wish to target and output the returned values using a function like show_debug_message(). Note that the DS map is not automatically cleared from memory and you should use the ds_map_destroy() function when you no longer need it.

layer_sprite_alpha.name: layer_sprite_alpha

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to change

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha for sprite sprite, from 0 to 1 (default is 1)

layer_sprite_alpha.description: This function controls the alpha (transparency) of the sprite on the asset layer. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and then set the alpha value to use. Alpha can be between 0 (fully transparent) and 1 (fully opaque) with the default alpha value for the sprite element being 1. Note that if the layer the sprite element has been assigned to is not visible - or the element itself has been made invisible - you will not see any difference with this function until the layer or element has been made visible again.

surface_getpixel_ext.name: surface_getpixel_ext

parameters.name: surface_id
parameters.description: The ID of the surface to use.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the pixel to check

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the pixel to check

surface_getpixel_ext.description: With this function you can get the full abgr 32bit value of any pixel of a (previously created) surface.

layer_sprite_change.name: layer_sprite_change

parameters.name: sprite_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sprite element to change

parameters.name: sprite_index
parameters.description: The new sprite index to use

layer_sprite_change.description: Using this function you can change the sprite resource assigned to a given sprite element on a layer. You give the sprite element ID (which you get when you create a sprite element using layer_sprite_create() or when you use the function layer_sprite_get_id()), and then supply a sprite index element asset will be changed. Note that if the sprite has sub-images then it will animate too (this can be controlled using the layer_sprite_index() and layer_sprite_speed() functions). Note that you can assign a value of -1 as the new sprite index and no sprite will be shown, although the element will still exist and can still be changed again later.

window_get_visible_rects.name: window_get_visible_rects

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The left edge of the rectangle to check

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The top edge of the rectangle to check.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The right edge of the rectangle to check

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The bottom edge of the rectangle to check.

window_get_visible_rects.description: With this function you can find the overlapping region of the rectangle defined by (x1,y1) to (x2,y2) on each of the attached displays. The function will return an array with 8 values per display (ie: if you have two displays, the array will have a length of 16 indices), where the values [0 ... 3] correspond to the overlapx1, overlapy1, overlapx2, overlapy2 - defining the region of overlap on this display and will be set to 0,0,0,0 if no overlap - and the values [4 ... 7] corresponds to the monitorx1, monitory1, monitorx2, monitory2 - the coordinates of the display in the virtual display space. This can be used to test whether a saved window position is going to be visible or not (the user may have disconnected an external monitor or moved the window off screen which left the window position that was saved as not being valid), for example.

gpu_set_blendmode.name: gpu_set_blendmode

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: The blend mode to use (see the table above)

gpu_set_blendmode.description: When GameMaker goes to draw a pixel there is a source colour (the colour of the pixel we're going to draw) and a destination colour(the colour that's already in the pixel we're drawing to), so when determining the new colour of the pixel, the source and destination colours are calculated according to the chosen blend mode. Each component of the colours is stored as a floating point value between 0 and 1, and the new colour is calculated by multiply each component of the source colour by some factor and by multiplying each component of destination colour by some other factor and then adding the results together component by component.

vertex_format_add_position.name: vertex_format_add_position
vertex_format_add_position.description: Tell GameMaker to accept 2D positional data (x and y) as part of the new vertex format being created.

make_colour_rgb.name: make_colour_rgb

parameters.name: red
parameters.description: The red component of the colour

parameters.name: green
parameters.description: The green component of the colour

parameters.name: blue
parameters.description: The blue component of the colour

make_colour_rgb.description: GameMaker provides this function (as well as others) to permit the user to make their own colours. This particular function takes three component parts, the red, the green and the blue components of the colour that you wish to make. These values are taken as being between 0 and 255 so you can make 16,777,216 (256*256*256) colours with this! Below you can see an image of how these components look when separated:

font_add_enable_aa.name: font_add_enable_aa

parameters.name: enable
parameters.description: Whether to enable (true) or disable (false) AA for added fonts.

font_add_enable_aa.description: This function can be used to enable or disable anti-aliasing (AA) for fonts added using font_add(). This function needs to be called before you add any fonts and setting it to true will enable AA, and setting it to false will disable it. By default AA is enabled. Note that this will have no effect on fonts that have been added before the function was called, and the function only needs to be called once when the font is added, and not every draw/step that the font is being used.

file_find_close.name: file_find_close
file_find_close.description: Must be called after handling files opened using file_find_first() and file_find_next() functions to free memory. The file find functions open handles into the file directory and these take up a minimal amount of memory, which (over time) mounts up. Therefore you should always call this function after you have found the files you require to "close" these handles.

buffer_fill.name: buffer_fill

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The index of the buffer to fill.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The data offset value (in bytes).

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of data that is to be written to the buffer (see the list of constants here).

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The data to write.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size of the buffer (in bytes) that you wish to fill.

buffer_fill.description: This function can be used to fill a previously created buffer with a given data type and value. The data you fill the buffer with must be in agreement with the "type" argument of this function, meaning that you can't try to fill with a string and use the unsigned 16bit integer type, for example. The type constants are the same as those used by the buffer_read() and buffer_write() functions. The "size" is the size of the buffer (in bytes) that you wish to fill, while the offset is the offset value (also in bytes) from the start of the buffer to start the fill from.

audio_sound_set_track_position.name: audio_sound_set_track_position

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound to change.

parameters.name: time
parameters.description: The time (in seconds) to set the start point to.

audio_sound_set_track_position.description: This function will set the position (in seconds) within the sound file for the sound to play from. The sound can either be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions) or a sound asset. If it is a unique sound ID that you use, then the position will change immediately to the new time given, and if it is a Asset Browser asset then all further plays of the given sound will start at the new time. The function will ignore any value given that is longer than the length of the sound given for the "index" value.

gpu_push_state.name: gpu_push_state
gpu_push_state.description: With this function you can push the current GPU state onto a stack to be used later. You would generally use this if you want to "save" the current GPU state (things like blend mode, alpha writing, culling, etc... will all be pushed to the stack), then draw something with different settings, and then reset the GPU stack to what it was before (by calling gpu_pop_state()).

file_attributes.name: file_attributes

parameters.name: fname
parameters.description: The name of the file to check.

parameters.name: attr
parameters.description: The attributes to check for.

file_attributes.description: You can use this function to check the attributes of a given file. You can add up the following constants to see the type of files you want:

physics_world_create.name: physics_world_create

parameters.name: pixeltometrescale
parameters.description: defines the ratio of pixels on screen to metres in the real world. A ratio of 32:1 will be specified as 1/32 (or 0.03125).

physics_world_create.description: Even if you have defined the physics for your objects, without a world to place them in they will default to the traditional GameMaker collision system, so you need this function to create the physics system for the specified room either in an object event, or the creation code of the room itself (it can also be defined without using code in the room editor). This function will associate a physics "world" with the room and all instances created in the room will behave using the physics that has been defined for them and the world itself.

tilemap_set_mask.name: tilemap_set_mask

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to set the mask of

parameters.name: mask
parameters.description: The mask value

tilemap_set_mask.description: This function can be used to set the tile bit mask for a single tile map. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), and then the mask value. The idea is that if you have, for example, a pretty small tile set of 16 x 16 tiles then you have a total of 256 different tiles in your tile set, which only uses up 8 bits of your index in the tile data "blob" (from an available 19 bits of data). These bits can be "masked" and then the rest of the tile data can be used to store additional values.

physics_fixture_set_awake.name: physics_fixture_set_awake

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the id of the bound fixture

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: whether a fixture is awake (true) or not (false)

physics_fixture_set_awake.description: When you start a room with physics, or bind fixtures to instances, the fixtures are always considered to be "awake"... that is to say, they are processing events and interacting with the surrounding instances. However this can sometimes lead to problems, especially if you have a number of instances with fixtures that are side by side when a room starts (think of a tower made of various instances with fixtures) as with them being "awake" they will move and possibly change position due to the sudden start of gravity and collisions affecting them. In these cases you can use this function to flag the fixture as been "asleep", in which case it will not be processing anything when it is first created in the room.

ds_list_find_index.name: ds_list_find_index

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the list to use.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The value to find.

ds_list_find_index.description: With this function you can check the given list for a value and the position within the list for that value will be returned. Note that if there are more than one entries in the list with the same value, the position of any one of them may be returned, and that if the value does not exist, then -1 will be returned. Note that the value can be an array, which you can check with the function is_array().

clipboard_set_text.name: clipboard_set_text

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The text (as a string) to set the clipboard to hold.

clipboard_set_text.description: This function will set the clipboard to hold the defined string. You can set it to an empty string "" to effectively clear the clipboard of text.

gc_is_enabled.name: gc_is_enabled
gc_is_enabled.description: With this function you can check to see if the garbage collector is enabled or not. The function will return true if it is enabled or false otherwise.

gesture_pinch_angle_away.name: gesture_pinch_angle_away
gesture_pinch_angle_away.description: This function is used to set the angle within which a touch must be moving away from another touch before a Pinch Out Gesture may potentially be started. The angle is measured in degrees and has a default value of 45°.

part_type_direction.name: part_type_direction

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: dir_min
parameters.description: The minimum direction the particle can start at.

parameters.name: dir_max
parameters.description: The maximum direction the particle can start at.

parameters.name: dir_incr
parameters.description: How much the particle direction should increase or decrease per step.

parameters.name: dir_wiggle
parameters.description: How much should randomly be added or subtracted from the particle's direction per step.

part_type_direction.description: This function is used to determine the direction of the particle when it is created and can also be used to make the particle increase or decrease its direction over its lifetime. The minimum and maximum direction values default at 0, which means that the particle will move to the right with no variation, but these values can be changed to limit the direction of movement following the standard GameMaker directions of 0 being right, 90 being up, 180 being left and 270 being down. If you set them to the same value the particles will only move in one direction.

audio_bus_create.name: audio_bus_create
audio_bus_create.description: This function creates and returns a new audio bus struct, which can be modified to configure the bus' properties and to add audio effects to it.

struct_foreach.name: struct_foreach

parameters.name: struct
parameters.description: The variable that holds the struct.

parameters.name: func
parameters.description: The name of the struct variable to check for (as a string)

struct_foreach.description: With this function you can execute a method on all of the members in the struct.

network_create_server_raw.name: network_create_server_raw

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of server to create (see the constants listed below).

parameters.name: port
parameters.description: The port that the server will use.

parameters.name: max_client
parameters.description: The maximum number of clients that can connect at once.

network_create_server_raw.description: This function is used to create a new network server for your game, using one of the permitted connection protocols (see the constants listed below). You supply the server type, then give it a port to use, and finally the number of maximum connections that should be permitted at any one time to the server (note that this number is up to you, but too many connected clients will saturate the network or the device CPU won't be able to handle the processing of that number of players, so use with care). The function returns a unique id which should be used stored in a variable and used to identify the server in all further network functions, or a value of less than 0 if the connection fails.

move_bounce_all.name: move_bounce_all

parameters.name: adv
parameters.description: Whether to enable advanced bouncing (true) or not (false).

move_bounce_all.description: With this function you can command an instance to bounce off all instances within the room, with the only exception being those that have no sprite or mask index assigned to them. You can also tell it to use precise collision checking when enabled, but be aware that this requires all instances to have precise masks enabled and will greatly slow down your game when many instances are involved due to the amount of processing that has to be done. This should normally go in the step event of an instance, but can be used selectively in a collision event too, as illustrated by the code example below.

ds_queue_head.name: ds_queue_head

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to read from.

ds_queue_head.description: This function will only read the first value of the queue (that which is "at the head"). It will not dequeue the value, meaning that it can still be read in the future by this function or the ds_queue_dequeue(). If the queue is empty then the function will return the constant undefined, otherwise it will return the real or string value contained in the queue.

draw_self.name: draw_self
draw_self.description: This function draws the sprite assigned to the instance exactly as it would be drawn if the draw event held no code or actions, and will reflect and changes that have been made to the sprite variables in other events.

gpu_set_blendmode_ext.name: gpu_set_blendmode_ext

parameters.name: src
parameters.description: Source blend mode factor(see constants above).

parameters.name: dest
parameters.description: Destination blend mode factor (see constants above)

gpu_set_blendmode_ext.description: When GameMaker goes to draw a pixel there is a source colour (the colour of the pixel we're going to draw) and a destination colour (the colour that's already in the pixel we're drawing to), so when determining the new colour of the pixel, the source and destination colours are calculated according to the chosen blend mode. Each component of the colours is stored as a floating point value between 0 and 1, and the new colour is calculated by multiply each component of the source colour by some factor and by multiplying each component of destination colour by some other factor and then adding the results together component by component.

gesture_get_pinch_angle_away.name: gesture_get_pinch_angle_away
gesture_get_pinch_angle_away.description: This function is used to get the angle within which a touch must be moving away from another touch before a Pinch Out Gesture may potentially be started. The angle is measured in degrees and has a default value of 45°.

ds_grid_get_sum.name: ds_grid_get_sum

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the grid.

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The left cell column of the region.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The top cell row of the region.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The right cell column of the region.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The bottom cell row of the region.

ds_grid_get_sum.description: This function can be used to add all the values all the cells found within the defined region of a grid together, as shown in the image below:

vertex_float2.name: vertex_float2

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The buffer to write the information to.

parameters.name: float
parameters.description: The first input value.

parameters.name: float
parameters.description: The second input value.

vertex_float2.description: This function will add two floating point values to the vertex data. The vertex must have been formatted correctly to accept this using the vertex_format_add_custom() function.

date_datetime_string.name: date_datetime_string

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The date to use.

date_datetime_string.description: With this function you can create a string containing the given datetime, formatted for the system or device that is running the game when the function is called.

parameters.description: More optional permissions

ceil.name: ceil

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The number to change.

ceil.description: This function takes any real number and rounds it up to the nearest integer. Care should be taken with this function as one common mistake is to use it round up a random value and expect it always to be greater than 1, ie:

network_send_udp_raw.name: network_send_udp_raw

parameters.name: socket
parameters.description: The id of the socket to use.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The url or IP to connect to (a string).

parameters.name: port
parameters.description: The port to connect to.

parameters.name: buffer
parameters.description: The id of the buffer to get the data from.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: The size (in bytes) of the data.

network_send_udp_raw.description: With this function you can send data over the network using UDP to a server. The function takes the socket id to connect through, the URL to connect to and the port to use. You must then supply the buffer id which contains the data to be sent (for more information on buffers see Reference - Buffers) and finally the size (in bytes) of the data. UDP is "connectionless" in that you don't actually do a connect, you just send a packet directly to an IP, and the server gets incoming data from an IP address and has to deal with it "as is". The data sent is not formatted by GameMaker in any way and the receiving devices will get the data as a stream which means you will have to handle it yourself. The function will return the number of bytes of data sent, or a number less than 0 if the send has failed.

texturegroup_load.name: texturegroup_load

parameters.name: groupname
parameters.description: The name of the texture group to load (a string)

parameters.name: prefetch
parameters.description: Whether each texture in the group should be loaded into GPU memory (defaults to true)

texturegroup_load.description: With this function you can load all the pages for the specified texture group. You supply the texture group ID string (as defined in the texture Group Editor) and (optionally) specify whether you want to also prefetch the pages in the group (load them into GPU memory)..

audio_sound_get_loop_start.name: audio_sound_get_loop_start

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the sound whose loop-start is retrieved.

audio_sound_get_loop_start.description: This function will return the offset (in seconds) of the start of a sound's loop section.

skeleton_collision_draw_set.name: skeleton_collision_draw_set

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: Set to true to turn on drawing, and false to turn it off.

skeleton_collision_draw_set.description: With this function, you can toggle on (true) or off (false) drawing the collision data for the current skeletal animation sprite being used by the instance. If this is switched on, the bounding box and the precise collision mask will be drawn as outlines around the sprite.

physics_fixture_add_point.name: physics_fixture_add_point

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the index of the fixture

parameters.name: xpos
parameters.description: the x position of the point (relative to the fixture origin for polygon shapes)

parameters.name: ypos
parameters.description: the y position of the point (relative to the fixture origin for polygon shapes)

physics_fixture_add_point.description: This function defines the points of a polygon which has previously been set to the fixture using either physics_fixture_set_polygon_shape() or it can be used to add points to a chain of edge fixtures using the function physics_fixture_set_chain_shape(). For a polygon shape, the points are relative to the origin of the fixture, with the 0,0 position of the x/y axis being the centre, and the subsequent coordinates being calculated as usual in GameMaker with down/right being +x,+y and up/left being -x,-y. Here is an illustration to help you visualise this process:

object_get_persistent.name: object_get_persistent

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The index of the object to check.

object_get_persistent.description: This function will tell you whether the object you are checking has been flagged as "persistent" or not. A persistent object is one that will cause any instances of it to be carried through from room to room unless they are explicitly destroyed. Please note that this is not an instance function! So, you can have a persistent object and a non-persistent instance of the same object and vice-versa. You can set an individual instances persistent flag using the persistent instance variable.

array_reduce.name: array_reduce

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: function
parameters.description: The function to be executed for each array entry. Accepts the following arguments (prev, value, index) and should return a new 'prev'.

parameters.name: init
parameters.description: The initial value to be used for the previous element. Defaults to array[offset], if ommitted first iteration will be skipped.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

array_reduce.description: With this function you can traverse the array/range performing a cumulative operation on its elements. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.

shop_leave_rating.name: shop_leave_rating

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: Text that appears on the dialog.

parameters.name: yes_string
parameters.description: Text that appears on the "yes" button.

parameters.name: no_string
parameters.description: Text that appears on the "no" button.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The full URL where the comment has to be sent.

shop_leave_rating.description: This function opens up an OS dependent dialog where you can ask the user to post a rating or comment to a particular page. You can define the text that is to appear in the dialogue, as well as the text you wish to appear on the two buttons and the URL where the comment has to be posted.

draw_text_ext_transformed.name: draw_text_ext_transformed

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the drawn string.

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to draw.

parameters.name: sep
parameters.description: The distance in pixels between lines of text.

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The maximum width in pixels of the string before a line break.

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The horizontal scale.

parameters.name: yscale
parameters.description: The vertical scale.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle of the text.

draw_text_ext_transformed.description: This function is a combination of the base draw_text() function with the draw_text_ext() and draw_text_transformed() functions, permitting you to scale and rotate text while maintaining a specific line spacing and maximum width per line. Note that the "width" argument is based on a scale of 1, so if the scale is different, this value should be changed proportionally. For example, if the base width for a line break is 300 and you set the scale to 2, then the text will appear wrong, over-running the given width. Instead you should have set the width to 150 to compensate the scaling.

matrix_build_projection_ortho.name: matrix_build_projection_ortho

parameters.name: w
parameters.description: The width of the projection.

parameters.name: h
parameters.description: The height of the projection.

parameters.name: znear
parameters.description: The near clipping plane.

parameters.name: zfar
parameters.description: The far clipping plane.

matrix_build_projection_ortho.description: This function builds an orthographic projection matrix based on the specified parameters listed below (this is the default projection method used when you create a room in GameMaker without changing anything). Sometimes you need to switch from a perspective projection to an orthographic projection which is what this function is for. It is typically used to draw an overlay, for example, to show the score or other aspects as this gives a "flat" view of the elements drawn (ie: no perspective) in a 3D game. See the image below to get an idea of the difference between orthographic and perspective views.

audio_listener_set_orientation.name: audio_listener_set_orientation

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The listener to set the orientation of.

parameters.name: lookat_x
parameters.description: The x look vector (default 0).

parameters.name: lookat_y
parameters.description: The y look vector (default 0).

parameters.name: lookat_z
parameters.description: The z look vector (default -1).

parameters.name: up_x
parameters.description: The x up vector (default 0).

parameters.name: up_y
parameters.description: The y up vector (default 1).

parameters.name: up_z
parameters.description: The z up vector (default 0).

audio_listener_set_orientation.description: With this function you can change the orientation of the given listener within the 3D audio space. The default listener index is 0, but you can use the function audio_get_listener_info() to get the different indices available for the target platform.

os_check_permission.name: os_check_permission

parameters.name: permission
parameters.description: The permission to request (a string)

os_check_permission.description: With this function you can check to see if a specific permission has been granted to the game by the user. You supply the permission to check as a string using the format "android.permission.<permission>". See Android documentation for the permissions that can be requested. Returns one of os_permission_granted, os_permission_denied, os_permission_denied_dont_request

instance_copy.name: instance_copy

parameters.name: perf
parameters.description: Whether to perform the new instance's Create event (true) or not (false).

instance_copy.description: With this function you can "clone" an instance as this will create a new version of the instance running the code at its same position. The "perf" argument is used to instruct this new instance to perform the create event or not. This function returns the id of the new instance which can then be stored in a variable or used to access that instance.

zip_create.name: zip_create
zip_create.description: This function will create a new zip object which files can be added to.

sprite_get_bbox_bottom.name: sprite_get_bbox_bottom

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the sprite to check.

sprite_get_bbox_bottom.description: This function returns the relative position of the bottom of the sprite bounding box. This value is given as a relative value based on the upper left corner of the base sprite asset being (0,0). it is the same value as can be found in the sprite editor for the collision mask properties. The image below shows how it is calculated:

audio_emitter_get_gain.name: audio_emitter_get_gain

parameters.name: emitter
parameters.description: The index of the emitter to use.

audio_emitter_get_gain.description: This function returns the current gain (volume) set for the given audio emitter, normally between 0 and 1, where 0 is silent and 1 is full volume. Note that on some platforms you can have a gain of greater than 1, although a value of 1 is considered "full volume" and anything greater may introduce audio clipping.

draw_roundrect.name: draw_roundrect

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the top left corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top left corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the bottom right corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the bottom right corner of the rounded rectangle (as if it were a normal rectangle).

parameters.name: outline
parameters.description: Whether the rounded rectangle is drawn filled (false) or as a one pixel wide outline (true).

draw_roundrect.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rounded rectangle or a filled rounded rectangle where the (x1,y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2,y2) position is the bottom right corner. You can define how precise the drawing of the corners is with the function draw_set_circle_precision(), but this function uses a fixed radius for them (should you need to change the corner radius, use the function draw_roundrect_ext()). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

layer_sequence_exists.name: layer_sequence_exists

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID or name of the layer to check

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

layer_sequence_exists.description: With this function you can check to see if a sequence element exists on the given layer. You supply the layer ID which can be a string of the layer name - as defined in the room editor - or the unique layer ID - as returned by the function layer_get_id(), as well the sequence element ID - as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions - and it will return true if the given element exists or false otherwise.

gpu_set_colorwriteenable.name: gpu_set_colorwriteenable

parameters.name: red
parameters.description: Enable/disable the red channel

parameters.name: green
parameters.description: Enable/disable the green channel

parameters.name: blue
parameters.description: Enable/disable the blue channel

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: Enable/disable the alpha channel

gpu_set_colorwriteenable.description: With this function you can switch on or off the colour channels and the alpha channel for all further drawing. For example, you can use this function to create alpha-channel only surfaces (switch off the RGB writing before using the surface), or to create special effects while drawing to the screen. The default value for each of the components is true, and can be supplied as either four unique arguments or as a 4 element 1D array with the following elements in it which will be either true (enabled) or false (disabled):

time_source_create.name: time_source_create

parameters.name: parent
parameters.description: The parent of the time source

parameters.name: period
parameters.description: The period of the time source

parameters.name: units
parameters.description: The units that the period is measured in

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The callback to be invoked when the time source expires

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: The arguments to be passed to the callback

parameters.name: reps
parameters.description: The number of repetitions the time source should perform

parameters.name: expiry_type
parameters.description: The expiry type of the time source

time_source_create.description: Creates a new time source, returning its index.

layer_get_x.name: layer_get_x

parameters.name: layer_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the layer to get the x position of

layer_get_x.description: You can use this function to retrieve the x position of the layer within the currently scoped room. You supply the layer ID (which you get when you create the layer using layer_create()) or the layer name (as a string - this will have a performance impact) and the function returns a real number for the x position of the layer, relative to the (0,0) position of the room. Default is 0.

gc_target_frame_time.name: gc_target_frame_time

parameters.name: time
parameters.description: The target time - in microseconds -  that the garbage collector should work each frame

gc_target_frame_time.description: With this function you can indicate to the garbage collector that it shoulde aim to spend no more than the time specified running each frame. The function takes a time value specified in microseconds (where 1,000,000 microseconds equals one second) and the default target frame time is 100 microseconds.

instance_id_get.name: instance_id_get

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index within the instance list from 0 - (instance count - 1).

instance_id_get.description: With this function you can get the unique ID value of any instance from the currently active instance list. You give the index in the instance list to get the ID from and the function will return the value for storing in a variable.

tilemap_get.name: tilemap_get

parameters.name: tilemap_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the tile map element to get the tile-data of

parameters.name: x_cell
parameters.description: The cell along the x-axis to get the tile data from

parameters.name: y_cell
parameters.description: The cell along the y-axis to get the tile data from

tilemap_get.description: Using this function you can retrieve the tile data from a cell of the tile map element. You give the tile map element ID (which you get when you create a tile map element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), as well as the cell x and y position and the function will return the tile data "blob". This data is essentially a bit mask that contains the tile index, the flip/rotate/mirror booleans and any mask data that has been applied (see tilemap_set_mask() for details), and the resulting data value can then be used in the tile_* functions to change a tiles properties. Note that we are using x/y cell positions based on the size of the tile map grid and not as a position in the room, so "cell_x" is a value from 0 to tile map width, and "cell_y" is a value from 0 to tile map height. If you need to get the data for a tile at a specific room position then you need to use the function tilemap_get_at_pixel().

random_set_seed.name: random_set_seed

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The seed to set.

random_set_seed.description: To generate a random number GameMaker starts with a random seed number. With this function you can set that seed to a known value and so "force" the outcome of all random events afterwards to be the same every time the program is run. For example, this function can be used in conjunction with random_get_seed() to create procedurally generated content and save the results without having huge savegames (you save the seed only, no need for anything else). Should you need truly random results for everything, you should be using the randomise() function.

gif_save_buffer.name: gif_save_buffer

parameters.name: gif_index
parameters.description: The ID of gif to save

gif_save_buffer.description: With this function you can save out a GIF animation. You supply the GIF index (as returned by the function gif_open()) and the function will return a 1 byte-aligned grow buffer with the GIF data. Note that the final GIF data will have been palletized using the Universal 884 Palette (see here for more information).

gpu_set_tex_mip_filter.name: gpu_set_tex_mip_filter

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description: The mip filter mode to use (a constant, default: tf_point).

gpu_set_tex_mip_filter.description: With this function you can set the current mip filter mode to one of the three types supported. You give the constant that refers to the mip filtering mode that you require, where you can choose between point filtering (default setting, meaning no filtering), linear filtering (this is also known as trilinear filtering) or aniostropic filtering (see the constants table below).

push_cancel_local_notification.name: push_cancel_local_notification

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The ID of the notification to cancel.

push_cancel_local_notification.description: This function cancels the given push notification. You can get the ID for the notification to cancel using the functions push_get_first_local_notification() and push_get_next_local_notification() and the function will return true on success or false otherwise (for example if the notification does not exist or has already been triggered).

application_surface_is_enabled.name: application_surface_is_enabled
application_surface_is_enabled.description: This function will return true if the application surface is being used for drawing, or false if the screen buffer is being used.

logn.name: logn

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The log base.

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The input value.

logn.description: This function is similar to the log2(n) and log10(n) functions, only you stipulate the log base value. For example, logn(5,25) will return how many 5's we need to multiply to get 25 (which is 2).

position_destroy.name: position_destroy

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of where to destroy colliding instances.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of where to destroy colliding instances.

position_destroy.description: This function simply destroys all instances that are found to be in collision with the specified position. Collisions are based on the mask of the instances, and if any part of the mask over-laps with the target point it then the function will destroy that instance. Instances destroyed in this way will trigger their Destroy and Clean Up events.

physics_set_friction.name: physics_set_friction

parameters.name: fixture
parameters.description: the id of the bound fixture

parameters.name: friction
parameters.description: the new friction value to apply

physics_set_friction.description: When you bind a fixture to an instance using physics_fixture_bind() this returns an "id" for the bound fixture. You can use this id to set the friction value of the bound fixture, not the "base" fixture, at any time using this function. Note that the friction is usually set to a value between 0 and 1, but you can use any non-negative value if required.

file_text_read_real.name: file_text_read_real

parameters.name: fileid
parameters.description: The id of the file to read from.

file_text_read_real.description: With this function you can read a real number value from a text file and the function returns that value to be used or stored in a variable.

physics_apply_local_impulse.name: physics_apply_local_impulse

parameters.name: xpos
parameters.description: The x coordinate relative to the origin where the impulse will be applied

parameters.name: ypos
parameters.description: The y coordinate relative to the origin where the impulse will be applied

parameters.name: ximpulse
parameters.description: the x component of the impulse vector (relative to the xpos coordinate)

parameters.name: yimpulse
parameters.description: the y component of the impulse vector (relative to the ypos coordinate)

physics_apply_local_impulse.description: Not only can you apply force and gravity to an object with the physics in GameMaker but you can also apply an impulse. This is slightly different to a force in that when it is applied it will immediately affect the speed, and, potentially the torque (or "spin") of the object, particularly if the point chosen to apply the impulse has a vector that is not aligned with the centre of mass (note: the center of mass is not necessarily the same as the origin!). This function applies an impulse locally to an instance. What this means is that the strength and direction of the impulse are calculated based on the origin (or the position if it has no sprite) of the instance, without taking into consideration the direction or rotation it may have in the game room or physics world. Here is an illustration:

array_delete.name: array_delete

parameters.name: array
parameters.description: The variable that holds the array.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index (position) in the array to delete the value(s) from.

parameters.name: number
parameters.description: The number of values to delete.

array_delete.description: With this function you can delete a value (or values) from an array at any given position. The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array, the index (position) in the array to delete from, as well as the number of values to delete.

log10.name: log10

parameters.name: n
parameters.description: The input value.

log10.description: This function is similar to the log2(n) function, only that log10(n) gets the number of 10's that we need to multiply together to get n. So log10(100) returns 2, as multiplying 10 by itself gives 100, log10(1000) returns 3 as 10x10x10=1000 etc... The number does not have to be divisible by ten, however, but this will still return an appropriate value, for example if we have log10(101) we get 2.00432137... which is how many times you could divide 101 by 10.

draw_point_colour.name: draw_point_colour

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the point.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the point.

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The colour of the point.

draw_point_colour.description: With this function you can draw a single pixel anywhere on the screen with a colour that you define. The colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour().

video_is_looping.name: video_is_looping
video_is_looping.description: This function will return true if loop is enabled

distance_to_object.name: distance_to_object

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object to check for.

distance_to_object.description: This function calculates the distance from the edge of the bounding box of the calling instance to the nearest edge of the nearest instance of the object specified. The object can be an object index or a specific instance ID as well as the keyword other, and the distance is returned in pixels. Note that if either of the objects have no sprite or no mask defined, the results will be incorrect.

clickable_add.name: clickable_add

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position within the window.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position within the window.

parameters.name: tpe
parameters.description: The texture page entry for the sprite to be used.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: The URL (website address) to link to, or the script to be run.

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: This is the target area to open the URL in (see description).

parameters.name: params
parameters.description: The various parameters for the icon (see description).

clickable_add.description: With this function you can create a custom, clickable, icon that acts as a "button" outside of the game canvas, but within the browser window itself. The function will return an id value which must be stored in a variable to be used in all further button functions that reference the new icon. This function is very useful to prevent the browser creating a pop-up window when clicking on the button as it is all done through GameMaker itself.

draw_line_color.name: draw_line_color

parameters.name: x1
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: y1
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the start of the line.

parameters.name: x2
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: y2
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the end of the line.

parameters.name: col1
parameters.description: The colour of the start of the line.

parameters.name: col2
parameters.description: The colour of the end of the line.

draw_line_color.description: With this function you can draw a 1 pixel wide line with the colour blended between colour 1 at the first point and colour 2 at the second point. The colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour(). Please note that the line being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

gamepad_remove_mapping.name: gamepad_remove_mapping

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: Which gamepad index "slot" to remove the mapping from.

gamepad_remove_mapping.description: This function can be used to remove the current device mapping from the given gamepad slot index. Once called, the slot index will need to be remapped using the gamepad_test_mapping() function if you want to be able to be able to use the gamepad constants to detect input correctly (direct input can always be retrieved using the gamepad_axis/button/hat_count() and gamepad_axis/button/hat_value() functions together).

achievement_increment.name: achievement_increment

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name/id of the achievement.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value to be sent as an increment.

achievement_increment.description: Games can have achievements with no completion value and so you can use this function to increment those achievement by a given amount. On Android, you send the ID of the achievement as a string (this is the unique achievement ID that got assigned when you set up the achievement), while on all other platforms you supply the defined achievement name as a string, and then you give the actual achievement value to increment by.

object_set_mask.name: object_set_mask

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the object to change.

parameters.name: spr
parameters.description: The new sprite to use as the object's mask.

object_set_mask.description: With this function you can set the mask_index of a specific object (for more information on masks see The Object Editor). This means that all instances of this object that are created after the mask has been changed will be created with this new mask, while instances that are already in the room may not be affected. You can set this to -1 to remove a mask sprite and so default to the mask defined for the sprite of the object (or no masks if no sprite has been chosen).

draw_primitive_end.name: draw_primitive_end
draw_primitive_end.description: This function must be called when you have finished defining the points of your primitive. If you do not call this function, nothing will be drawn as this effectively tells GameMaker that you have finished and that it can now draw the defined primitive.

string.name: string

parameters.name: val_or_format
parameters.description: The value to be turned into a string or a format string.
Values to replace the placeholders with.

string.description: With this function you can turn any value into a string. If the real number is an integer, it will be saved with no decimal places, otherwise, it will be saved with two decimal places. If you require more decimal places, then use the function string_format(). Also note that using this function on a variable storing an array, a data structure, or a struct will convert the contents of these variables into a string which can then be output to the console or saved to a file for debugging. You are also able to use a format string with "{x}" placeholders (i.e. {0},{1},...) where 'X' is the argument number after the format string (starting at 0).

audio_group_name.name: audio_group_name

parameters.name: groupid
parameters.description: The index value constant of the audio group to check (as defined in the Audio Groups Window)

audio_group_name.description: This function will return a string containing the name of the given audio group for displaying or checking. When you define an audio group in the Game Options, you give it a unique "name" which is really a constant to use as an ID value for the group. All this function does is take the ID and return a string of the ID name you gave.

ds_map_find_first.name: ds_map_find_first

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map to use.

ds_map_find_first.description: This function returns the first key stored in the DS map. This is not the first key in the order you added them! DS maps are not stored in a linear form, for that use DS list, so all this does is find the first key as stored by the computer. This can be useful if your have to iterate through the DS map looking for something, but should be avoided if possible as it can be slow.

audio_sound_get_audio_group.name: audio_sound_get_audio_group

parameters.name: sound_index
parameters.description: The index of the sound whose audio group should be retrieved.

audio_sound_get_audio_group.description: This function will return the index of the audio group that is associated with the given sound index.

dbg_text_input.name: dbg_text_input

parameters.name: dbgref
parameters.description: reference to the variable to change

parameters.name: label
parameters.description: label to use.

dbg_text_input.description: Creates a text input entry within the current debug section. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.

file_text_writeln.name: file_text_writeln

parameters.name: fileid
parameters.description: The id of the file to edit.

file_text_writeln.description: With this function you can write a new line to an opened text file. In this way you can skip lines or write information on a line by line basis (see example code below).

instance_exists.name: instance_exists

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object or instance to check for the existence of.

instance_exists.description: This function can be used in two ways depending on what you wish to check. You can give it an object_index to check for, in which case this function will return true if any active instances of the specified object exist in the current room, or you can also supply it with an instance id, in which case this function will return true if that specific instance exists and is active in the current room.

window_set_max_height.name: window_set_max_height

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The maximum height in pixels for the game window.

window_set_max_height.description: This function can be used to set a maximum window height for your game. If you enable the window resize option in the Game Options for the target platform, then the player can resize the game window to any size they wish, however by using this function you can limit the maximum height to the size you specify. If you wish to go back to the default behaviour (ie: no minimum), then use a value of -1.

string_letters.name: string_letters

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to convert to letters.

string_letters.description: With this function you can remove all characters that are not classed as letters. This is handy for preventing people from entering unwanted characters into a text entry (like entering "#" to force a new line).

audio_bus_get_emitters.name: audio_bus_get_emitters

parameters.name: bus
parameters.description: The audio bus whose emitters should be returned.

audio_bus_get_emitters.description: This function returns an array of all of the audio emitters linked to a given audio bus.

device_get_tilt_y.name: device_get_tilt_y
device_get_tilt_y.description: This function returns a value between -1 and 1 depending upon the angle of "tilt" of the device. The actual correlation between degrees of tilt and the value returned depends on the device and OS that it uses, but generally a value of 1 or -1 is the same as +/-90°. The image below shows how each if the available functions relates to the device:

show_message_async.name: show_message_async

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The message to show to the user.

show_message_async.description: This function opens a window and displays the message you define in the function to the user. This is an asynchronous function, and as such GameMaker does not block the device it is being run on while waiting for an answer, but rather keeps on running events as normal. Once the user has pressed the "Okay" button, an asynchronous Dialog event is triggered which, for the duration of that event only, will have a ds_map stored in the variable async_load.

object_get_solid.name: object_get_solid

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The index of the object to check.

object_get_solid.description: This function will tell you whether the object you are checking has been flagged as "solid" or not. A solid object generates a special collision event when using the traditional collision system (ie: the physics world is off). Please note that this is not an instance function! So, you can have a solid object and a normal instance of the same object and vice-versa. You can set an individual instances solid flag using the solid instance variable.

ds_queue_read.name: ds_queue_read

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to read into.

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to read from.

parameters.name: legacy (optional)
parameters.description: Can be either true or false or omitted completely.

ds_queue_read.description: With this function you can recreate a saved DS queue (one that has previously been written as a string using ds_queue_write()). You must first create a new DS queue to read the string into, and if the DS queue already exists and has information stored in it, then this will be cleared before reading. This function is of vital importance when creating save/load mechanisms for your game.

window_has_focus.name: window_has_focus
window_has_focus.description: With this function you can poll the window (or tab) state and if it loses focus the function will return false otherwise it will return true. In most cases you can simply use the os_is_paused() function to test this, but in some very specific cases (for example games on Chrome Apps) that function will not trigger, in which case you should use this function instead.

ds_map_replace.name: ds_map_replace

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map to change.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key with the value that should be replaced by the new one

parameters.name: val
parameters.description: The new value to replace the given value with

ds_map_replace.description: With this function you can change the value for the given key within the a DS map . You supply the index to the map (as returned by the function ds_map_create()) and then the key to replace - either a string or an integer - and the value to replace the key value with. If the given key does not exist then it will be created for you, and if it does then the current value will be replaced with the new value. The function will return true if the key exists and the value is replaced, and false if the key does not exist and a new key was created with the value.

layer_background_xscale.name: layer_background_xscale

parameters.name: background_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the background element to change

parameters.name: xscale
parameters.description: The scale value to use (1 is no scaling)

layer_background_xscale.description: This function can be used to set the scale along the x-axis of a background element. You give the background element ID (which you get when you create a background element using layer_background_create() or when you use the function layer_background_get_id()), and then set the scale value. The scale value you give is a multiplier that will be used to change the way the background element is displayed, where a value of 0.5 would display the element at half scale, and a value of 2 would display at double scale. Note that negative values are valid, and will "flip" the element around the (0,0) position, so an x scale of -1 would show the image reversed.

draw_get_color.name: draw_get_color
draw_get_color.description: This function returns the current draw colour which is used for drawing forms, text, primitives and un-textured 3D models. This can be set with the draw_set_color() function.

gpu_set_tex_min_mip_ext.name: gpu_set_tex_min_mip_ext

parameters.name: sampler_index
parameters.description: The index of the shader sampler to get

parameters.name: minmip
parameters.description: The minimum mipmap level to use

gpu_set_tex_min_mip_ext.description: With this function you can set the minimum mipmap level which is currently used for a given shader sampler. You supply the index value for the shader sampler (as returned by the function shader_get_sampler_index(), and then give a value, where 0 is for full resolution, 1 is for the first mipmap, 2 for the second etc...

physics_particle_get_radius.name: physics_particle_get_radius
physics_particle_get_radius.description: With this function you can find out what the current radius (in pixels) is for particles in the physics simulation (you can set this value using physics_particle_set_radius()).

timeline_size.name: timeline_size

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the timeline get the information from.

timeline_size.description: With this function you can get the total number of active moments for a timeline (an "active" moment is one which has GML Code or GML Visual added to it). This can be handy when creating dynamic timelines using the timeline_moment_add_script() and timeline_moment_clear() functions, as you can check to see if a given timeline has the correct number of active moments or none at all.

video_seek_to.name: video_seek_to

parameters.name: milliseconds
parameters.description: Set the position in milliseconds.

video_seek_to.description: This function will move the position of the video in milliseconds

window_mouse_get_delta_y.name: window_mouse_get_delta_y
window_mouse_get_delta_y.description: Returns how many pixels has the mouse cursor moved on the y axis since the last frame.

dbg_watch.name: dbg_watch

parameters.name: dbgref
parameters.description: reference to the variable to change

parameters.name: label
parameters.description: label to use.

dbg_watch.description: Creates a watch for any value within the current debug section, each value is converted to a string and displayed. NOTE: if no section is declared a "Default" section will be created.

string_pos_ext.name: string_pos_ext

parameters.name: substr
parameters.description: The substring to look for in the string.

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string.

parameters.name: start_pos
parameters.description: The starting position to search from.

string_pos_ext.description: This function will return the character position of an instance of a sub-string within a string, searching forwards through the string from the position given as the starting position. The function will return 0 if the search string is not found, or the position of the first character of the search string if it is. Keep in mind that for legacy support strings are indexed from 1, so 1 is the first position in the string, not 0 as you may expect.

ini_key_delete.name: ini_key_delete

parameters.name: section
parameters.description: The section to delete a key from.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to delete.

ini_key_delete.description: With this function you can remove the selected key (and its corresponding value) from an ini file.

gesture_pinch_distance.name: gesture_pinch_distance
gesture_pinch_distance.description: This function is used to set the distance within which you have to touch/click the screen and move with two fingers before you trigger a Pinch Gesture. The distance is measured in inches and has a default value of 0.1.

layer_sequence_speedscale.name: layer_sequence_speedscale

parameters.name: sequence_element_id
parameters.description: The unique ID value of the sequence element to target

parameters.name: speedscale
parameters.description: The speed scale to use (a multiplier), default is 1

layer_sequence_speedscale.description: With this function you can change the playback speed of the given sequence. You supply the sequence element ID as returned by layer_sequence_create() or by one of the layer element functions and then a speed scale value. This value is a multiplier, where 1 is the default playback speed and values less than 1 will slow the playback and values larger than 1 will speed it up, eg: a value of 0.5 would be half playback speed, while a value of 2 would be double playback speed.

ds_map_find_next.name: ds_map_find_next

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the map to use.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key to find the next one to.

ds_map_find_next.description: This function returns the next key stored in the DS map after the one specified in the function. This can be useful if your have to iterate through the DS map looking for something, but should be avoided if possible as it can be slow. If no such key exists then the function will return undefined. You should always check this using the is_undefined() function.

ds_map_read.name: ds_map_read

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to read the string into

parameters.name: str
parameters.description: The string to read

parameters.name: legacy (optional)
parameters.description: Can be either true or false or omitted completely.

ds_map_read.description: This function will take a string that has previously been created by the function ds_map_write() and then read it into a previously created DS map. If the map that the string is being read into contains any key/value pairs, these will be cleared first before the saved map is re-constructed.

gpu_set_tex_mip_bias.name: gpu_set_tex_mip_bias

parameters.name: bias
parameters.description: The mipmap bias value to use (default: 0)

gpu_set_tex_mip_bias.description: With this function you can set the mipmap bias value, where a value of 0 equals no bias, 1 equals the first mipmap, 2 equals the second mipmap etc... This controls the rate at which the mip map is swapped and will generally make rendered textures blurrier the higher the value and the greater the "distance" being viewed. Note that this function can take negative values too, in which case rendered textures will be sharper over a greater distance the lower the value.

part_type_color1.name: part_type_color1

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle type to change.

parameters.name: colour1
parameters.description: The single colour to make the particle type.

part_type_color1.description: This function is used to set a particle type to be a single colour for the total duration of the lifetime of each individual particle.

part_system_depth.name: part_system_depth

parameters.name: ind
parameters.description: The index of the particle system to change.

parameters.name: depth
parameters.description: The depth at which to set the particle system.

part_system_depth.description: With this function you can set the draw depth for the particle system, much the same as you can set the render depth of different layers within the room, where a low draw depth means that it will appear on top of all things drawn with a higher depth, and a high draw depth placing it below everything with a lower draw depth.

view_get_yport.name: view_get_yport

parameters.name: view_port
parameters.description: The view port to target (0 - 7)

view_get_yport.description: This function can be used to retrieve the y position of the given view port.

ds_priority_destroy.name: ds_priority_destroy

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the data structure to remove.

ds_priority_destroy.description: This function will remove the given priority queue data-structure from memory, freeing up the resources it was using and removing all values that it contained. This function should always be used when you are finished using the DS priority queue to prevent memory leaks that can slow down and crash your game.

draw_getpixel.name: draw_getpixel

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the pixel to check

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the pixel to check

draw_getpixel.description: With this function you can get the colour value of any pixel that is being drawn to the current render target. This means that the results will depend on the event in which the function is called, and also on the target surface being used. Note that this will not return any alpha values, for that you should use draw_getpixel_ext().

string_byte_length.name: string_byte_length

parameters.name: string
parameters.description: The string to measure the number of bytes of.

string_byte_length.description: This function returns the number of bytes in a string, but you should note that due to their being held as UTF8, this will not be equal to their string length.

asset_has_any_tag.name: asset_has_any_tag

parameters.name: asset_name_or_id
parameters.description: The name of the asset (a string) or its index value (an integer).

parameters.name: tags
parameters.description: A single asset tag string or an array with various asset tags.

parameters.name: asset_type
parameters.description: OPTIONAL! The type of asset to check the tags for, only used when supplying an index for the first argument.
